Chapter 1: The Brewing of the Reform and Opening Up in the New Era and the Restoration and Reestablishment of the Correct Line
I. The Generation of Political Reconciliation in the Process of Wavering Progress
During the transition period from 1976 to 1978, the generation of political reconciliation mainly occurred through the restoration of Deng Xiaoping's leadership position, the restoration of the college entrance examination system, and the redressment of the Tiananmen Incident.
1. The Restoration of Deng Xiaoping's Leadership Position and the Redressment of the Tiananmen Incident
After the defeat of the "Gang of Four," although the political forces that supported the "Cultural Revolution" were toppled from the highest level of the central government, the top leadership of the party and the country, which was crucial to the future and fate of China after the "Cultural Revolution," had not yet made decisive progress.
Mao Zedong, who received the order from Mao Zedong before his death, later served as the chairman of the Chinese Communist Party Central Committee, chairman of the Central Military Commission, and premier of the State Council. With the support of the Central Political Bureau and executing the will of the people, Hua Guofeng took decisive measures to overthrow the "Gang of Four" and put an end to the Cultural Revolution. In the process of overthrowing the "Gang of Four," Hua Guofeng, in his position as the core of the central leadership, played an important role. The vast majority of the people celebrated and raised their glasses in joy.
At the beginning of the overthrow of the "Gang of Four," Hua Guofeng seized the opportunity to criticize and denounce them, stabilize the situation, and gained support from within and outside the party. In various parts of the country, the gang factions of the "Gang of Four" were gradually investigated and normal production and work orders were restored. Efforts were also made to restore the national economy, with obvious results. However, a contradictory problem did not receive a satisfactory solution: on one hand, the criticism and denunciation of the "Gang of Four" was carried out, but on the other hand, there were great efforts to limit the accountability for the harm caused by the extreme leftist policies of the "Gang of Four," especially the prohibition of touching the mistakes made by Mao Zedong in his later years. As a result, the work of rectifying the wrongful cases of the "Cultural Revolution" proceeded slowly, and the rectification of major problems was obstructed.
As early as October 26, 1976, Hua Guofeng told the person in charge of the Central Propaganda Department: "Do not criticize anything that Chairman Mao has said or agreed to." On November 18, Wang Dongxing said at the Central Committee's propaganda work meeting: "Chairman Mao has already issued a document on Deng Xiaoping. We must uphold everything that Chairman Mao has said or instructed. We will not go wrong." On February 7, 1977, the "Two Newspapers and One Magazine" published an editorial titled "Study the Documents and Grasp the Main Points," which clearly put forward the principle of "two whatevers": "We resolutely uphold all the decisions made by Chairman Mao, and we always adhere to Chairman Mao's instructions without wavering." The "two whatevers" aimed to uphold Mao Zedong's "banner," including the mistakes of the "Cultural Revolution," but it contradicted the development of the situation. After the end of the Cultural Revolution, in view of the increasing calls from within and outside the party to rehabilitate the Tiananmen Incident and allow Deng Xiaoping to emerge, Chen Yun, in his written speech at the Central Work Conference in March, proposed four points affirming the Tiananmen Incident and fully supported Deng Xiaoping's return to the leadership of the Party Central Committee. Wang Zhen also made a similar statement and received support from many people. Vice Chairmen Ye Jianying and Li Xiannian also clearly agreed. In this situation, Hua Guofeng stated that "at the appropriate time, allow Comrade Deng Xiaoping to come out and work." In July 1977, the Third Plenary Session of the Tenth Central Committee formally decided to restore Deng Xiaoping's work and position.
Restoring Deng Xiaoping's leadership position meant that the 1976 Tiananmen Incident, which was suppressed by the "Gang of Four," should be redressed. However, the political identities and situations of those who participated in the Tiananmen Square "April Fifth" Movement, who had experienced their hardships with Deng Xiaoping, remained vague. As a result, a spontaneous movement arose among the public to vindicate the Tiananmen Incident: 16 teachers from the Chinese Language Teaching Research Group of Beijing Second Foreign Language Institute (signed as "Tong Huaizhou") spontaneously collected and spread the "Tiananmen Poetry Extract" through mimeograph printing. People rushed to buy and copy it, creating a great social impact. Shanghai worker Zong Fuxian wrote a four-act play called "In Silence," praising the "April Fifth" Movement in Tiananmen Square and exposing the ugly face of the "Gang of Four" and their followers. The play was successively performed in Shanghai and Beijing, causing a sensation. The first issue of the magazine "Chinese Youth" published the deeds of Beijing young worker Han Zhixiong in the "April Fifth" Movement (later severely criticized by Wang Dongxing and the magazine was confiscated). It can be said that the vindication of the Tiananmen Incident was not achieved overnight, but rather the result of the unremitting efforts and persistence of the forces of social justice from the bottom up.
Until November 14, 1978, after approval from the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the expanded meeting of the Standing Committee of the Beijing Municipal Committee of the Communist Party of China officially made a decision to rectify the Tiananmen Square incident, and it was announced in the Beijing Daily on the 15th: "On Qingming Festival in 1976, the masses gathered at Tiananmen Square to mourn our beloved Premier Zhou, purely out of infinite love, infinite nostalgia, and deep mourning for Premier Zhou, purely out of deep hatred for the heinous crimes of the 'Gang of Four' that harmed the country and the people. It reflects the wishes of the hundreds of millions of people nationwide, it is a revolutionary action, and all comrades who were persecuted because of this should be rectified, and their reputations restored." However, it was evident that it was not enough for such a nationally influential event to be announced for rectification only in local newspapers.
Xinhua News Agency President Zeng Tao, People's Daily Editor-in-Chief Hu Jiwei, and Guangming Daily Editor-in-Chief Yang Xiguang keenly noticed this report and extracted the specific paragraph to publish it as a separate news article, with the title "Beijing Municipal Committee of the Communist Party of China announces that the 'Tiananmen Square incident' was a complete revolutionary action", thus greatly elevating the significance of this news. It is worth mentioning that Xinhua News Agency did not seek approval from the Central Politburo or report to any member of the Standing Committee when releasing this news. Afterwards, even Hu Yaobang said to Hu Jiwei, "Didn't you inform me about such an important matter?" The consideration of Zeng Tao and others at the time was: it is better not to seek consultation on this matter and let Xinhua News Agency take responsibility for it. Everyone appreciated Zeng Tao's courage and decisiveness.
After discussion and approval by the Standing Committee of the Central Committee, Hua Guofeng, representing the Central Committee, announced at the Central Work Conference being held at that time: "The Tiananmen Square incident was a completely revolutionary mass movement, and the Tiananmen Square incident should be publicly and thoroughly rectified." Thus, the "Tiananmen Square incident" finally received rectification.
2. Starting the rectification of certain unjust, false, and erroneous cases
During the "Cultural Revolution," a large number of unjust, false, and erroneous cases were created, affecting a considerable number of social groups both inside and outside the party throughout the country. The grievances of these groups were not redressed, and their basic political rights, job rights, and basic living conditions were not ensured. Therefore, after the collapse of the "Gang of Four," the most immediate and urgent demand of the entire society was to rectify the unjust, false, and erroneous cases as soon as possible. This became the eager anticipation and strong desire of a wide range of social classes, including leading cadres at all levels who had suffered severe persecution.
In July 1977, the Third Plenary Session of the Tenth Central Committee decided to restore Deng Xiaoping's leadership position, revealing obvious political rationality and value. In the political report of the 11th National Congress of the Communist Party of China in August, it was pointed out: "Regarding the problems left among cadres after the past political examination, they should be seriously and quickly addressed. For those who can work but have not been assigned work, they should be assigned work as soon as possible. For the elderly and frail who cannot work, proper arrangements should be made. For the few who need to make review conclusions, they should do so as soon as possible. All the slanderous words imposed by the 'Gang of Four' should be refuted." These important pieces of information opened up a gap for further clarifying historical rights and wrongs. In the hearts of those who had not been liberated, the light of hope began to ignite, concerning themselves, their families, relatives' fate, and future, and it burned brighter and brighter.
At that time, Hu Yaobang served as the Executive Vice President of the Central Party School of the Communist Party of China, and he had always been pondering the issue of accelerating the rectification of unjust, false, and erroneous cases and implementing cadre policies. On October 7, 1977, the People's Daily published a full-page article titled "Correcting the Cadre Line that the 'Gang of Four' has Reversed," written with the support of Hu Yaobang. The article pointed out with specificity: Some comrades, especially those involved in cadre work, have not been effective in their work because of the influence of the "Gang of Four." This has led to some capable cadres with a correct understanding of the line not being assigned work, many cadres undergoing review having not reached correct conclusions, and bad elements infiltrating the cadre ranks not being dealt with. All of these indicate that implementing the cadre policies of the Party is still a serious battle task.
The article emphasizes the need to break through resistance and overturn the false accusations and erroneous conclusions imposed by the gang of four on many cadres. This article has provoked widespread social resonance, and relevant departments of the central government have received more than 10,000 letters from cadres and the masses within a month, all expressing agreement with the views expressed in the article and the proposed measures. The People's Daily continues to publish commentary articles on the implementation of cadre policies and publishes excerpts from letters from the masses, reporting on the implementation of cadre policies in some local areas. This further spurred people's emotions of rectifying unjust grievances and they have been striving for early solutions to their problems through means such as petitions and appeals.
However, the implementation of cadre policies and the rectification of unjust cases still face significant obstacles. On the one hand, in the organizational departments of the central government, some regions, and units, as well as among individuals influenced by the gang of four's factional system, there are always excuses to delay and a lack of serious implementation of the Party's cadre policies. On the other hand, many people still have lingering fear and concerns, worrying that dealing with the inherited problems in reviewing and handling cadres, especially correcting those erroneous cases, will negate the achievements of the "Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution." A typical example is the former First Secretary of the Shandong Provincial Party Committee, Shu Tong, who went to the Central Organization Department to request policy implementation and job assignments, but was blocked by the then head of the Central Organization Department and was not even allowed to stay in the department's guesthouse. There are over 6,000 such cadres "suspended" or "side-lined" in central and national organs alone, and these people continue to petition, but find no help.
This incident had a great impact on Hu Yaobang and further strengthened his determination to promote the implementation of cadre policies. "If we don't go to hell, who will?" Hu Yaobang said, borrowing a line from Dante's Divine Comedy, "Our position is: If we don't jump into the oil pan, who will?" Now we are also at a critical moment of contending with a new level 12 typhoon. Since we have firmly and confidently taken the first step, we will never retreat and strive to expand the breakthrough that has already been made. Hu Yaobang also analyzed: It seems that resolving cadre issues will still be an arduous task, which requires our determination to overcome each obstacle one by one. He organized comrades from the Central Party School to write a second call-to-action article entitled "Chairman Mao's Cadre Policy Must be Seriously Implemented", criticizing behaviors similar to persistently clinging to the wrong organizational line.
At this time, veteran comrades like Ye Jianying, Deng Xiaoping, and Chen Yun also believed that it was necessary to strengthen the leadership of the organizational departments. Some organizational departments needed to adjust and strengthen their capacities and vigorously recommended Hu Yaobang to be the Minister of the Central Organization Department.
Hu Yaobang took office in the Central Organization Department on December 15, 1977. That morning at 8 o'clock, the front courtyard of the Central Organization Department was filled with excitement, firecrackers were booming, and all cadre staff welcomed the arrival of the new minister with sincere trust and joy. This enthusiastic scene reflects the strong desire of the majority of cadres and masses to completely rectify unjust cases. After that, the number of petitions received by the Central Organization Department increased day by day. In January 1978, the number of people petitioning every day reached several hundred, and the number of appeal letters reached six bags. Some letters even had Hu Yaobang's name directly mentioned.
With the support of Deng Xiaoping, Chen Yun, and other veteran comrades, Hu Yaobang, who joined the Chinese Red Army at the age of 14 as a "little red devil," with selflessness and fearlessness, broke through the various restrictions and taboos set by the "two whatevers," and boldly organized and led a series of urgent work in the Central Organization Department to implement cadre policies and rectify unjust cases.
At the first working meeting after assuming the position of the Central Organization Department, Hu Yaobang proposed that it is the department's responsibility to rectify wrongful cases and implement cadre policies. He said: During the "Cultural Revolution" alone, there were major cases such as the Tiananmen Incident, the "61 People" problem, the Peng Dehuai case, the Tao Zhu case, the Wang Renzhong case, the Inner Mongolia "Neiren Party" problem, the so-called "traitor group" problem in the Northeast, the "traitor group" problem of Xinjiang's Ma Mingfang and others, the case of speaking out for Liu Shaoqi's grievances and "viciously attacking the great leader", the case of "viciously attacking Vice Commander Lin", and the "current counter-revolutionaries" who were executed. No one can say exactly how many victims were involved in these cases. In the previous political movements before the "Cultural Revolution", as well as some wrongful cases before the establishment of New China, including the wrongful cases in the Central Soviet Area in the 1930s, it can be said that there are "mountains of unresolved cases", while the current situation of the Central Organization Department is "difficult to move forward".
Hu Yaobang explicitly stated that the clearing and implementation of wrongful cases since the establishment of New China and during the "Cultural Revolution" is the primary task of the organization department. As for the historical legacy issues before the establishment of New China, whether it was due to historical conditions or the impact of war that prevented them from being resolved or not thoroughly resolved, we should also strive to thoroughly resolve them. No matter how difficult it is, we must have the determination to overcome all obstacles. He also greeted the people present and said: If any old comrades who have been wronged come to find me in the future, I will meet and talk with them. I ask that no one obstruct them. Any letter with the three characters "Hu Yaobang" written on the envelope should be promptly delivered to me. If there is no indication from me, I hope that no comrade will take the initiative to handle it or withhold it.
According to statistics, the Central Organization Department received 391,363 cases consisting of 1,730 volumes at that time, and 669 senior cadres were reviewed. Among them, 320 people were identified as having serious problems or contradictions with the enemy, accounting for 47.8% of the total number of cases reviewed. Among these people, there were 213 cadres at the deputy ministerial level, 71 members of the Central Committee and alternate members, 10 members of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee, 10 members of the Secretariat of the Central Committee, and 7 deputy prime ministers.
From March to April 1978, Hu Yaobang organized and guided the Central Organization Department to hold seminars on researching difficult and unresolved cases in the central and state organs, as well as in some provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the central government. He personally attended the discussions or gave speeches, provided handling suggestions for hundreds of long-standing difficult cases, defined policy boundaries, and proposed four standards for implementing cadre policies: (1) Cases without conclusions should reach conclusions as soon as possible, and if the conclusions are incorrect, they should be corrected pragmatically; (2) Those who have not been assigned work should be appropriately allocated work, and those who are elderly and weak should be properly arranged; (3) The deceased should have a pragmatic conclusion, and the aftermath work should be done well; (4) The families and children of those who have been implicated should be resolved properly. The general policy is pragmatism and the method is the mass line.
Under the leadership of Hu Yaobang, the Central Organization Department issued more than forty guiding documents to liberate cadres and rectify wrongful cases. Over ten articles were published in newspapers, and policy commentaries totaling nearly one hundred thousand words were published in the "Organizational Work Communication". During his time in the Central Organization Department, Hu Yaobang was almost busy every day handling various types of letters. On average, he would handle 33 appeal letters from deputy bureau chiefs and party committee secretaries or positions above per day, and on the busiest day, he handled 200 letters. According to a member of the Central Organization Department recalling, in that year alone, Hu Yaobang approved 902 letters for the review bureau to handle. Through Hu Yaobang and the comrades of the Central Organization Department's relentless efforts and meticulous work, a considerable number of problems of middle and senior cadres were resolved, and their work and livelihood arrangements were properly handled.
As Hu Yaobang said, "When a wrongful case is rectified, people are greatly pleased." By July 1978, a total of 5,344 cadres were allocated and arranged according to policies in central and state organs, accounting for 87.2% of the originally unallocated cadres in 53 units of central and state organs, playing a leading role in freeing minds and rectifying chaos. Until August, among the main leaders in 20 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the central government, 9 people were found to be implicated in the overthrow of the party by the "Gang of Four" and were dismissed from their posts, accounting for about one-third of the total number of main leaders in these areas. The central government also made significant adjustments to the leadership teams of 14 provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities directly under the central government, and 23 ministries and commissions. This played an organizational guarantee role in stabilizing the situation, restoring and developing the national economy, and promoting the struggle of exposing and criticizing.
3. Restoring the college entrance examination system to give young students equal opportunities for development
On October 21, 1977, the People's Daily published the news of the restoration of the college entrance examination with an unusually eye-catching headline "Doing a good job in college admissions is the hope of the whole nation." The restoration of the college entrance examination marked the beginning of China's education reform and development in a new historical period, and it was also the prelude to the magnificent reform and opening up in China in the 1980s. At the end of that year, thousands of young intellectuals participated in the college entrance examination. With the knowledge accumulation from years of grassroots labor, most of them only had a short and hurried review, and with anxious and excited hearts, they rushed to the hastily established examination centers all over the country with various identities such as rural youth sent to the countryside, factory apprentices, demobilized soldiers, and unemployed at home. They participated in and witnessed the first college entrance examination after the "Cultural Revolution" that changed the era and the fate of a generation of young people. In that year, a total of 5.7 million people nationwide registered to take the college entrance examination, with an unprecedented age span of examinees, with the oldest being 37 years old and the youngest being 13 years old. However, the number of admissions that year was only slightly over 270,000. It was the most competitive year for the college entrance examination in New China.
At the end of the year, there were many people who, due to various reasons of their own, their families, and the society, missed the opportunity of the first restoration of the college entrance examination. Fortunately, the restoration of the college entrance examination in 1977 was only partial. Starting from 1978, college admissions were fully restored through a nationwide unified examination organized by the Ministry of Education. Each province, autonomous region, and municipality directly under the central government organized the examination, marking, and admission work locally. According to Deng Xiaoping's instructions, "At the same time as announcing the list of candidates for physical examination, announce the test scores of all candidates. The method of announcement shall be notified by the county (district) admissions committee to inform the candidates' respective units to relay to the candidates themselves." The publication of the examination scores was an important measure to improve the transparency of the admission examination process and played a key role in changing the social atmosphere, preventing nepotism and cheating, and promoting fair practices.
Due to the interruption of regular college admissions for ten years, more than 30 million young people and students in the country were eligible to register. However, the colleges and universities had just started to recover from the destruction of the "Cultural Revolution", and the conditions of school buildings and teaching staff were limited, unable to accommodate the large number of students. In 1978, the Ministry of Education decided to restore and establish 60 key universities and 55 ordinary universities and requested that each university expand enrollment by all means. As a result, in 1978, there were 6.1 million candidates for the national college entrance examination, with 402,000 admissions. The unprecedented scale of the examination still evokes nostalgia in many people's memories.
With doors wide open, talent surged forward. The backlog of talent for 11 years erupted at once. More than 670,000 people were fortunate enough to enter the hall of higher education, and more than 11 million young people successively registered to participate in the college entrance examination. This involved the considerations and concerns of countless families, units, and all sectors of society, and brought about a very extensive social impact.
Due to the abolition of the enrollment model for college students from workers, peasants, and soldiers based on power and background during the Cultural Revolution, the new enrollment system based on unified examinations and selective admission expanded the scope of enrollment to include high school graduates and young people from various professions. Many people who had never dared to imagine having any opportunity before were able to "stand up through their own efforts" and change their destinies. The phenomenon of "blank paper heroes" during the Cultural Revolution disappeared. The restoration of the college entrance examination stimulated the enthusiasm for learning among a generation of young people and began to form a mechanism of fair competition.
In 1977, since the comprehensive rectification had not yet been carried out, many candidates were not admitted due to family problems. However, candidates and their parents no longer remained silent and give up, but instead appealed and fought for their rights, resulting in the resolution of some issues. In this regard, People's Daily published a commentator article titled "Political Reviews in the College Entrance Examination Must Firmly Implement the Party's Policies," criticizing the tendency to assess candidates primarily based on their family and relatives' political history rather than their political performance. It pointed out that this one-sided and irresponsible practice was extremely harmful and seriously interfered with the implementation of the Party's policies. With the deepening of ideological rectification, the one-sided emphasis on the so-called "class line" in college entrance examination and enrollment work was resolved.
After the fall of the "Gang of Four," from a societal perspective, a significant change was the emergence of an atmosphere of social reconciliation. This change was largely due to the gradual resolution of the highly tense political relations in Chinese society. Not only did the college entrance examination resume comprehensively, but in March 1978, during the National Scientific Conference, Deng Xiaoping emphasized the important view that "science and technology are productive forces and also a great revolutionary force that propels history forward," reaffirming that the vast majority of intellectuals were already part of the working class. This reversed the "leftist" policies towards intellectuals that had been in place for many years. A "spring" that respected knowledge and talent emerged, greatly inspiring intellectuals in various fields such as science, education, and literature. People universally felt the long-lost atmosphere of social cohesion and reconciliation, which accelerated the restoration and reconstruction of normal social and living order, and the whole society began to show vitality.
II. Resolution of Theoretical Understanding and Ideological Obstacles
During the ten years of the Cultural Revolution, not only did it cause severe damage to the national economy, but it also led to great confusion in ideological and theoretical aspects. With the restoration and development of the national economy starting in 1977, the theoretical field gradually clarified various erroneous ideas propagated during the Cultural Revolution by exposing and criticizing the fallacies of the "Gang of Four" in economic theory. It gradually restored the correct Marxist economic theory, the Party's pragmatism, and the correct criteria for testing truth, and correctly applied them in socialist construction.
1. The Great Debate in the Economic Theory Field on the Issues of Commodities, Circulation, and Distribution
The Stalinist model of planned economy is a highly centralized economic model. Therefore, commodity economy has always been in an awkward position in China. For many years, the commodity economy has been treated as something capitalist, to the point that even the simplest exchange of goods in rural markets was considered capitalist. Under this ideological guidance, the development of our country's commodity economy was greatly constrained, with a low degree of commercialization of agricultural products. Industrial products were far from meeting the daily needs of the people, and they could not provide sufficient machinery, fertilizers, and pesticides for agricultural development. The circulation of commodities was single-channel, and the goods people needed were often acquired through a "supply" system, while scarce goods had to be obtained through "vouchers." This is a characteristic of a shortage economy underdeveloped in terms of commodity economy. After the fall of the "Gang of Four," in order to get rid of the dilemma of a shortage economy, the first issue raised was the development of the commodity economy. In fact, to boost economic development, it is necessary to develop the commodity economy. This requires stripping away the "capitalist" shell attached to commodity production and circulation.
On December 5, 1977, the State Council issued a notice titled "Regarding the Convening of the National Urban and Rural Commerce and Learning from Daqing and Dazhai Conference," which pointed out that socialist commodity production and circulation are fundamentally different from capitalist commodity circulation. Currently, our country's commodity production is not excessive, but rather insufficient. Under the conditions where both public ownership and collective ownership coexist, socialist commodity production needs to be greatly developed. Only in this way can the economic power of socialism be strengthened, urban and rural capitalist activities be eliminated, and the material basis of proletarian dictatorship be strengthened. We must confidently promote socialist production and develop socialist commodity circulation. Although this notice carries the linguistic characteristics of that era, such as discussing the importance of commodity production and circulation from the perspective of "eliminating urban and rural capitalist activities," it nevertheless points out the essential differences between socialist and capitalist commodity economies, and proposes the confident development of the commodity economy, which was significant at that time.
On July 7, 1978, Hua Guofeng delivered a speech at the National Finance and Trade Learning from Daqing and Dazhai Conference. This speech draft was written by several comrades in the field of theory, and was modified multiple times by Hu Qiaomu. The speech analyzed the relationship between economic development and supply guarantee, essentially focusing on the interrelationships among the four components of production, exchange, distribution, and consumption, as all these components are indispensable. Production is the determining factor in the overall process of production, but exchange, distribution, and consumption also play significant roles in production, emphasizing that the development of commerce is a "strong promoter" of industrial and agricultural production development. This speech had a great impact after it was delivered.
In order to promote the confident development of commodity production and circulation, the theoretical group of the State Council Finance and Trade Team drafted the article titled "Refuting the Reactionary Fallacy of the 'Gang of Four' that Defames Socialist Commodity Production," expounding on the correct understanding of socialist commodity production. The article pointed out that commodity production must be allowed to exist in socialist society and be used to facilitate close connections between urban and rural areas. Only by vigorously developing commodity production and circulation can various needs of national construction and people's lives be met. The vigorous development of the socialist commodity economy is necessary to promote mutual reinforcement between industry and agriculture. Although these arguments still have shortcomings, they represent significant progress compared to the previous notion of viewing the commodity economy as a breeding ground for capitalism, where, for example, raising three ducks by rural members is considered socialist while raising five ducks is considered capitalist.
After progress was made in reevaluating the issues of commodity production and exchange, there were significant obstacles in clarifying the influence of the "left" on the issue of distribution according to work. This was because it involved Mao Zedong. As early as 1958, Mao Zedong regarded wage systems, bonuses, and the like as "bourgeois rights" and believed that these things were a regression from the communal life of military communism during the war. He had attempted to restore the system of supply. In 1974, Mao Zedong made the following statement during a meeting with Danish Prime Minister Poul Hartling: "In summary, China belongs to the socialist countries. Before liberation, it was similar to capitalism. Even now, we still implement the eight-grade wage system, distribution according to work, and monetary exchange. These have not changed much compared to the old society, what is different is the ownership has changed... "In this regard, it can only be restricted under the dictatorship of the proletariat."
The Gang of Four exaggerated the similarities between "distribution according to work" and the old society, and took it to extremes. In 1975, Zhang Chunqiao and Yao Wenyuan respectively published two articles titled "On the Comprehensive Dictatorship of the Bourgeoisie" and "On the Social Basis of the Lin Biao Anti-Party Group". They claimed that distribution according to work was a bourgeois privilege, an important economic basis for the emergence of new bourgeoisie, and that it could only be restricted under the dictatorship of the proletariat. Due to their use of Mao Zedong's speeches, "abolishing bourgeois privileges" seemed to become the classic Marxist interpretation of the socialist distribution problem. At that time, various newspapers and magazines extensively propagated these ideas, leading to not only great theoretical confusion but also many practical difficulties, as distribution according to work and the principle of material interest were completely denied.
In January 1977, some people specifically criticized Zhang Chunqiao and Yao Wenyuan. However, Wang Dongxing, who was in charge of propaganda work at the time, disagreed. His reasoning was that Chairman Mao had read these two articles, so they could not be completely denied. Instead, the incorrect views within the articles were criticized without mentioning the authors by name. In practice, this actually set a taboo on rethinking the issue of distribution according to work. However, this did not prevent further and deeper discussions on the issue from taking place. In February 1977, with the participation of the National Economic Commission's Economic Research Institute, the Chinese Academy of Sciences' Economic Research Institute, the State Labor General Bureau, Peking University, and other units, a national economic theory discussion conference was decided to be held. It started with criticizing the fallacies of the Gang of Four regarding distribution according to work. In April, the first discussion conference was attended by over 100 theoretical workers from more than 30 units in Beijing. In June, the second discussion conference was attended by over 400 theoretical workers from nearly 100 units in Beijing.
Soon after Deng Xiaoping's comeback in July, he reacted to the economic circle's discussions. He said that the articles on distribution according to work were generally good, but he felt that they were not satisfying enough, lacking boldness in expression. On August 3rd, Deng Xiaoping and Yu Guangyuan talked about the articles on distribution according to work, saying they were basically well-written and stood firm, but were a bit hesitant in their message and needed to be revised after discussion. He pointed out that there should be appropriate material incentives; clearly stating that those who work less should receive less, and those who work more should receive more. On August 8th, during a symposium on scientific education work, Deng Xiaoping pointed out that when talking about distribution according to work, it essentially meant "more work, more gain; less work, less gain; no work, no gain." This issue, from theory to practice, requires research and resolution of many specific problems. It is not only a problem for the scientific community and the education sector but also a problem for the whole country.
"With more work, more gain; less work, less gain; no work, no gain" - Deng Xiaoping, in his unique way of expression, promoted the liberation of thought in the economic circle. On August 9th, the People's Daily published an article titled "Refuting Yao Wenyuan's Fallacy of Distribution According to Work Leading to the Emergence of the Bourgeoisie," directly criticizing the fallacies in Yao Wenyuan's article. From late October to early November, the economics circle held the third discussion conference on the issue of distribution according to work. In addition to the participation of over 500 theoretical workers from units in Beijing, over 300 theoretical workers from 23 provinces, municipalities, and autonomous regions also attended the conference. More than 100 people gave speeches, indicating that the scale of the conference was growing. The number of articles published in newspapers such as People's Daily, Guangming Daily, and Economic Research has been increasing, and discussions in the field of economics have gradually extended to society.
From February 6th to March 5th, in 1978, the First Session of the Fifth National People's Congress was held. The government work report explicitly affirmed the principle of "those who do not work shall not eat, each according to their abilities and remuneration according to their work" throughout the entire socialist historical stage. It pointed out that in terms of distribution, we should avoid excessive disparities and also oppose egalitarianism, implement the principle of "more work, more pay; less work, less pay". All communes and brigades must earnestly implement quota management and the piece-rate system, implement equal pay for equal work between men and women. State-owned enterprise employees' wages are mainly determined by working hours, supplemented by piece-rate wages and incentives. A job allowance is provided for occupations with high labor intensity and poor working conditions. The principle of remuneration according to work was also included in the constitutional amendment passed at the conference.
According to Deng Xiaoping's opinion, the State Council Research Office organized the writing of articles on remuneration according to work. On March 28th, Deng Xiaoping met with the heads of the Research Office, Hu Qiaomu, Deng Liqun, Yu Guangyuan, etc., and said about the draft of the article, "I have read this article and it is well written. It explains that the nature of remuneration according to work is socialist, not capitalist. Some parts still need to be revised to address the practical problems that exist in the current system."
How to connect with practical problems? Deng Xiaoping outlined some of the ideas he formed through contemplation:
According to the principle of distributing based on the quantity and quality of labor, when determining the level of employee wages, the main factors to consider are the quality of their work, their level of skills, and the size of their contributions. Dealing with distribution issues should only be based on work, not politics or qualifications. We are implementing a policy of low wages, which will last for a considerable period of time. Currently, the highest wage for an eighth rank worker is just over 100 yuan, and in the future, as production develops, wages will gradually increase, and the amount of wages at all levels should increase. Currently, the wages of primary school teachers are too low. The labor that a good primary school teacher puts in is quite heavy, so their wages should be increased. In the future, some primary school teachers who teach very well can be evaluated as "special grade". Special grades should be established in all professions to encourage people to engage in their chosen careers for life.
An evaluation system should be implemented. The evaluation must be strict, comprehensive, and frequent. This should be done in all industries. There should be rewards and punishments, with clear distinctions between them. Different rewards should be given based on performance, whether it is good or poor, through the evaluation process. The bonus system should also be reinstated. Incentives should be given to inventors and those who have made special contributions. Those who have made significant achievements in scientific research can have their salary levels increased in addition to rewards for their inventions. The system of remuneration for contributions should also be restored and revised based on the new situation. There are many things to be done in implementing the principle of distribution according to work. Some issues need to be investigated and gradually resolved. Some systems need to be reinstated and established. The overall aim is to encourage everyone to strive for progress.
On May 5th, after being personally reviewed by Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian, and others, an article entitled "Implementing the Socialist Principle of Distribution According to Work" was published in the name of a special commentator in the People's Daily. The article comprehensively argued for the socialist nature of distribution according to work, expounded on various forms of labor compensation according to work, and systematically clarified theoretical errors and confusion regarding distribution according to work. The article received wide social response after its publication. At the same time, it was criticized by leaders who adhered to the "Two Whatevers" principle. Wang Dongxing publicly criticized the article during a small meeting, stating that it "actually targeted the Chairman's ideology." Deng Xiaoping, on the other hand, believed that the article was Marxist. He also told the leaders of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, "We cannot make concessions in theory, compromising will lead to losing principles."
In August, the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, the Institute of Economic Research, and other institutions held a special discussion on implementing the principle of distribution according to work in rural areas. Comrades from 17 provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities directly under the central government, and relevant central departments participated in the meeting. The participating comrades generally believed that the main tendency in agricultural distribution at the current stage is egalitarianism. Some comrades called for the need to improve management, stating that the principle of material interests must be implemented in order to make people care about the results of their labor from a material perspective. This principle could not be discussed in the past, but now it must be emphasized and applied in practical work. We must start from reality and not confine our thinking to certain concepts. Some economists also pointed out that despite the significant amount of investment by the state in agriculture over the past twenty years of collective ownership, agricultural production has not correspondingly developed. The reasons for this must be found in the relations of production. In order to elevate agriculture, it is necessary to strengthen the material foundation of agricultural production, but more importantly, the policies of equivalent exchange and distribution according to work must be earnestly implemented.
From October 25th to November 2nd, during the fourth meeting on distribution according to work, a key topic of discussion was whether the combination of distribution according to work, commodity production, and currency exchange could give rise to a new bourgeoisie. The majority of participants believed that socialist distribution according to work, commodity production, and currency exchange would not generate capitalism, nor could they form a new bourgeoisie. Moreover, some participants presented evidence from systematic social surveys to demonstrate that no new bourgeoisie member has emerged as a result of distribution according to work.
The discussion on the issue of distribution according to work in this stage was large in scale and long in duration, mainly clarifying the following issues: (1) Distribution according to work is the distribution principle of socialism, and it is by no means a factor of capitalism. (2) The right of equal exchange of equal labor in distribution according to work is both an equal right and an unequal right, and there is no system of hierarchy in distribution according to work. Distribution according to work will not produce capitalism and bourgeois elements. (3) Bonuses and piece-rate wages are not things of revisionism and should be restored and implemented. In the situation of correcting chaos, the large-scale discussion on the issue of distribution according to work has played a positive role in clarifying people's vague understanding.
At the same time, the theoretical circles also criticized the "Gang of Four" for slandering the development of production as "advocating the theory of productive forces". After discussion, several points of consensus were reached: (1) True socialism should be a more advanced mode of production than capitalism, and should create a higher level of productivity than capitalism. Socialism and poverty are incompatible, and poverty is not the essential requirement of the socialist system. (2) Our country is carrying out socialist construction in a country with relatively backward productivity, and we must take the road from poverty to prosperity, so that our country can quickly become prosperous and strong, and become a modern socialist country. To achieve this goal, we can only rely on the development of productive forces to solve it. (3) The real contradiction faced by China at present is still the contradiction between productive forces and production relations. This contradiction is mainly manifested in the many factors that hinder the development of productive forces in terms of production relations and superstructure, which are contradictory and conflicting with the requirements of productive forces development. The solution to this contradiction must first rely on the development of social productive forces. (4) Production relations must be in line with the nature of productive forces. According to this law, on the one hand, it is necessary to change backward production relations and open up the road for the development of productive forces, while also preventing the excessive counter-effects of production relations. If the production relations change too quickly and exceed the level of development of productive forces, it will hinder the development of productive forces and even destroy them.
On this issue, Deng Xiaoping also expressed his views. In October 1977, he said during a meeting with Canadian guests: "The Gang of Four" denies the importance of productive forces. Whoever proposes to develop productive forces will be accused of advocating the theory of productive forces. This is one of the major debates between us and the "Gang of Four". If the productive forces are not developed to a material abundance, how can we achieve distribution according to needs and how can we enter communism? There is no such term as "the theory of productive forces" in Marxism-Leninism, and this term is unscientific. In December, he said during a meeting with Australian guests: How can we reflect the superiority of socialism that Lenin talked about? What does superiority mean? Is not working, not studying considered superiority? Is it considered superiority for the people's living standards to not improve but regress? If this is considered the superiority of socialism, we can also do without such socialism.
In addition, the theoretical circles also conducted theoretical analysis on the prevalence of "leftist" errors during that era, when acting in accordance with economic laws was regarded as something in direct opposition to emphasizing politics. At that time, a representative article was the one drafted by Hu Qiaomu, Yu Guangyuan, and Ma Hong, titled "Acting in Accordance with Economic Laws and Accelerating the Realization of the Four Modernizations". This article was first delivered by Hu Qiaomu at a virtual meeting of the State Council, and was published in the People's Daily on October 6, 1977. The article discusses the following issues: economic laws are objective and not subject to people's will; although economic laws are objective, they do not automatically ensure that people act according to them, so it is necessary to study them and consciously abide by them; in order to act according to economic laws, it is necessary to first improve scientific management and expand the role of economic organizations and means. Specifically, this includes promoting contract systems, developing professional companies, strengthening the role of banks, and developing economic legislation and economic justice. These discussions hit the nail on the head and provide directional guidance for solving problems in real economic life. Some effective economic management methods have begun to be implemented, such as performance-based rewards and piece rate wages.
2. Reflection on the History of Literature and Art
After the defeat of the "Gang of Four" and the complete overthrow of the so-called "black line governance theory in literature and art," a large number of films, dramas, and other excellent works of literature and art that had been suppressed for a long time were liberated. Mass organizations such as the Federation of Literary and Art Circles and the Writers' Association resumed their work, and various forms of literary and artistic creation gradually became active. Soon, there emerged literary and artistic works that began to reflect and reexamine the trauma of the "Cultural Revolution". In the context of a decade of "cultural desert," it was far from enough to only restore the works that existed before the "Cultural Revolution" to meet the needs of society. Without new works that reflect the fate of ordinary people from a new perspective, it would still be difficult to change the situation of withered literary and artistic forms. In this period of transition, reportage literature, with its strong documentary nature, emerged first.
Reportage literature is a form that is closest to people's real lives. It can show readers the true state of existence and relevant events of protagonists that they are unfamiliar with but eager to understand. After the defeat of the "Gang of Four," signs of a "spring" were first released in the field of scientific education. Sensitive writers sensed the aroma of spring. In particular, the stories of Chinese scientists who, despite the decade-long catastrophe, remained steadfast in their commitment to scientific research at the cost of their lives, are very vivid and touching. Even without deliberate polishing, they are enough to deeply move people.
The first to pick up the pen was the older generation writer, Xu Chi, who recorded the life experiences of scientists who were buried by the fanatical and ignorant political atmosphere but were determined to revitalize China's technology industry in his works. He enthusiastically celebrated the scientists who willingly endured loneliness and made selfless contributions in difficult times. He wrote works such as "The Light of Geology," "The Goldbach Conjecture," and "The Evergreen Tree of Life". The emergence of these works injected vitality into the literary and artistic forms that had been devastated and distorted during the ten years of chaos, and they flourished.
The reportage article "The Goldbach Conjecture," published in the first issue of "People's Literature" in 1978, vividly portrayed the mathematician Chen Jingrun's persistent efforts and unwavering perseverance in tackling world-class mathematical problems, his sincere dedication to the country's scientific cause, and his valuable qualities of not succumbing to evil forces and being unaffected by temptations. It truly reproduced the feelings of the new generation of intellectuals in China, who were infatuated with scientific exploration. "People's Daily" unusually published this reportage literature in its entirety, occupying two whole pages, which is rare in the history of the newspaper.
Afterward, a batch of documentary works praising Chinese scientists emerged one after another. Through the profound historical perspective of the authors, readers got to know the names of leading figures in China's scientific and technological community as well as young and middle-aged research elites. They included geologist Li Siguang, biologist Tong Dizhou, quantum chemist Tang Aoqing, physicist Xie Xide, mathematician Chen Jingrun, botanist Cai Xitao, engineering physicist Wu Zhonghua, hydraulic engineer Zhang Guangdou, mathematician Hua Luogeng, science and technology icon Chen Zhen, and revolutionary model for cotton production Wu Jichang, etc. People marvel at this group of scientists, each with their own personality and common ideals. Despite the extremely weak material conditions and the impact and interference of the "left" political tendencies in the past decades, they have still achieved scientific accomplishments that are world-leading and have earned the respect of society. These works of reportage literature bring a strong impact and shock in terms of rationality, emotions, and values, igniting and fueling the fire of social rational thinking, and forming an unstoppable trend.
During this period, works in the form of literature began to emerge, revealing the trauma of the "Cultural Revolution" and were called "scar literature". In the 11th issue of "People's Literature" in 1977, a short story called "Class Teacher" by Beijing writer Liu Xinwu was published, which is considered the foundation of "scar literature". The author deliberately portrayed two typical middle school student figures in the story - small thug Song Baoqi and Youth League Committee secretary Xie Huimin. The mark of the "Cultural Revolution" seems to be completely different on the two students, but deep in their souls are indelible scars caused by extreme left-wing thinking. Among them, Xie Huimin's character is referred to as "the first artistic representative character in literature of the new era". Author Liu Xinwu said that writing this story was due to "deep-seated resentment accumulated during the 'Cultural Revolution', which concentrated on the strong dissatisfaction with the cultural authoritarianism of the 'Gang of Four'."
After the publication of the novel, it caused a strong response among readers. Works reflecting on the pain of the "Cultural Revolution" appeared in succession in newspapers and magazines. Among them, the representative one is the novel "Scar" published in "Wen Hui Bao" on August 1, 1978. This novel reveals the hardships and inner "injuries" caused by the ultra-left line and "bloodline theory" to Chinese society, especially to young people, through a tragic story. This highly stimulating theme directly touches upon the hidden pains of social reality, igniting people's thoughts on reflecting on the past and projecting into the future, and has a considerable influence nationwide.
The reason why the novel "Scar" caused a great response in society and resonated with a significant portion of people is mainly because it reveals the inexplicable pain in people's hearts at that time. Of course, there were diverse opinions on the themes and ideas reflected in this work, and the comments were divided. There were debates at symposiums held in Shanghai and Beijing. However, whether for or against it, this kind of literary work quickly formed a trend and was later collectively referred to as "scar literature". In fact, this phenomenon is the inevitable result of historical reflection that people went through after a major social upheaval in China. Although this reflection is still preliminary and superficial, it has prompted more people to engage in deep rational thinking about the mistakes of the prevailing "left-wing" ideology in the past.
This kind of historical reflection triggered by "scar literature" will become a lasting proposition for rational thinking in the transition from tradition to modernity: in the decades of China's development, the overall cultural situation has experienced a rupture. The distant cause was the May Fourth Movement, which fundamentally negated the grand unifying principles of pre-Qin thinkers. The recent cause was the "Cultural Revolution", which overturned the tradition of science and democracy since the May Fourth Movement. The consequence is that the humanistic spirit gradually nurtured in modern China has been sacrificed as a cost during this tumultuous era, and the core values passed down by the Chinese nation have been interrupted. After the interruption, it can be restored, but the wounds leave scars and cannot return to their original state. The problems of individuals, society, and ideological forms that emerged during the "Cultural Revolution" and unfolded in the following two to three decades slowly manifested themselves in various groups and classes, showing up everywhere due to various new reasons and old roots - this is the truly severe problem. With the return of the rationality of the entire social values and the development of the economy, society, and national strength to a certain extent after the reform and opening up, the focus will shift back to the "people" issue. The humanistic conditions of a civilized society are always unavoidable.
Literature played a leading role in promoting rational thinking in the ideological and cultural sphere at that time, while drama played a more unique role in stirring people's thoughts and emotions. In March 1978, the Beijing People's Art Theater staged the play "Heart Score" written by Su Shuyang. This was the first political-themed play performed by the theater after its restoration. The play depicted a thrilling struggle between medical workers represented by the old intellectual Fang Lingxuan and the minions of the "Gang of Four" as they developed a new drug to treat coronary heart disease, in accordance with the instructions of Premier Zhou Enlai. It deeply exposed the great "internal injuries" caused by the Gang of Four's various retrogressive actions deep in people's hearts and fervently praised Fang Lingxuan's steadfast pursuit of scientific endeavors. It also strongly condemned the despicable actions of Feng Jisheng, a member of the "Gang of Four" who had sided with them. The performance of this play, as well as the performance of the four-act play "In the Silence" written by Zong Fuxian, a Shanghai worker, received rave reviews and tickets were in high demand.
As stated in a comment in the People's Daily at the time, these works "use the form of art to reverse the distorted history imposed by the 'Gang of Four', convey the words that billions of people want to say and express the strong emotions deep in the hearts of billions of people." The Chinese literary and artistic community's criticism and repudiation of the "Gang of Four" used various artistic forms and imagery, opening the door to historical reflection on the Cultural Revolution and effectively driving the wave of ideological liberation at the time.
3. The Great Debate on the Criteria of Truth
The discussion in the economic theory field and the historical reflection in the literature and art field played a leading role in breaking through the "forbidden area" and played a role in "piercing through the wall to let light in." However, it is still difficult to thoroughly clarify the right from wrong of the Cultural Revolution and its preceding period under the rigid shells of the "two whatever" stance. As Hu Yaobang said, since we have firmly and resolutely taken the first step forward, we must never retreat and strive to expand the breakthrough that has already been made. Therefore, criticism must be raised against the "two whatever" stance.
The older generation of Communist Party revolutionaries in China not only have noble political prestige but also have rich experience from long-term struggles. They first brought out their ideological weapon - seeking truth from facts.
On September 5, 1977, Nie Rongzhen published an article titled "Restoring and Carrying Forward the Fine Tradition of the Party's Style" in Issue 9 of the Red Flag magazine. Nie Rongzhen put forward that seeking truth from facts is the most precious theoretical legacy left to us by Mao Zedong. "To uphold the style of seeking truth from facts, we must adopt the correct attitude towards Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought. In our study and application of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, we must grasp their spiritual essence, learn their positions, views, and methods, take their basic principles as our guide for action, and resolutely oppose taking certain words and phrases of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought as dogmas detached from time, place, and conditions." "All correct ideology is relative to time, place, and conditions; otherwise, it becomes metaphysics." "We must never forget to seek truth from facts, hold a dialectical perspective, and recognize that everything is determined by time, place, and conditions, otherwise, we would deviate from the most fundamental essence of Mao Zedong Thought."
On September 19th, Xu Xiangqian emphasized the importance of adhering to the principle of the Party's leadership in the article "Always Adhere to the Principle of the Party Commanding the Gun" by discussing the struggle between the Party and Zhang Guozhen and the "Gang of Four" on military issues. He pointed out: "We must not be like some people, regardless of whether the line is right or wrong, just follow whoever has the most power, which is very dangerous. Of course, identifying the correct line and the wrong line is not so easy." Therefore, it is necessary to "comprehensively and accurately understand and grasp Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought."
On September 28th, Chen Yun criticized the rampant idealism and metaphysical behavior of the "Gang of Four" during their reign in the article "Adhering to the Revolution Style of Seeking Truth from Facts". He pointed out that the "Gang of Four" and their followers told lies, fabricated false cases, played the role of counter-revolutionary two-faced individuals, which became a common occurrence. They severely distorted, fragmented, tampered with, and forged Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought. They used bits and pieces of words from classic Marxist authors as magic weapons to suppress and harm people, the Party, and the country. They severely undermined the fine traditions and style of our party that Chairman Mao had nurtured for a long time. They not only greatly undermined the party's style of seeking truth from facts but also openly created "theoretical" justifications for their subjective idealism. They advocated such slogans as "oppose empiricism", which actually negated the practical experience as the basis of knowledge, negated the correct principles based on practice, and negated Mao Zedong's thought of "On Practice", namely the thought of seeking truth from facts.
Chen Yun pointed out profoundly: "Seeking truth from facts is not an ordinary style issue; it is a fundamental ideological and theoretical issue of Marxist materialism. If we want to adhere to Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, we must adhere to seeking truth from facts. If we depart from the revolutionary style of seeking truth from facts, we will depart from Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought and become idealists who are divorced from reality. Then our revolutionary work will be doomed to failure. Therefore, whether to adhere to the revolutionary style of seeking truth from facts is, in reality, one of the fundamental signs distinguishing true from false Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought."
The older generation of revolutionaries emphasized the need to adhere to the fundamental ideological and theoretical line of seeking truth from facts and opposed the use of certain words or phrases from Mao Zedong Thought to fragment Mao Zedong Thought. In this regard, the "Two Whatevers" exactly aimed to uphold everything of Mao Zedong, including his erroneous theories and practices in his later years. In response to this difficult problem, in July 1977, after Deng Xiaoping returned to work at the Third Plenary Session of the Tenth Central Committee, he immediately proposed to accurately and comprehensively understand Mao Zedong Thought and to adhere to the scientific system of Mao Zedong Thought. He actively advocated the basic principle of seeking truth from facts, which is a fundamental viewpoint of Mao Zedong Thought, in order to guide people to treat Mao Zedong Thought and Mao Zedong with the correct attitude.
However, at a time when personal worship of Mao Zedong still had a deep influence within the party just after Mao Zedong's passing, it was extremely difficult to achieve "completeness and accuracy". This requires an objective standard that puts everything and everyone under its purview. Otherwise, it would be impossible to break free from the shackles of the "Two Whatevers" and reestablish the guiding principles of emancipating the mind and seeking truth from facts. This would definitely affect the deepening of the rectification and hinder the reversal of the various works. Therefore, the issue of testing the standards of truth was raised.
At the end of 1977, more than eight hundred senior cadres studying at the Central Party School gathered to discuss the history of the Communist Party since the "Cultural Revolution". During the discussion, they encountered a prominent issue, which was what should be used as the standard to understand and determine the right and wrong of history. In response, Hu Yaobang, who was then the Vice President of the Central Party School and in charge of its executive work, instructed the school's theoretical researchers to make several revisions and wrote a document guiding the study of Party history. This document explicitly put forward two guiding principles: first, it should fully and accurately apply the basic principles of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought; second, it should use practice as the standard to test truth and discern right and wrong in line with the party's guiding principles. Under the guidance of these two principles, some theoretical researchers at the Party School began to prepare articles discussing the influence of the "Two Whatevers" and the issue of standards of truth.
In March 1978, in response to the confusion about the standard of truth, the editorial department of the People's Daily published a thought commentary titled "There is Only One Standard", explicitly stating that "the standard of truth is one, and that is social practice." After the article was published, it received opposition from some people who believed that Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought were the standards for testing truth. In response, the editorial department decided to organize further articles to clarify this issue.
In early April, the Guangming Daily was preparing to publish a submission by Hu Fuming, a teacher in the Philosophy Department of Nanjing University, titled "Practice is the Only Standard for Testing Truth", as part of the "Philosophy Supplement" of the newspaper. Yang Xiguang, who had just returned from studying at the Central Party School, keenly felt the significance of the issue discussed in this article in the intellectual and political circles of China at that time. He decided to withdraw the article from the "Philosophy Supplement" and add some practical relevance before publishing it prominently on the front page. At this time, the author Hu Fuming came to Beijing to participate in a theoretical discussion meeting, so the newspaper invited him to discuss and revise the article together with the theoretical research office of the Central Party School. After the revision, the manuscript was further processed by the newspaper's editors twice before being sent back to the theoretical research office of the Central Party School for final modification and polishing.
After being personally reviewed and approved by Hu Yaobang, the article "Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth" was first published in the "Theory Trends" of the Central Party School on May 10, 1978. The next day, it was published as a special commentary article in the Guangming Daily. On the 12th, the People's Daily and the Liberation Army Daily reprinted the full text, and Xinhua News Agency also issued a press release. Many provincial and municipal party newspapers subsequently reprinted the article.
This article, which condensed the collective wisdom of the theoretical world at that time, explained with a large number of facts that practice is not only the criterion for testing truth but also the sole criterion. Any theory must undergo continuous tests of practice. The reason Marxism is recognized as the truth lies in the results confirmed by the practice of millions of people. The dialectical materialist epistemology's view of the absolute and relative dialectical unity of the criterion of practice holds that any thought or theory must unconditionally, forever, and continuously accept the test of practice. This is also the view of the development of truth. The revolutionary mentors have already set an example for us in the practice of testing truth.
In connection with the situation in the ideological and political field at that time, the article emphasized that although the Gang of Four and their network had been destroyed, the spiritual shackles imposed by the Gang of Four on people were far from completely shattered. The tendency that Mao Zedong criticized that "only what is included in the Bible is correct" still existed. Whether in theory or practical work, the Gang of Four set up many "forbidden zones" that imprisoned people's thinking. We must dare to touch these "forbidden zones" and dare to clarify right and wrong. There are no forbidden zones in science. Wherever there are "forbidden zones" that go beyond practice and regard themselves as absolute, there is no science, no real Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought, only obscurantism, idealism, and cultural authoritarianism.
The article concludes: Socialism is still a kingdom that has many areas that are unknown to us. In order to accomplish this great task, we face many new problems that need us to understand and study. Lying on the ready-made provisions of Marxism and Mao Zedong Thought, and even using ready-made formulas to restrict, truncate, and cut the rapidly developing revolutionary practice is a mistaken attitude. We should have the responsibility and courage of Communists, daring to study dynamic real-life, study the exact facts of reality, and study new problems raised in new practices. Only in this way can we have the correct attitude towards Marxism and gradually move forward from the kingdom of necessity to the kingdom of freedom, smoothly embarking on a new and great Long March.
In fact, the article "Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth" repeatedly argues for a commonsensical philosophical proposition of Marxism, and does not have any particularly innovative theoretical ideas. However, in the specific historical conditions where the "Cultural Revolution" has just ended and the "Two Whatevers" still restrict people's thoughts, its distinct tendency and strong directionality have infinite power. After the article was published, it immediately elicited different reactions from all sectors of society, causing a stir within and outside the party. The nationwide debate on the issue of the standard for truth thus begins.
On May 12th, the same day when the People's Daily reprinted the article "Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth", a person in charge of the newspaper received a phone call accusing the article of "making directional mistakes".
On May 17th, Wang Dongxing, who was then Vice Chairman of the Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee, specifically criticized the article "Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth" and the article published by the People's Daily on May 5th titled "Implementing the Socialist Principle of Distribution According to Work" in a small meeting. He said that they had not read these two articles, causing discussions inside and outside the party. In fact, the criticism was aimed at Chairman Mao's thoughts. Our party's newspaper shouldn't do this. He questioned, "Whose opinion is this from the central government?" and expressed that "it should be investigated, lessons should be learned, a unified understanding should be reached, and it should not happen again." He also demanded that the Central Propaganda Department "censor carefully".
On May 18th, during the National Education Work Conference held by the Central Propaganda Department and the symposium with provincial and municipal education secretaries and propaganda department ministers, Zhang Pinghua, Minister of the Central Propaganda Department, asked everyone to "discuss and express different opinions" about the article "Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth". He said, "Don't think that once the People's Daily publishes it and Xinhua News Agency releases it, it becomes a settled matter." Chairman Mao said to responsible comrades of provinces and municipalities before his death that no matter where things come from, including those from the central government, they should be sniffed with a nose to see if they are fragrant or foul, and not follow the wind.
On June 15th, Wang Dongxing convened a meeting with the leaders of the Central Propaganda Department, central authorities, and relevant news units. At the meeting, he criticized the article "Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth" and several other articles again, and mentioned Hu Yaobang, reminding him to pay attention when writing articles in the newspaper. He particularly emphasized that special commentator articles should be noted, as some of them are not so appropriate. Don't seek momentary popularity. He believed that deficiencies in propaganda would be exploited by domestic and foreign enemies, both the Soviet Union and the United States, as well as reactionaries. They would incite relations between members of the Political Bureau, incite relations between Central Committee members, incite relations between Chairman Mao and Chairman Hua, and incite relations between workers and farmers. If the grip on propaganda is loose, it would be a serious matter to be exploited by the enemy.
In July, leading comrades in charge of propaganda work from the central government visited Shandong for inspection. They spoke to comrades in charge of the Shandong Provincial Committee in Jinan and mentioned the issue of the standard for truth. In summary, there are three main points: firstly, do not cut the flag; secondly, do not throw knives; thirdly, do not make a 180-degree turn.
In this political situation, many newspapers have actively participated, but the magazine "Red Flag" has remained silent for a long time. Of course, silence is also a form of expression. When the head of the magazine reflected on the criticism of "Red Flag" by the party members and the masses, Wang Dongxing said, "Don't be afraid of isolation, what are you afraid of! Don't be afraid. "Red Flag" will not participate in this discussion."
At a time when the discussion on the standard of truth was suppressed and faced a heavy burden, veteran revolutionaries like Deng Xiaoping stood up clearly to provide strong support. On May 30th, during a conversation with several officials, Deng Xiaoping pointedly said, "If what you say is different from what Chairman Mao said, then it's not acceptable. If Chairman Mao didn't say it, and Chairman Hua didn't say it, then it's not acceptable for you to say it. You have to copy everything Chairman Mao said, everything Chairman Hua said, word for word. This is not an isolated phenomenon, it is a reflection of a current trend of thought." He emphasized, "The most fundamental and important thing about Mao Zedong Thought is seeking truth from facts. Now, even the criterion of practice being the test of truth has become a problem, it's simply absurd."
On June 2nd, during the Political Work Conference of the entire army, Deng Xiaoping once again spoke on this issue and criticized, "We also have comrades who talk about Mao Zedong Thought every day, but often forget, abandon, or even oppose Mao Zedong's insistence on seeking truth from facts, starting from reality, and combining theory with practice, which are basic Marxist viewpoints and methods. Not only that, some people think that whoever insists on seeking truth from facts, starting from reality, and combining theory with practice is committing a heinous crime. In essence, their point of view is that as long as you copy the original words of Marx, Lenin, and Comrade Mao Zedong, it's enough. Otherwise, they will say that you are violating Marxism, Mao Zedong Thought, and the spirit of the central party. This problem they raise is not a minor one, but involves how to view Marxism and Mao Zedong Thought."
On July 21st, Deng Xiaoping specifically spoke with the Minister of the Central Propaganda Department, Zhang Pinghua, requesting him, "Do not issue bans or set forbidden zones anymore, do not push the lively political atmosphere we just started backward."
On August 19th, during a conversation with the head of the Ministry of Culture, Deng Xiaoping said again, "I have said that the article 'Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth' is Marxist, and it cannot be refuted. I agree with the viewpoint in this article."
