On September 16th, when listening to the work report from the Jilin Provincial Party Committee, Deng Xiaoping directly said, "Now, many people inside and outside the party, at home and abroad, support holding high the banner of Mao Zedong Thought. What does it mean to hold high? How to hold high? As we all know, there is a kind of discussion called 'the Two Entirely Different Standpoints.' Isn't it well-known? It means that no document read by Comrade Mao Zedong can be altered, and nothing done or said by Comrade Mao Zedong can be changed. Is this what it means to hold high the banner of Mao Zedong Thought? No! If we continue in this way, it will harm Mao Zedong Thought. " The basic point of Mao Zedong Thought is seeking truth from facts, that is, combining the general principles of Marxism-Leninism with the specific practice of the Chinese revolution."
On September 9th, in his speech at the State Council's virtual meeting, Li Xiannian also expressed support for the discussion on the criterion of truth. He said that the destruction caused by Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" has confused many theoretical issues, including the relationship between theory and practice, causing ideological confusion that must be clarified. He emphasized that practice is the sole criterion for testing truth, pointing out that anything that has been proven in long-term social practice to conform to objective laws and to benefit the majority of people must be resolutely pursued and carried through. All of our policies, plans, and measures should be tested against the standard of whether they can benefit the people.
To commemorate the 85th anniversary of Mao Zedong's birth, the Red Flag magazine invited Tan Zhenlin to write an article reminiscing about Mao Zedong's leadership in the struggle at Jinggangshan. After the article was written, the editors found that besides recalling history, the article also discussed the criterion of truth being tested through practice. This obviously contradicted the "non-involvement" attitude of the Red Flag magazine, and the author was unwilling to make any changes. Therefore, it had to be submitted to the Central Committee for a decision. Hua Guofeng, Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian, and others agreed to publish this article in the Red Flag magazine.
Deng Xiaoping and Li Xiannian also criticized the Red Flag magazine in their annotations. Deng Xiaoping wrote, "I think this article is good, at least there are no mistakes." "If the Red Flag magazine is unwilling to publish it, it can be published in the People's Daily. Why doesn't the Red Flag magazine involve itself? It should involve itself. Articles with different viewpoints can be published. It seems that not involving oneself may actually be involving oneself." Li Xiannian commented, "I have read this article. Comrade Tan Zhenlin talked about historical facts, so it should be published. It's too passive for the Red Flag magazine to not publish it. The Red Flag magazine is already quite passive."
When the discussion among the top leaders of the central government further intensified the struggle against the "whatever-ism" camp concerning the criterion of truth, the academic, scholarly, and journalistic communities also took action. Encouraged by the support and concern of the older generation of revolutionaries, they resisted various pressures from the "whatever-ism" camp and continued to write articles and hold discussions in order to further deepen the ongoing debate.
Regarding the criterion that practice is the test of truth, the majority of people expressed support, but some questioned whether practice is the "sole criterion." They believed that while practice is indeed the criterion of truth, Marxism should also serve as the criterion of truth. This was a problem of ideological understanding that had some universality at the time. In response to this situation, Xing Bensi from the Philosophy Research Institute of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences published an article titled "On the Criterion of Truth," in which he specifically addressed the aforementioned question. The article argued that advocating both practice and Marxism as the criteria of truth violated the unity of dialectical materialism and would lead to theoretical confusion. In terms of understanding, this confuses the concept of truth with the criterion of truth. Marxism is a truth, but just like any truth cannot prove itself, Marxism also cannot prove itself on its own, it also needs to be proven by practice. At the same time, Marxism cannot be used as a standard to test other truths. Another confusion is to confuse Marxism as a pointer to revolutionary practice with Marxism as the standard of truth. These are two different issues. Philosophically speaking, while acknowledging the counteractive effect of theoretical knowledge on practice, we cannot deny the fundamental determining role of practice and replace it with this counteractive effect as the question of testing truth.
Faced with various criticisms that practice is the only criterion to test the truth, theoretical workers have provided persuasive answers and refutations. One of the most systematic, sharp, and vigorous responses was an article published on June 24th in the Liberation Army Daily under the name of a special commentator titled "One Most Basic Principle of Marxism". The article clearly pointed out: "The most powerful refutation of skepticism, agnosticism, and other philosophical absurdities is practice. This is a well-known phrase Engels used to criticize Hume's and Kant's agnosticism and skepticism, and it is still meaningful for us to cite it today." "The epistemology of Marxism recognizes practice as the true authority. It is precisely because the objective criteria (practice) for discerning truth have not been established in the world that skepticism and agnosticism have gained popularity. It is never because the objective criteria for discerning truth have been established that skepticism and agnosticism have become popular. Those who hold the opposite view are astonishingly 'reversed'!"
In response to this inverted relationship, the article pointed out sharply: "Marxist theory is a science, not superstition; theory must first be subordinate to practice in order to guide practice; theory is not eternal, but constantly supplemented, corrected, enriched, and developed in practice." Therefore, we cannot stick to old conclusions and slogans, of course, changing these old slogans is not easy. "The reason is that, in addition to the fact that people's thinking often lags behind reality, it is also because some people's interests are more or less connected with these old slogans. These people, who claim to be worried that the modification of certain old slogans and formulations will lead to the negation of the entire revolution and theory (obviously, this is nothing but a whimsical rhetoric), are actually afraid that their personal interests will be harmed as a result." In response to the criticisms of some people, for example: If we prioritize practice as the only criterion for testing the truth, then where does Mao Zedong Thought and Chairman Mao's words fit in? The article pointed out: For those who speak such confused words, just ask them back: Chairman Mao said that only the revolutionary practice of millions of people is the criterion for testing truth, "there is no other way to test truth besides this." Where do you place Chairman Mao's guidance? How should we act according to Chairman Mao's guidance?
This article, which is more than 10,000 words long, is fully reasoned and highly targeted. It is known as the sister article of "Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth". It was published with the concern and support of Luo Ruiqing, the Secretary-General of the Central Military Commission. After the article was completed, the Liberation Army Daily sent it to Luo Ruiqing for review. Luo Ruiqing read it carefully three times, made five phone calls personally, and personally looked up related works, and made many suggestions for revision, requesting that the article be flawless. This general, who was persecuted and had his leg broken during the Cultural Revolution and had a high-level amputation before going to West Germany for leg treatment, even called Hu Jiwei, the person in charge of the People's Daily, before going to Germany and said, "If this article is going to be attacked, I am willing to take 50 big slaps first." This spirit of willingly taking risks demonstrates Luo Ruiqing's clear attitude in supporting the discussion on the standard of truth, which he never had the chance to stand up for again after his treatment in the West German hospital.
The standard of practice as the criterion for testing truth is a self-evident and non-debatable issue in the field of natural science. However, natural scientists are still actively engaging in this discussion. In mid-May, the Joint Meeting of the State Science and Technology Commission, the Chinese Academy of Sciences, and the Communist Party Committee of the China Association for Science and Technology, chaired by Fang Yi, was held to discuss relevant articles and made a decision to support this discussion. On July 5th, the "Seminar on the Relationship between Theory and Practice" organized by the Theoretical Group of the Chinese Academy of Sciences and the Chinese Society for Dialectical Materialism was held in Beijing. Many scholars from the natural sciences and social sciences participated in the discussion and made speeches. Scientists used a large number of examples from the history of natural sciences to illustrate that when the original theory of natural science conflicts with new scientific experimental facts, the breakthrough of the old theory and the establishment of the new theory must seek practical support at the same time. The arguments they provided in the field of natural sciences played a special supportive role in this ideological and political discussion.
From July 17th to 24th, the Institute of Philosophy of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences and the editorial department of "Philosophical Research" invited more than 160 theoretical workers from central and state departments, party schools, colleges and universities, scientific research institutions, and news units at the provincial, municipal, and autonomous region levels to hold a discussion on the relationship between theory and practice. Many social science workers made speeches at the conference, connecting with reality and fully affirming the practical significance of this discussion. After the conference, many representatives from provinces and cities went back and conveyed the discussion on the issue of truth standards, pushing the discussion on truth standards to the whole country.
In the second half of 1978, the theoretical, academic, literary, and journalistic circles nationwide actively engaged in the discussion on the issue of truth standards. According to incomplete statistics, by the end of the year, more than 650 articles on the discussion of truth standards had been published in central and provincial newspapers and magazines. As the discussion continued, more articles were published. A nationwide discussion frenzy, led by the theoretical circle and affecting all sectors of society, attracted everyone's attention.
In this discussion frenzy, one phenomenon is noteworthy, that is, along with the discussion on truth standards, most of the provincial party and government leadership organizations and major military region leadership institutions nationwide launched discussions on truth standards. Many provincial, autonomous region, direct-controlled city, and major military region leaders openly wrote articles or gave speeches, expressing their support for the view that practice is the sole criterion for testing the truth and highly evaluating the theoretical significance and practical significance of this discussion. This is rare in the history of the Party and the Republic. Their speeches generally connected with the actual situation at the time, not only pointing out the theoretical significance of this discussion but also emphasizing its political significance. This at least indicates that the discussion on the issue of truth standards has indeed become a major political issue of utmost concern to the whole Party, the entire army and the people of the whole country, and it shows that the correct view that practice is the sole criterion for testing the truth has gained stronger support from more and more senior cadres. Power standards, ignorance, idealism, and cultural authoritarianism are increasingly losing ground.
The discussion on the issue of truth standards, by restoring the role of practice as the criterion for testing truth standards, not only provided people with sharp ideological weapons to break away from the confinement of the "two whatevers", but also provided a theoretical basis for correctly summarizing the lessons of the "Cultural Revolution" and correcting historical errors during the "Cultural Revolution" and in the past. As pointed out in the article "Practice is the Sole Criterion for Testing Truth", the only places that consider themselves as absolute "forbidden zones" are ignorance, idealism, and cultural authoritarianism. The discussion on the issue of truth standards has greatly promoted people's ideological liberation, accelerated the pace of rectification, fully prepared for the Communist Party of China to break away from the ideological confinement of the "two whatevers", re-establish the guiding principle of seeking truth from facts, and achieve a great historical turning point.
More importantly, this movement, later known as a great ideological liberation in the history of modern Chinese thought, laid the foundation for the exploration of the socialist path with Chinese characteristics after the reform and opening up, as well as a series of theoretical innovations and development in practice.
III. Local brewing of the issue of the shift in the focus of Party and state work
The discussion on the problem of standards of truth has brought about intellectual liberation and promoted the new exploration of the Chinese Communist Party on the socialist path of China. This new exploration, due to the end of the "Cultural Revolution" and the rapid increase in China's foreign exchanges, has gained a broader vision. China has started to learn from and draw on the experiences of different types of countries' economic development in the world, gradually clarifying its basic policy of opening up to the outside world.
1. The extensive visits of Chinese leaders and the emergence of awareness of reform and opening up
Since 1978, China has changed the situation of very few visits by party and government leaders during the "Cultural Revolution" period. In that year, 13 vice premiers and vice chairpersons of the National People's Congress visited 21 times to 51 countries. Among them, Deng Xiaoping himself visited 8 countries 4 times. These visits not only improved our country's foreign relations but also provided the top party and state leaders with a more direct and comprehensive understanding of the development and changes in the international situation in recent years. One common strong feeling among the visiting leaders was that our country was far behind the world's advanced level in terms of economic and scientific and technological development.
In March 1978, at the National Science Conference, some comrades talked about the closer relationship between the development of the world economy and science and technology. The development of the national economy and various industries mainly relied on the development of science and technology. An important reason for our country's economic backwardness was the backwardness of science and technology. Compared with the world's advanced level, our country's science and technology lagged behind by about 15 to 20 years in most fields, and even more in some fields. Therefore, if we want to improve our economy, we must first honestly learn advanced technology from the world. If we close our ears and eyes, without understanding the trends, tendencies, and levels of scientific and technological development internationally, there is no way to talk about catching up with the world's advanced level. These opinions attracted the attention of the leaders of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council.
On May 17, 1978, the State Council established a leading group for the introduction of new technologies, responsible for studying and formulating plans to introduce advanced technologies from abroad. Subsequently, the leaders of the State Council, various departments, and local officials successively visited and investigated Western developed countries and regions to understand their level of economic development and the experience of developing their economies. Before Gu Mu, the Vice Premier of the State Council, led a delegation to visit Western Europe, Deng Xiaoping specifically requested them to conduct detailed investigations and research to see to what level modern industry had developed and how they managed their economic work, as well as to bring back the advanced experience of capitalism.
When Chinese leaders stepped out of the country, capitalism had already gone through a "golden age" of great development after World War II. In the first half of the 1970s, capitalist countries successively encountered the most serious economic crises since the post-war period. In the two years of 1974 and 1975, the gross domestic product of the United States, Japan, West Germany, Britain, France, and Italy all experienced negative growth. In the second half of the 1970s, the Western economies were in a state of "stagflation" and had weak recovery. In this situation, not only were developed countries willing to expand trade with China, but they were also willing to provide preferential loans to China and even make investments.
Through visits and investigations, these leading comrades not only saw the gap in our country's level of economic development but also saw the favorable opportunities provided by the international situation at that time for our development. After returning to the country, they all suggested to the central government: we should fully utilize the current favorable conditions, absorb foreign capital as much as possible, introduce a large amount of advanced technology and equipment from abroad, learn from their advanced management experience, and accelerate the modernization of our country. When Gu Mu reported on the visit to the Central Committee and the State Council, he specifically mentioned: when Western Europe took off economically, they all had the experience of using foreign capital and introducing advanced technology, why can't we do the same? The opinions and suggestions raised by the comrades mentioned above were organized into documents, circulated among the leaders of various departments in the central and state organs, and aroused strong reactions.
2. The convening of the State Council's brainstorming session and the proposal for reform
Understanding the world's advanced level raised people's reflections on the experiences and lessons of our country's economic construction. How to summarize the experience and accelerate the pace of construction has become an increasingly prominent issue before the whole party.
During this period, Deng Xiaoping mentioned many times: we now have relatively good international conditions that we can take advantage of. We should take the world's advanced achievements as the starting point for our development. In the past, the Gang of Four hindered us from understanding what the world was like by isolating ourselves and focusing only on construction. The world economy is developing so fast, but our minds are still filled with outdated ideas. We need to ask and solve problems based on the current realities. Talking about the Four Modernizations every day will be empty if we don't compare ourselves with the world's advanced level. Not only are we technologically backward, but our management level is also low. Our country's system, including the institutional system, is basically learned from the Soviet Union and is outdated. There is duplication of personnel, overlapping of institutions, and the development of bureaucratism. Many institutional issues need to be reconsidered. These views gradually became the consensus among the leadership within the party.
From July 6 to September 9, 1978, the State Council held a two-month brainstorming session to specifically study how to accelerate the pace of modernization in our country. Department heads attending the meeting proposed ideas to speed up construction and, based on a careful summary of the experiences and lessons since the establishment of New China, put forward suggestions to reform the economic management system and actively introduce advanced foreign technology and equipment.
Several leaders who returned from foreign visits introduced the current international situation and the experiences of economic development abroad. The State Planning Commission proposed actively expanding exports and increasing foreign trade ports. The Ministry of Machinery Industry proposed combining the introduction of new technology with the reform of domestic management systems. The State Labor Service Administration proposed reforming the wage system and mobilizing the enthusiasm of workers. Hu Qiaomu listed the shortcomings of relying solely on administrative methods to manage the economy in his speech and proposed that this method "should be limited to the necessary scope, and the majority of economic work should be transferred from government administration to enterprise management. Enterprises themselves should also minimize pure administrative management and expand the use of economic means for management."
In the summary speech of the meeting, Li Xiannian clearly proposed the implementation of the reform and opening-up policy. He pointed out based on historical experience: in the past 20-odd years, we have reformed the economic system more than once, "but when it comes to enterprise management systems, we often focus too much on transferring administrative power, and we often circulate in the old patterns of loosening and tightening, thus failing to meet the requirements of economic development." "This reform we are now carrying out must take into account the initiative of central departments, localities, and enterprises, and must consider the economic interests and development prospects of large enterprises and major professional companies, and strive to manage the modern economy with modern management methods." He pointed out that the current international situation is very favorable to our country, and we should have the courage and ability to use foreign advanced technology, equipment, capital, and organizational experience to accelerate our construction. We must not miss this very rare opportunity. This will speed up progress by countless times compared to starting from scratch on our own.
On September 30, the Central Committee forwarded this speech and prepared to further discuss it at the upcoming Central Working Conference.
Shortly after this virtual meeting, the State Council convened a national planning conference, which proposed that three transformations must be implemented on the economic front: first, the attention must be focused on the struggle for production and technological revolution from top to bottom; second, the bureaucratic management system and methods that do not consider economic efficiency or work efficiency must be transformed into scientific management that follows economic laws and combines democracy and centralization effectively; third, the closed or semi-closed state of economic and technological exchange with different capitalist countries must be transformed into actively introducing advanced foreign technology, utilizing foreign capital, and boldly entering the international market.
On October 11th, in his speech at the 9th National Congress of Trade Unions, Deng Xiaoping said, "Achieving the four modernizations is a fundamental change in China's backward economic and technological appearance and further consolidates the great revolution of proletarian dictatorship. This revolution not only needs to significantly change the current backward productive forces but also must change the productive relations, the superstructure, the management methods of industrial and agricultural enterprises, and the state's management methods towards industrial and agricultural enterprises to meet the needs of modern large-scale economic development." Therefore, "each economic front not only needs major technological reforms but also needs major institutional and organizational reforms. Undertaking these reforms is in the long-term interests of the people of the whole country. Otherwise, we cannot get rid of the current backward state of production technology and management."
Under the promotion of the above-mentioned ideas, in 1978, China signed contracts for 22 complete sets of imported projects with Western developed countries one after another. Although there were tendencies to seek immediate success in the import work, these imported projects provided relatively advanced technological equipment and a higher starting point for China's modernization construction. For example, the introduction of complete equipment for the Baoshan Iron and Steel Plant in Shanghai enabled us to learn world-class production technology and management methods, and it also shortened the gap between our steel industry and the world's advanced level by at least 20 years. Both ideological brewing and practical attempts have indicated that the general principle of reform and opening up is about to emerge.
3. The brewing and proposal of the shift in the focus of Party and state work
The brewing of the idea of shifting the focus of Party and state work among the top leaders of the Party has been quite early. For instance, as early as 10 days after the "Gang of Four" was overthrown, Li Xiannian called Chen Yun on October 16, 1976, to seek his opinions on future work. After discussing with Wang Zhen and Yao Yilin, Chen Yun put forward several suggestions. One of them was to "vigorously promote production to enable the national economy to recover and develop rapidly." This is the earliest material discovered so far regarding the brewing of the shift in work focus.
In September 1978, after concluding his visit to North Korea, Deng Xiaoping made an unusual inspection tour of the three northeastern provinces, as well as Tangshan, Tianjin, and other places. This was an important effort made by Deng Xiaoping to promote historical changes.
During the inspection tour, Deng Xiaoping repeatedly called on responsible comrades in various places to emancipate their minds and seek truth from facts. They should dare to think, raise questions, and solve problems based on current international and domestic conditions. They must not create forbidden areas. The harm of forbidden areas is that they make people's thinking rigid and prevent them from considering problems based on their own conditions. In short, seek truth from facts, use your brain, and let a revolution happen. After introducing advanced technology and equipment, one must manage according to internationally advanced management methods and in accordance with economic laws. To revolutionize, not to reform, not to patch up. We should advocate and educate all cadres to think independently, and boldly reform things that are unreasonable. Currently, our superstructure needs to be changed.
He also emphasized repeatedly that the most urgent task facing China now is the development of productive forces. We are too poor, too backward, and truthfully, we are sorry for the people. We are a socialist country, and the fundamental manifestation of the superiority of the socialist system is that it allows the social productive forces to develop rapidly at a speed that the old society did not have, and continuously satisfy the growing material and cultural needs of the people. According to the viewpoint of historical materialism, the achievements of correct political leadership ultimately need to be demonstrated in the development of social productive forces and the improvement of the people's material and cultural lives. We need to think about how much we have done for the people. Therefore, we must now accelerate the development of productive forces and improve the people's material and cultural lives.
For this reason, Deng Xiaoping proposed to timely end the mass movement of exposing and criticizing the "Gang of Four" and shift the focus of the party and the country's work to socialist modernization construction. This is a thought of major strategic significance. When listening to the report on the situation of the movement to expose and criticize the "Gang of Four" by the the Communist Party of China Shenyang Military Region Party Committee Standing Committee, he said: When it comes to carrying out movements, you can study, what is the bottom? There is never anything completely thorough. Movements should not last too long, otherwise people will get tired. There must always be a bottom to the movement of exposing and criticizing the "Gang of Four". It can't be carried out for another three or five years. When it is almost completed, it can be ended and normal work can be resumed. After leaving the northeast, he reiterated this opinion to relevant comrades in the central government and received the support of other leading comrades in the central government. In this way, the possibility of shifting the focus of work is ready to become a major decision of the overall situation.
On October 11, in his speech at the 9th National Congress of Trade Unions, Deng Xiaoping made this opinion more explicit. He stated that the struggle to expose and criticize the "Gang of Four" has already achieved a decisive victory nationwide, and "we have been able to start new battle tasks on the basis of this victory". Now the Party Central Committee and the State Council require accelerating the pace of realizing the Four Modernizations, "this is a revolutionary change that fundamentally changes the backward economic and technological situation of our country and further consolidates the great revolution of proletarian dictatorship". He hoped that the delegates present would "have in-depth discussions on the current situation, in order to unite all members and fight for this great task on the basis of the complete victory in the struggle to expose and criticize the 'Gang of Four'".
At this time, quite a few people had already realized that in order to achieve the goal of socialist modernization and quickly implement the brewing reform and opening up, it was necessary to shift the focus of the party and the country's work to modernization construction. There was basically no disagreement within the party on this point. However, in terms of the guiding ideology of modernization construction, there was still no consensus within the party. Some comrades still adhered to the guiding ideology of "two musts" and believed that to achieve the Four Modernizations, "we must uphold class struggle as the key link and concurrently promote the three great revolutionary movements of class struggle, struggle for production, and scientific experiment". Most comrades advocated that in order to carry out modernization construction, it is necessary to adhere to the guiding ideology of seeking truth from facts and first carry out rectification of chaos. This ideological disagreement has inevitably sparked a fierce clash of ideas over the issue of shifting work priorities.
IV. The 1978 Central Work Conference and the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee
From the convening of the 1978 Central Work Conference to the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party, these two conferences had a significant impact on the Party and the country in the process of moving towards a great historical turning point after the overthrow of the "Gang of Four". With the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee as a symbol, the Party and the country embarked on a new journey of reform and opening up.
1. The convening of the 1978 Central Work Conference
On November 10, 1978, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China held a work conference in Beijing. The conference was attended by the main responsible comrades of the provinces, cities, autonomous regions, major military regions, and central departments, as well as some veteran comrades who had previously held important positions in the central, local, and military. A total of 219 people attended the conference. The participants were divided into six large groups according to regions. This was an extremely important central conference in preparation for the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee.
At the opening ceremony, Hua Guofeng announced: The agenda of this conference is, firstly, to discuss the "Decision on Accelerating the Development Speed of Agriculture" and the "Regulations on Rural People's Communes (Trial Draft)"; secondly, to make arrangements for the national economic plans of 1979 and 1980; thirdly, to discuss Li Xiannian's speech at the State Council's virtual meeting. Before discussing these topics, the Politburo of the Central Committee decided to first discuss the issue of shifting the Party's work emphasis to the construction of socialist modernization starting from next year.
In his speech, Hua Guofeng did not mention the discussion of the standard of truth, the shift in guiding ideology, or the issue of rectifying miscarriages of justice, which were widely concerned by both the Party members and the public at that time. He said that the basis for shifting work emphasis was that the mass movement of criticizing and repudiating the "Gang of Four" on a large scale could be concluded with victory, and new tasks should be proposed in response to the development of the situation. "When the main problem of a stage is solved, it should move on to a new stage." This means that the shift in work emphasis is only a change in the stage of work, and not a fundamental change in guiding ideology and the Party's political line. Influenced by this, the documents submitted to the conference for discussion on agricultural issues still followed the thinking of "emphasizing revolution and promoting production" and the overall estimation of "continuous bumper harvests for more than a decade" promoted during the "Cultural Revolution", which concealed the truth. It is obvious that this way of achieving the shift in work emphasis is not satisfactory to those comrades attending the conference who were most concerned about resolving issues of guiding ideology and major historical problems.
Starting from the group discussions on November 11th, some raised the issue of rectifying major miscarriages of justice, such as the "Tiananmen Incident". On the 12th, Chen Yun made a speech in the Northeast Group and put forward his opinion on the need to first address the issue of historical legacy. He said: Achieving the four modernizations is the urgent desire of the whole Party and the entire people of our country, and stability and unity are also matters of concern to the whole Party and the entire people. In order to ensure stability and unity, "for some legacy issues that have a significant impact or a wide scope, the central authorities need to consider and make decisions". He then raised six major historical legacy issues, including the rehabilitation of Bo Yibo and 60 other individuals, the rehabilitation of the "Tiananmen Incident", and conclusions regarding Tao Zhu, Peng Dehuai, and others. Once these major issues of concern inside and outside the Party were raised, a strong response was aroused, and the atmosphere of the conference became lively. The focus of each group's speeches quickly turned to the issue of redressing wrongful cases, especially the "Tiananmen incident," with nearly all groups suggesting that it be redressed as soon as possible.
In this situation, the central government approved the announcement of the redress of the "Tiananmen incident" at an expanded meeting of the Beijing Municipal Committee of the CPC. All comrades who had been persecuted as a result were to be redressed and their reputations restored. On the 15th, Xinhua News Agency reported on this with the headline "The 'Tiananmen Incident' was an entirely revolutionary action." On the 16th, newspapers such as People's Daily and Guangming Daily published this news, which greatly encouraged the masses and cadres. Subsequently, the provincial committees of Henan, Zhejiang, Jiangsu, and others solemnly announced that comrades who were persecuted during the Qingming Festival in 1976 for mourning Premier Zhou and opposing the "Gang of Four" would be thoroughly redressed and their reputations restored.
Regarding the redress of other major wrongful cases raised at the meeting, some comrades pointed out that these were all previously decided by the central government and it was necessary for the central government to come out and clearly explain it. Otherwise, there would be opposition from the cadres and masses. It would be best if the central government could clarify these issues before the shift in work focus.
In this situation, the members of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee discussed the opinions mentioned above. On November 25th, Hua Guofeng, on behalf of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee, announced at the meeting that the central government had decided to publicly and thoroughly redress the "Tiananmen incident" and the significant wrongful cases of the so-called "February counterflow" and the "61-person traitor group led by Bo Yibo." The central government would correct the previous erroneous handling of comrades such as Peng Dehuai, Tao Zhu, and Yang Shangkun. All major local incidents would be handled by the party committees of the provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the central government based on the situation in a practical and objective manner. The central task force would conclude its work and transfer all cases to the Central Organization Department. People felt great anger towards Kang Sheng and Xie Fuzhi, so they demanded their exposure and criticism, among other things. Later, on December 14th, when the central work conference distributed Huo Guofeng's speech, it added the withdrawal of all central documents related to the "counter rightist wind" as a recognition of the error. These decisions essentially resolved several major issues that had been strongly called for by cadres and the masses for the past two years, and the comrades at the meeting immediately felt relieved. Everyone spoke their minds freely and felt more intellectually liberated. Some comrades even suggested that the "Cultural Revolution" should be reevaluated and reevaluated. They believed that there was no such thing as "Liu Shaoqi's bourgeois headquarters," and the evaluation of the "Cultural Revolution" as having achieved "70% success and 30% error" was not convincing. However, the time was not yet ripe for full discussion and clear resolution of this issue.
After resolving some major historical legacy issues, the meeting heatedly discussed the differences of opinion that had arisen in the debate on the criterion of truth. Some comrades still believed that discussing the criterion of truth actually amounted to "advocating doubt about everything" and was leading people to criticize Chairman Mao's mistakes, which did not conform to the guidelines of the 11th Party Congress. This view was criticized by the majority of comrades. Many comrades also criticized the negative attitudes displayed by the magazine "Hongqi" and the responsible persons from the Central Propaganda Department during the previous discussions and hoped they would quickly rectify their attitudes. Everyone felt that the essence of the division on this issue was a division between two different guiding ideologies. If this problem was not resolved and if right from wrong was not clarified, the shift in work focus would not proceed smoothly. After intense ideological struggle, some comrades who had lacked a proper understanding of the significance of this debate experienced a transformation and engaged in self-criticism. Everyone also requested that the Central Committee of the Party clearly state its position on this debate in order to thoroughly resolve the ideological line problem.
During the discussion of other topics, everyone also freed themselves from the constraints of the "Two Whatevers" and carried forward the tradition of seeking truth from facts, carefully reflecting on the guiding ideologies and some policy guidelines of the past years, and boldly put forward criticisms and suggestions.
What ideology should guide the shift of work priorities, this is a very crucial question. Some comrades believe that "while we are engaged in construction, we still must adhere to the principle of class struggle". However, many comrades pointed out that the issue of class struggle during the construction period should be reconsidered, and vague concepts should be clarified. This is a problem that the Party must solve in guiding modernization. Some comrades pointed out that the shift of work priorities is not a change in the usual nature of the Party's specific work, but a fundamental change of historical significance. In the future, unless war occurs, production struggle and technological revolution must be the center and there cannot be any other centers. Some comrades also questioned the formulation of "simultaneously seizing the three major revolutionary movements of class struggle, production struggle, and scientific experiment", which has been used for many years, believing that this formulation is not clear about priorities, and in the future, the focus should be explicitly on production struggle. After a heated discussion, the majority of people believe that the issue of class struggle during the socialist period should be reconsidered, thus paving the way for the negation of the principle of "class struggle as the guiding principle".
During the discussion of the two agricultural documents, many comrades expressed strong dissatisfaction with the avoidance of the harsh reality in the documents and the empty talk of the "superiority of the people's commune" and "continuous years of abundant harvests". They pointed out that there are nearly 200 million people in the country now, with food consumption per capita below 150 kilograms, unable to eat their fill, and the per capita grain production in the country is even less than in 1957; the main cause of this situation is that the policies toward the peasants in the past have been too stringent, and the development of agriculture has been stagnant, mainly due to the damage caused by "Left"ist errors. Some comrades said: Do not be afraid of the peasants getting rich. If it is believed that if the peasants become rich, capitalism will arise, then we will be poor for generations to come, and what are we revolutionizing for? Many suggestions were also made to quickly restore and develop agriculture. Chen Yun proposed in his speech: "In three to five years, we can import 20 million tons of grain each year. We cannot be nervous everywhere, we must first stabilize the peasants on this end." "Stabilizing this end is equivalent to stabilizing the majority... then everything will be settled." "This is the biggest economic measure." These opinions and suggestions received attention from the central leadership, and the two documents on agricultural issues were rewritten according to everyone's opinions.
During the discussion of Li Xiannian's summary speech at the State Council's Work Forum, many people agreed to reform the management system and implement the policy of opening up to the outside world. The meeting circulated a batch of materials introducing how foreign countries and Hong Kong and Taiwan regions of China developed their economies rapidly. After reading them, many comrades proposed changing the past practice of "no internal debt and no external debt", fully utilizing the favorable international situation for us, absorbing foreign capital as much as possible, importing advanced technology and equipment, and accelerating the pace of construction. The Standing Committee of the National People's Congress should quickly formulate laws related to accepting foreign loans, borrowing, and investment, and encourage foreign businessmen to jointly operate enterprises with us. These opinions further concretized the deliberations on the policy of reform and opening up, and the conditions for formally making the decision on reform and opening up have matured.
The conference also discussed issues such as party building, democratic and legal construction in the country. Combining with the painful lessons of the "Cultural Revolution", everyone talked about the need to restore the fine tradition of the party's democratic centralism and strengthen the necessity of socialist democracy and legal construction. They also put forward a series of suggestions to strengthen the democratic construction of the party and the country.
Deng Xiaoping watched the progress of the conference and, based on the discussions and issues raised by everyone, felt that the prepared speech was no longer applicable. He personally wrote an outline, listing seven key issues: "(1) Liberate the mind and set things in motion; (2) Promote democracy and strengthen the legal system; (3) Looking backward is for looking forward; (4) Overcome bureaucracy and excessive staffing; (5) Allow some to get rich first; (6) Strengthen the system of responsibility and make it more certain; (7) New problems." Based on this outline, several comrades redrafted the speech for him.
On December 13th, the closing ceremony of the conference was held, and Huo Guofeng, Ye Jianying, and Deng Xiaoping made speeches respectively. Huo Guofeng made self-criticism in his speech on the issue of the "Two Whatevers", admitting that "these two sentences were not fully considered" and "to varying degrees, they have bound our thinking and been detrimental to the implementation of the party's policies in a realistic and practical manner and detrimental to the liveliness of thoughts within the party." He announced that the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee would be held after the conference to further determine the principles and tasks for the transfer of the party's work focus.
Ye Jianying made three suggestions in his speech: (1) To have a good leadership team, especially the Central Committee needs to have a good leadership team; (2) To promote democracy and strengthen the legal system, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress should assume its responsibility of formulating laws and improving the socialist legal system as soon as possible; (3) Diligently study and liberate the mind. He pointed out, "We are carrying out the socialist modernization construction, which is not only a significant improvement of the social productive forces, but also a profound social revolution from economic foundation to superstructure." Many people are still unprepared and their minds are not sufficiently liberated for such a revolution, so "we must eliminate the various superstitions caused by feudalism and free our thoughts from constraints."
Deng Xiaoping delivered an important speech entitled "Liberating the Mind, Seeking Truth from Facts, and Uniting to Look Forward". In this speech, he pointed out, "First, we need to liberate our minds. Only when our minds are liberated can we correctly solve the problems left over from the past and solve a series of new problems, with Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought as our guide." "Without breaking away from ideological rigidity and liberating the minds of officials and the masses, there is no hope for the Four Modernizations."
Deng Xiaoping summarized the discussion on the issue of the criterion of truth that had been passionately conducted throughout the party for the past six months. He pointed out that the discussion on the question of whether practice is the sole criterion of truth is actually also a debate on the need to liberate the mind. This debate is very necessary and of great significance. "If a party, a country, or a nation bases everything on its own book, with rigid thinking and prevailing superstition, it cannot progress, its vitality will cease, and the party and the country will perish." Currently, in order to restore the tradition of seeking truth from facts, it is necessary to liberate the mind and overcome the state of ideological rigidity formed due to various reasons. In this sense, "the debate on the question of the criterion of truth is indeed a question of ideological orientation, a political question, and a question that concerns the future and destiny of the party and the country."
Deng Xiaoping emphasized: to emancipate the mind, use our brains, a very important condition is to truly implement proletarian democratic centralism. In the current period, it is particularly necessary to emphasize democracy. We must create the conditions for democracy and strengthen socialist democracy and the rule of law. This conference has solved some past problems, clarified the merits and demerits of some individuals, corrected a number of major unjust, false, and erroneous cases. This is also a need to emancipate the mind, and the purpose is to look forward and smoothly achieve the shift of the party's work focus.
Regarding the upcoming reform, he said: to look forward, we must timely study new situations and solve new problems. Currently, our economic management work is bloated, with overlapping levels, cumbersome procedures, and extremely low efficiency. Political empty talk often drowns everything. This is not the responsibility of certain comrades, but the responsibility lies in our failure to propose reform in a timely manner. However, if we do not implement reform now, our modernization and socialist cause will be buried.
He also proposed that in the management system in the future, special attention should be paid to strengthening the system of responsibility. Any task, construction project, must implement a system with set tasks, set personnel, set quantity, set quality, and set time. In terms of economic policy, we should allow some regions and some individuals to have a higher income and a better life due to their hard work and great achievements. This will generate great demonstrative power, influence neighboring areas, and drive other regions, continuously advancing the entire national economy in a wave-like manner. "This is a major policy that can impact and drive the entire national economy."
Deng Xiaoping's speech not only put forward and answered a series of fundamental questions at a historical turning point, summarized the central work conference, but also provided guiding ideology for the upcoming Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee. Therefore, this speech actually became the theme report of the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee.
After the closing session, the conference continued for two days of discussions and ended on December 15th. With the promotion of the older generation revolutionaries and the joint efforts of the majority of participants, this 36-day Central Work Conference finally broke free from the "two whatevers" policy, turning the originally planned conference focused on economic work into a comprehensive rectification and new development conference.
2. The convening of the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party
On the basis of achieving significant results in the Central Work Conference, from December 18th to 22nd, 1978, the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Communist Party of China was held in Beijing. The conference was attended by Central Committee members, alternate Central Committee members, and responsible comrades from central departments, totaling 290 people. Hua Guofeng announced at the opening ceremony: "The main task of this plenary session is to discuss and approve the proposal of the Central Political Bureau to shift the party's work focus to socialist modernization construction starting from January next year." The conference deliberated on and passed two documents on agricultural issues, namely, the "Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Accelerating Agricultural Development (Draft)" and the "Regulations on Rural People's Communes (Trial)". It also discussed and approved the national economic plan arrangements for the years 1979 and 1980. Personnel matters were also discussed, and the establishment of the Central Disciplinary Inspection Committee was elected.
Prior to this, after 36 days of extensive discussions at the Central Work Conference, consensus has been reached among the comrades on some major issues. Based on this, the plenum decided to promptly and decisively end the nationwide mass movement of criticism and repudiation against Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four," and from 1979 onwards, to shift the focus of the Party's work to socialist modernization construction. In the future, the policy for class struggle in socialist society should be to strictly differentiate and correctly handle two types of contradictions, to resolve them according to the procedures defined by the constitution and laws, never allowing the mixing of the boundaries between these two types of contradictions, and never allowing damage to the stable and united political situation necessary for socialist modernization construction. Since the policy of "taking class struggle as the key link" was put forward, this is the first time that the Party has formally imposed such clear restrictions and regulations on the issue of class struggle, which politically ensures the realization of the shift in work focus.
Under the guidance of the guiding principles of liberating the mind, seeking truth from facts, and seeking unity for advancement proposed by Deng Xiaoping, the comrades at the conference conducted in-depth discussions on the Party's ideological line issue. It was unanimously agreed that only under the guidance of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, by liberating the mind, seeking truth from facts, starting from reality, and integrating theory with practice, can our Party successfully achieve the shift in work focus. The plenum highly praised the discussion on the proposition that practice is the sole criterion for testing truth, considering it to have profound historical significance for promoting the liberation of ideology among all Party comrades and the entire nation, and for rectifying the ideological line.
Based on a diligent summary of the experiences and lessons since the establishment of the People's Republic of China, the comrades at the conference universally felt that after implementing the shift in work focus, we must not continue to use the past management system and methods, but must boldly reform the traditional system and methods according to the needs of modernization construction and explore new development paths. The plenum announced in the communique: now, based on new historical conditions and practical experience, we should adopt a series of significant new economic measures, earnestly reform the economic management system and operational management methods, actively develop economic cooperation on the basis of self-reliance, and strive to adopt world advanced technology and equipment. This effectively makes the previous brewing about reform and opening up formally become the overall guiding principle for socialist modernization construction and the shift in work focus, and also marks the beginning of a new revolution initiated by the Party through reform and opening up to explore a new path for socialist construction.
During the discussion on agricultural issues, the plenum put forward a series of policy measures to promote agricultural development, such as raising the purchase prices of agricultural products, and agreed to send the "Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Accelerating Agricultural Development (Draft)" and the "Regulations on Rural People's Communes (Trial)" to all provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the central government for discussion and implementation. The rewritten documents, with a solid grounding in reality, pointed out the backward status of agriculture in our country and proposed a series of policy measures to accelerate agricultural development. Among them, it emphasized the need to "respect the autonomy of production brigades," to politically guarantee the democratic rights of farmers, and to fully care about the material interests of farmers, thus initiating reforms in rural areas in practice.
When deliberating on the national economic plan arrangements for the years 1979 and 1980, the plenum affirmed the Central Work Conference's opinions on adjusting the national economy, and proposed the guiding principle that basic construction must be actively pursued within our capabilities, thereby rectifying the guiding ideology for economic construction.
The plenum confirmed the Central Work Conference's decision to rectify a series of major wrongful cases and reevaluate the merits and demerits of some important leaders. It reaffirmed the principle of seeking truth from facts and resolving historical legacy issues by appropriately addressing mistakes, thus initiating the process of rectifying all unjust, false, and wrong cases, comprehensively clearing up and thoroughly resolving the significant historical issues before and during the "Cultural Revolution".
The plenum also made a series of decisions to strengthen socialist democracy and the rule of law, improve the democratic centralism of the Party, and enhance Party discipline. It emphasized the need for national laws and Party rules and discipline. All Party members and cadres must comply with Party discipline.
While firmly correcting the errors of the "Cultural Revolution" and some previous "leftist" mistakes, the plenum affirmed the achievements of Mao Zedong and Mao Zedong Thought. The plenum communique pointed out that Comrade Mao Zedong's great contributions in the long-term revolutionary struggle are indelible. At the same time, it noted that it is not Marxist or in line with Comrade Mao Zedong's own self-evaluation to demand that a revolutionary leader have no faults or mistakes. The central task of the Party is to lead and educate the entire Party and the people of the country to historically and scientifically recognize Comrade Mao Zedong's great achievements, fully and accurately grasp the scientific system of Mao Zedong Thought, integrate the universal principles of Marxism and Mao Zedong Thought with the specific practice of socialist modernization, and develop them in the new historical conditions. This allows us to both objectively point out and correct the mistakes of Mao Zedong's later years, and respect the struggle history of the Party and the people, so as not to lose our direction and lose our fundamental standpoint.
After careful consideration, the plenum elected Chen Yun as a member of the Central Political Bureau, a member of the Standing Committee of the Central Political Bureau, and Vice Chairman of the Central Committee; elected Deng Yingchao, Hu Yaobang, and Wang Zhen as members of the Central Political Bureau; supplemented Huang Kecheng, Song Renqiong, Hu Qiaomu, Xi Zhongxun, Wang Renzhong, Huang Huoqing, Chen Zaidao, Han Guang, and Zhou Hui as members of the Central Committee, to be approved by the 12th National Party Congress; and elected the Central Discipline Inspection Committee, with Chen Yun as the Secretary, Deng Yingchao as the Deputy Secretary, Hu Yaobang as the Third Secretary, Huang Kecheng as the Executive Secretary, and Wang Heshou and others as Deputy Secretaries. On December 25th, the Central Political Bureau decided that Hu Yaobang would serve as the General Secretary of the Communist Party of China and concurrently as the Minister of the Central Propaganda Department. Hu Qiaomu and Yao Yilin would serve as Deputy General Secretaries of the Communist Party of China. Wang Dongxing's concurrent appointment as Director of the Central Office was removed.
These organizational measures provided a reliable guarantee for the smooth implementation of the shift in work priorities and the implementation of the various guiding principles and policies determined by the plenum. Although Hua Guofeng was still the Chairman of the Party Central Committee at that time, in terms of reflecting the correct guiding ideology of the Party and determining the major guiding principles and policies for reform, opening up, and modernization, Deng Xiaoping had already become the core of leadership of the Party Central Committee.
The series of major decisions made by the Third Plenum of the Eleventh Central Committee in ideological, political, economic, and organizational aspects marked the Party's reaffirmation of the ideological line, political line, and organizational line of Marxism. The plenum not only began a comprehensive rectification of the errors of the "Cultural Revolution" and the previous "leftist" mistakes but also laid a solid foundation for the Party to explore a new path of socialist construction under the correct guiding ideology.
As the work priorities of the Party and the country shifted, the guiding ideology of the Party and our country's socialist cause began to shift from "class struggle as the guiding principle" to putting the development of productive forces at the center, from a closed or semi-closed state to opening up to the outside world, from a highly centralized planned economic system to a vibrant socialist market economy system, and from Mao Zedong Thought as guidance to gradually shifting to Deng Xiaoping's theory as guidance. These transformations not only sparked a revolutionary change in China, completely transforming its impoverished and backward appearance but also broke through the old model of socialist construction that had fallen behind the times and become increasingly rigid, opening up a new path and theory for socialist construction with Chinese characteristics. Deng Xiaoping's report, "Liberate Thought, Seek Truth from Facts, Unite as One and Look Forward," is the declaration of opening a new era, a new path, and creating a new theory for socialist construction.
After 29 years of twists and turns, China's socialist cause has finally embarked on the path of victory. The Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) is a milestone in achieving this great historical transformation and marks the beginning of a new path and new theories. A particularly notable statement in the communique of the plenary session reads: "To achieve the Four Modernizations, it is necessary to significantly increase productivity, which in turn requires comprehensive changes in the production relations, superstructure, management methods, activities, and thinking that are not compatible with the development of productive forces." With this historical requirement, China began a new era of reform and opening up, heading towards a great era.
Chapter 2: The comprehensive launch of rectification efforts and the adjustment of social relationships in the new situation
I. The comprehensive launch of rectification of wrong cases
After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the CPC, as the rectification work progressed and deepened throughout the party, a large-scale rectification of wrong cases and adjustment of social relationships was also launched, greatly liberating people's minds and mobilizing all aspects' enthusiasm.
1. Further clarification of major policy principles for rectifying wrong cases
Regarding the rectification of wrong cases, it is generally believed that it is conducted in two phases. The first phase is from the defeat of the "Gang of Four" to the period before the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the CPC. During this phase, the rectification of important figures and major events in the party's history created favorable political conditions for the ongoing historical transformation. However, the rectification work during this phase was not smooth sailing. Due to the deep-rooted influence of the expansion of class struggle within the party and the implementation and persistence of a series of "leftist" erroneous policies by the party's central leadership during these two years, the progress was hindered and the advancement was not smooth, and it could only be carried out partially and relatively slowly.
The convening of the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the CPC created conditions for the large-scale rectification of wrong cases. After the session, the work of rectifying wrong cases and implementing personnel policies rapidly and comprehensively unfolded nationwide. According to the documentary materials publicly released by the Central Organization Department, breakthroughs were made in the rectification of wrong cases during this period in the following aspects:
During the process of rectifying wrong cases and implementing personnel policies, the CPC Central Committee issued a series of important documents, including "Notice on Removing the Labels of Rightists from All Individuals," "Notice on Rectifying and Correcting Issues Concerning Those Labelled as Right Opportunist Elements," "Notice on Handling the Treatment of Central Documents Related to the Clearance of Historical Issues," "Notice on Publicly Rectifying the So-called 'Yang, Yu, Fu Incident,'" "Notice on Rectifying the So-called 'North China Clique'," "Notice on Diligently Conveying and Implementing the Resolution on Rectifying Comrade Liu Shaoqi's Situation," and a large number of other important documents. It also forwarded and endorsed a series of reports, such as the Central Organization Department's "Investigative Report on the 'Group of 61' Case," the Sichuan Provincial Committee's "Notice on Several Issues to Be Kept in Mind in the Implementation of Policies," the Shanghai Municipal Committee's "Request Report on Resolving the So-called 'January Revolution' Issue," the Central Organization Department's "Report on Rectifying the Novel 'Liu Zhidan'," the Supreme People's Court Party Group's "Request Report on Urgently Reinvestigating and Correcting Wrong, False, and Mistaken Cases and Seriously Implementing the Party's Policies," and the Central Organization Department's "Request Report on Several Issues Regarding the Successful Completion of the Work of Reinvestigating and Rectifying Wrong Cases in a Satisfactory Manner." In these documents and remarks, the central government, in accordance with the fundamental principle of seeking truth from facts established at the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, has determined the "two no matters", that is: all false words, all incorrect conclusions and handling, regardless of when or under what circumstances they were done, regardless of which level of organization or who established and approved them, must be corrected; "correct all the wrongs, partially correct the partial, not correct not correct"; "solve problems while stabilizing the situation"; for political and historical issues, avoid getting into trivial details, do not leave any "loose ends"; for issues regarding misappropriation of property and wage deductions, due to large quantities, the central government has determined to "focus on solving the problems politically and providing appropriate economic compensation"; and the series of major policy principles such as "leaders taking responsibility, personally taking action, and the whole party handling cases."
Based on the relevant files and spirit of the central government, and following the instructions of the leading comrades of the central government, the Central Organization Department or in collaboration with the Central United Front Work Department, the Ministry of Public Security, the Ministry of Education, the National Science and Technology Commission, the State Council Overseas Chinese Affairs Office and other relevant departments, have studied and formulated a series of specific policy provisions for rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies.
Before the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, based on in-depth investigations and repeated discussions, the Central Organization Department successively formulated policy documents such as "Notification on Correctly Dealing with the Spouses and Children of Persons Under Investigation", "Notification on Not Implicating Children on Serious Historical and Political Issues of Their Parents", "Notification on Implementing Policy for Grassroots Cadres in Rural Areas", "Notification on Implementing Party Policy for Intellectuals", forming the guiding ideology, principles, and basic framework for rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies.
After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, according to the arrangements of the central government, Hu Yaobang was transferred to the position of Secretary-General of the Central Committee and Minister of the Central Propaganda Department, and Song Renqiong took over as Minister of the Central Organization Department. With the comprehensive implementation of rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies, the Central Organization Department, in response to new problems encountered in their work, based on the spirit and requirements of the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, accelerated the research, formulation, and implementation of policies for rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies. According to incomplete statistics, from 1979 to 1982, the Central Organization Department, or in collaboration with relevant departments of the central and state authorities, researched and formulated nearly thirty specific policy provisions on a particular aspect, further improving the guidelines and policy system for rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies.
The formulation and implementation of these guidelines and policies have greatly promoted the unity and improvement in understanding among various organizations and leaders regarding rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies, standardized the methods and procedures in specific work, and ensured that all levels of organizations have "laws" to follow and guidelines to uphold in the work of rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies, thus guaranteeing the continuous development of this work along a healthy track.
2. Further emancipating the mind and advancing the work of rectifying wrong cases
After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, in the work of rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies, some units and regions still have remnants of "leftist" thinking among their leaders and workers, especially under the influence of the "two no matters" errors, their thinking is not emancipated. They continue to delay the study and resolution of certain cases, stubbornly refuse to handle problems that should be resolved when assigned by higher authorities, and even believe that policy implementation has gone too far. Some leaders in certain regions and units, due to factionalism, have been passive and resistant in their attitude towards rectifying wrong cases and implementing cadre policies, have failed to solve the problems of certain individuals for a long time, and even covered them up. To address these issues, relevant departments of the central government, firstly, need to increase efforts in implementing the spirit of the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, widely publicize the ideological line of the Communist Party of liberating the mind and seeking truth from facts, and further eliminate the remnants of "leftist" thinking, especially the interference caused by the "two no matters". Secondly, by redressing major cases of wrongful conviction, it promotes people's ideological liberation, advances the redress of wrongful cases, and implements policies for cadres. For example, by redressing the wrongful conviction of Liu Shaoqi, the greatest miscarriage of justice during the "Cultural Revolution," it greatly promoted the further liberation of the minds of cadres and the masses, effectively pushed for the redress of wrongful cases, and implemented policies for cadres. Thirdly, documents were formulated and issued to clearly stipulate that deliberate delays and passive resistance in redressing wrongful cases and implementing policies for cadres due to resistance to the spirit of the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee or sectarian interference must be dealt with seriously and necessary organizational measures be taken.
During the process of redressing wrongful cases and implementing policies for cadres, some leaders and staff members, due to insufficient understanding of the importance, continuity, and difficulty of this work, have developed similar thoughts and slackened emotions. Some of them even disbanded the institutions without inspection and acceptance. For this reason, party organizations at all levels have strengthened the education on the importance and difficulty of redressing wrongful cases and implementing policies for cadres, making them realize the profound historical significance and significant practical significance of redressing wrongful cases and implementing policies for cadres and understand the historical responsibilities they bear. Emphasis is placed on ensuring the redress of wrongful cases and the implementation of policies for cadres from beginning to end, and being responsible for the political life of each comrade. We must not only focus on the surface problems that have been resolved 80% or 90%, as long as one wrongful case has not been corrected, then for that comrade, his problem is 100% unresolved. Each case and each comrade must be dealt with solidly, withstand the test of history. At the same time, the requirements for carrying out inspection and acceptance work and the acceptance criteria are put forward.
In response to the problems of neglecting in-depth and meticulous ideological work, and the unreasonable or excessive demands made by a small number of people or their relatives who have been implemented with policies, and even causing trouble for no reason, the Central Organization Department has required the strengthening of political and ideological work in redressing wrongful cases and implementing policies for cadres. We must patiently and meticulously do the ideological work of implementing policies for the targets, and leaders at all levels must personally conduct the ideological work of comrades who have been persecuted and their families, encourage them to lift their spirits, work hard, unite, and look forward, and contribute to realizing the "Four Modernizations." Emphasis is placed on solving problems politically when implementing policies, without getting entangled in trivial matters. We must strengthen the political care and protection for those implementing policies and strictly follow the party's policies. Criticism and education are necessary for those who cause trouble for no reason.
3. New progress in redressing wrongful cases during the "Cultural Revolution"
Under the guidance of the spirit of the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, after the efforts of the whole party, by the end of 1982, the task of redressing wrongful cases during the "Cultural Revolution" had been basically completed, achieving a decisive victory in redressing wrongful cases and implementing policies for cadres. In total, 2.3 million cadres who were filed for "review and investigation" during the "Cultural Revolution" were re-examined and redressed, and nearly 20,000 cases of collective wrongful conviction were resolved, including several major cases that had a significant impact throughout the party, the country, and the world.
(1) A large number of senior cadres were re-examined and redressed after receiving the review materials from the central special case group. The Eleventh Plenary Session of the Party decided to abolish the organization of the central special case leadership group and transfer all the archives to the Central Organization Department. In order to implement the decision of the plenary session, on December 19, 1978, comrades from the central special case group and the Central Organization Department, including Wang Dongxing, the former leader of the central special case leadership group, and Ji Dengkui, Wu De, held a meeting to convey the decision of the plenary session. Comrades responsible for the Central Organization Department, such as Hu Yaobang, Minister of the Central Organization Department, Chen Yeping, Vice Minister, Zhao Cangbi, Minister of the Ministry of Public Security, and the three special case offices and the responsible comrades of the Organization Department's investigation and audit bureau, attended the meeting. It was announced at the meeting that the First Office, the Third Office, and the "May 16" special case joint office of the central special case review group were abolished from that day onwards. All project materials shall be handed over to the Central Organization Department for processing. During the handover process, no materials may be destroyed. On the morning of December 20th, Vice Minister Chen Ye Ping of the Central Organization Department conveyed the spirit of the handover meeting at the department's hall meeting with directors and bureau chiefs. He made specific arrangements for the reception and review work and mobilized a dedicated team to establish the receiving organization, working day and night on this task. By the end of February 1979, all project materials had been successfully transferred. The Central Organization Department received a total of 1,730 volumes and 391,363 items of materials from the original Central Investigation Group, involving a total of 669 people under investigation.
Subsequently, the Central Organization Department immediately carried out the review and rehabilitation work. According to statistics, there were 213 cadres included in the central investigative cases, including deputy ministers of central and state organs, vice governors of provinces, autonomous regions, and directly governed municipalities (including cadres at the equivalent military level).
