Among them were 10 members of the Eighth Political Bureau, 10 members of the Central Secretariat, 71 Central Committee members and alternate Central Committee members (excluding those reviewed by provinces and cities), 7 deputy prime ministers of the State Council, as well as marshals and generals who fought in the south and north, party secretaries and deputy governors of the central bureau, provinces, autonomous regions, and directly governed municipalities, ministers and deputy ministers of central organs and State Council departments, heads of agencies and a group of experts, professors, writers, and technical personnel, and even a small number of residents and students. Among the reviewed individuals, 320 were classified as having "serious problem nature or enemy-contradiction," accounting for 47.8% of those under investigation. With so many major cases, in order to make objective and fair review and rehabilitation conclusions in a short period of time, relying solely on the strength of the Central Organization Department was evidently impossible. In view of this, the Central Organization Department took the following measures: First, all leading comrades who had been sent by the central investigation group to work in other places while still under supervisory labor were immediately brought back to Beijing and relevant units. After the Third Plenum of the Eleventh Central Committee, the Central Organization Department had greater initiative in this matter. Peng Zhen and his wife Zhang Jieqing returned to Beijing after the meeting. Wang Guangmei, who had been detained, was also released. Other comrades were also gradually brought back by various units. Second, for some comrades, a method of first assigning work and then conducting review and rehabilitation was adopted, enabling these leading comrades to return to their work posts as soon as possible. Third, following the principles of the Party's handling of cases and the mass line, a method of transferring the cases to the original units for review and then submitting them to the Central Organization Department for adjudication and approval was adopted, greatly speeding up the progress of review and rehabilitation. Practice has proved that these measures have achieved good results. From 1979 to 1980, a total of 445 people were directly concluded by the Central Organization Department and reported to the central government for approval, including a large number of senior leaders such as Peng Zhen, Lu Dingyi, Tao Zhu, Liu Lantao, Xi Zhongxun, An Ziwen, Qian Ying, Hu Qiaomu, Shuai Mengqi, Zhao Yimin, Lin Feng, Tan Zhenlin, Li Lisan, Wang Renzhong, and so on.
(2) A number of major influential cases were thoroughly rectified.
①The Wuhan "720 incident" was thoroughly rectified. The Wuhan "720 incident" occurred on July 20, 1967, when the masses of workers, peasants, and soldiers in Wuhan took to the streets to protest against the conspiracy activities of the "Gang of Four," which sent people to create chaos within the military, destroy the relationship between the military and civilians, support violent struggles, support looting and destruction, and undermine production. Afterwards, Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" fabricated the "720 incident" as a "thoroughly counterrevolutionary event," falsely accusing Wang Renzhong, Chen Zaidao, and other leading figures of the Hubei Provincial Committee and the Wuhan Military Region Party Committee of being the "backstage" of the "720 incident," branding a group of party, government, and military leaders as a "tiny handful of capitalist roaders" within the party and military, and subjecting the broad masses of cadres and public who participated in or supported the demonstrations to cruel persecution. In the struggle against the "Gang of Four", the Hubei Provincial Party Committee, the Provincial Revolutionary Committee, and the Wuhan Military Region Party Committee, based on the demands of the cadres and masses, studied and believed that Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" distorted the facts and confused right and wrong by labeling the "July 20th Incident" as a "counterrevolutionary incident". They should be rehabilitated, and all false accusations imposed on the People's Liberation Army and the cadres and masses should be completely overturned. They submitted the "Request Report on Dealing with the Wuhan 'July 20th Incident'" to the central government. In November 1978, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China forwarded the request report from the Hubei Provincial Party Committee, the Provincial Revolutionary Committee, and the Wuhan Military Region Party Committee, thoroughly rehabilitating the Wuhan "July 20th Incident".
②To rehabilitate the so-called "February Counterflow" issue. In February 1967, Tan Zhenlin, Chen Yi, Ye Jianying, Li Fuchun, Li Xiannian, Xu Xiangqian, Nie Rongzhen, and other leaders of the Central Politburo and Military Commission, at meetings such as the Central Military Commission Meeting and the Central Politburo Meeting, criticized the incorrect practices of the "Cultural Revolution" proposed by Lin Biao, the "Gang of Four", Kang Sheng, and Chen Boda, and instigated the slogan "topple everything, start a comprehensive civil war" with the intention of destabilizing the military and the nation, and seizing power from the party. They strongly criticized the "Cultural Revolution" and conducted a resolute and confrontational struggle against Lin Biao, the "Gang of Four", Kang Sheng, and Chen Boda. However, they were suppressed and repressed under the accusation of "February Counterflow". After the defeat of the Lin Biao group, Mao Zedong proposed to rehabiliate the "February Counterflow" and pointed out: Once this matter is clarified, we should no longer mention the "February Counterflow". After the defeat of the "Gang of Four", at the Central Work Conference in 1978, the Central Committee pointed out that the so-called "February Counterflow" was entirely a distortion and deliberate fabrication by Lin Biao and his group, with the aim of overthrowing several senior generals and vice premiers who opposed them, and then overthrowing Zhou Enlai and Zhu De. The Central Committee decided that all comrades who had been wronged due to this case should have their reputation restored, and all comrades who had been implicated and punished should be rehabilitated. All false statements regarding the so-called "February Counterflow" in various documents and materials in the past should be nullified.
③To rehabilitate the "61-person Traitor Group" case. The so-called "61-person Traitor Group" case was a major political case that caused a sensation at home and abroad during the "Cultural Revolution". The so-called "traitors" referred to 61 members of the Chinese Communist Party, including Bo Yibo, who were released from Caolanzi Prison in Beiping in 1936 with special approval from the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China. During the "Cultural Revolution", only 40 of them survived, among whom 22 held leadership positions such as provincial party secretary, deputy provincial governor, deputy minister of central agencies, and even vice premier of the State Council. At that time, not only did these 40 veteran comrades suffer persecution, but their families, their relatives, and their former subordinates were almost all implicated. Tens of thousands of people were subject to investigation and persecution. In June 1978, Deng Xiaoping instructed in a letter of appeal regarding the "61-person case": "We must deal with this issue, which is also a matter of seeking truth from facts." In accordance with the spirit of this instruction, the Organization Department of the Central Committee conducted a review of this case. On December 6 of the same year, the central government agreed to and forwarded the investigation report on the "61-person Case" by the Organization Department, pointing out that it was a major wrongful case and calling for correction and arrangements for the comrades who had been wrongly handled as a result. This way, justice was served for this major miscarriage of justice.
④To rehabilitate the cadres and masses who were criticized and persecuted in the so-called "January Revolution". The so-called "January Revolution" refers to the period from January 4, 1967, when Zhang Chunqiao and Yao Wenyuan returned to Shanghai, to February 5, when they established the "Shanghai People's Commune", during which they opened a gap in Shanghai and engaged in a conspiracy to seize power overall.
In 1966, Zhang Chunqiao and Yao Wenyuan colluded with Lin Biao, Chen Boda, and Jiang Qing, and instigated the slogan "oppose the Shanghai Municipal Party Committee". On January 4, 1967, Zhang Chunqiao and Yao Wenyuan returned to Shanghai and further incited "no need to have illusions about the Municipal Committee" and "the current fundamental issue is to take back the leadership from the capitalist roaders", and propagated the overthrow of everything and the comprehensive seizure of power. On January 6, under the pretense of various revolutionary organizations in the city, they held a "Down with the Municipal Committee Conference", criticized the leadership comrades of the Shanghai Municipal Committee, and brought hundreds of bureau-level or higher cadres to the meeting to be criticized. They declared that they no longer recognized Cao Diqiu as the secretary of the Shanghai Municipal Committee and the mayor. In fact, they seized power in Shanghai and established the so-called "Shanghai People's Commune" on February 5. Subsequently, a wave of power seizure swept the whole country, and in many places it even escalated into armed conflicts, resulting in many local party and government organizations falling into a paralyzed or semi-paralyzed state, and further serious destruction of social order and industrial and agricultural production.
The so-called "January Revolution" was completely a conspiracy carefully planned by Lin Biao, Chen Boda, and the "Gang of Four". It was an important step for them to disrupt the entire country and carry out a comprehensive seizure of party power. 
In December 1978, the Shanghai Municipal Committee decided to reverse the public criticism of Cao Diqiu and others and all persecuted cadres and masses in the "January Revolution". In January 1979, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China forwarded the Shanghai Municipal Committee's "Report on Addressing the Issue of the so-called 'January Revolution'" and thoroughly reversed the cadres and masses who were criticized and persecuted during the so-called "January Revolution".
⑤ To publicly reverse the "Yang, Yu, Fu Incident". In March 1968, Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" fabricated the so-called "Yang, Yu, Fu Incident" in order to counter the military and seize party power, creating the so-called "Yang, Yu, Fu Incident". They falsely accused Yang Chengwu (alternate member of the 8th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, standing committee member of the Central Military Commission, acting chief of the General Staff), Yu Lijin (political commissar of the Air Force, second secretary of the Air Force Party Committee), and Fu Chongbi (commander of the Beijing Garrison District) of "reversing the February tide". They fabricated that Yang Chengwu "colluded with Yu Lijin to seize the leadership of the Air Force" and "colluded with Fu Chongbi to seize the power of Beijing", and "fabricated black materials against Jiang Qing", and "Yang Chengwu gave three orders to Fu Chongbi to go from Goashan Island to the Central Cultural Revolution to arrest people", and even "attacked Jiang Qing". They said that Yang Chengwu's "hidden support" was "Ye Jianying, Nie Rongzhen, Chen Yi, and Tan Zhenlin". They falsely accused Yu Lijin of being a "traitor" and slandered Yang, Yu, and Fu as the "hidden support of May 16", and so on. They even included the "Yang, Yu, Fu Incident" as the "evil wind of reversing the February tide" in the Communiqué of the 12th Plenary Session of the 8th Party Central Committee and the political report of the 9th National Congress. Yang Chengwu, Yu Lijin, Fu Chongbi, and others were brutally persecuted, and a large number of comrades were implicated nationwide, some were disabled or killed, causing serious consequences. In March 1979, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued a notice on publicly reversing the "Yang, Yu, Fu Incident", pointing out that the so-called "Yang, Yu, Fu Incident" was a wrongful case fabricated by Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" against the party. The central government decided to publicly reverse the "Yang, Yu, Fu Incident". All unfounded accusations should be overturned, and the documents issued by the central government in the past should be revoked. As for the comrades who were implicated and persecuted in this case and were forced to die or become disabled, their names should be cleared, and their reputations should be restored.
⑥ To publicly reverse the so-called "North China Regionalism". In March 1968, Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" fabricated the charges of "North China Regionalism" and "Shanxi-Shaanxi-Hebei Regionalism" during the fabrication of the "Yang, Yu, Fu Incident". Afterwards, in the Beijing Military Region, they repeatedly launched a large-scale campaign against the so-called "North China Regionalism", directly targeting Nie Rongzhen, Xu Xiangqian, Luo Ruiqing, and Yang Chengwu, who had served as major leaders in the North China region. They falsely accused and brutally persecuted some leading comrades in the Beijing Military Region, implicated a large number of comrades, disrupted people's thinking, undermined the unity and construction of the troops, and caused serious consequences and influence. In December 1979, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued a notice entitled "Regarding the Rectification of the So-Called 'North China Factionalism'," stating that Lin Biao and the Gang of Four's defamation of the glorious history of the Jin-Cha-Ji Military Region, North China Military Region, and Beijing Military Region was completely driven by their counterrevolutionary political needs. They regarded the Beijing Military Region as a serious obstacle to their anti-revolutionary coup, so they repeatedly launched attacks against the "North China Factionalism," doing everything they could to overthrow the older generation of proletarian revolutionaries who had previously worked in North China and some leading comrades in the Beijing Military Region, in order to realize their conspiracy to seize party and state power. The Central Committee officially declared that the so-called "Jin-Cha-Ji Factionalism," "North China Factionalism," and others were all false accusations and should be thoroughly rejected. All related materials should be revoked. Comrades who were persecuted and implicated in this case should be fully rehabilitated and their reputation restored.
⑦ Rectify the wrongful cases of Liu Shaoqi and a large number of comrades who were implicated in the wrongful case of Liu Shaoqi. The wrongful case of Liu Shaoqi, Vice Chairman of the Central Committee and President of the People's Republic of China, was the largest wrongful case during the "Cultural Revolution" and the largest wrongful case in the history of the People's Republic.
After the downfall of the Gang of Four, a large number of cadres and the masses inside and outside of the party requested and advised the Central Committee to reexamine the case of Liu Shaoqi. In February 1979, the Central Committee decided that the case of Liu Shaoqi should be reexamined by the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection and the Central Organization Department. The results of the reexamination were carefully discussed at the Fifth Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee in February 1980, and the Resolution on Rehabilitating Comrade Liu Shaoqi was unanimously passed. It stated: "The three major accusations of 'traitor, spy, and capitalist-roader' that were unjustly imposed on Comrade Liu Shaoqi in the original review report, as well as other various charges, were entirely the deliberate frame-up by the clique of Lin Biao, Jiang Qing, Kang Sheng, and Chen Boda. The decision made at the 12th Plenary Session of the 8th Central Committee to 'permanently expel Liu Shaoqi from the party and revoke all his party and non-party positions' was wrong." "Comrade Liu Shaoqi was a great Marxist and a proletarian revolutionary who devoted his whole life to the struggle for communism. As one of the outstanding leaders of the party and the country, he made indelible contributions to the construction of our party, the democratic and socialist revolutions in our country, and socialist construction." "All the previous slanders, accusations, forged materials, and all false accusations against Comrade Liu Shaoqi should be completely overturned."
The Plenary Session decided to revoke the charges imposed on Liu Shaoqi and the handling resolution against him by the 12th Plenary Session of the 8th Central Committee, restore the honor of Liu Shaoqi as a great Marxist and proletarian revolutionary, and rehabilitate the wrongful, false, and mistaken cases related to the Liu Shaoqi issue. On March 19, 1980, the Central Committee issued a notice entitled "Regarding the Thorough Implementation of the Resolution Rehabilitating Comrade Liu Shaoqi."
The Plenary Session required that party organizations at all levels actively and responsibly continue to resolve similar outstanding and unresolved issues in line with this spirit. In order to implement the spirit of the Fifth Plenary Session, the Organization Department forwarded the notice from the Guizhou Provincial Committee entitled "Regarding Rectifying the Wrongful, False, and Mistaken Cases Caused by the Liu Shaoqi Issue and Effectively Implementing the Party's Policies" on April 18, 1980. It demanded that all regions and departments strive to complete the rehabilitation work for those implicated in the wrongful case of Liu Shaoqi and other wrongful, false, and mistaken cases during the "Cultural Revolution" in the first half of the year. On May 17, a memorial meeting for Liu Shaoqi was solemnly held in Beijing. More than 10,000 representatives from the party and state leadership and various sectors in the capital attended the memorial meeting. The rehabilitation of Liu Shaoqi cleared his name and also thoroughly rehabilitated tens of thousands of people who were implicated in the wrongful case of Liu Shaoqi nationwide. The rehabilitation of this highly influential wrongful case further liberated the thinking of a large number of cadres and promoted the rehabilitation work of other wrongful, false, and mistaken cases.
⑧ Rectify the cases of comrades unjustly accused due to the so-called "First Big Character Poster" nationwide. At the beginning of the Cultural Revolution, Nie Yuanzi, the secretary of the Party branch of the Department of Philosophy at Peking University, and others accused the Party Committee of Peking University and individuals such as Lu Ping (Secretary of the Party Committee of Peking University), Song Shuo (Deputy Minister of the University Science Department of the Beijing Municipal Party Committee), and Peng Peiyun (Deputy Secretary of the Party Committee of Peking University) of publishing the so-called "First Big-character Poster". This accusation was applauded by Mao Zedong. Taking advantage of this opportunity, Lin Biao, Jiang Qing, Kang Sheng, and Chen Boda fabricated charges against Lu Ping, Song Shuo, Peng Peiyun, and others, leading to their persecution. Not only was the big-character poster broadcasted on the radio, but the People's Daily also organized commentator articles to praise it, causing a very bad influence nationwide. This was a major wrongful case that occurred in the early stages of the Cultural Revolution. In February 1979, the Beijing Municipal Committee of the Communist Party of China decided to completely clear the Party Committee of Peking University and Lu Ping, Song Shuo, and Peng Peiyun. In August 1980, the Central Organization Department forwarded the Notice from the Beijing Municipal Committee on completely clearing the comrades who were unjustly accused in the so-called "First Big-character Poster" nationwide, ensuring that this wrongful case was completely cleared.
⑨ Completely clear the so-called "Black Party" and "Fake Party" accusations. During the Cultural Revolution, under the influence of Lin Biao and the Gang of Four's ultra-leftist line, the underground party organization of the 38th Army of the former Yang Hucheng Department was falsely accused of being the "Black Party" and "Fake Party". Many old comrades in this organization were falsely accused of being the "true Kuomintang, false Communist Party" and were labeled as "traitors" and "spies", suffering from cruel persecution. After the Gang of Four was overthrown, an investigation by the Shaanxi Provincial Party Committee found that the accusations of the so-called "Black Party" and "Fake Party" were completely unfounded. After reporting to the central authorities, in February 1981, the Central Organization Department forwarded the Shaanxi Provincial Party Committee's request report on completely clearing the accusations against the underground party organization of the 38th Army of the former Yang Hucheng Department as the "Black Party" and "Fake Party". Thoroughly clear the accusations against the underground party organization of the 38th Army of the former Yang Hucheng Department and the underground party members who were persecuted in this case, eliminate all false accusations, and handle the aftermath properly.
⑩ Completely clear the so-called "Red Flag Party" accusations. During the Yan'an Rectification Movement in 1943, Kang Sheng fabricated the so-called "Red Flag Party" case. Underground parties in Gansu, Henan, Shaanxi, Sichuan, Hunan, Hubei, Yunnan, Guizhou, Zhejiang, Guangxi, and other places were falsely accused of being the "Red Flag Party", and many underground party members were labeled as "spies", "traitors", and "internal agents". In the later stage of the Yan'an rectification, the central authorities found that the so-called "Red Flag Party" case fabricated by Kang Sheng was completely false and made timely corrections. However, due to the historical conditions at that time, a comprehensive conclusion was not reached. During the Cultural Revolution, this historical issue was brought up again, and many comrades were once again falsely accused and subjected to brutal struggles. Some were even persecuted to disability or death. In order to completely resolve the legacy of the so-called "Red Flag Party" and eliminate the adverse consequences caused by Kang Sheng's fabrication, in September 1981, the General Office of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued the Notice on officially clearing the underground party organizations in Gansu, Henan, Shaanxi, and other provinces that were falsely accused of being the "Red Flag Party". Thoroughly clear all false accusations imposed on these underground party organizations, and completely clear and vindicate the comrades who were persecuted in this case.
⑪ Completely clear Pan Hannian's name and restore his reputation. Pan Hannian was an old party member of our party and has held important leadership positions both within and outside the party. He made significant contributions to the party's cultural work, united front work, and particularly in carrying out concealed struggle against the enemy. Since 1955, due to serious neglect of the particular nature of the concealed struggle against the enemy, confusion of the boundaries of right and wrong, and the enemy and ourselves, Pan Hannian was falsely labeled as an "internal traitor". He was arrested, detained, and subjected to investigation, and later convicted, sentenced, and expelled from the party. He remained wrongly accused and suffered for more than twenty years until his death in 1977. Because of Pan Han's issues, many comrades who had worked with him in the past were also unjustly treated for a long time. In March 1981, the Party Central Committee instructed the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection to reexamine the Pan case. The CCDI retrieved and studied materials from various aspects, and also conducted investigations with dozens of comrades who had worked with Pan Han in the past. The review results showed that the previous conclusion that Pan Han was a "spy" could not stand and should be denied. This was a major wrongful case since the founding of New China. On August 23, 1982, the central government issued a document solemnly announcing to the entire party: Pan Han has been vindicated and his reputation restored; for comrades who were mistakenly implicated and dealt with inappropriately due to the Pan case, their cases should also be reexamined and redressed in a realistic and fair manner, and post-settlement issues should be properly handled.
(3) Conduct a review and redress for a group of party and state leaders, hundreds of provincial and ministerial-level cadres, and a large number of well-known figures from various fields.
During the "Cultural Revolution," a large number of important party and state leaders were impacted and persecuted. After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, the Party Central Committee successively conducted a review and redress of the issues of a group of party, state, government, and military leaders such as Liu Shaoqi, Peng Dehuai, He Long, Tao Zhu, Peng Zhen, Bo Yibo, Yang Shangkun, Zhang Wentian, Lu Dingyi, Tan Zhenlin, Xi Zhongxun, Huang Kecheng, Wang Renzhong, Song Renqiong, and Luo Ruiqing. The issue of martyr Qu Qiubai, an early leader of our party, was also redressed.
Before the "Cultural Revolution," there were a total of 1,253 vice provincial governors and vice ministers or higher-level cadres across the country. Among them, 1,011 were impacted during the "Cultural Revolution," accounting for 81% of the total number of cadres at the same level. Among them, 453 were falsely accused of being "traitors," "spies," "counterrevolutionary revisionist elements," "agents of the capitalist headquarters," or "executors of the revisionist line," accounting for 36% of the total number (excluding those directly examined by the original Central Special Case Group). Most of the so-called reviews of these cadres were based on groundless accusations, fabricated slanders, or the exaggeration of minor issues and the labeling of them as major offenses, which resulted in severe damage to these comrades both mentally and physically. Forty comrades died with grievances during the "review" period, and some comrades were left with lifelong disabilities.
After the fall of the "Gang of Four," the Central Organization Department, entrusted by the central authorities, conducted a review or trial of the conclusions of 453 vice provincial governors, vice ministers or higher-level cadres from 1978 to the end of 1980.
All 85 individuals who were regarded as enemies during the "Cultural Revolution" have been completely vindicated and their reputations restored. For those who had historical issues and faced intensified reevaluations during the "Cultural Revolution," most of their previous conclusions were maintained. After implementing the policies, those comrades who were physically fit and capable were appointed to leadership positions, and those who were in poor health were properly placed, while those who died with grievances received posthumous rehabilitation. Work was done to eliminate the impact on comrades, their family members, and children caused by these mistaken cases.
(4) Redress the mistakes and false accusations of certain central government departments during the "Cultural Revolution." The main tasks were: revoking the erroneous conclusion of the Central Committee's External Liaison Department, which had implemented the policy of "three representatives and one inheritor for each department" and "three reductions and one extermination"; completely redressing the so-called "Yanwang Palace" of the Central Propaganda Department; removing the label of "implementing the surrenderist line" from the National United Front, Ethnic Affairs, and Religious Affairs departments; thoroughly redressing the mistaken case of labeling the original Ministry of Culture as the "department of emperors, prime ministers, and dead foreigners"; completely redressing the wrongful case of the Political Department of the PLA being falsely accused as the "Yanwang Palace" and revoking the "Summary of Symposium on Military Literary Work" issued in February 1966; overturning the conclusion of the so-called "implementation of the revisionist line" imposed on the education front and revoking the "Summary of National Education Work Conference" in 1971; and so on.
After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, party organizations at all levels further conducted a review and redress of a large number of well-known figures in various fields such as literature and art, sports, science and technology, and health.
II. Properly handle historical legacy issues.
Properly handling historical legacy issues is an important part of rectifying work and a challenging task in implementing cadre policies. 
Due to the influence of the erroneous "left" ideology in previous political movements, as well as some mistakes in work, the special historical conditions of the war era, failure to resolve some complex problems in time, and various other reasons, a large number of historical legacy issues have been left behind. According to incomplete statistics, there are millions of cases left over from the "Cultural Revolution" in the whole country, involving millions of people and affecting tens of millions of people.
With the restoration and development of the Party's principle of seeking truth from facts, the call for rectifying wrongful cases and implementing cadre policies has been increasing as more appeals to solve historical legacy issues before the "Cultural Revolution" emerge. This is not only an inevitable requirement for our Party to emancipate the mind, seek truth from facts, rectify wrongful cases, and develop the implementation of cadre policies, but also directly related to the rectification of wrongful cases during the "Cultural Revolution". Many wrongful cases during the "Cultural Revolution" were intentionally brought up again by Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four", causing endless confusion and harm. Therefore, with the deepening development of rectifying wrongful cases and implementing cadre policies, many historical legacy issues are inevitably involved. If these issues are not properly handled, the enthusiasm of these cadres and masses will be difficult to mobilize and exert, and the stability and development of the situation of unity and stability will be difficult to consolidate. The principle of seeking truth from facts of the Party will not be thoroughly restored and developed.
Shortly after the rectification of wrongful cases and the implementation of cadre policies began, the review and correction of legacy issues from the "Anti-Rightist" and "Four Cleanups" movements were already on the agenda. The central authorities issued relevant documents, clearly defining the relevant policy provisions, and started to review and correct historical legacy issues before the "Cultural Revolution".
After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, especially after the rectification of wrongful cases during the "Cultural Revolution" was basically completed, the focus shifted to properly handling historical legacy issues in the work of rectifying wrongful cases and implementing cadre policies. A large number of major historical legacy issues were reviewed and dealt with, such as the "Anti-Rightist," "Anti-Right Deviationist," "Four Cleanups," "Underground Party," "Intelligence Personnel," "Mistaken Executions in the Anti-Rightist Campaign in the Red Army," "Huxi Purge," and "Central Plains Breakthrough." This work was basically completed before the Thirteenth National Congress in 1987.
How to actively and properly handle historical legacy issues is related to whether the rectification of wrongful cases and the implementation of cadre policies can proceed steadily and healthily, as well as to the stability of the overall situation of unity and stability. Therefore, the Central Organization Department and relevant departments of the central state organs focused on the following two areas of work in macro guidance:
1. Make efforts to eliminate various obstacles and disturbances
In the initial stage of handling historical legacy issues, the obstacles and disturbances mainly came from the "left" side. Some people continue to view historical legacy issues from a "leftist" standpoint and do not correct the wrong classification.
After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, another incorrect tendency appeared in the review and correction of historical legacy issues, which is that some people adopt a negative attitude toward everything and demand a thorough review of the problems in all political movements since the founding of the People's Republic of China and the historical legacy issues before its establishment. The calls for this are getting louder and there is a trend of an increasing number of letters and visits. Even things that shouldn't be changed were changed. To address these issues, in June 1979, the Central Organization Department held a symposium on "Implementing Cadre Policy Work." In the symposium, the leadership of the Organization Department clearly pointed out that there is a difference between the wrongful, fabricated, and incorrect cases during the "Cultural Revolution" and the incorrect cases before the "Cultural Revolution". For old cases before the "Cultural Revolution," the principles of dialectical materialism and historical materialism should be used, following the principles of seeking truth from facts and correcting mistakes when they occur. In general, we should deal with the problems at that time based on the situation, conditions, and policies at that time. Guidelines and principles were put forward for dealing with the historical legacy issues before the "Cultural Revolution". After the meeting, with the approval of the central government, the Central Organization Department issued a notice on the handling of some cases before the "Cultural Revolution". The document pointed out that in addition to the correction of historical cases of falsely accusing rightists and the correction of cases wrongly handled during the anti-rightist struggle since 1959 and the rectification of cases in the "Four Cleanups" movement, which had been regulated by the central government, the remaining cases could be reviewed and tried according to the principle of handling them individually. It is fundamentally different from the large number of wrongful, false, and mistaken cases caused by the serious interference and destruction of Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" during the "Cultural Revolution". If we do not analyze these old cases in a historical manner and review and handle them all again based on the current policy standpoint, it will inevitably lead to confusion, affect stability and unity, and alienate a large number of party cadres and the masses. Historical cases should be handled cautiously considering different situations. For those who have made mistakes and have been properly handled based on the party's policy at that time, or even if the handling was somewhat heavy, but the main facts have not changed, no further review should be conducted. For cases where the main basis for the original qualification was untrue, and cases that were wrongly expelled from the party, dismissed from public office, and concluded as enemies according to the party's policies at that time, a review and correction should be conducted. Party membership can be restored or rejoining the party is possible for those who were wrongly expelled from the party but have performed well subsequently and meet the membership requirements.
In order to further improve the review work of historical legacy issues, the Central Organization Department convened a symposium in Yichang, Hubei Province in January 1983, attended by organization departments of seventeen provincial and municipal party committees and comrades from some central state organs. At the meeting, experiences in this work were exchanged, difficulties encountered in the work were studied, opinions and measures for solving the problems were put forward, and the principles and tasks of this work were further determined. After the meeting, the Central Organization Department issued a notice and distributed the Summary of the Symposium on the Review and Correction of Wrongful, False, and Mistaken Cases before the "Cultural Revolution", stating that the wrongful, false, and mistaken cases that occurred before the "Cultural Revolution" were mainly caused by restrictions in understanding at that time and work mistakes, and they are fundamentally different from the large number of wrongful, false, and mistaken cases deliberately created by the specific historical conditions of the "Cultural Revolution" and the counter-revolutionary group of Lin Biao and Jiang Qing. To review and correct the wrongful, false, and mistaken cases before the "Cultural Revolution" and solve the historical legacy problems, the policies and regulations approved by the Central Organization Department and the spirit of the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee should be followed. Taking into account the background at the time, based on factual materials, a historical and comprehensive approach should be taken, each case should be analyzed specifically, and the principle of seeking truth from facts should be adhered to. Any mistakes should be corrected actively and carefully in a step-by-step manner. In the work, attention should be paid to preventing two kinds of deviations: one is to continue viewing historical old cases from a "left" perspective, not correcting cases that were wrongly handled, or even not dealing with cases that one has processed and approved despite their obvious errors; The other is to take a negationist view and change things that should not be changed. For the cases before the "Cultural Revolution", all appeals and cases that may have been mishandled but were not appealed should be reviewed, with a focus on major cases, key cases, public cases, and cases that were categorized as enemies or wrongly expelled from the party or dismissed from public office. The handling of cases should be based on facts and guided by the party's policies. Those cases with principally unfounded conclusions should be completely overturned; those cases based on solid evidence but with wrong handling should be corrected; those cases with clear facts, conclusive evidence, and correct handling of conclusions, or those cases with no significant difference in the main basis, and whose handling is generally appropriate but biased, can remain unchanged, and some consideration can be given in terms of their use and daily life. After rectifying wrongful and unjust cases, the focus should be on resolving the problems politically. It is necessary to do ideological work well, while handling the aftermath properly according to relevant regulations.
Through these two meetings and the documents issued afterwards, the work of properly handling historical legacy issues has been effectively promoted and advanced.
2. Develop correct guidelines and policies for addressing historical legacy issues.
The proper handling of historical legacy issues is of great responsibility and has strong policy implications. It directly relates to the recognition and evaluation of martyrs who sacrificed their lives for the revolution, as well as the political lives of some comrades. There is no room for any negligence. It must be strictly implemented in accordance with the central guidelines and policies. Therefore, it is particularly important to establish correct guidelines and policies.
Under the guidance and care of the central leadership and older generation revolutionaries, the Party Central Committee and relevant departments of the central state organs have successively formulated a series of policies and regulations on handling historical legacy issues, including the "Notice on Removing the Hats of Rightists," the "Implementation Plan for Implementing the Central Decision on Removing the Hats of Rightists," the "Notice on Rehabilitating and Correcting the Cases of Individuals Labelled as Right-Wing Opportunists," the "Notice on Handling Recommendations for Some Cases before the 'Cultural Revolution'," the "Supplementary Notice on Handling Recommendations for Some Cases before the 'Cultural Revolution'," the "Notice on Issuing the Summary of the Discussion Meeting on the Review of Cases of Wrongful Convictions prior to the 'Cultural Revolution'," the "Notice on Forwarding the Opinions of the Party Group of the Ministry of Railways on the Review of Wrongful Convictions since the Founding of the People's Republic of China," the "Notice on Forwarding the Report on the Investigation and Review of the Queueing and Review Work on Cases of Wrongful Convictions before the 'Cultural Revolution' by the Organization Department of the Jiangsu Provincial Party Committee," and other policies and regulations on handling historical legacy issues. These policies and regulations clearly put forward the principles, guidelines, and policy limits for addressing historical legacy issues before the "Cultural Revolution," and strictly define the scope, focal points, and approval authority of the review process. Practice has proven that these policy regulations have played an important role in promptly unifying understandings, correcting the direction of work, and properly carrying out the review and handling of historical legacy issues before the "Cultural Revolution."
In this work, the major historical legacy issues that have had a significant impact and were directly reviewed and handled by the Party Central Committee, relevant departments of the central state organs, and entrusted by the central committee to certain provinces and cities, include the following cases:
(1) Review and correct wrongful convictions during the "Anti-Rightist Struggle." During the rectification process carried out throughout the Party in 1957, a few bourgeois rightists took the opportunity to advocate for the so-called "big democratic discussions" and launched an aggressive attack on the Party and the newly established socialist system, attempting to replace the leadership of the Communist Party. In this situation, the Party Central Committee decided to counterattack the rightist offensive, which was necessary and correct. However, the anti-rightist struggle was severely expanded, a group of intellectuals, patriots, and cadres were wrongly labeled as "rightists," resulting in unfortunate consequences. As Deng Xiaoping pointed out, "As the movement developed, it became too expansive, the scope of attack widened, and the blows were too heavy. Many people were indeed handled improperly, and the punishments were too severe. For many years, they suffered injustice and were unable to contribute their intelligence and talent to the people. This is not only their personal loss but also the loss of the entire country."
In 1959, the Party Central Committee issued instructions to gradually remove the hats of rightists in stages and batches. By 1964, the hats of rightists were removed for the majority of those who were wrongly labeled.
After the downfall of the "Gang of Four," the issues of rehabilitating wrongfully convicted individuals and implementing cadre policies, including removing the hats of rightists and correcting the problems, were raised again. Due to the prevailing "leftist" ideological constraints at that time and the incomplete denunciation of the "Cultural Revolution," it was very difficult to handle this issue properly and faced considerable obstacles and criticisms.
In the spring of 1978, relevant departments of the central state organs convened a meeting in Yantai, Shandong Province to discuss how to properly handle the historical legacy issues of the "Anti-Rightist Struggle." At the meeting, a consensus was reached on the issue of removing the hats of rightists, but opinions on correcting the wrongly labeled rightists were still not consistent. After the meeting, the United Front Work Department and the Ministry of Public Security drafted the "Request Report on Removing the Hats of Rightists in its Entirety" to be submitted to the central authorities. According to research approval, in April 1978, the Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee issued a notice titled "On Removing the Label of Rightist from All Rightist Elements", deciding to remove the labels of the remaining rightist elements.
Subsequently, at the suggestion of Hu Yaobang, the Central Organization Department wrote a report to the Central Committee, proposing to correct the mistakes made during the "anti-rightist" struggle based on seeking truth from facts and correcting errors when found. In August 1978, relevant departments of the central government held another meeting to specifically discuss the issue of correcting rightist mistakes. During the meeting, some people still insisted on only removing the labels without making corrections. Some people believed that the past disputes and controversies should be left behind and there was no need to settle them one by one. Today, as long as the labels are unifiedly removed and everyone is treated as members of the same group, it would be sufficient. Some believed that no matter what, each place and department should leave some "examples" and not make changes across the board. Some even said that if hundreds of thousands of rightists were all corrected, the entire party would be in chaos. Comrades who insisted on both removing the labels and correcting their views believed that it was necessary to adhere to the principle of seeking truth from facts and correcting errors. They pointed out that only by correcting all wrongful, false, and mistaken cases could right from wrong be distinguished, unity be strengthened, and the development of the cause be promoted. After intense debates, the latter's opinions received the support of the majority of comrades present at the meeting.
In September 1978, based on the principle of seeking truth from facts, cracking down on opposition, and correcting mistakes, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China approved and implemented the "Implementation Plan for Carrying out the Decision of the Central Committee on Removing the Labels of Rightist Elements" drafted by the Central Organization Department, the Central Propaganda Department, the Central United Front Work Department, the Ministry of Civil Affairs, and the Ministry of Public Security. A notice was issued, deciding to review and correct the cases of those who were mislabeled as rightist elements and rectify the wrongful labeling. This document provided guidance for resolving the lingering issues of the anti-rightist struggle and formulated basic policies and methods.
In order to carry out the work of removing the rightist labels and making corrections, the Central Organization Department, the Central Propaganda Department, the Central United Front Work Department, the Ministry of Public Security, and the Ministry of Civil Affairs jointly established the "Office for Removing Labels". The Central Organization Department also established an office specifically responsible for the correction of rightist mistakes. In order to promote the progress of this work, on January 4, 1979, the Central Organization Department published an article titled "The Correction of Rightist Mistakes Must Be Accelerated" in the 33rd issue of "Organizational Work Communication". The article provided a specific analysis of the situation regarding the correction of rightist mistakes, clarified some misunderstandings, and proposed concrete measures.
In order to withstand pressure and overcome resistance, the older generation of revolutionaries, represented by Deng Xiaoping, provided tremendous support for this work. Deng Xiaoping emphasized, "Removing the labels of all rightist elements, correcting the handling of the majority of them, and assigning them appropriate work is a necessary and significant political measure."
Under the correct leadership of the CPC Central Committee, the strong support of the older generation of revolutionaries, and the joint efforts of relevant departments of the central government, the solid ice that hindered the removal of rightist labels and the correction of wrongful labeling was finally broken through tireless and meticulous work.
In February 1979, the Central Organization Department and the Central United Front Work Department jointly held a national experience exchange meeting on the review and correction of rightists. The Central Party School, the Ministry of Public Security, the Yancheng County Committee in Henan Province, and other units introduced their experiences in liberating ideological thinking and carrying out successful reviews and corrections. The leaders of the Central Organization Department and the Central United Front Work Department also spoke at the meeting, emphasizing the significance of implementing the spirit of the 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th CPC Central Committee and seeking truth from facts in dealing with historical legacy issues. For the first time, they raised the issue of the "excessive expansion" mistake made in the "anti-rightist" struggle in 1957, emphasizing that "correcting wrongly labeled rightists is correcting our mistakes in the 'anti-rightist' struggle." They emphasized that regardless of which level organization or individual approved the verdicts, all incorrect ones must be corrected. This was an experience exchange meeting and also a promotion conference for liberating ideological thinking. Subsequently, similar meetings were held in provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities, as well as districts and counties. Subsequently, in response to new situations and prominent contradictions in this work, the party center issued a notice on the policy issues of rectifying the placement and other follow-up work after the correction of the wrong labeling of rightists, which provided a thorough solution to the problems left over from the "anti-rightist" struggle. By the first half of 1981, this work had concluded successfully, with a total of over 540,000 people having their rightist problems corrected, accounting for over 98% of the original number of rightists. Of the 270,000 people who lost their public positions, they had their positions restored and were reassigned to work or resettled in their lives. Adjustments were also made to improper job arrangements. Additionally, the policies were implemented for over 315,000 people labeled as "centrist-rightists" and "counter-revolutionary elements," as well as for their affected relatives. The successful completion of this work not only "liberated" several hundred thousand comrades who had been wrongly labeled as rightists, but also relieved the pain of a larger number of affected family members and friends, stimulating their enthusiasm to build socialism.
(2) Review and rectification of unjust, false, and mistaken cases in the "anti-rightist" struggle. From July 2 to August 16, 1959, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China held the expanded Political Bureau Meeting and the Eighth Plenary Session of the Eighth Central Committee, known as the "Lushan Conference". In the later stages of the "Lushan Conference," an erroneous criticism of Peng Dehuai was launched, which led to the mistaken "anti-rightist" struggle throughout the Party. The resolution of the Eighth Plenary Session of the Eighth Central Committee regarding the so-called "Peng Dehuai, Huang Kecheng, Zhang Wentian, Zhou Xiaozhou anti-Party group" was completely mistaken. The resolution proposed transferring comrades such as Peng Dehuai from their positions in the Ministry of National Defense while retaining their positions as members of the Political Bureau for later observation. The plenary session also passed the resolution "Struggle to Defend the Party's General Line and Oppose Rightist Opportunism." The resolution stated that "rightist opportunism has become the main danger within the Party. Uniting the whole Party and the people of the whole country to defend the general line, repulse the attack of rightist opportunism, has become the Party's main battle task at present." Thus, the "anti-rightist" struggle was pushed throughout the entire Party. During the "anti-rightist" struggle, a large number of party members and cadres were subjected to erroneous criticism and punishment, and some comrades were mistakenly labeled as rightist opportunists. During the "Cultural Revolution," under the interference of extreme leftist trends, these comrades were again subjected to criticism, struggle, and various forms of punishment.
The "anti-rightist" struggle was a major mistake in the political life within our party after the establishment of the new China. It severely undermined the democratic life within the Party from the central to the grassroots level, wrongly attacked a large number of comrades who dared to seek truth from facts, reflect actual circumstances to the Party, and put forward critical opinions, supported the detrimental tendency of exaggeration and falsehood, and contributed to the development of the phenomenon of personality cult within the Party.
Although after the Seventh Thousand People's Congress in 1961 and 1962, the central authorities decided to review the individuals who had been identified as rightist opportunists (or rightist opportunism errors) since 1959, and conducted a considerable amount of work, many people had been vindicated and rectified. However, as the errors of "leftism" at that time were not fundamentally corrected, the rectification was not thorough. Later, after the Eighth Plenary Session of the Tenth Central Committee, due to the proposal to counteract the tendency of right-wing overturning verdicts, this work was practically suspended. During the "Four Cleanups" campaign and the "Cultural Revolution" movement, under the interference of extreme leftist trends, many places reclassified individuals who had been vindicated and rectified in 1961 and 1962 as rightist opportunists or for their rightist opportunism errors, subjecting them to struggle; those who had not yet been vindicated and rectified were singled out for criticism, struggles, or disciplinary sanctions, with many people being expelled from the Party, the Communist Youth League, demoted, had their salaries reduced, sent down to the country, or had their public positions terminated, among other forms of punishment.
After the downfall of the "Gang of Four," at the beginning of rectifying unjust, false, and mistaken cases and implementing the cadre policies, some elderly comrades put forward suggestions and requests for exonerating comrades who had been wrongly criticized during the "anti-rightist" struggle. The Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee exonerated Peng Dehuai. In July 1979, the central authorities officially issued the "Notice on the Exoneration and Rectification of Individuals Labeled as Rightist Opportunists." The notice emphasizes that in the struggle against "rightist deviation" since 1959, those who were labeled as rightist opportunists or made rightist opportunistic mistakes due to reflecting the actual situation or expressing different opinions within the party, must all be rehabilitated and corrected, and various policies regarding political and living treatment must be implemented properly.
After the document was issued, according to the central deployment, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection was responsible for and assisted by the Central Organization Department to promptly and properly handle the remaining issues in the "anti-rightist" movement.
(3) Review and correct the unjust, false, and mistaken cases in the "Four Cleanups" campaign. The "Four Cleanups" campaign was a large-scale mass movement launched and led by the party. In February 1963, the Central Work Conference determined that a socialist education movement mainly focusing on "Four Cleanups" (cleaning up accounts, warehouses, finances, and work points) would be carried out universally in rural areas; and in cities, the "Five Anti" (anti-corruption and bribery, anti-speculation and profiteering, anti-waste, anti-decentralization, anti-bureaucracy) campaign would be launched. At the end of 1964 to early 1965, the Central Work Conference, presided over by Mao Zedong, discussed and formulated the "Some Issues Currently Put Forward in the Rural Socialist Education Movement," also known as the "23 Rules." In this document, the "Four Cleanups" were defined as political cleansing, economic cleansing, organizational cleansing, and ideological cleansing. It emphasized that the nature of this movement was to resolve the "contradiction between socialism and capitalism" and put forward a more "leftist" view, such as the focus of the movement being on "the power-holders within the party who take the capitalist road." Although the "Four Cleanups" campaign played a certain role in solving problems such as the work style of cadres and economic management, many grassroots cadres were unjustifiably affected due to considering problems of different natures as class struggle or as reflections of class struggle within the party. During the "Cultural Revolution," Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" took advantage of the chaos to further complicate this issue.
In May 1978, Li Jingquan, the former first secretary of the Southwest Bureau, submitted a report to the central government titled "The Situation of Remaining Issues in the 'Four Cleanups' Campaign in Guiyang City." Deng Xiaoping instructed, "Agree with this report. It seems that the Organization Department of the Central Committee and the Provincial Party Committee should jointly study a policy and approach for handling this matter and report to the central government." In July of the same year, the Guizhou Provincial Party Committee submitted a report titled "The Situation of Remaining Issues in the 'Four Cleanups' Campaign in Guiyang City and Recommendations for Handling" to the central government. In August, the Central Committee of the CPC replied and agreed to the report from the Guizhou Provincial Party Committee. The reply pointed out that in the "Four Cleanups" campaign in Guiyang, there were problems with the improper classification and handling of certain comrades, which mixed up contradictions of different natures and harmed some comrades. It emphasized the necessity of correcting this situation objectively and truthfully for the restoration and development of the party's fine traditions, the implementation of party policies, the mobilization of the enthusiasm of cadres and party members, and the strengthening of unity. Regarding the comrades who participated in the "Four Cleanups" work and those who were criticized or disciplined during the campaign, good work should be done without investigating individual responsibilities or personal grievances. We should unite and fight against the common enemy, and make new contributions to the development of a favorable situation in Guizhou. In the same month, an article titled "Errors in the 'Four Cleanups' Campaign Should Also Be Corrected" was published in Issue 12 of the "Organizational Work Newsletter." This article was written based on the spirit of the central government's reply to the Guizhou Provincial Party Committee's report on the Guiyang "Four Cleanups" issue. The article called for the objective correction of cases in the "Four Cleanups" campaign that were indeed mishandled. It also addressed concerns such as whether correcting the mistaken cases in the "Four Cleanups" campaign would overturn the achievements of the campaign or cause trouble. It further proposed that the correction of mistaken cases in the "Four Cleanups" campaign must be carried out with a positive and cautious approach, focusing on both problem-solving and stabilizing the situation. Political solutions should be prioritized. Stability and unity should be promoted, and a favorable situation should be developed. Subsequently, the Central Organization Department put forward specific regulations and work requirements for the review and correction of unjust, false, and mistaken cases in the "Four Cleanups" campaign. In accordance with the central government's spirit, local governments and departments across the country began to review and correct the mistaken cases in the "Four Cleanups" campaign.
In view of the significant differences and special characteristics of the "Four Clearings" movement in Guizhou in 1964 compared to the nationwide situation, in December 1983, the Guizhou Provincial Committee again submitted a request report to the Central Organization Department on "Thoroughly Resolving the Guizhou 'Four Clearings' Issue", once again requesting approval from the central government. Acting on behalf of the central government, the Central Organization Department drafted a reply (draft) to the Guizhou Provincial Committee on "Resolving the Guizhou 'Four Clearings' Issue", which was approved by the central government and replied to the Guizhou Provincial Committee in June 1984 in the name of the CPC Central Committee. The reply pointed out: "The 'Four Clearings' movement in Guizhou in 1964 was conducted under the guidance of a 'left' leaning erroneous ideology. The previous conclusion that the Provincial Committee had committed errors of a right-opportunist nature and that 'Guiyang Municipal Committee had formed a dual counterrevolutionary regime' was completely incorrect. It is completely correct to thoroughly redress the grievances, misconceptions, and wrongful cases caused by this. Based on the relevant regulations of the central government, the erroneous conclusions and documents related to the Guizhou 'Four Clearings' issue have become invalid on their own." "The central government believes that the provincial committee of Guizhou, the municipal committee of Guiyang, and the leading cadres in other localities where the 'Four Clearings' movement was carried out are good comrades. The two thousand cadres sent by the central government to participate in the 'Four Clearings' in Guizhou at that time are also good comrades. Currently, strengthening unity among cadres is of great significance for creating a new situation in Guizhou's work." Starting from this point, all provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the central government carried out comprehensive and thorough reexaminations and corrections of wrongful cases in the "Four Clearings" work based on the spirit of the central government. Nationwide, over 630,000 wrongful cases from the "Four Clearings" movement were reexamined and corrected.
(4) Properly handle the lingering issues of underground party history. In the early days of the establishment of the People's Republic of China, in the work of universally cleaning up underground party organizations, due to insufficient understanding of the complexity of underground struggles in some places, lack of knowledge about the historical environment and characteristics of underground struggles, and mistakes in work, some comrades of underground parties were subjected to incorrect treatment and unfair treatment, resulting in many lingering issues. During the "Cultural Revolution", some comrades of underground parties were also defamed and persecuted as a result. In July 1981, Hu Yaobang instructed in a letter, "We must handle the lingering issues of underground party history very well, solve them properly and fairly, and start with Fujian." The Central Organization Department sent a letter to the Fujian Provincial Committee and other relevant provincial committees, conveying Hu Yaobang's instruction. The Fujian Provincial Committee attached great importance to this issue. It was led by the Secretary of the Provincial Committee and took more than three years to thoroughly reexamine the historical lingering issues of underground parties in Fujian and handle them properly.
The Yunnan Provincial Committee also immediately started to address the lingering issues in Yunnan's work of clearing underground parties in accordance with the spirit of the instruction. In March 1982, the Central Organization Department issued the approved reports of the Yunnan Provincial Committee on "Resolving the Historical Lingering Issues of Underground Parties and 'Bian Zong' in Yunnan" and "Restoring the Political Reputation of Comrade Zheng Boke", respectively. All false accusations imposed on underground parties and "Bian Zong" by the Provincial Military Control Commission and Provincial Revolutionary Committee during the "Cultural Revolution" were thoroughly refuted, and a large number of wrongful cases were completely redressed. At the same time, inappropriate conclusions made about Yunnan underground parties and "Bian Zong" in several political movements before the "Cultural Revolution" were resolved, as were the erroneous criticisms of Zheng Boke, the main person in charge of Yunnan underground parties in the 1950s by the Provincial Committee. The contributions and achievements of Yunnan underground parties and "Bian Zong" in the remote multi-ethnic border areas, where they confronted arduous struggles far from the central government, were fully recognized. In August 1982, the Central Organization Department also approved and issued the report of the Shaanxi Provincial Committee Organization Department on the situation of the underground party organization of Northwest United University and the handling opinions on relevant personnel's party membership.
Based on a careful summary of the experience in properly handling the historical legacy of underground parties in the above-mentioned regions, the Central Organization Department held a symposium on dealing with the historical legacy of underground parties in 16 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities in December 1984. The work of dealing with the historical legacy of underground parties was seriously studied and deployed. After the meeting, with the approval of the Central Secretariat, the Central Organization Department issued a notice on the printing and distribution of the "Summary of the Symposium on Dealing with the Historical Legacy of Underground Parties" (referred to as the "Summary"). The "Summary" affirms the long-term heroic struggle of underground party organizations and underground party-led guerrilla forces in the white terror, and their contributions to the liberation cause of the Chinese people. It points out that the historical legacy of underground parties mainly refers to the underground party organizations established before the local liberation, or the guerrilla forces led by underground parties, secret peripheral organizations, and the issues such as false, exaggerated, and erroneous cases and the remaining party membership caused by incorrect handling. In dealing with these issues, we should follow the "Resolution on Several Historical Issues of the Party since the Founding of the People's Republic of China" and the relevant policies and instructions of the Central Committee, adhere to the principle of "seeking truth from facts, correcting mistakes", and solve them in a fair and just manner. We should not only distinguish right from wrong, solve problems, but also promote stability and unity. Personal responsibility should not be pursued. It is necessary to focus on solving the problems politically and provide appropriate remedies for comrades who have been subjected to incorrect handling for a long time in terms of political and living arrangements. The "Summary" also puts forward opinions on several issues in the work of dealing with the historical legacy of underground parties. After that, this work was widely carried out nationwide. In November 1985, the Central Organization Department issued a notice on "Accelerating the Handling of the Historical Legacy of Underground Parties", requiring the organization departments at all levels to continue to accelerate the work of handling the historical legacy of underground parties in accordance with the spirit of the Central Committee's policy implementation work before the Thirteenth National Congress; specific replies were given to the subsidy issues related to the living arrangements of underground party comrades who have been subjected to incorrect handling for a long time. 
With the correct leadership of the Party Central Committee and the joint efforts of the relevant provinces, cities, and districts, this work was basically completed before the Thirteenth National Congress. The historical legacy of underground parties was properly handled, the revolutionary image of underground parties was restored, right from wrong was clarified, and the unity of the Party was strengthened.
(5) Seriously implement the policies regarding intelligence and reconnaissance personnel. This is an important task in the later stage of rectifying false cases and implementing cadre policies. The intelligence and reconnaissance work of our party has played an important role in both the war period and the construction period. However, since the founding of New China, in various political movements, especially in the "Cultural Revolution", due to the influence of "leftist" ideology and work mistakes, the special situation of intelligence and reconnaissance work has been neglected, resulting in many intelligence and reconnaissance personnel and leading cadres being subjected to incorrect handling, causing many false, exaggerated, and erroneous cases. Since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, party organizations at all levels have rectified some false cases in intelligence and reconnaissance personnel and implemented the cadre policy work, especially the exoneration of Pan Hannian, who had been unjustly treated for many years, by the Central Committee, which has had a great impact. However, the historical legacy issues of intelligence and reconnaissance personnel are relatively complex. In some regions and departments, due to insufficient understanding of the policy, approach, and characteristics of our party's intelligence and reconnaissance work, as well as the lack of policy basis for handling the problems that occurred under specific conditions, the problems and follow-up work of some intelligence and reconnaissance personnel who have been subjected to incorrect handling have not been completely resolved.
In April 1986, the Party Group of the State Security Ministry and the Central Organization Department submitted a request for instructions to the Central Secretariat on the implementation of the policy regarding intelligence and reconnaissance personnel. The Central Secretariat instructed that the implementation of the policy regarding intelligence and reconnaissance personnel is a serious political task, and localities and relevant departments should seriously and promptly implement it. In implementing the policy, the special nature of intelligence work should be fully considered. Based on the policies and strategies of our party's struggle against enemies at different periods, closely combining the historical environment and actual conditions at that time, a pragmatic and comprehensive analysis should be carried out. Regarding specific issues, they should be handled with the principle of being broad rather than detailed and lenient rather than strict. In May of the same year, with the approval of the central government, the General Office of the CPC Central Committee forwarded this request report. In July, the Ministry of State Security and the Central Organization Department jointly held a symposium in Beijing on the implementation of policies for intelligence and investigation personnel by provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the central government. The focus of the symposium was to study the implementation of the instructions from the central government and the notice from the General Office of the CPC Central Committee regarding the implementation of policies for intelligence and investigation personnel, further deepen the understanding of the importance of doing this work well, clarify the principles and guiding ideology for this work, as well as the measures that should be taken, and make corresponding work arrangements. After the symposium, the work of implementing policies for intelligence and investigation personnel was comprehensively launched in 24 provinces, municipalities, and autonomous regions nationwide, as well as in central state organs.
All provinces and municipalities attached great importance to this work, and some provinces even established dedicated organizations to undertake this work. However, due to the uniqueness, complexity, and arduousness of implementing policies for intelligence and investigation personnel, this work was not completely finished until the early 1990s. In total, thousands of people and cases were rectified, and significant achievements were made in the implementation of policies for intelligence and investigation personnel.
This nationwide rectification of wrongly accused cases and the implementation of policies for intelligence and investigation personnel were unprecedented in the history of intelligence and investigation work, and the results were remarkable. It fully embodies the party's concern for intelligence and investigation personnel and a thoroughly responsible spirit, relieving comrades and their families from years of heavy burdens. It played a positive role in winning over friends, uniting comrades, mobilizing the enthusiasm of comrades in the intelligence and investigation front, enhancing cohesion, and promoting the development of national security undertakings.
(6) The exoneration of the novel "Liu Zhidan". At the 1962 Beidaihe Central Work Conference and the 10th Plenary Session of the 8th CPC Central Committee, due to Kang Sheng's initiation, the unpublished novel "Liu Zhidan" was criticized. After the conference, writing this novel was treated as a counter-revolutionary incident within the party and underwent a long-term special case review involving the novel itself, the author Li Jiantong, the readers of the manuscript Xijongxun and Liu Jingfan, as well as comrades from the worker publishing house who organized the creation of this novel. The special case review had not been concluded by the start of the "Cultural Revolution". During the "Cultural Revolution", Kang Sheng, together with Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four", conducted larger-scale political persecution on the issue of the novel "Liu Zhidan". Yao Wenyuan published an article publicly declaring that "Liu Zhidan" was a counter-revolutionary novel and claimed that the author and comrades who supported the book were anti-party elements. After that, comrades who had undergone the special case review suffered even more severe persecution, and more people were implicated. Leaders who had read the manuscript and supported this creation, a group of old cadres and party members from the former Shaanxi-Gansu Revolutionary Base, and even some comrades who participated in the special case review work, all suffered varying degrees of persecution, with some being driven to death. Li Jiantong was designated as a "key figure in the Xi Zhongxun counter-revolutionary group using the novel to engage in anti-party activities". Until May 1977, in the review conclusion made by the central task force for Liu Jingfan, it still mentioned that Liu Jingfan "colluded with Xi Zhongxun to publish the anti-party novel 'Liu Zhidan' and vindicate Gao Gang".
After the reexamination by the Central Organization Department in 1979, it was elucidated that the novel "Liu Zhidan" (as reviewed in the sample book) was not only not a counter-revolutionary novel but also a relatively good novel that extolled the older generation of proletarian revolutionaries and depicted the history of revolutionary struggles. It was completely legitimate for comrades like Xi Zhongxun to be concerned about the creation of this novel and to express their opinions on how to improve it. It was by no means a conspiracy by an anti-party group. Looking at the process before and after the case, the so-called case of using the novel "Liu Zhidan" to engage in anti-party activities was a major erroneous case created by Kang Sheng. It was an even wider-ranging modern literary inquisition intensified by Kang Sheng collaborating with Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" during the "Cultural Revolution". Therefore, in August 1979, the Central Committee forwarded the report from the Central Organization Department titled "Regarding the Exoneration of the Novel 'Liu Zhidan'". By publishing articles in newspapers and clarifying the truth, all comrades who have been falsely accused are cleared of charges and their names restored. The aftermath work is done well, resulting in a just resolution of this major wrong and winning people's hearts.
(7) Conduct a thorough review and reversal of the so-called "Peng, Gao, Xi anti-party clique". The so-called "Peng Dehuai, Gao Gang, Xi Zhongxun anti-party clique" was fabricated by Kang Sheng during the special case review of Xi Zhongxun after the 10th Plenary Session of the 8th Central Committee of the Party. He used his authority to issue instructions, randomly naming people and carrying out a series of activities to expose and criticize the "Peng, Gao, Xi anti-party clique". In 1965, the "Guidelines for Conveying the Issue of Xi Zhongxun's Anti-Party Activities", which was approved by Kang Sheng, was distributed and conveyed among cadres at all levels, aiming to thoroughly eliminate the "harmful influence of Peng, Gao, Xi". As a result, not only Peng Dehuai and Xi Zhongxun were falsely accused and persecuted, but also a group of comrades who had worked with them were implicated.
During the "Cultural Revolution", Kang Sheng, along with Lin Biao, the "Gang of Four", and their proxies in Shaanxi, further intensified the so-called "Peng, Gao, Xi anti-party clique" issue. They claimed that there was a serious enemy situation in Shaanxi, and that Peng Dehuai, Gao Gang, and Xi Zhongxun used Xi'an in Shaanxi as their rear base. Under the pretext of "purging", they carried out activities such as "investigation of the black line" and "digging out the black roots", accusing the original Northwest Bureau, Shaanxi Provincial Party Committee, Provincial People's Council, Xi'an Municipal Party Committee, and Municipal People's Council of being "five black nests" and regarding them as the "old forces" of Peng, Gao, Xi, all of which were to be "thoroughly smashed". They imprisoned more than fifty leading cadres from the Northwest Bureau, the Shaanxi Provincial Party Committee, and the Xi'an Municipal Party Committee, fabricated charges, and subjected them to fascist persecution.
