In 1979, through a re-examination by the Shaanxi Provincial Party Committee, the term "Peng, Gao, Xi anti-party clique" was found to be extremely absurd and purely a false accusation, resulting in many wrongful cases, damaging and influencing the work in Shaanxi. Although Peng Dehuai has been cleared of charges and Xi Zhongxun's issue has been resolved, considering that the so-called "Peng, Gao, Xi anti-party clique" issue has widespread implications in Shaanxi and has a significant impact, with strong reflections from various aspects, the Communist Party of China Shaanxi Provincial Committee believes that it is still necessary to solemnly announce a complete exoneration and restoration for this false case. In January 1980, with the approval of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the Organization Department of the Central Committee forwarded the "Report on the Request for a Thorough Exoneration of the so-called "Peng, Gao, Xi anti-party clique" Issue" from the Shaanxi Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China, calling for comprehensive and complete exoneration of this false case.
(8) Properly resolve the issue of wrongfully killed personnel during the rectification campaigns in the Soviet areas. The problem of personnel wrongfully killed during the rectification campaigns in the Soviet areas is a major historical legacy issue that has a wide impact and involves a large number of people. From 1930 to 1935, under the influence of the "Left" deviationist line, several major Soviet areas, including the Central Soviet Area, Xiang-Gan-Xi, He-Yu-Wan, Min-Xi, Chuan-Shan, and Shan-Gan, successively carried out movements to eliminate the "8th Route Army Faction", "reorganize faction", "Social Democratic Party", "Third Party", "Cancellation Faction", and others. Many comrades were wrongly arrested and killed. In the resolution "On Several Historical Issues" adopted at the 7th Plenary Session of the 6th Central Committee of the Party in 1945, it was clearly pointed out: "Due to the entanglement of sectarianism in the wrong rectification policy and cadre policy, a large number of excellent comrades were wrongly handled and falsely accused, resulting in extremely heartbreaking losses within the Party." "Comrades who have been falsely accused due to the wrong handling of the investigation should be cleared of charges, have their party membership restored, and be memorialized by their comrades." However, due to the limitations of historical conditions at that time, this issue had not been resolved before the establishment of the People's Republic of China. After the establishment of New China, in 1954, the central government proposed opinions on dealing with this issue. The Central People's Government issued the Notice on the Handling of the Issue of Wrongful Killing of Anti-Counterrevolutionaries and Their Families during the Second Revolutionary War Period, according to the spirit of the notice, nearly 20,000 people were rehabilitated in provinces such as Jiangxi, Fujian, and Hubei. Other provinces also rehabilitated the main party, government, and military leaders who were wrongly killed, but the problems of the majority of the people have not been solved. After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party, many relatives of the wrongfully killed personnel and some old comrades repeatedly demanded a thorough solution to this historical legacy problem. Central leadership comrades instructed the Organization Department of the Central Committee and the Ministry of Civil Affairs to study and propose handling methods. In March and June 1983, the CPC Central Committee and the State Council approved two opinions on handling this issue, and the State Council forwarded the Notice on the Handling of the Problem of Wrongly Killed Personnel in the Anti-Counterrevolutionary Campaign during the Second Revolutionary Civil War period issued by the Ministry of Civil Affairs. The organization departments and civil affairs departments of Hubei, Anhui, Henan, Fujian, Jiangxi, Sichuan, Shaanxi, and other relevant provinces closely cooperated and conducted in-depth and meticulous review work.
Under the leadership of the Party Central Committee and the efforts of the relevant provinces and cities, after three years of hard work, the false cases in the anti-counterrevolutionary campaign in the Soviet Area were thoroughly rehabilitated and the post-mortem issues of those who were wrongly killed or wrongly handled were properly handled, thus thoroughly solving this major historical legacy problem that had dragged on for decades.
(9) The famous generals Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue, who participated in the Ningdu Uprising, were rehabilitated. In June 1979, 12 old comrades including Ji Pengfei, Li Da, Huang Zhen, Wang Youping, Yuan Xuezu, and Su Jin wrote a letter to the central government, reflecting that Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue, who were originally members of the Red Fifth Army Corps, were wrongly killed in 1934 and proposed rehabilitation and restoration of their reputations. In accordance with the instructions of the central leadership comrades, the Organization Department of the Central Committee sent personnel to investigate more than 70 old comrades and reviewed relevant archival materials. Ji Zhentong was originally the commander of the 74th Brigade of the 25th Division of the Nationalist Party's 26th Route Army, and Huang Zhongyue was the commander of one regiment of the brigade. On December 14, 1931, they led their troops to participate in the "Ningdu Uprising" led by CCP member Zhao Bosheng and important commander Dong Zhentang, which shook the whole country. After more than 10,000 soldiers and officers rebelled, they were organized into the Red Fifth Army Corps, and Ji Zhentong was admitted as a special CCP member and appointed as the commander of the corps, while Huang Zhongyue was appointed as the commander of the 15th Army. In the spring of 1932, the National Security Bureau discovered the defection activities led by a few officers headed by Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue, accusing them of counterrevolutionary activities and imprisoning them. Later, influenced by Wang Ming's "left" sectarian line, they were executed on the eve of the Long March. Comrade Ye Jianying commented on this case: "I heard Chairman Mao say (in Yan'an, I think) that the killing of Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue was a mistake, and now I think this unjust case should be redressed." From the results of the review by the Organization Department, Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue made contributions and had a significant influence during the Ningdu Uprising, which should be affirmed. Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue themselves had patriotic and anti-Japanese thoughts. We have admitted Ji as a special CCP member and decided that he will go to the Soviet Union for study, and we still trust him politically. He Yingqin had sent people to contact Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue for defection, although Ji and Huang did not report their contact with the organization, the enemy's defection conspiracy did not succeed, and it is believable that Ji said he could not pull the team away from the Soviet Area. It was a mistake to label Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue as counterrevolutionaries, and it was even more wrong to execute them. They should be rehabilitated, their reputations should be restored, and Ji's party membership should be restored. In August 1981, the Secretariat of the CPC Central Committee approved the Report from the Organization Department of the Central Committee on the Issue of Rehabilitating Comrades Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue from the Red Fifth Army Corps. The contributions made by Ji Zhentong and Huang Zhongyue during the uprising were appropriately evaluated. In this way, this unjust case that lasted for nearly half a century was finally resolved fairly and reasonably.
(10) Completely overturn the "Suto Incident" in Huxi. The "Suto Incident" in Huxi occurred between August and November 1939, starting and developing from the local committee by the lake, and then expanding to the entire Sulu-Yu border area. In this incident, a large number of cadres were arrested and killed, resulting in extremely severe losses. In November 1939, Luo Ronghuan, Guo Hongtao, and other leaders of the Shandong Branch of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) rushed to Huxi and took emergency measures to stop the development of this incident. From 1940 to 1945, the Central Committee and the Shandong Branch conducted several reviews and affirmatively identified Wang Xuren, the former Minister of the Organizational Department of the former Hubei Provincial Committee, as the primary instigator of the "Suto Incident" with unclear origins. However, due to the limitations of the historical conditions at that time, an exact conclusion on the nature of the incident was not made, resulting in many unresolved issues. The family members of some martyrs were once again labeled as "counterrevolutionaries" during the Cultural Revolution. Based on the instructions from the central authorities regarding the overturning of wrongful, false, and mistaken cases, the Shandong Provincial Committee reviewed this historical wrongful case again. In May 1983, the Shandong Provincial Committee of the CCP submitted a report to the central authorities entitled "Opinions on Handling the Remaining Issues of the 'Suto Incident' in Huxi," stating that this case was not an issue of amplification. The "Suto Movement" in 1939, aimed at eliminating "Trotskyist elements" and "Trotskyist organizations," had no factual basis. The original identification of the seven so-called "real Trotskyist bandits" was thoroughly investigated, and it was found that not one of them was genuine. This is a significant case of wrongful accusations, false charges, and mistaken handling, which should be thoroughly overturned. The comrades who were mistakenly killed or wrongly handled should all be completely exonerated and vindicated. The family members and children who suffered from the consequences should be thoroughly vindicated and the impacts eliminated. With the central approval, the Central Organization Department forwarded the report from the Shandong Provincial Committee of the CCP entitled "Opinions on Handling the Remaining Issues of the 'Suto Incident' in Huxi" in December 1983, finally completely overturning this long-standing wrongful case.
(11) Completely overturn the so-called "Trotskyist cases" of the New Fourth Army's Fourth Division and the Huabei and Huainan bases in 1941. In October 1984, the Central Organization Department of the Chinese Communist Party (CCP) and the Political Department of the People's Liberation Army made a decision entitled "Decision on Completely Overturning the So-called 'Trotskyist Cases' of the New Fourth Army's Fourth Division and the Huabei and Huainan Bases in 1941." The decision pointed out that the CCP branch of the Guangxi Student Army, from its establishment in May 1938 to its retreat to the Huainan and Huabei bases in March 1940, had directly operated under the leadership of the Anhui Provincial Committee, the Eyuwan Area Party Committee, and the Lihuang City Committee. They actively mobilized and organized the masses, persisted in the anti-Japanese resistance behind enemy lines, propagated the CCP's policy of a united front against Japan, and advocated anti-Japanese political ideas. They also protected the underground party leadership organs and made beneficial contributions. The CCP members and progressive masses from the Guangxi Student Army who joined the New Fourth Army and the Huainan and Huabei bases had actively contributed to the armed resistance against Japan and the construction of the base areas. The baseless accusation of the CCP branch of the Guangxi Student Army as a "Trotskyist organization" and the unjustified investigation of dozens of comrades under the pretext of the "Trotskyist problem" constituted a complete miscarriage of justice. In order to eliminate the influence of this historical wrongful case, it is hereby decided to completely exonerate and restore the reputation of the CCP branch of the Guangxi Student Army and all comrades who were investigated and wrongly handled or executed in this case. The relevant regional and unit party organizations should, in accordance with the relevant regulations of the central authorities, carefully review the archival materials and carry out post-work.
(12) Properly handle the lingering historical issues of the "Central Plains Breakout." In August 1980, Zheng Shaowen, Zhang Zhiyi, and others wrote to the Party Central Committee, requesting a practical and realistic resolution to the lingering issues of the "Central Plains Breakout." Hu Yaobang made important instructions on the letter, demanding that the relevant departments handle it properly.
In 1946, our Central Plains troops and the party and government organs of the Central Plains Liberation Area, surrounded by the Kuomintang's 300,000 troops, carried out a strategic transfer - a breakout. Due to a very desperate situation during the breakout, in order to preserve our strength, the original Central Plains Bureau of the CCP formulated some special policies and mobilized a large number of comrades who could not breakout with the army to return to civilian life and hide. In the process of the breakout, many comrades were separated or got dispersed. Some of them, due to issues such as demobilization, concealment, and falling behind, have not only failed to receive proper resolution in matters such as party membership, participation in revolutionary work, and historical conclusions, but have also been treated unfairly. On May 29, 1957, Comrades Zheng Weisan, former Secretary of the Central Plains Bureau, and Chen Shaomin, former Minister of Organization, wrote a letter to the Central Organization Department, explaining the situation in detail. The letter stated: Before the breakout in the Central Plains in 1946, the situation was already very urgent. A large number of local cadres could not move with the army, so to preserve our strength, we made the following decisions at the time: disguise with the use of social relationships as much as possible to go to other liberated areas; for those who cannot disguise, utilize social relationships to conceal their identity; if discovered by the enemy and unable to conceal, surrender to the enemy as a soldier of the New Fourth Army or as a member of the Agricultural Association, as long as their identity as a Party member is not exposed, surrendering with the identity of a Party member will be treated differently. This decision was made in special difficult circumstances, and we take responsibility if this decision was wrong. The Central Organization Department forwarded this letter to the Hubei and Henan provincial committees for handling, asking them to pay attention to the situation mentioned in the letter when dealing with the issue of Party members surrendering in the Central Plains Liberation Area. However, at that time, it did not receive the attention it deserved. In the early days of the founding of the People's Republic of China, when dealing with the historical legacy of the "Central Plains Breakout," some comrades did not consider the historical background and specific analysis enough, resulting in overly strict handling, especially during the "Cultural Revolution," some comrades suffered further mistreatment and the handling of their cases intensified.
According to the instructions of the leading comrades of the central government, the Organization Department of the Hubei Provincial Committee and the Party Committee of the Provincial Civil Affairs Department conducted a thorough investigation into the historical legacy of the "Central Plains Breakout" issue. They put forward the "Opinions on Dealing with the Historical Legacy of Personnel who Disbanded, Concealed, and Fell Behind During the Central Plains Breakout," stating that for the historical legacy of personnel who disbanded, concealed, and fell behind during the Central Plains Breakout, they should be dealt with in accordance with the basic principles of the Central Organization Department's opinions on thoroughly rectifying false cases and further implementing cadre policies issued on February 19, 1981, as well as the letter of Comrades Zheng Weisan and Chen Shaomin that was forwarded by the Central Organization Department on June 6, 1957. In line with the principle of "seeking truth from facts and correcting mistakes," their problems should be seriously addressed through a thorough review, adopting a proactive and cautious attitude to properly resolve the issue. Regulations were also made regarding the handling of cases related to Party membership, work arrangements, retirement, and calculation of work participation time that were previously handled incorrectly, as well as the treatment of disbanded soldiers and the issue of posthumous recognition. In July 1981, the Central Organization Department forwarded the "Opinions on Dealing with the Historical Legacy of Personnel who Disbanded, Concealed, and Fell Behind During the Central Plains Breakout" from the Organization Department of the Hubei Provincial Committee and the Party Committee of the Provincial Civil Affairs Department. Relevant provinces, cities, and departments quickly organized reviews and corrections. Through this review and correction, more than 50,000 cases of personnel who disbanded, concealed, or fell behind were resolved, correcting the cases mishandled in the early days of New China’s establishment and properly resolving this historical legacy issue.
(13) Properly handle the historical legacy issue of the unidentified martyrs who were killed in the "China-America Cooperation Institute" prison on the eve of the liberation of Chongqing. After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, the Central Organization Department of the Communist Party of China entrusted the Organization Department of the Sichuan Provincial Committee to re-investigate and verify the issue of unidentified martyrs who were killed in the "China-America Cooperation Institute" prison on the eve of the liberation of Chongqing. The Organization Department of the Sichuan Provincial Committee organized a thorough investigation and clarified the situation of 83 people. The Party organizations reached a pragmatic conclusion on each of them. Among them, Xie Mazhao, Zhang Luping, and others, 64 people in total, resolutely upheld the noble character of a Communist Party member, bravely struggled, were unwavering and unyielding, and met their deaths calmly, demonstrating deeds that are worthy of praise and admiration and serve as models for future generations. They were posthumously recognized as revolutionary martyrs. This historical legacy issue, which was delayed for more than thirty years, was finally resolved relatively properly. On November 20, 1986, Xinhua News Agency also made a special report on this matter.
The handling of the above-mentioned significant historical legacy issues has promoted the progress of properly resolving historical legacy issues nationwide. Each province, city, autonomous region, and ministry has also conducted a review and clearance of historical issues in their respective areas and departments, properly handling a large number of historical legacy issues. According to incomplete statistics, nearly two million cases of historical legacy issues before the "Cultural Revolution" have been reviewed and resolved nationwide. By the time of the 13th Party Congress in 1987, the work of properly handling historical legacy issues at the national level was basically completed. Through the proper handling of historical legacy issues, the enthusiasm of cadres and the masses has been greatly mobilized, social stability and unity have been promoted, unjust, false and wrong cases have been corrected, cadre policies have been implemented, and the successful completion of this work before the 13th Party Congress has been ensured.
III. Reasonably adjust social relationships in the new situation
While reversing unjust, false, and wrong cases on a large scale, the Party Central Committee has also pragmatically studied and addressed some historical legacy issues, adjusted social relationships, and implemented policies in various aspects.
1. Fully implement policies for intellectuals and solve their practical problems
Implementing policies for intellectuals is an important part of reversing unjust, false, and wrong cases and implementing cadre policies. It runs through the entire process of reversing unjust, false, and wrong cases and implementing cadre policies, starting from 1978 and continuing until the successful completion before the 13th Party Congress in 1987.
Intellectuals in our country have a fine tradition of patriotism. Under the long-term education of the Party, the vast majority of intellectuals support the leadership of the Communist Party of China and love the socialist motherland. However, due to the "left" bias and discrimination against intellectuals that has formed over a long period of time, intellectuals have been affected to varying degrees in previous political movements. During the "Cultural Revolution", many intellectuals suffered severe repression and persecution once again.
After the downfall of the "Gang of Four", in March 1978, Deng Xiaoping delivered an important speech at the National Scientific Congress, clarifying the basic principles of Marxism regarding the position and role of science and technology in social development. He pointed out that intellectual workers who serve socialism are part of the working people and emphasized the necessity of cultivating a grand scientific and technological team in our country. Deng Xiaoping's discourse on intellectuals being part of the working people greatly inspired the enthusiasm of intellectuals to love the Party and construct the socialist motherland, and also cleared obstacles and indicated the direction for the large-scale implementation of policies for intellectuals.
From October to November 1978, the Communist Party of China Central Committee organized a symposium on the implementation of policies for intellectuals. The meeting believed that the situation of the intellectual ranks had undergone profound changes, and the policy of "unity, education, and transformation" towards intellectuals proposed during the early days of the founding of the country was no longer applicable to the current situation. It is necessary to do a good job in implementing policies for intellectuals. On November 3rd, the Organization Department issued a notice entitled "Several Opinions on Implementing the Party's Policies for Intellectuals", which put forward six requirements for the implementation of policies for intellectuals: first, there should be a correct estimation of the intellectual ranks; second, continue to do well in reviewing and correcting unjust, false, and wrong cases; third, fully trust, empower, and hold accountable intellectuals; fourth, adjust positions according to abilities, making the best use of talents; fifth, strive to improve working and living conditions; sixth, strengthen leadership and improve work style. After the issuance of the document, the work of implementing policies for intellectuals on a large scale gradually unfolded nationwide, and a social trend of respecting knowledge and talents gradually emerged.
Hu Yaobang paid great attention to this work and devoted a lot of effort to it. He made many important instructions to address the problems encountered in implementing policies for intellectuals. Based on a series of instructions from Hu Yaobang and the requirement of the central government to basically complete the rectification of false cases before the 13th National Congress, the Central Organization Department, together with relevant departments, vigorously implemented the inspection, supervision, and finalization of the policy for intellectuals, making it one of the key tasks of the Central Organization Department during this period.
In May 1985, the Central Organization Department and the United Front Work Department also jointly held a national symposium on the implementation of policies for intellectuals, focusing on how to complete the tasks of implementing policies for intellectuals before the 13th National Congress, as pointed out by the central authorities. The establishment of a responsibility system at various levels was proposed. The leading organs at all levels, especially comrades from the organization departments, should personally go to the grassroots level to supervise and inspect, assist in solving difficult problems, and solidly carry out the implementation of policies for intellectuals.
In September 1986, with the approval of the central leadership comrades, the Central Organization Department of the Communist Party of China issued a notice on inspecting the implementation of policies for intellectuals. It pointed out that the task of implementing policies for intellectuals and resolving historical issues has been basically completed in some regions and departments, and most regions and departments have planned to complete it in the second half of the year. In order to ensure the quality and successful completion of the work, it was required to conduct a serious inspection of units that have basically completed the tasks and specific requirements were provided for the scope and content of the inspection, organizational leadership, and steps and methods. In November, the Central Organization Department of the Communist Party of China held three batches of national symposiums on the exchange of experiences in implementing policies for intellectuals in Dalian, Wuhan, and Beijing, respectively. According to statistics from 25 provinces (regions, cities), various types of issues involving over 7.1 million people were resolved in the implementation of policies for intellectuals.
These measures and efforts greatly promoted the deep development of the implementation of policies for intellectuals. With the warm care of the central leadership and the joint efforts of various regions and departments, this great project that had undergone numerous challenges was finally basically completed before the 13th National Congress of the Party.
2. Lifting the labels of landlord and bourgeois peasant elements and resolving the issue of children from landlord and bourgeois peasant families
On January 11, 1979, in accordance with the relevant provisions of the "Regulations on the Work of Rural People's Communes (Trial Draft)" adopted based on the principles of the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China made a decision on lifting the labels of landlord and bourgeois peasant elements and resolving the issue of children from landlord and bourgeois peasant families (referred to as the "Decision"). The "Decision" declared that those landlords, bourgeois peasant elements, counter-revolutionary elements, and bad elements who have followed government laws for many years, worked honestly, and refrained from doing bad things, after undergoing mass evaluation and approval by the county revolutionary committee, will have their labels removed and be granted the status of rural people's commune members. The individuals from landlord and bourgeois peasant families were all classified as rural people's commune members and enjoyed the same treatment as other members. In the future, their admission to schools, enrollment in the military, joining the Communist Youth League and the Communist Party, and job assignments should primarily consider their political performance and discrimination should not be allowed. The children from landlord and bourgeois peasant families should be classified as commune members and should no longer be classified based on their family backgrounds. The "Decision" also required that extensive study of the Party's policies and ideological education should be carried out from within the Party to outside the Party.
This decision ended the discriminatory political situation for at least 20 million people and allowed them to enjoy the rights of citizens, starting a new political life. According to Xinhua News Agency, by November 1984, the final batch of work to remove the labels of landlord, bourgeois peasant elements, counter-revolutionary elements, and bad elements was successfully completed nationwide. Correction was also made for those who were wrongly categorized. All four types of individuals who had already left the country or gone abroad had their labels removed, and their families were notified.
3. Restoration of the laborer identity of former business owners
On November 12, 1979, the Communist Party of China issued a report titled "Regarding the Distinction of Laborers from Business Owners in the Original Industrial and Commercial Sector," which was approved by the Central Committee and several other departments including the United Front Work Department. The report explicitly stated that during the implementation of public-private partnerships in the private industrial and commercial sector in 1956, a large number of small business owners, vendors, craftsmen, and other laborers were brought into the state-owned enterprises. They were collectively referred to as private personnel and treated as capitalist industrial and commercial owners, which was inappropriate. They should be distinguished from the original capitalist industrial and commercial owners and have their true identity as laborers clarified. In accordance with the spirit of this document, after more than a year of work, over seven hundred thousand small traders, vendors, craftsmen, and other laborers were distinguished from the original industrial and commercial owners, restoring their status as laborers. This effectively resolved the historical issues left over from the socialist transformation and corrected the mistakes made at that time. While carrying out this distinction work in various regions, according to the specific policies on original industrial and commercial owners provided by the Central Committee, the labels of capitalists or capitalist agents were also removed from them.
4. Resolving the issue of restrictions on the historical use of certain cadres
In the latter stages of rectifying wrong, false, and mistaken cases and implementing cadre policies, the Organization Department of the Central Committee conducted a systematic review of specialized documents related to cadre reviews issued since the founding of the People's Republic of China. It modified or abolished those documents influenced by "leftist" thinking or no longer applicable due to changes in circumstances. For cadres who had been wrongly treated, reexaminations and corrections were conducted to resolve a number of long-standing issues related to restrictions on their historical use.
The practice of imposing restrictions on the use of certain cadres was a special method adopted by our party to adapt to the war era and specific circumstances in cadre utilization. During the war era and the early stages of the People's Republic of China, due to objective limitations, it was difficult to immediately ascertain the political history or social relations of some cadres, and definite conclusions could not be drawn. Therefore, in terms of their assignment, the party organization placed them in minor positions and exercised appropriate control to facilitate ongoing assessments. This temporary measure was necessary at the time. However, this method did not change in a timely manner in the long period after the founding of the People's Republic of China; on the contrary, it continued. During the "Cultural Revolution," this method was abused by some localities and units, and arbitrary conclusions of restrictions on the use of certain comrades were made, severely undermining the enthusiasm of some cadres and the masses. On February 1, 1979, the 38th issue of "Organization Work Communication" published an article titled "Conclusions About Not Arbitrarily Imposing 'Controlled Use' on Cadres." The article pointed out that almost thirty years had passed since the nationwide liberation, and through multiple political campaigns and organizational reviews, some comrades had already been thoroughly cleared of any issues. For those comrades who, despite having certain problems, had consistently performed well after long-term assessments, the suspicions of the organization should be removed, the conclusions of "controlled use" should be lifted politically, and they should be trusted based on their moral and talent conditions and be boldly utilized. It explicitly stated that in the future, conclusions of "controlled use" on cadres would generally not be made. Only for the extremely rare individuals whose unrestricted use could potentially harm the socialist cause, necessary controls would be imposed. However, until their issues were thoroughly clarified, for those who possessed special skills, their roles should be developed according to the circumstances, and education and assessments should continue during their utilization. With the deepening of rectifying wrong, false, and mistaken cases and the implementation of cadre policies, in October 1983, with the approval of the CPC Central Secretariat, the Organization Department of the Central Committee issued the "Opinions on Resolving the Issue of Restrictions on the Historical Use of Certain Cadres." The document pointed out that before and after the founding of the People's Republic of China, during the rectification of cadres and the struggle against counterrevolutionaries, the Central Committee and the Organization Department had implemented regulations imposing restrictions on the use of cadres with political or historical issues. At that time, these regulations were necessary given the historical conditions. However, after undergoing long-term revolutionary struggles and tests, the majority of these cadres had performed well and very well. Some comrades had even made significant contributions to the Party and the people. In order to make rational use of cadres and fully unleash their positive roles in the construction of the Four Modernizations, the original regulations needed to be changed.
To carry out this work effectively, in September 1984, the Organization Department of the CPC Central Committee forwarded the pilot work report on resolving the issue of restrictions on the historical use of certain cadres from the Changchun Municipal Committee and the Nongan County Committee's Office for Cadre Review. In September 1986, the Organization Department of the Communist Party of China (CPC) submitted a request to the central leadership titled "Regarding the Change of Restrictions on the Use of Forty-One Cadres at or above the Deputy Ministerial Level." This request was approved by the comrades of the central leadership. The document pointed out that based on the relevant provisions of the approved opinions of the Organization Department of the CPC Central Committee in July 1981 on changing the restrictions on the use of cadres who made mistakes after being arrested or captured, as well as the opinions in October 1983 on lifting the restrictions on the use of some cadres with historical limitations, a comprehensive review was conducted regarding the original restrictions on the use of 41 comrades, and the restrictions were lifted, canceled, or relieved, depending on the circumstances. The provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities directly under the central government, and central state organs, as well as various ministries and commissions, actively and steadily carried out this work according to the suggestions of the central leadership and in accordance with their cadre management authority. Before the 13th National Congress of the CPC, the work of lifting the restrictions on the use of some cadres with historical limitations was basically completed.
5. Implementing the Party's ethnic and religious policies
From 1980 to 1981, the Central Secretariat of the CPC successively held conferences in Tibet, Yunnan, Xinjiang, Inner Mongolia, and other provinces and regions to conscientiously address issues related to implementing the Party's ethnic policies. The central and some local party committees also removed the label of "local nationalist" from comrades.
In March 1982, the Central Secretariat of the CPC issued a document on religious issues during the socialist period, clarifying the Party's basic principles and policies on religious matters. Prior to and after this, the activities of patriotic religious organizations were restored, temples and monasteries were gradually restored and opened in various places, and the Party's religious policies were implemented.
6. Implementing policies for foreign experts and friendly individuals working in China
In September 1981, a foreign expert working in China wrote a letter to the comrades of the central leadership, requesting a modification of the review conclusion. After studying the matter, the leaders of the Organization Department of the CPC Central Committee suggested conducting a comprehensive review of the implementation policy for foreign expert friends and submitting a proposed solution to the Central Secretariat for unified consideration and approval. The central leadership agreed and instructed: "The request of this foreign expert is reasonable and should be thoroughly vindicated without leaving any traces. A comprehensive review and handling of the implementation policy for foreign friends is completely necessary."
In accordance with the instructions of the comrades of the central leadership, the Organization Department of the CPC Central Committee and the Ministry of Public Security reevaluated the conclusions regarding this foreign expert and the conclusions of Epstein and Qiu Moli, who had worked at the Foreign Languages Bureau, as well as the British expert Shapiro, who had worked at Xinhua News Agency, and the British expert Koruk, who had worked at the Foreign Language Institute. The policies were implemented accordingly. The Organization Department of the CPC Central Committee and the Ministry of Public Security also made inquiries to the State Foreign Experts Bureau and other units regarding the implementation of policies for foreign experts. According to the investigations, most of these units have conducted a comprehensive review and vindication of the foreign experts who were affected during the "Cultural Revolution." Their reputations have been restored, salaries have been paid, and they have been assigned jobs. However, there are still many issues that need to be seriously resolved.
Therefore, the Party Group of the Organization Department of the CPC Central Committee and the Party Group of the Ministry of Public Security submitted a report to the central leadership titled "Report on the Implementation of Policies for Foreign Expert Friends." It affirmed the significant contributions made by foreign experts in China's revolution and construction, pointing out that they should be respected by our Party and the people of the whole country. It required relevant units to conduct a comprehensive inspection and review of the implementation policy issues concerning foreign expert friends, and promptly resolve any problems and eliminate adverse influences. For experts who were harmed during the "Cultural Revolution," they should be completely vindicated politically, receive sufficient care in their lives, and receive enthusiastic support in their work. The series of guidelines and policies for implementing the cadre policies of our Party should be fully implemented and carefully applied to foreign expert friends, taking their characteristics into consideration. In March 1982, the Central Secretariat of the CPC forwarded the report from the Party Groups of the Organization Department of the CPC Central Committee and the Ministry of Public Security. After the issuance of the document, relevant units conducted a comprehensive review and orderly handling of the implementation policy issues concerning foreign experts working in China. This eliminated the adverse influences, enabling foreign experts and friendly individuals working in China to serve the socialist modernization construction of our country with peace of mind and restored our reputation internationally.
This national exoneration of wrong and false cases, the adjustment of social relations, and the implementation of various policies is unprecedented in the history of our party in terms of duration, scope, and scale, and the problem-solving is relatively thorough. The resolution of the aforementioned historical legacy issues and the implementation of various party policies have effectively mobilized the enthusiasm of all sectors of society, consolidated and developed the patriotic united front, and played a significant role in promoting the ideological liberation of the entire party, promoting the comprehensive rectification of the organizational front, consolidating and developing a stable and united political situation, ensuring socialist modernization, and realizing the great cause of national reunification.
IV. Restoration of the Party's Ethnic and Religious Policies
During the "Cultural Revolution," as in other areas, ethnic and religious work suffered serious damage and restrictions from "left-wing" guiding ideologies. Ethnic and religious institutions were abolished, and ethnic and religious work was unjustly accused. After the defeat of the "Gang of Four," the urgent task in the field of ethnic and religious work was to heal the wounds caused by the ten years of turmoil, adjust ethnic and religious relations, reaffirm and restore the party's ethnic and religious policies, and formulate guiding principles for ethnic and religious work in the new era and implement pioneering work.
1. Restoration of the Party's Ethnic Policies
Reaffirming and adhering to the party's ethnic policies and implementing them requires work institutions and people to do this work. In 1978, the first session of the Fifth National People's Congress decided to restore the National Ethnic Affairs Commission of the People's Republic of China and appointed Yang Jingren as its director. In 1979, the second session of the Fifth National People's Congress decided to restore the National People's Congress Ethnic Affairs Committee, with Vice Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress Apei Awang Jinmei concurrently serving as Chairman. Other ethnic work institutions and ethnic affairs work institutions at all levels and in all regions have also been restored.
Shortly after the convening of the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, in April 1979, the central government presided over the National Border Defense Work Conference. This conference, with important historical significance, aimed to consolidate the country's border defense and promote national unity, and was instrumental in the "rectification" of ethnic work. One of the main topics of the conference was to discuss the tasks of ethnic work in the new period. Since the vast majority of China's border regions are inhabited by ethnic minorities, in order to establish and consolidate border defense, maintain national unity, and develop a favorable situation of stability and unity, it is necessary to do a good job in ethnic work and promote ethnic unity and common development and prosperity. In response to the damage caused by Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" to ethnic policies and ethnic work, a series of policies on ethnic, religious, and united front work that had been proven correct in practice were reiterated at the conference. Emphasis was placed on the practice of ethnic work since the establishment of New China, and experiences and lessons were summarized: First, we must adhere to the principle of integrating theory with practice, starting from the actual conditions in the border areas where ethnic minorities are concentrated. In order to implement the party's line, policies, and tasks in the new era, they must be well integrated with the ethnic and regional characteristics of the border minority areas. Second, we must adhere to the view that ethnic issues exist in the long term. The socialist stage is a period of common development and prosperity for all ethnic groups. Throughout the socialist historical stage, ethnic work tasks are arduous and must be given due attention. The party's ethnic policies must be earnestly implemented, and the equal rights and the right to self-governance of ethnic minorities must be respected. Third, we must adhere to the proletarian perspective on ethnicity and, on the basis of consolidating the alliance between the working class and the peasantry, continuously strengthen the great unity of all ethnic groups. The consolidation of national unity and the unity of all ethnic groups within the country are the fundamental guarantees for accelerating the realization of the overall tasks in the new era. Fourth, we must adhere to the policy of combining state support with self-reliance, and accelerate the economic and cultural development of ethnic minority areas in the border regions. Practice has proven that the economic and cultural development of ethnic minority regions on the border relies on the revolutionary spirit of the local people, who must work hard and be self-reliant. At the same time, the state must adopt supportive policies and prioritize care, sincerely and actively assisting the economic and cultural development of ethnic minorities. This is a major task for the country in ethnic affairs. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China has reviewed the conference report and called for the whole party to attach great importance to ethnic work, conduct the reeducation of ethnic policies, and thoroughly examine the implementation of ethnic policies in order to effectively address existing problems.
In September 1979, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China reviewed the document "Guidelines and Tasks for the United Front in the New Historical Period" from the National United Front Work Conference. The main content regarding strengthening ethnic work is as follows: according to the instructions of the Party Central Committee, carry out widespread, in-depth, and vigorous reeducation on ethnic policies among the entire party and all the people of various ethnic groups nationwide. Carefully examine the implementation of ethnic policies and effectively address problems in ethnic relations, eliminating all factors detrimental to ethnic unity. Educate cadres and people of all ethnic groups, especially Han cadres and people, to fully understand the importance of enhancing ethnic unity and doing a good job in ethnic work, continuously improving their awareness of implementing ethnic policies. Treat ethnic minorities equally, respect their equal rights and autonomy, and respect their language, customs, and religious beliefs. It also pointed out the need to comprehensively implement the Party's policy of religious freedom.
Implementing the Party's ethnic policies not only requires doing well in ethnic work in areas where ethnic minorities are concentrated, but also attaching importance to ethnic work in areas where different ethnic groups live together or separately. In October 1979, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council reviewed and approved the report from the Party Group of the Central Committee for Nationalities Affairs on doing a good job in the work of ethnic minorities living together or separately. It pointed out that while the struggle against Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" had achieved great victory, their remnants had not been completely eradicated. In many areas, ethnic and religious policies had not been earnestly implemented, and some unjust, false, and mistaken cases had not been rectified. In doing the work of ethnic minorities living together or separately, there were many problems that needed to be effectively addressed through appropriate measures. Ensuring the equal rights of ethnic minorities, actively assisting their economic and cultural development, respecting their customs, and implementing the policy of religious freedom were all emphasized. It also called for strengthening party leadership and restoring and improving various levels of ethnic work institutions. Party committees and governments at all levels, in accordance with the instructions of the Party Central Committee and the State Council and based on the opinions of the Party Group of the State Ethnic Affairs Commission, organized inspections of the work of ethnic minorities living together or separately, formulated measures, implemented the Party's ethnic policies, and did a lot of work in this regard.
In response to the situation of weak awareness of ethnic policies caused by the turmoil of the past decade, in order to educate cadres of all ethnic groups and the general public on ethnic policies, the Central Propaganda Department of the Communist Party of China, the United Front Work Department of the CPC Central Committee, and the State Ethnic Affairs Commission held a symposium on ethnic policy propaganda work in December 1979. They made arrangements for conducting reeducation on ethnic policies and decided to concentrate efforts for a period of time to extensively carry out propaganda and education on ethnic policies and ethnic unity. In January 1980, the minutes of the conference were approved by the three departments mentioned above, pointing out that conducting education on ethnic policies was crucial. The key focus of the reeducation was to overcome Han chauvinism, which was the key to adjusting ethnic relations and promoting ethnic unity at present. Attention should also be paid to preventing and overcoming major Han nationalism and local nationalism. The education should target cadres and the masses, with a particular emphasis on educating the Han people. Reeducation should be combined with examining the implementation of ethnic policies and solving practical problems. From the central to the local level, combining inspections of the implementation of ethnic, religious, and united front policies, extensive reeducation on ethnic policies was carried out, effectively addressing some prominent problems in ethnic relations, and improving the awareness of cadres and the masses in safeguarding ethnic policies and promoting ethnic unity. There was initial improvement in ethnic relations. For example, in Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region, efforts are being made to implement ethnic policies and promote ethnic unity. The "Regulations on Strengthening Ethnic Unity" have been issued and implemented, and the "Ethnic Unity Covenant" has been formulated. Ethnic unity and progress commendation conferences are widely held throughout the autonomous region, and activities promoting ethnic unity and progress are carried out. The General Office of the CPC Central Committee forwarded a document from the Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region Party Committee, stating that faithfully implementing the party's ethnic policies and continuously strengthening ethnic unity is an extremely important task for all levels of Party Committees in all autonomous regions and areas with mixed ethnic populations. Concrete measures should be formulated, and efforts should be made to enhance ethnic policy education work, promoting the great development of ethnic unity.
The restoration and adherence to the party's ethnic policies is important, particularly in adhering to and implementing policies on ethnic regional autonomy. The first step is to restore the system of ethnic regional autonomy, followed by the cultivation of minority ethnic cadres. In 1979, the CPC Central Committee and the State Council decided to restore the original administrative divisions of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region, including some administrative regions that were temporarily assigned to Liaoning, Jilin, Heilongjiang, Gansu, and Ningxia during the Cultural Revolution, which were brought under the jurisdiction of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region. Efforts to resume the interrupted work on ethnic regional autonomy after the ten years of turbulence were restarted. At the same time, a number of new autonomous areas were established. From 1979 to the end of 1988, 53 new ethnic autonomous areas were successively established nationwide. The key to implementing and implementing the policy of ethnic regional autonomy is to empower the ethnic minorities who exercise autonomy to truly be in charge of their own affairs within their ethnic and local regions, as well as to cultivate a minority ethnic cadres. The "Constitution of the People's Republic of China" promulgated in 1982 restored and developed some important principles on ethnic regional autonomy in the 1954 Constitution. Based on the changes in the national situation during the new era of socialist construction, a series of important amendments and supplements were made to expand the autonomous rights of ethnic autonomous organs, clearly stipulating the autonomy rights of ethnic autonomous regions in terms of minority ethnic cadres and in the independent arrangement and management of economic and cultural construction in their local areas. The constitution also indicates that the state and higher-level people's governments will help ethnic minorities in their development of economic and cultural undertakings, fully reflecting the spirit of respecting and guaranteeing the democratic rights of minority ethnic groups to manage their internal affairs. In the new era of reform and opening up, the policy of ethnic regional autonomy not only recovered from the destruction of the ten years of turmoil but also achieved new developments. After the Third Plenum of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party, a large number of minority ethnic cadres returned to their positions through the rectification of previous wrongdoings and the redress of miscarrying justice cases. Efforts to cultivate minority ethnic cadres were strengthened from the central government to local governments, adopting many practical and effective measures. Minority ethnic cadres grew rapidly, reaching 1.84 million people by 1988.
2. New Guidelines for Tibet Work
In China's ethnic relations, Tibet is particularly sensitive. Tibet began to address its historical issues as early as 1977, including reviewing and redressing the cases of full-time cadres who were investigated and persecuted during the Cultural Revolution, rearranging patriotic elites as national or regional People's Congress representatives, members of the Political Consultative Conference, or government officials, and granting amnesty to all incarcerated personnel involved in the 1959 Tibetan rebellion. In November 1978, one week after the Central Working Conference, Deng Xiaoping conveyed the intention to reconcile with the Dalai Lama to the West. Three months later, Deng Xiaoping met with representatives sent by the Dalai Lama in Beijing and said, "Welcome the Dalai Lama's return, welcome more people to come and see."
Hu Yaobang, who became the General Secretary of the Central Committee in February 1980, was first concerned with the Tibet issue. On March 14th to 15th, 1980, he presided over a conference on Tibet work, listening to reports from the responsible party committee leaders of the Tibet Autonomous Region. Hu Yaobang emphasized at the meeting that to accelerate Tibet's development, it was necessary to further liberate thinking, implement policies, resolutely eliminate the remnants of the "left" leaning, correct the "left" economic policies, courageously cultivate and promote Tibetan cadres, and gradually make Tibetan cadres the main body of county-level and above Party and government organs. In terms of religion, we must handle the Lamaism issue carefully, deal with the historical legacy issues such as suppressing rebellions, expanding them, and wrongly classifying wealthy peasants, strengthen our work on the Dalai Group and the relatives of Tibetans who have fled abroad and remained in the country, mobilize all positive factors, and consolidate the stable and united situation. On April 7th, the Communist Party Central Committee approved the summary of this meeting and issued a notice. In late May, Hu Yaobang, Wan Li, and more than ten officials from relevant departments of the central government visited Tibet for investigation. On May 29th, Hu Yaobang delivered a speech at a meeting of cadres above the county level in the Tibet Autonomous Region, proposing that Tibet should prioritize six major tasks, including resolutely implementing the policy of recuperation and revitalization and adopting more flexible economic policies compared to those on the mainland, as well as restoring and developing Tibetan culture and scientific endeavors. The most important part includes two points: firstly, granting Tibet "sufficient and independent autonomy", and regarding central policies, those that do not conform to the situation in Tibet may be not be implemented or implemented with flexibility; those that are not conducive to ethnic unity and the development of productive forces may be disregarded. Secondly, emphasizing the strengthening of unity between Han and Tibetan cadres, and the method is to gradually withdraw Han cadres and replace them with Tibetan cadres, so that within two to three years, Tibetan cadres account for more than two-thirds of the national cadre stationed in Tibet. Regarding the cadres working in Tibet, Hu Yaobang had both encouragement and criticism, stating that "Han cadres working in Tibet have completed their historical tasks" and proposed the withdrawal of 80% of Han people from Tibet. Based on Hu Yaobang's opinion, the Tibet Autonomous Region submitted a report to the central government titled "Request for a Large-scale Withdrawal of Cadres and Workers from Tibet", proposing that, except for a small number of leading cadres and technical backbone personnel, most of those sent to Tibet should be gradually recalled or retired. On August 6th, the report was approved by the Central Committee of the Communist Party and the State Council. From 1980 to the end of 1981, more than 20,000 cadres were withdrawn from Tibet in two separate groups, mostly those who had been sent to Tibet in the 1950s and 1960s. In 1986, the decision was made to transfer an additional 17,000 cadres and workers (including retirees) to Tibet from the mainland.
The central government's policies on Tibet have had a significant impact on Inner Mongolia, Xinjiang, Yunnan, Qinghai, Ningxia, Gansu, and other ethnic regions. On May 31, 1980, when Hu Yaobang made a brief stop in Golmud, he told officials from Qinghai Province, "The six points we discussed at the cadre conference in the Tibet Autonomous Region basically apply to the situation in Qinghai as well, and you can refer to them for study and implementation." Both Hu Yaobang and Wan Li emphasized that the policies should be further relaxed and that the right to exercise autonomy in ethnic autonomous regions should be fully exercised. The intention was to extend the policy guidelines for resolving Tibet's issues to other ethnic regions. Subsequently, party committees in provinces and autonomous regions such as Gansu, Inner Mongolia, Ningxia, and Guangxi held meetings to study the instructions of the Communist Party Central Committee regarding work in Tibet and Hu Yaobang's speech on Tibet, and decided to solve local issues in accordance with the instructions of the central government regarding work in Tibet. Afterwards, the General Office of the Communist Party Central Committee successively discussed work in Yunnan, Xinjiang, and Inner Mongolia, forming the summary of ethnic work in Yunnan, Xinjiang, and Inner Mongolia.
In the early 1980s, the party began to adjust its ethnic policies with a focus on improving ethnic relations. However, the official publication "Contemporary Tibet in China" pointed out that the large-scale withdrawal of Han people and Han cadres from Tibet was done "relatively crudely," leading to the transfer of a group of urgently needed talents from Tibet and greatly impacting various aspects of Tibetan work, especially in science and technology, education, healthcare, and finance. Deng Liqun also critically criticized the decision to withdraw a large number of cadres sent to Tibet from a political perspective. Some domestic scholars also expressed dissent regarding the decision to withdraw cadres sent to Tibet, based on considerations of national security.
3. Restoration and adjustment of religious policies
Since 1957, the party has gradually developed "leftist" errors in religious work, which further escalated in the mid-1960s. In particular, during the "Cultural Revolution", Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" group deliberately exploited this "left" mistake, blatantly trampling on the scientific theories of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought regarding religious issues, completely negating the correct policy of the Party towards religion since the founding of the People's Republic of China, and fundamentally canceling the Party's work on religion. They forcibly banned the normal religious life of the religious masses, treating patriotic individuals in the religious community and even ordinary religious believers as "objects of dictatorship", and created a large number of unjust cases in the religious community. They also regarded the customs and traditions of certain ethnic minorities as religious superstition and forcibly banned them, even suppressing religious believers in some areas, undermining national unity. They used violence in religious matters, but as a result, religious activities developed in a secret and fragmented manner. A few bad elements took advantage of these conditions to engage in illegal criminal activities and disruptive activities under the guise of religious activities.
After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party, the correct policy and direction of the Party towards religion gradually resumed. At this time, the core of the adjustment in religious policies was to a certain extent the opening up of religious freedom. On December 1, 1978, the Central United Front Work Department held a national religious work symposium, putting forward the main tasks of religious work in the future period: earnestly implementing the policy of religious freedom, properly arranging religious activity venues, and uniting the vast religious believers to participate in socialist construction. It proposed to restore and improve religious work institutions and the activities of patriotic religious organizations. The summary of this meeting was forwarded by the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China.
In 1979, nationwide religious organizations and local religious groups successively resumed their activities. Religious clergy gradually returned to temples and churches and resumed their religious duties. Some long-prohibited ethnic religious festivals were gradually restored.
On January 25, 1980, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China approved the report from the Central United Front Work Department on holding national conferences for various religious organizations. That year, the Chinese Islamic Association, the Chinese Taoist Association, the Chinese Catholic Patriotic Association, the Three-Self Patriotic Movement Committee of the Protestant Churches in China, and the Chinese Buddhist Association successively held conferences, elected leaders of various religious organizations, formulated activity regulations, and resumed their work. In various regions, 164 provincial-level religious organizations and over 2,000 county-level religious organizations were gradually restored or established. On July 16, the State Council forwarded reports from the Religious Affairs Bureau and the National Construction Commission, returning the property rights of religious organization housing to the religious organizations and offering discounted payments for those unable to be returned; returning occupied temples and churches, returning deposits of religious organizations. In some large and medium-sized cities, famous religious sites, places where believers gather, especially in ethnic minority areas, a number of temples, monasteries, and churches were restored in a planned and systematic manner. On April 1, 1983, the State Council also approved the opening of 163 key Buddhist and Taoist temples in Han areas. The government provided financial subsidies for the maintenance of some temples, monasteries, and shrines. According to incomplete statistics, from 1980 to 1991, more than 140 million yuan in repair subsidies were allocated from the central finances to temples, monasteries, and churches. As of 1992, over 60,000 religious activity venues had been restored nationwide. Starting from 1980, national religious colleges and 41 local religious colleges such as the Chinese Buddhist Academy, Chinese Islamic College, Nanjing Union Theological Seminary of the Protestant Churches in China, Chinese Catholic Philosophy and Theology Institute, Chinese Taoist Academy, and Chinese Tibetan Buddhism Advanced Buddhist Academy were successively restored or newly established. In March 1982, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China put forward the "Basic Viewpoints and Basic Policies on Religious Issues in China during the Socialist Period", emphasizing the long-term nature of religious issues under socialist conditions and criticizing the idea and practice of trying to eliminate religion at once by relying on administrative orders or other coercive means. It reaffirmed the policy of respecting and protecting religious freedom but did not allow religious intervention in state political affairs.
From August 29th to September 7th, 1979, the Chinese religious delegation, led by Zhao Puchu, the deputy head of the China Buddhist Association, and Ding Guangxun, the vice chairman of the Three-Self Patriotic Movement of the Protestant Churches in China, participated in the Third World Conference on Religion and Peace (WCRP) held in Princeton, New Jersey, USA. In October, the Chinese Muslim pilgrimage group was allowed to make a pilgrimage to Mecca for the first time after the Cultural Revolution, indicating that the Communist Party of China was willing to restore international exchanges with the domestic religious community under certain conditions. However, a high degree of vigilance was maintained towards the infiltration of foreign churches into domestic religions. On March 4th, 1980, the Communist Party of China Central Committee and the State Council forwarded a report from the Bureau of Religious Affairs and other departments titled "Regarding the Request to Resist the Religious Infiltration by Foreign Churches" which pointed out the harmfulness of foreign religious infiltration and emphasized the need for internal and external efforts to prevent and restrict its influence as much as possible.
A comprehensive review of the basic situation of religious work during this period clearly reveals that the fundamental tasks of the Party and the government in religious work are to firmly implement the policy of religious freedom, consolidate and expand the patriotic political alliance of the religious circles of all ethnic groups, strengthen their education on patriotism and socialism, and mobilize their positive factors to jointly strive for the construction of a modern socialist country, the fulfillment of the great cause of national reunification, and the opposition against hegemonism and the maintenance of world peace. Guided by these basic tasks, the entire Party comrades, party committees at all levels, especially the departments responsible for religious work at all levels, earnestly summarized and absorbed the historical experiences, both positive and negative, of the Party's religious work since the founding of the New China. They further understood and grasped the objective laws of the occurrence, development, and disappearance of religions, overcame all difficulties and obstacles, and firmly placed the Party's religious policy onto the scientific track of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought.
4. Implement the policy of the united front and develop a patriotic united front
After the fall of the "Gang of Four," the organizations and activities of various democratic parties gradually resumed. After the Third Plenum of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, with the comprehensive launch of rectification and the start of reform and opening up, the Party's united front work fully resumed. The democratic parties began to play their role in the country's political life in terms of participating in policy-making and democratic supervision. The theory of the Party's united front also became enriched and developed.
In June 1979, during his opening speech at the Second Session of the Fifth National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, Deng Xiaoping analyzed the situation of various classes in Chinese society and clearly pointed out the new tasks and changes facing the united front in the new era. He used the concepts of "socialist workers and patriotic supporters of socialism." He stated, "The united front in our country has become a broad alliance led by the working class, based on the alliance between workers and peasants, comprised of socialist workers and patriotic supporters of socialism. In the new era, the task of the united front and the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference is to mobilize all positive factors, strive to turn negative factors into positive factors, unite all possible forces, and work together to maintain and develop a stable and united political situation, and strive for the construction of a modern socialist country." Shortly after, the Party Central Committee further proposed that "the united front which can be revolutionary and patriotic is now the largest united front, which is the issue of Taiwan's return and the reunification of the motherland." In accordance with this directive, the 14th National United Front Work Conference held in August 1979 used the term "revolutionary patriotic united front." The conference believed that in the new era, although there are still various contradictions between socialist workers, farmers, intellectuals, and other patriotic supporters of socialism within the united front, there are no fundamental conflicts of interest. The basic policies and methods of the revolutionary patriotic united front must be based on the actual transformation of the main internal contradictions. It is necessary to strictly distinguish between two different types of contradictions, take the correct handling of internal contradictions among the people as the overall theme, strictly adhere to socialist democracy and socialist legal system, and correctly handle various contradictions within the united front. Actively help non-Party members in all aspects to make new progress and contributions in achieving the Four Modernizations. For all those who love the motherland, "as long as they support the reunification of the motherland, even if they do not support the socialist system, they should unite."
In October of the same year, the CPC Central Committee forwarded the guidelines and tasks of the National United Front Work Conference for the New Historical Period. This document provides a realistic and objective analysis of the fundamental changes in the social class conditions in the 30 years since the establishment of New China, and clarifies the nature, guidelines, and tasks of the united front in the new period. The document points out that the foundation of our united front, the alliance between the workers and peasants, has entered a new stage with the central task of realizing socialist modernization. The vast majority of intellectuals, including most intellectuals who came from the old society, have become part of the working class and an important backbone force in realizing modernization. The various ethnic groups in the country have formed a new type of socialist unity, friendship, mutual assistance, and cooperation. In the process of realizing modernization, the socialist consensus among the various ethnic groups will further develop, and patriotic individuals of different religious beliefs will also make great progress. The capitalist class as a class no longer exists in our country. They have undergone various tests in accepting the path of socialist transformation and the struggle against Lin Biao and the Gang of Four, and the majority of them support the Party's leadership and the socialist system. Now, as self-reliant workers or state officials, they are contributing to the Four Modernizations. The democratic parties in our country have become political alliances serving socialism, and they are part of the socialist workers and those who support socialism. Part of the individuals who were originally on the enemy side, such as amnestied war criminals and released KMT officials at the county and regimental levels, have been transformed to the side of the people after a long period of reform. Class struggle is no longer the main contradiction in our society. With the strategic shift of the party's work focus and the fundamental changes in the domestic class conditions, the united front in the new period should be called the revolutionary patriotic united front, which is a broad alliance of all socialist workers and patriots. In the new historical period, the guidelines and tasks of the united front are to unite all forces that can be united, mobilize all positive factors at home and abroad, make efforts to transform negative factors into positive ones, and make unremitting efforts to maintain and develop a stable and unified political situation. Together, we strive to build our country into a modern socialist power, and strive for the reunification of Taiwan with the motherland and the realization of national unity. This document not only deals with the influence of "Left" mistakes in the work of the united front, but also plays a role in implementing the party's various policies.
Soon afterwards, the CPC Central Committee put forward the concept of "patriotic united front." This is because although the concept of the revolutionary patriotic united front has developed significantly compared to the past, it still cannot cover a wider range of united front targets and does not fully adapt to the tasks and requirements of the new historical conditions. In June 1981, the Resolution on Some Historical Issues of the Party Since the Founding of the People's Republic of China, passed at the Sixth Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party, clearly pointed out, "We must unswervingly unite all forces that can be united and consolidate and expand the patriotic united front."
The 15th National United Front Work Conference, held from December 1981 to January 1982, further elaborated on the "patriotic united front" and emphasized that the united front in the new period is still a major weapon of the Party. The conference believed that for a long time, due to the influence of "Left" thinking, there has been a tendency to neglect or even abandon the united front. Recognizing the importance and long-term nature of the united front is a prerequisite for doing a good job in united front work. Hu Yaobang pointed out in his speech: "In the new historical period, in the long, long historical period to come, the united front will still be necessary, important, and still have great vitality. It will still be a great treasure of our party." The meeting further clarified the scope and target of the patriotic united front in the new era, proposing that there are two united fronts in the new era, one is the united front against aggression and expansion on an international scale, and the other is the patriotic united front within the country. The patriotic united front within the country is the widest united front of all socialist workers, patriots who support socialism, and patriots who support national reunification. In the long term to come, the target of united front work will not decrease, but increase; the scope of united front work will not narrow, but expand. The united front work within the country can include ten aspects: the democratic parties, non-party prominent figures, mainly patriots; non-party intellectual cadres; former Kuomintang military and political personnel who have defected or surrendered; former wealthy business owners; upper-class figures of ethnic minorities; patriotic religious leaders; family members and friends of those who left Taiwan and settled in mainland China; compatriots from Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macao; and returnees and overseas Chinese. 
The introduction of the concept of "patriotic united front" is the development of the party's theory of united front. This understanding accurately expresses the characteristics of the united front in the new era. It has developed from the "revolutionary patriotic united front" to the "patriotic united front," encompassing more united front targets without changing its nature, which is more conducive to strengthening unity. This change not only develops the party's theory of united front but also makes the united front policy more in line with China's social reality in the new era. The patriotism spoken of by the patriotic united front is essentially socialist patriotism, but its range is broader than socialism, including patriots who support national reunification but may not necessarily endorse socialism or have doubts about socialism. The proposal of the patriotic united front is a combination of principles and flexibility. Regarding the relationship between the Communist Party of China and the democratic parties, as well as other non-party patriotic democratic people in the united front, Mao Zedong proposed the eight-character principle of "long-term coexistence and mutual supervision" as early as April 1956. This eight-character principle objectively reflects the history and reality of the Chinese revolution, embodying the Communist Party of China's proposal for long-term coexistence with the democratic parties and the equal status of the democratic parties. However, from the late 1950s to the end of the "Cultural Revolution", this correct principle for handling the relationship between the Communist Party of China and the democratic parties was not well implemented. Especially during the "Cultural Revolution", the work and activities of the democratic parties were forced to stop. After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the Communist Party of China reaffirmed the guideline of "long-term coexistence and mutual supervision" with the democratic parties. Deng Xiaoping also clearly stated, "This is a long-term unchanging principle."
In the new era of reform and opening up, with profound changes in China's social class relations, the class color of the democratic parties has gradually faded, and they have essentially become political parties of some socialist workers.
