Deng Xiaoping's remarks showed his extraordinary ability and level of insight into problem analysis and observation as a great Marxist.
In October 1980, the draft resolution was discussed for 20 days among 4,000 senior cadres. During the discussions, everyone spoke freely, and many good opinions were expressed. However, some people still expressed extreme views during the discussions. For example, some suggested not writing about Mao Zedong Thought at all; that Comrade Mao Zedong was a Marxist and communist in the early period, but not in the later period; and some even believed that all the mistakes before the "Cultural Revolution" and during it should be solely the responsibility of Mao Zedong.
Based on this situation, Deng Xiaoping proposed during a conversation with senior party officials on October 25, 1980, that not mentioning Mao Zedong Thought and making inappropriate evaluations of Comrade Mao Zedong's achievements and mistakes would be unacceptable to old workers, poor and lower-middle peasants who underwent land reform, and a large group of cadres associated with them. Mao Zedong Thought is an indispensable banner. If we discard this banner, we would actually negate the glorious history of our party. The part of the draft resolution that expounds on Mao Zedong Thought cannot be omitted. This is not just a theoretical problem, but especially a political problem, which is a major political issue both domestically and internationally. If this part is not written or written poorly, the whole resolution would be better off not being done. Not writing or not upholding Mao Zedong Thought would be a historical and major mistake. When it comes to Comrade Mao Zedong's mistakes, they must be criticized without any ambiguity, but it must be done objectively, analyzing various different circumstances. One cannot attribute all problems to personal qualities. Comrade Mao Zedong was not an isolated individual; until his death, he was always the leader of our party. When it comes to Comrade Mao Zedong's mistakes, they cannot be exaggerated. Exaggerating them would not only tarnish Comrade Mao Zedong's reputation but also tarnish our party and our country. This goes against historical facts.
In March 1981, Deng Xiaoping pointed out that the outline of the draft resolution could be established: the achievements of the first seven years of the founding of the People's Republic of China were unanimously recognized by everyone. The ten years before the "Cultural Revolution" should be affirmed, overall they were good, and they were basically developed on a healthy path. Although there were twists and turns and mistakes were made, the achievements were the main focus. As for the part about the "Cultural Revolution," it should be summarized. Compared to the mistakes in the previous 17 years, the "Cultural Revolution" was a serious and comprehensive error, with extremely severe consequences that still have an impact today. On April 7, Deng Xiaoping expressed his views on some issues during the "Cultural Revolution" to the responsible officials of the drafting group: (1) The legitimacy of the Eighth Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee and the Ninth National Congress should be recognized. During the "Cultural Revolution", our party still existed. (2) During the "Cultural Revolution", great achievements were made in foreign affairs. 
At the same time, Chen Yun also made important suggestions for the revision of the draft resolution. On March 24th, Chen Yun made two suggestions on the draft resolution: First, specifically add a section to talk about the history of the Party before the founding of the country and write about the Party's 60 years. This way, Mao Zedong's achievements and contributions will be summarized more comprehensively, establishing Mao Zedong's historical status, upholding and developing Mao Zedong Thought, and having a comprehensive basis. Second, it is suggested that the central government promote learning, with a focus on studying Mao Zedong's philosophical works. Deng Xiaoping attached great importance to this opinion. Two days later, he conveyed these two suggestions to the drafting group of the resolution. Before and after this, Chen Yun also made the following suggestions on the draft resolution: (1) Regarding the mistakes in the Party's work in the past 32 years since the founding of the People's Republic of China, it must be written accurately and the judgments must be in line with reality. It must be "finalized"; (2) Suggest adding a paragraph reviewing the history of the 28 years before the founding of the People's Republic of China; (3) Fully affirm Mao Zedong's historical achievements; (4) Write about the international help we have received. 
In May 1981, the Communist Party of China (CPC) Central Committee Politburo invited more than forty people to discuss the draft resolution for twelve days. Based on the discussions, the drafting group made repeated modifications. 
On May 19th, Deng Xiaoping pointed out at an expanded meeting of the CPC Central Committee Politburo: The historical resolution document must be released as soon as possible, it cannot be delayed any longer, any delay is unfavorable. In order to release it earlier, the current method is to hold an expanded meeting of the Politburo. With over seventy people, spend some time and effort to scrutinize the draft more meticulously, make further improvements to it, and once it is decided, it can be mentioned at the Sixth Plenary Session, and the plan is to publish it on the occasion of the Party's 60th anniversary. 
Subsequently, based on Deng Xiaoping's suggestions, the CPC Central Committee Politburo invited over seventy people to discuss the draft resolution for twelve days. After the modifications, the opinions and suggestions of 130 representatives from various democratic parties were also sought, leading to further modifications and improvements to the resolution's content. In June 1981, the preparatory meeting of the Sixth Plenary Session of the 11th CPC Central Committee carefully and meticulously discussed the draft resolution. Deng Xiaoping made some important remarks on the draft resolution during the meeting. 
In this way, after more than a year, the draft resolution went through a process of drafting, discussion, and repeated modifications. Through extensive discussions that occurred four or five times, by drawing upon the collective wisdom, collective modifications, and the wisdom of the entire Party, the opinions of the majority of comrades gradually unified, achieving the goal of drafting the resolution. 
On this basis, the CPC Central Committee held the Sixth Plenary Session of the 11th CPC Central Committee from June 27th to 29th, 1981. The plenary session deliberated on the "Resolution on Some Historical Issues of the Party Since the Founding of the People's Republic of China" (referred to as the "Resolution"). After thorough discussions, the plenary session unanimously passed this "Resolution". The "Resolution" applies Marxist dialectical materialism and historical materialism to provide a correct summary of the major historical events of the Party in the 32 years since the founding of the People's Republic of China, especially the "Cultural Revolution".
The most important contribution of this historical document is as follows:
Firstly, it provides a truthful and scientific evaluation of Mao Zedong's historical position, fully explaining the great significance of Mao Zedong Thought as the guiding ideology of the party. The "Resolution" points out that Mao Zedong is a great Marxist, a great proletarian revolutionary, strategist, and theorist. Looking at his entire life, his contributions to the Chinese revolution far outweigh his mistakes. Mao Zedong has made indelible merits in the founding and development of our party and the Chinese People's Liberation Army, the victory of the cause of liberation of the people of all ethnic groups in China, the establishment of the People's Republic of China, and the development of our country's socialist cause.
The "Resolution" provides a full exposition of Mao Zedong Thought, stating that it is the application and development of Marxism-Leninism in China, and it is a proven correct theoretical principle and summary of experiences in the Chinese revolution. It is the crystallization of the collective wisdom of the Communist Party of China. Many outstanding leaders of our party have made important contributions to its formation and development. Mao Zedong's scientific works are a concentrated summary of it. The scientific system of Mao Zedong Thought mainly includes the following aspects: the construction of the revolutionary army and military strategy; policies and strategies; ideological and political work and cultural work; and the construction of the party. In these constituent parts, the fundamental aspects that run through are "seeking truth from facts," "the mass line," and "independence and self-reliance," which are the living soul of Mao Zedong Thought.
The "Resolution" distinguishes Mao Zedong's errors in his later years from Mao Zedong Thought and states that it is completely wrong to deny the scientific value of Mao Zedong Thought because of Mao Zedong's errors in his later years. At the same time, it is also completely wrong to adopt a doctrinaire attitude towards Mao Zedong's speeches and to be unwilling to truthfully acknowledge his errors in his later years, and even attempt to adhere to these errors in new practices. It is necessary to distinguish Mao Zedong Thought, which has become a scientific theory through long-term historical tests, from Mao Zedong's errors in his later years. Mao Zedong Thought is the precious spiritual wealth of our party and will guide our actions for a long time.
The "Resolution" not only provides a scientific summary and definition of this first theoretical achievement formed by the party in the path of Marxist Chineseification, but also paves the way for inheriting and developing this theory, thus continuing to promote the cause of Marxist Chineseification.
Secondly, it provides a scientific summary of the history of the party, especially the 32 years after the establishment of New China. Regarding the seven years (1949-1956) of basically completing the socialist transformation, the "Resolution" believes that the guiding principles and basic policies determined by the party during this period were correct, and the victories achieved were glorious. The establishment of the socialist system was the most profound and greatest social transformation in the history of our country, and it became the foundation for all future progress and development in our country. Regarding the ten years (1957-1966) of starting comprehensive socialist construction, the "Resolution" believes that we have achieved great success but also suffered serious setbacks. All the achievements in these ten years were made under the collective leadership of the Party Central Committee with Mao Zedong as the leader. Later, due to various complex subjective and objective reasons, such as lack of experience, there were deviations in the analysis of the situation and the understanding of the national conditions, resulting in mistakes of subjectivism, expansion of class struggle, rashness and impetuosity in economic construction, including the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution, a comprehensive and long-lasting error. These mistakes have caused serious setbacks and losses to the socialist cause.
The "Resolution" completely negates the Great Proletarian Cultural Revolution (May 1966 - October 1976). The "Resolution" points out that the Cultural Revolution has caused the most serious setbacks and losses to the party, the country, and the people since the establishment of New China. The main arguments put forward by Mao Zedong to launch the Cultural Revolution neither conform to Marxism-Leninism nor to the Chinese reality. The arguments referred to as "the theory of continuing revolution under proletarian dictatorship" were completely wrong in their assessment of the class situation in our country at that time, as well as the political situation of the Party and the state. History has already proven that the "Cultural Revolution" was an internal upheaval caused by the leaders' mistakes and exploited by the Lin Biao and Jiang Qing factions, which brought disastrous consequences to the Party, the country, and the people.
The "Resolution" made the following evaluation of the two years of hesitation and progress after the elimination of the "Gang of Four" in October 1976: The victory in crushing the counter-revolutionary gang of Jiang Qing in October 1976 marked the beginning of a new period of historical development for our country. However, in the first two years, the strong demands from both within and outside the Party to correct the mistakes of the Cultural Revolution encountered serious obstacles. This was not only because the political and ideological confusion caused by the ten-year Cultural Revolution was not easily eliminated in a short period of time but also because at that time, Hua Guofeng, who was serving as the Chairman of the Party Central Committee, continued to make "left" mistakes in guiding ideology. The Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, held in December 1978, was a significant turning point in the history of our Party since the founding of New China. The Plenary Session ended the situation of the Party's work hesitatingly moving forward since October 1976 and began to comprehensively and seriously correct the "left" deviation in the Cultural Revolution and before it. A series of victories were achieved in rectifying the chaos, resulting in a favorable situation in both economic and political aspects of our country.
Third, the "Resolution" also pointed out for the first time that our socialist system is still in the primary stage and emphasized that our socialist system must go through a long process of moving from relative imperfection to relative perfection. This understanding represents progress compared to the past. Based on a correct summary of historical experience, it made a preliminary summary of the socialist construction path that suits China's national conditions and which the Party has gradually established since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee. These are: (1) after the basic completion of socialist transformation, the primary contradiction to be resolved in our country is the contradiction between the growing material and cultural needs of the people and the backward social productive forces. The focus of the work of the Party and the state must shift to the socialist modernization construction centered on economic development; (2) socialist economic construction must proceed from China's national conditions, proceed step by step, and in different stages, achieve the goal of modernization; (3) the transformation and improvement of the relations of production must adapt to the state of productive forces. The development of socialist production relations does not exist in a fixed model. It needs to create specific forms of production relations that are appropriate and conducive to continuous progress at each stage, based on the needs of China's productive forces; (4) after the elimination of the exploiting classes as class, class struggle is no longer the primary contradiction. We must oppose the view of expanding class struggle and also oppose the view that class struggle has been extinguished; (5) gradually build a highly democratic socialist political system, which is one of the fundamental tasks of socialist revolution; (6) socialism must have a high degree of spiritual civilization, striving to elevate the status and role of education, science, and culture in modernization construction; (7) improving and developing socialist ethnic relations has significant significance for our multi-ethnic country; (8) it is necessary to strengthen modern national defense construction, and national defense construction must be in accordance with the state's economic development; (9) in foreign relations, we must firmly oppose imperialism, hegemonism, colonialism, and racism, and maintain world peace; (10) the Communist Party of China must be built into a party with a sound system of democratic centralism. Although the specific expressions of these main points have changed in subsequent documents, their basic spirit and main content reflect the preliminary understanding achieved by the Party under new historical conditions in exploring the path of socialist construction.
The adoption of the "Resolution on Several Historical Issues Since the Founding of the People's Republic of China" is of great significance for the Party's construction and the political construction of the country. It further unified the thinking and understanding of the whole Party and the people of the whole country, strengthened the unity of the whole Party and the people of all ethnic groups, and marked the Party's victorious completion of the task of rectifying chaos in guiding ideology. This resolution immediately generated a strong response among the entire Party and the people of the whole country and received extensive and warm support. At the same time, the adoption and announcement of this resolution also had a significant impact overseas and internationally.
Chapter 4: The Proposal and Formulation of the Overall Reform Program for Building Socialism with Chinese Characteristics
I. The Proposal of "Socialism with Chinese Characteristics"
From September 1 to 11, 1982, the Communist Party of China held the 12th National Congress in Beijing. This was the most important national congress in the history of the Party since the 8th National Congress.
The 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee held in December 1978 put forward a series of major decisions that determined the future and destiny of the Party and the country. It criticized the erroneous policy of "two whatevers" and fully affirmed the need to comprehensively and accurately grasp the scientific system of Mao Zedong Thought. It determined the guiding principles of emancipating the mind, seeking truth from facts, and uniting for progress, decisively stopped using the slogan of "taking class struggle as the key link," and made strategic decisions to shift the focus of the Party's work to socialist modernization construction.
1. The Launch of Preparatory Work for the 12th National Congress
The transformation achieved at the 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee marked a fundamental breakthrough by the Party, breaking free from the long-term constraints of "left" mistakes, correcting the Party's guiding ideology, re-establishing the ideological, political, and organizational lines of Marxism, and putting an end to the situation of the Party's work wavering since October 1976. It laid the foundation for exploring the path of development that suits China's national conditions and the Party's basic line, and opened a new period for China's socialist modernization construction.
After the 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, the Party carried out large-scale rectification work, step by step solving many long-standing problems and new problems that emerged in practical life since the establishment of New China. Centered around the shift of the Party's and the country's work focus to economic construction, efforts were concentrated on developing social productive forces and carrying out the theme of socialist modernization construction in China, as well as heavy construction and reform work. How to further outline the blueprint for China's reform and opening up and modernization construction, and explore the path of building socialism with Chinese characteristics, has become a new topic facing the entire Party. The convening of the 12th National Congress of the Party was precisely in this context.
In order to successfully convene this Party Congress, the Party Central Committee made preparations for over two years. As early as February 1980, the 5th Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee officially decided to convene the 12th National Congress earlier and made provisions on the main agenda, allocation principles of delegates, and selection methods.
The Plenum believed that since the 11th National Congress, especially since the 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, there have been significant changes and developments in the domestic and international situation. With the shift in the Party's work focus, the cause of socialist modernization construction has begun to embark on a path of healthy development. The political, ideological, and organizational lines of the Party determined by the 3rd and 4th Plenary Sessions have become widely popular; the ultra-leftist line pursued by Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" and their remnants have been further exposed and criticized; a large number of unjust, false, and wrong cases from history have been redressed, and the Party's policies have been widely implemented across the country. On this basis, the entire Party, army, and people are closely united around the Party Central Committee and working hard for the great cause of socialist modernization and the implementation of the guidelines for adjusting, reforming, rectifying, and improving the national economy. Progress is being made on various fronts such as agriculture, industry, finance and trade, education, science, culture, politics, national defense, and diplomacy; a stable, united, vibrant situation is developing. These facts prove that the Party Central Committee's line, principles, and policies are correct. Our country has basically transformed from the serious chaos caused by the unchecked activities of Lin Biao and the "Gang of Four" over the past ten years into a situation with leadership, order, direction, goals, favorable conditions, and confidence that has been achieved through overcoming tremendous difficulties – a great victory.
This plenum pointed out that the practice of the people of all ethnic groups in China advancing toward the Four Modernizations now presents our Party with a series of major issues that need to be promptly resolved in a timely manner, including determining the long-term development plan for the national economy, determining the economic system that suits the needs of national economic development, and determining the education plan and education system that suits the needs of national economic development. With the changes in the domestic situation, a series of important issues in the country's political and party life, as well as some important ideological and theoretical issues, also need to be resolved accordingly, in order to facilitate the development and consolidation of a stable, united, lively political situation, and to facilitate the smooth progress of modernization. In order to solve these urgent problems, the Central Committee is required to convene the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China earlier. The specific time for convening this congress will be determined by the Political Bureau of the Central Committee.
This plenary session initially decided on the main agenda for the 12th Congress. It stipulated that there would be 1600 delegates attending the 12th Congress, and each electoral unit would elect alternate delegates in a proportion of one-tenth of the number of delegates. Each province, autonomous region, directly-controlled municipality, central government agency, central state agency, headquarters and military branches of the People's Liberation Army, and major military regions will hold party congresses or representative conferences, and through sufficient deliberations and differential electoral methods, delegates will be elected through anonymous voting.
Immediately after the 5th Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, the Party Central Committee started preparations for the 12th Congress.
Regarding the election of delegates to the 12th Congress, in order to do this work well, the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee passed several opinions on the election of delegates to the 12th Congress in April 1980. According to the spirit of the resolution of the 5th Plenary Session of the CPC Central Committee, the document puts forward specific opinions on several issues related to the election of delegates, and requires party congresses or representative conferences at all levels to adhere to the principle of democratic centralism from beginning to end. Delegates attending the 12th Congress must be fully deliberated and elected through differential electoral methods with anonymous voting. Provincial and municipal party committees should strengthen leadership and hold good party congresses or representative conferences at the county and city levels. At the same time, preparations for provincial, autonomous region, and directly-controlled municipality congresses or representative conferences should be completed through sufficient deliberations, and a preliminary list of candidates for delegates to the 12th Congress should be proposed. The list of candidates for delegates should only be known to the leadership. The entire election work should fully reflect the opinions of the majority of delegates. The election work in various regions and units should be completed before the end of November.
In this document, the Political Bureau of the Central Committee also made principle provisions on the proportions of representatives from various sectors: women party members should account for about 15% of the total number of delegates; nationally renowned labor models and heroes should account for about 6%; professionals in science, culture, education, health, sports, etc. should account for about 15%; ethnic minority representatives should be no less than 5%. At the same time, it is also required that the delegates strive to be younger, with no less than two-fifths of delegates being under 55 years old.
The meeting of the Political Bureau also made a decision on "Not Appointing the Elderly Comrades Who Have Lost Work Capacity as Delegates and Candidates for Central Committee of the 12th Congress", pointing out: in order to ensure that the delegates attending this conference and the central committee members elected by the conference have a considerable proportion of comrades who are young and strong, so that the leadership of the party can meet the heavy tasks of socialist modernization construction, ensure the long-term continuity of the party's line, principles, and policies, and ensure the centralized leadership and long-term stability of the party, based on the suggestions of many older comrades and the masses inside and outside the party, and in accordance with the spirit of the 5th Plenary Session and the principles of the new Party Constitution (draft), the Central Committee has decided that elderly comrades who are already old and have lost work capacity and self-care ability shall not serve as delegates to the 12th Congress or candidates for the Central Committee. It is not difficult to see that this is an important step in abolishing the de facto lifelong tenure system for cadres and gradually renewing the leadership team.
On May 18-19, 1980, Hu Yaobang, at the conference on selecting excellent young and middle-aged cadres organized by the Central Organization Department, gave a speech on making preparations for the party congress. He pointed out that we should strive to make the 12th Congress of our party one of the best congresses since the founding of the People's Republic of China. He said: To make it the best congress, there are three main criteria: (1) The line it formulates is correct; (2) The leadership team it selects is prestigious and satisfies the majority of comrades in the Party; (3) Its methods adhere to the principles of democratic centralism and fully implement the mass line. When it comes to how the elected representatives should truly represent, Hu Yaobang requested comrades in the organizational departments to seriously study and carefully examine. If they meet the requirements, they should become representatives, but if they do not meet the requirements, they should not be forced.
It is necessary to fully prepare and truly obtain the consent of the majority of party members, not just a few people. The list is not secretive and can be discussed among party members. Do not fear change, this is also dialectics. Through convening the Party Congress, democratic practices within the party can be carried out to strengthen the party's leadership and enhance party members' education.
According to the spirit of the Communist Party's 5th Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee and relevant instructions from the central authorities, party organizations in various provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities directly under the central government, central agencies, and the People's Liberation Army have successively held party representative conferences or meetings to elect representatives to attend the 12th National Congress on schedule, completing the election work.
Another preparatory task for the 12th National Congress, that is, the preparation work for amending the party constitution, is also underway.
Starting from the winter of 1979, under the leadership of the Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee, relevant units of the central government have held several discussions with a group of cadres and conducted investigations and solicited opinions in many places across the country, resulting in a draft.
In January 1980, Deng Xiaoping put forward many important guiding opinions on amending the party constitution. Under the leadership of the Central Committee, a special group for amending the party constitution was established, with Deng Xiaoping and Hu Yaobang as the leaders, and Hu Qiaomu responsible for specific work. The original draft was repeatedly discussed and modified to form the first draft of the revision. In February 1980, it was submitted to the 5th Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee for discussion and made the first round of modifications based on the discussions at the plenary session. In April, the Central Secretariat sent it to the whole party for discussion and solicited opinions from some non-party members. In May 1980, more modifications were made. In June of the same year, it was sent to party organizations at all levels, including provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities directly under the central government, major military regions, and central party, government, and military departments, as well as all delegates attending the 12th National Congress, to solicit opinions. In July, the third round of modifications was made.
Based on the above preparations, the Politburo of the Central Committee held an expanded meeting in late July 1982 in Beijing. Over 130 central and provincial, autonomous regional, and municipal leaders attended the meeting. The meeting discussed some important issues related to the 12th National Congress.
On August 6, 1982, the CPC Central Committee held the 7th Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee. The meeting was attended by 185 Central Committee members, 112 alternate members, and 21 attendees. The meeting was chaired by members of the Political Bureau Standing Committee, including Hu Yaobang, Ye Jianying, Deng Xiaoping, Zhao Ziyang, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun, and Hua Guofeng.
At this plenary session, it was decided to convene the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China on September 1st and publicly announced to the entire party and people nationwide the restoration of the good tradition of completely opening their own congresses in front of the Chinese people, just like what was done in the 8th National Congress, and abandoning the secretive approach used in the 9th National Congress. The plenary session reviewed and approved the report of the Central Committee on the 12th National Congress and the "China Communist Party Constitution (Draft Amendment)", and decided to submit these two documents for deliberation at the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party.
On August 30, the preparatory meeting for the 12th National Congress was held in Beijing. The conference determined four agenda items for the congress, elected a 12-member Presidium composed of 252 people, and elected Zhao Ziyang as the Secretary-General of the conference. Hu Yaobang proposed at the meeting that the task of the Twelve Congress is to make a victorious summary of the great historical turning points achieved in the six years since the defeat of the "Gang of Four," especially since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee. At the same time, it will determine the grand goals and battle tasks of the party in the new period, so that our party can lead the people of all nationalities in the country to strive for the creation of a new situation in socialist modernization with a new appearance and strong combat effectiveness. The conference passed the "Decision on Confirming the Additions to the Central Committee at the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee and the Fourth Plenary Session". The Presidium of the conference selected a Standing Committee of the Presidium composed of 31 people, including Hu Yaobang, Ye Jianying, Deng Xiaoping, Zhao Ziyang, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun, Hua Guofeng, Xu Xiangqian, Nie Rongzhen, Peng Zhen, Deng Yingchao, etc., and passed the examination report made by Song Renqiong on behalf of the Credentials Review Committee of the Twelfth Congress, and passed the conference agenda. At this point, all the preparations for the Twelfth Congress of the Party have been successfully completed.
2. The Twelfth National Congress of the Communist Party of China is held.
From September 1 to 11, 1982, the Twelfth National Congress of the Communist Party of China was held in Beijing with great solemnity. The conference was attended by 1545 formal delegates and 145 alternate delegates, representing more than 39 million party members. The main agenda of the conference includes three items: (1) deliberating and approving the report of the Central Committee, and determining the guidelines for fully opening up a new era of socialist modernization construction; (2) deliberating and approving the new Constitution of the Communist Party of China; (3) according to the provisions of the new Constitution, electing a new Central Committee, Central Advisory Commission, and Central Commission for Discipline Inspection.
The conference was presided over by the Presidium and the Standing Committee of the Presidium. Representatives of various democratic parties and non-party democratic individuals were invited to the opening ceremony. Deng Xiaoping, the executive chairman of the conference, delivered the opening speech.
In the opening speech, Deng Xiaoping reviewed the history since the Seventh Congress of the Party and explained the important historical position of the Twelfth Congress. He said, "The Seventh National Congress of the Communist Party of China held under the leadership of Comrade Mao Zedong in 1945 was the most important congress of our party during the period of democratic revolution after the party was founded. That congress summarized the historical experience of the twists and turns in our country's democratic revolution for more than 20 years, formulated correct guidelines and strategies, overcame erroneous ideas within the party, unified the understanding of the whole party based on Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, and achieved unprecedented unity of the whole party. That congress laid the foundation for the victory of the new democratic revolution nationwide." "Since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, our party has resumed correct policies in various fields of economy, politics, and culture, and has studied new situations and experiences, formulating a series of new correct policies. Compared with the Eighth Congress, our party now has a much deeper understanding of the laws of socialist construction in our country, and has gained much more experience. The consciousness and firmness in implementing our correct guidelines have been greatly strengthened. With ample grounds, we believe that the correct guidelines formulated by this congress will surely fully open up a new era of socialist modernization construction, make our party prosperous and strong, make our socialist cause prosperous and strong, and make our country and all nationalities prosperous and strong."
In this opening speech, Deng Xiaoping also summarized the party’s historical experience and put forward the guiding ideology of taking the road of socialism with Chinese characteristics. He proposed, "Our modernization construction must start from China's reality. Whether in revolution or construction, we must pay attention to learning from and drawing on foreign experience. However, copying foreign experience or foreign models can never achieve success. We have learned many lessons in this regard. We must combine the universal truth of Marxism with China's specific reality, follow our own path, and build socialism with Chinese characteristics. This is the basic conclusion derived from summarizing our long-term historical experience." This basic conclusion is an accurate understanding and application of the objective laws of socialist construction in our country by the Communist Party of China. It is also the concentrated expression of the will, wishes, and requirements of all ethnic groups in our country. China's reform, opening up, and modernization construction have achieved great achievements and success under this ideological guidance.
In his speech, Deng Xiaoping accurately assessed the situation and proposed three major tasks facing the Chinese people in the 1980s: intensifying socialist modernization, striving for reunification of the motherland including Taiwan, opposing hegemonism, and safeguarding world peace. Among these tasks, the core is economic construction, as it forms the foundation for resolving international and domestic issues. Deng emphasized that in the coming long period, at least the next twenty years until the end of the 20th century, we need to focus on four key areas: carrying out institutional and economic system reforms, revolutionizing the cadre team by making it younger, more knowledgeable, and specialized; building socialist spiritual civilization; combating criminal activities that undermine socialism in the economic and other fields; and consolidating the party's style and organization based on a thorough study of the new party constitution. These are the most important guarantees for adhering to the socialist path and concentrating our efforts on modernization.
At the 12th Party Congress, Hu Yaobang delivered a political report titled "Fully Opening up a New Phase of Socialist Modernization Construction". The report comprised six parts: (1) Historical changes and new major tasks; (2) Promoting comprehensive growth of the socialist economy; (3) Striving to build a highly developed socialist spiritual civilization; (4) Striving to build a highly developed socialist democracy; (5) Upholding an independent foreign policy; (6) Strengthening the party as a strong core leading the socialist modernization cause.
The report reviewed the Party's journey since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee and the significant achievements across various fronts, while outlining the Party's overall tasks in the new historical period. These tasks are as follows: uniting all ethnic groups in the country, relying on our own efforts, working hard, and gradually achieving modernization in industry, agriculture, national defense, and science and technology, thus constructing our country into a highly civilized and highly democratic socialist state. Over the course of the five years between this congress and the next, we must vigorously promote the construction of both material and spiritual civilization of socialism based on the requirements of the overall task mentioned above. We should continue to improve socialist democracy and the legal system, conscientiously rectify the party's style and organization, and strive for fundamental improvement in the national financial and economic situation. At the same time, we need to work together with all patriotic people, including our compatriots in Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macau, and overseas, to promote the great cause of national reunification. Furthermore, we must join hands with people all over the world to continue the struggle against imperialism, hegemonism, and for the maintenance of world peace.
Based on the actual conditions of our country and around the overall task, the report formulates strategic goals, strategic priorities, and a series of policy guidelines for China's economic construction. The report states that among the various tasks in fully opening up a new phase, the primary task is to continue pushing forward the socialist modernization of our economy and promote overall growth of the socialist economy. From 1981 to the end of the 20th century, the overall goal of our economic construction struggle is to strive for the total annual output value of industry and agriculture to double, from 710 billion yuan in 1980 to around 2.8 trillion yuan in 2000, while constantly improving economic efficiency. To achieve these strategic goals, it is important to address the issues of agriculture, energy, transportation, education, and science, considering them as strategic priorities. By solving these problems on a balanced basis, it will be possible to promote rapid growth in consumer goods production, drive the development of the entire industry and other areas of production and construction, and ensure the improvement of people's livelihoods.
To achieve the 20-year goal, the strategic deployment will be implemented in two steps: the first ten years will mainly establish a solid foundation, accumulate strength, and create conditions; the second ten years will usher in a new period of economic revitalization. This important decision was made by the Central Committee of the Party after a comprehensive analysis of China's economic situation and development trends. During the sixth Five-Year Plan period from 1981 to 1985, we must continue to resolutely implement the guidelines of adjustment, reform, rectification, and improvement, practice thrift, oppose waste, and shift all economic work towards focusing on economic efficiency. To concentrate efforts on adjusting various aspects of the economic structure, consolidate and improve the preliminary reforms that have been implemented in the economic management system, and urgently formulate the overall plan and implementation steps for the reforms. During the seventh Five-Year Plan period from 1986 to 1990, extensive technological transformation of enterprises should be carried out, and reforms of the economic management system should be gradually launched. At the same time, rationalization of enterprise organizational structure and various aspects of the economic structure should be completed. In the 1980s, a series of necessary basic construction in energy, transportation, and other areas, as well as a series of major scientific and technological projects, must be undertaken. As long as we effectively accomplish the above tasks, we can solve historical problems and lay a solid foundation for economic growth in the next decade. China's economic development in the 1990s will definitely be much faster than in the 1980s, and China's economy will enter a period of rapid growth in all aspects.
The report highly affirms the significance and role of constructing socialist spiritual civilization and emphasizes the need to strive for building socialist spiritual civilization. The report points out that while constructing a high level of material civilization, we must also strive to build a high level of socialist spiritual civilization. This is a strategic policy issue for socialist construction. Socialist historical experience and the current situation in our country tell us that whether we adhere to this policy will be related to the rise and fall, success and failure of socialism. The relationship between spiritual civilization and material civilization in socialist construction is very close. The construction of material civilization is an indispensable foundation for the construction of socialist spiritual civilization. Socialist spiritual civilization not only plays a huge role in promoting the construction of material civilization but also guarantees its correct direction of development. The construction of the two civilizations is mutually conditional and mutually desired. The report points out: Building socialist spiritual civilization is not an easy task, especially today. We must make the greatest efforts to adapt to the new conditions and circumstances of the construction period, and carry out the construction of socialist spiritual civilization conscientiously, inspiring the masses with revolutionary thoughts and spirit to construct socialism with great enthusiasm.
The report also points out that building a high level of socialist democracy is one of our fundamental goals and tasks. The report emphasizes that we must continue to reform and improve the country's political and leadership systems in accordance with the principles of democratic centralism, and expand socialist democracy to all aspects of political, economic, cultural, and social life. Develop democratic management in various enterprises and institutions, develop grassroots social self-governance, and closely integrate the construction of socialist democracy with the construction of socialist legal system, institutionalizing and legalizing socialist democracy.
Regarding our country's foreign policy, the report points out: Combining patriotism with internationalism has always been the fundamental starting point for us in handling foreign relations. We adhere to an independent foreign policy. China's foreign policy is based on the scientific theories of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought. It starts from the fundamental interests of the Chinese people and the people of the world. It has long-term and overall strategic basis and will never yield to temporary events or be influenced and incited by anyone. Under any circumstances, we will never seek hegemony. At the same time, the report also points out that our Party adheres to developing relations with communist parties and other working-class parties of all countries based on Marxism, according to the principles of independence, complete equality, mutual respect, and non-interference in internal affairs. Parties of all countries should respect and help each other. China should make a significant contribution to the world.
The report emphasizes the need to build the Party into a strong core for leading the socialist modernization cause. In order to strengthen the Party's construction in the new era, the Twelfth National Congress made many fundamental and significant amendments to the Party Constitution of the Eleventh National Congress. The general principles of modifying the Party constitution are to adapt to the characteristics and needs of the new era, put forward more stringent requirements for Party members, improve the fighting capacity of Party organizations, and uphold and improve the Party's leadership. The new Party constitution eliminates the "Left" mistakes in the Party constitution of the Eleventh National Congress and inherits and develops the advantages of the Party constitutions of the Seventh and Eighth National Congresses. The report pointed out that in order to make the Party the core force leading the socialist modernization construction, it is necessary to improve the Party's democratic centralism, improve the leadership structure and cadres system, realize the revolutionization, youthfulness, intellectualization, and professionalization of the cadres, and strengthen the Party's work among workers, peasants, and intellectuals, and closely connect with the masses. In three years, a planned and systematic Party reorganization should be carried out to fundamentally improve the Party's style.
Hu Yaobang's report focuses on the construction of socialism with Chinese characteristics as the center, and outlines a blueprint for achieving this grand goal from various aspects such as politics, economy, culture, diplomacy, and Party building. Through the combination of theory and practice, Hu's report resolves a series of major issues in China's socialist revolution and construction and has attracted strong reactions from all aspects. From September 2nd to 4th, the delegates attending the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC) spent three days in a heated discussion on the report. Everyone spoke their minds freely and the atmosphere of the meeting was very lively.
On the afternoon of September 5th, the Presidium of the Congress held a meeting. Hu Qiaomu, Deputy Secretary-General of the Congress, explained the suggestions and opinions put forward by the delegates during the group discussions on the report of the 11th Central Committee of the CPC and the draft of the Party Constitution, as well as the modifications made based on these suggestions and opinions. The meeting approved the draft resolution on the report of the 11th Central Committee of the CPC and the draft resolution on the Party Constitution, and decided to submit these two draft resolutions to the Congress for approval. The meeting also decided to submit the list of candidates for the Central Committee, the Central Advisory Committee, and the Central Discipline Inspection Committee proposed by the Presidium for discussion by all delegates, and approved the election methods for these three committees to be submitted for the Congress' deliberation.
On the afternoon of September 6th, a plenary session was held. The Congress adopted a resolution on the report of the 12th Central Committee and approved the report made by Hu Yaobang on behalf of the 11th Central Committee. The resolution of the Congress stated, "The correct line, principles, and policies since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee have been effective in their work." "The correct outline and a series of guidelines and policies put forward in the report for comprehensively opening up a new phase of socialist modernization construction should be the basic basis for the Party's future work." The Congress also adopted the Party Constitution proposed by the 11th Central Committee and a resolution on this constitution. The resolution called on the Party to organize a serious study of the Party Constitution, make efforts to ensure that all Party members truly understand the general principles and provisions of the Party Constitution, and elevate the understanding of all Party members, especially cadres and Party members, so as to fully prepare for the comprehensive rectification of the Party's style and organization, and make the Party a strong core leading the socialist modernization construction.
Ye Jianying and Chen Yun delivered speeches at the Congress on the 6th, expressing their support for Deng Xiaoping's opening speech, Hu Yaobang's political report, and the Party Constitution of the CPC, and emphasizing the significance and principles of cooperation and alternation between new and old cadres. Ye Jianying said, "Our Party is a vibrant party. After this Congress, a group of young and capable comrades will take up leadership positions in the central and other leadership positions. This is an important symbol of the prosperity and development of the Party's cause. Our older comrades, seeing this situation, cannot help but feel joy." At the same time, he quoted the line from Tang Dynasty poet Li Shangyin, "The young phoenix sings more clearly than the old phoenix," to praise the young comrades sincerely and express his "hope that the young comrades who have just taken up their positions will cooperate closely with the old comrades, shoulder heavy responsibilities, and bravely move forward," surpassing the older comrades; and hopes that the retired old comrades will not retreat in their thinking and will continue to contribute to the Party and the people's interests in their practical actions, continuing to do work within their capabilities.
Chen Yun analyzed the situation of the Party's cadre team and explained the significance and principles of cooperation and alternation between new and old cadres. He said, "Solving the handover problem of cadres is an important task facing the whole Party. To solve this problem, firstly, old cadres must gradually withdraw from the leadership team. The old comrades who temporarily stay on the front line must handle major issues well and promote succession planning." He emphasized the need to promote thousands of young and middle-aged cadres to enter leadership positions at all levels. He emphasized, "We must promote thousands of cadres, instead of just a few dozen or a few hundred." Only in this way can there be enough cadres to replace the work of the old cadres. However, "those who followed Lin Biao and Jiang Qing in rebelling during the 'Cultural Revolution', those with serious clique mentality, and those who engaged in vandalism and looting, none of these 'three types of people' can be promoted, and those who have been promoted must be resolutely removed from the leadership team." He said, on one hand, we must promote boldly, and on the other hand, we must ensure political integrity. When comparing moral character and abilities, we need to pay more attention to moral character. In other words, we need to truly promote those who have a strong party spirit, a proper work style, and the courage to adhere to principles. He believes that as long as we solve the handover problem of the cadre team, our Party's cause will surely have successors.
On the morning of September 9th, the Presidium held a meeting to establish the official list of candidates for the three committees based on the preliminary selection results, and also passed the draft resolution on the work report of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission. In the afternoon, each delegation held group meetings to discuss the list of candidates proposed by the Presidium.
From October 10th to the morning of the 11th, the plenary session was held to conduct the election of members of the Central Committee and members of the Central Advisory Committee. After thorough preparation, the plenary session democratically elected 210 members of the Central Committee and 138 alternate members, forming a new Central Committee. Among these 348 Central Committee members and alternate members, 211 were newly elected, accounting for 65% of the total. There were 171 members below the age of 60, accounting for 49.1% of the total. There were 122 members with a college degree, accounting for 35.1% of the total. In terms of knowledge and specialization, there was a significant improvement compared to the previous Central Committee. The Central Committee retained eight revered elder revolutionaries, including Ye Jianying, Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun, Xu Xiangqian, Nie Rongzhen, Peng Zhen, and Deng Yingchao, who had high prestige both domestically and internationally. At the same time, the Central Advisory Committee, which had never been established in the party's history, was newly formed, with 172 members elected. These members had over 40 years of party membership, made significant contributions to the party, and had rich leadership experience. The Central Discipline Inspection Commission elected 133 members.
The establishment of these three committees reflects Deng Xiaoping's "Reform of the Party and State Leadership System," which calls for the establishment of three committees and further implementation of the principle of alternating old and new cadres. It provides reliable organizational guarantees for strengthening and improving the party's leadership, for long-term stability of the party and the country, and for achieving a new phase of comprehensive socialist construction.
On September 11th, the 12th National Congress concluded, and Li Xiannian delivered the closing speech. He highly praised Hu Yaobang's report, the new party constitution, and the achievements of the congress. He called for the wide and in-depth promotion and study of the spirit of the 12th National Congress, and the implementation of practical measures to steadily achieve our great goals.
From September 12th to the 13th, the 12th Central Committee held its first plenary session. Hu Yaobang and Zhao Ziyang presided over the meeting. The plenary session elected Wan Li, Xi Zhongxun, Wang Zhen, Wei Guoqing, Ulanhu, Fang Yi, Deng Xiaoping, Deng Yingchao, Ye Jianying, Li Xiannian, Li Desheng, Yang Shangkun, Yang Dezhi, Yu Qiuli, Song Renqiong, Zhang Tingfa, Chen Yun, Zhao Ziyang, Hu Qiaomu, Hu Yaobang, Nie Rongzhen, Ni Zhifu, Xu Xiangqian, Peng Zhen, and Liao Chengzhi as members of the Central Political Bureau, and elected Yao Yilin, Qin Jiwei, and Chen Muhan as alternate members of the Central Political Bureau.
Hu Yaobang, Ye Jianying, Deng Xiaoping, Zhao Ziyang, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun were elected as members of the Standing Committee of the Central Political Bureau.
Election of Hu Yaobang as the General Secretary of the Central Committee, Wan Li, Xi Zhongxun, Deng Liqun, Yang Yong, Yu Qiuli, Gu Mu, Chen Pixian, Hu Qili, and Yao Yilin as Secretaries of the Central Secretariat, Qiao Shi and Hao Jianxiu as Alternate Secretaries.
The plenum decided that Deng Xiaoping should be the Chairman of the Central Military Commission, with Ye Jianying, Xu Xiangqian, and Nie Rongzhen as Vice Chairmen, and Yang Shangkun as Executive Vice Chairman.
The plenum approved that Deng Xiaoping should be the Director of the Central Advisory Committee, with Bo Yibo, Xu Shiyou, Tan Zhenlin, and Li Weihan as Vice Directors, and Wang Ping and 24 others as Executive Committee members. It also approved Chen Yun as the First Secretary of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission, Huang Kecheng as the Second Secretary, Wang Heshou as the Executive Secretary, and Wang Congwu, Han Guang, Li Chang, Ma Guorui, and Han Tianshi as Secretaries. Ma Guorui and Han Tianshi, along with 11 others, were designated as Executive Committee members.
The 12th National Party Congress was a very important meeting, with significant historical achievements and significance in the history of the Party and the socialist construction in our country.
3. The main contributions and historical significance of the 12th National Party Congress
This congress explicitly put forward the proposition of "building socialism with Chinese characteristics." Deng Xiaoping's theory of socialism with Chinese characteristics has had great guiding significance for our country's reform and opening-up and socialist modernization.
First, the 12th National Party Congress successfully achieved the transition between the old and new leadership of the Party. Resolving the issue of the transition between old and new cadres, and achieving the revolutionary, youthful, knowledgeable, and professionalization of cadres as soon as possible, was one of the main topics of the 12th National Party Congress. From the history of the international communist movement, the issue of the handover of leadership at the top of the Party has always been a major event concerning the future and destiny of the Party and the country, but it is also a problem that has not been well resolved and has had painful lessons. The 12th National Party Congress actively and effectively explored this issue.
Second, the congress formulated and passed a new Party Charter. The Party Charter is the fundamental law of the Party. Our Party has attached great importance to amending and formulating the Party Charter in every representative congress. The 12th National Party Congress, in order to make the Party a strong core in leading the socialist modernization construction, and to significantly improve the political quality and fighting capacity of the entire Party, formulated a new Party Charter with distinctive characteristics. Its characteristics are as follows: it has a relatively substantial "general outline," which succinctly summarizes the nature of the Party and its overall tasks, and makes Marxist provisions on how the Party should correctly play its leadership role in national life; it sets higher requirements for Party members and cadres in terms of ideology, politics, and organization compared to previous Party Charters; based on historical experience and lessons, the new Party Charter emphasizes that all levels of organizations, from the central to the grassroots, must strictly adhere to the principles of democratic centralism and collective leadership, and clearly stipulates: "any form of personality cult is prohibited." It makes many new provisions for improving the organizational structure of the Party's central and local organizations, strengthening Party discipline and the disciplinary inspection organs, and building grassroots Party organizations. The new Party Charter passed by the 12th National Party Congress embodies the wisdom of the entire Party and is formulated based on the Party's historical experience.
Third, the 12th National Party Congress enriched and developed Marxism on certain theoretical issues. Regarding the issue of the basic characteristics of socialism, the congress report of the 12th National Party Congress proposed that a new content, namely, socialist spiritual civilization and highly advanced socialist democracy, should be included. This way, the basic characteristics of socialism include not only the relations of production and the productive forces but also the superstructure and ideology, making them more comprehensive and complete. Regarding the issue of the structure of socialist ownership, the congress report of the 12th National Party Congress pointed out that state-owned economy occupies a dominant position in the national economy as a whole but, for a long period, a variety of forms need to coexist. Regarding the issue of socialist planning and the market, previous discussions often emphasized planning and excluded the market. The 12th National Party Congress put forward the principle of giving priority to planned economy and regulating it with the market. Under this principle, the scope and boundaries of directive planning, guiding planning, and market regulation should be correctly defined. In the issue of class struggle during the socialist era, the 12th Party Congress report put forward that after the elimination of the exploiting class as a class, most of the contradictions existing in our society do not have the nature of class struggle. Class struggle is no longer the principal contradiction in our society, but class struggle will still exist in a certain scope and may intensify under certain conditions. In addition, the 12th Party Congress report also provides new explanations on issues such as the construction of spiritual civilization and party building. These new understandings enrich and develop the treasure trove of Marxist theory.
Fourth, the 12th Party Congress scientifically summarized the Party's historical experience, formulated grand goals and a more complete series of correct principles, policies, and measures to create a new phase of socialist construction based on the current situation in our country. It established the Party's overall tasks and general line for the new historical period. It simultaneously ranks economic construction, political construction, and ideological and cultural construction as the objectives of socialist construction, which is the first time in the history of socialist construction in our country and a pioneering move in the international communist movement. The 12th Party Congress fully initiated a new phase of socialist modernization construction in our country. After the 12th Party Congress, China's reform and opening up and the cause of socialist modernization construction entered a period of vigorous development.
II. The formulation of the economic system reform agenda and the comprehensive launch of the reform and opening up
With the advancement of rural and urban economic reforms, the content of the reform has greatly exceeded the original scope of developing commodity production and exchange. It has increasingly revealed the orientation of developing a commodity economy and market regulation, further touching upon the core of the planned economic command system. This has exposed some deeper contradictions and problems, leading to intense debates. The focus of the debate is whether China's current economy is a commodity economy and whether an economic system adapted to a commodity economy should be established.
1. The clash over the theory of "socialist commodity economy"
At that time, many people believed that the socialist economy is a planned economy, not a commodity economy. Since it is a planned economy, the economic system should be compatible with a planned economy. This opinion is, of course, in a morally advantageous position because, in the eyes of many, there are already a large number of discussions in Marxist classics. By quoting the words of the "forefathers," one already has sharp theoretical weapons. The argument that "socialism is a commodity economy" cannot withstand a refutation.
However, both before and after the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, many economists insisted on the concept of a "commodity economy." Going back earlier, in 1959, Wang Xuewen and Qi Qi jointly published an article in Economic Research, proposing "a planned development of the commodity economy." After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, in the spring of 1979, Zhuo Jiong, an old generation of economists in Guangdong, wrote an article that decisively stated: "Abandon a planned economy and develop a commodity economy." In the same year, at a symposium on socialist economic value law held in Wuxi, Hu Zhaopei, a professor at Xiamen University, clearly stated the viewpoint that "the socialist economy is a planned commodity economy based on public ownership." In 1979, Deng Liqun, Vice President of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, published an article in Finance and Trade Economics advocating that the current stage of the socialist economy is a commodity economy.
In October 1979, the Preliminary Opinions on the Overall Plan for Economic System Reform issued by the Reform Small Group of the State Council's Finance and Economics Commission explicitly stated: China's current stage of socialist economy is a commodity economy with the dominance of public ownership of the means of production and the coexistence of multiple economic components. An economic system adapted to it must be established. Although this statement has added two attributes before it, it clearly states that establishing an economic system compatible with the commodity economy is the goal of the reform. According to Professor Yang Qixian, who participated in the drafting, this statement was added by Xu Muqiao.
During this period, Chen Yun was also contemplating how to reform the planned economic system. In March 1979, he summarized in the "Outline of Plan and Market Issues": "The main shortcomings in the planning systems of the Soviet Union and China for the past sixty years are that there is only 'planned proportionality' and there is no requirement for market regulation under the socialist system. The so-called market regulation refers to the adjustment according to the law of value. In certain aspects of economic life, it can be regulated by the methods of 'non-government' and 'blind' production." This was the earliest expression within the party of the need for market regulation under the planned economic system, and throughout the 1980s, the discussion of the relationship between planning and market, and their respective proportions, became the mainstream discourse within the party and the theoretical community. In 1981, Chen Yun summarized this expression as "planned economy as the mainstay, market regulation as the supplement."
The debate between the economic and ideological circles regarding planned economy versus commodity economy has been ongoing. However, in 1982, the situation underwent a sudden change. In early May of that year, the National Economic System Reform Office (later renamed the Economic System Reform Commission in 1983) and the Economic Center of the State Council jointly held a large-scale seminar to discuss theoretical issues related to economic reform. The seminar was divided into eight groups, with over two hundred participants. The main theme of this seminar was to affirm planned economy and consider it as the socialist economic system. Although some scholars pointed out that commodity economy is a theoretical generalization of real-life, and that commodity production and exchange are the fundamental elements of commodity economy without essential differences, the dominant opinion believed that while commodity production and exchange exist in socialist society, it does not mean that there is a commodity economy.
Since no new theoretical progress was made, the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, held in September 1982, emphasized the principle of "planned economy as the mainstay, market regulation as the supplement" in its political report, stating: "China implements a planned economy on the basis of public ownership. Planned production and circulation are the mainstay of China's national economy." "For the production and distribution of production materials and consumer goods that are related to the national economy in state-owned enterprises, especially for key backbone enterprises that affect the overall economy, mandatory planning must be implemented... For collectively owned enterprises, some mandatory targets should also be issued according to needs."
The 12th National Congress confirmed that China still implements planned economy and must implement mandatory planning and targets, which was an inevitable stage of understanding during the initial phase of China's reform when they were "crossing the river by feeling the stones." In this situation, the theory of "commodity economy" naturally fell into an awkward position. In 1982 and 1983, criticisms of the terms "socialist commodity economy" and "planned commodity economy" increasingly intensified in newspapers.
Some scholars believed that "as the basic characteristic of the socialist economy, it should be a planned economy, not a commodity economy." "The starting point of a planned commodity economy is still a commodity economy. The concept of 'planned' is abstract; since planned economy no longer exists, where does the concept of 'planned' come from?"
Other scholars believed that "if we generalize our economy as a commodity economy, it will blur the essential differences between socialist economy and capitalist economy." "The essential characteristic of a socialist economy can only be a planned economy... Demeaning the socialist economy to a 'commodity economy' can only be a historical regression. In fact, without planned economy, there can be no socialism." 
Of course, there were also scholars who believed that considering the presence or absence of mandatory planning as an important criterion for distinguishing between socialist planned economy and capitalist market economy was correct.
For a time, newspapers and public opinions were filled with strong criticisms against the theory of "commodity economy." Xue Muqiao, who advocated the theory of "commodity economy," was even criticized for having "the vices of intellectuals." After intense criticism, Xue Muqiao finally made concessions and proposed that "the most important characteristic of a socialist economy is not the commodity economy, but a planned economy based on public ownership of the means of production, with the existence of commodity production and exchange." 
On September 6, 1982, Liu Guoguang, an economist at the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences, published an article titled "Adhering to the Basic Direction of Economic System Reform" in the People's Daily, emphasizing the importance of guiding plans and relatively reducing the scope of command plans. On September 21, the People's Daily, on behalf of the commentator, published a long article on the front page criticizing Liu Guoguang without naming him. 
The article repeatedly emphasized the importance of command plans, stating that "the use of the market is not equal to market regulation" and argued that "command plans are not only necessary in specific situations when the national economy is adjusting, but also necessary for the production and distribution of products that are vital to the nation's economy, as well as for the operation of backbone enterprises under general conditions. In fact, it is the key to the principle of planned economy as the mainstay and market regulation as the supplement." Liu Guoguang's article was submitted to the People's Daily before the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China and was published just before the Congress, contradicting the spirit of the political report of the Congress. From autumn 1982 to 1983, the forces defending command plans were quite strong. Deng Liqun, who had advocated for the "commodity economy" in an article written in 1979, also joined the ranks of criticizing the commodity economy.
In fact, the reason for the high-profile criticism of the commodity economy in 1982 and 1983 was largely due to a macro interpretation of China's economy after the 12th National Congress, namely the relationship between market regulation and planned economy, which was likened to the relationship between a bird and a cage. If the bird represents a vibrant economy, then the cage is the national plan. An active economy and market regulation can only play a role within the scope of planned permission and cannot be separated from the guidance of the plan. This is equivalent to saying that the ongoing reform of state-owned enterprises is a "reform within the cage." Another political background was the anti-"spiritual pollution" campaign in 1983. At that time, some people criticized the advocacy of the "commodity economy theory" as "spiritual pollution". Fortunately, this deviation was quickly corrected by the central government. The process of China's reform always unfolds in the midst of "mountains and rivers with no way out" and opens up new horizons of "a bright village amidst dark green willows." While the criticism of the commodity economy was at its peak, a new situation was brewing.
2. Differences and Breakthroughs in the Reform of the Plan Management System
In 1983, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council prepared to advance the strategy of "macro reforms first" comprehensively. Where should the starting point for macro reforms be? It was chosen in the "command system of the planned economy system," which is the plan management system. As the plan management system controls the overall situation of the planned economy system, reforming the plan management system first becomes the starting point for advancing the strategy of "macro reforms first" comprehensively.
From August to December 1983, under the leadership of the Secretariat of the CPC Central Committee, the Reform Leadership Group for the Plan Management System was established, and a working group for the reform of the plan management system was set up. The main members of the working group were from the State Planning Commission and the State Council's Reform Commission, with an office located in the southern district guardhouse in Zhongnanhai. The task of the working group for the reform of the plan management system was to propose reform plans. This work was carried out from August to December 1983, but due to divergent opinions and significant differences between different views, most of the time was spent on debates.
In the great debate, two representative opinions stood out:
The first opinion is that state-owned enterprises should expand their autonomy in production and management, expand the scope of market regulation, and implement profit and loss responsibility. This requires reducing the scope of directive plans and corresponding pricing of state-priced products.
The second opinion mainly emphasizes two points: (1) All important products related to the national economy, whether they are in shortage or surplus, should be subject to directive planning. The scope of directive planning should not be reduced. (2) State-owned enterprises cannot implement profit and loss responsibility or relative profit and loss responsibility. The reason is that if state-owned enterprises implement profit and loss responsibility, they will not be willing to accept low-priced directive production plans and product allocation plans.
The debate is very intense and in-depth. Economist Wang Zhuo, who participated in this discussion, also recalled several incidents that occurred during the discussion process:
The first incident was when Népszabadság, known as the father of Hungarian reform, visited our country. When he visited the State Planning Commission, some people from the Commission asked him: Did Hungary truly abolish the directive planning? Some of the people present clearly expressed doubts about this. When Népszabadság visited the Ministry of Materials and other ministries, some units also raised similar questions, revealing doubts about Hungary's abolition of directive planning. Népszabadság was deeply puzzled by this and when he went to the State Council's Office for Economic Reform, he asked: Why don't some of your ministries believe in Hungary's reform of abolishing directive planning? He expressed regret about this! This incident shows that at that time, the various ministries of the central government generally disagreed with the reform of reducing the scope of directive planning, let alone canceling it.
The second incident occurred during a reporting meeting attended by leaders of a ministry. A person specifically mentioned that Wang Zhuo had proposed the argument of commodity production during the discussion. At that time, anyone who advocated the development of commodity production was considered a heretic. Wang Zhuo was about to speak in response. Liao Jili, from the State Council's Office for Economic Reform, immediately protected Wang Zhuo and said, "That's not the case," and countered the attacking opinion of that comrade. Wang Zhuo didn't need to speak anymore.
The third incident occurred at the same meeting when a somewhat famous economist spoke against the reform of reducing the scope of directive planning. After the meeting, some comrades had various discussions and accused him of being a verbal reformist who changes his original argument as soon as the "political winds" shift.
The fourth incident was that several different opinions discussed within the planning management system reform working group, which were initially meant to be internal discussions, were later known to comrades outside the group. Based on this, someone from the Central Party Policy Research Office wrote a letter to the leading comrades of the Party Central Committee, saying that there are people rekindling the debate on directive planning.
