This was originally a debate on reform issues, but it was painted with a political color, preventing this beneficial debate from achieving the expected results.
After several months of work, the planning management system reform working group finally produced a draft document that compromised between the two opinions. After the meeting, it was revised multiple times but ultimately failed to become a decent document. However, the macro-strategy for reform has not failed, and the "Great Debate" has not ended. In 1984, this Chinese reform project continued and achieved breakthrough results. This was the "Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Economic System Reform" passed at the Third Plenary Session of the 12th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on October 20, 1984. This decision recognized for the first time that China was implementing a "planned commodity economy."
3. Drafting and Adoption of the "Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Economic System Reform"
The members of the drafting group of the "Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Economic System Reform" were selected from the team responsible for drafting the government work report of the Sixth National People's Congress. They included Yuan Mu, Gao Shangquan, Gui Shipu, Wang Renzhi, Xie Minggan, Yang Qixian, and others. Yuan Mu initially took charge and drafted an outline. The outline was discussed multiple times, but it always remained within the circle of "planned economy as the mainstay, market regulation as the supplement." At this point, some of them believed that in order to break free from this circle, there had to be a breakthrough in the issue of a commodity economy, specifically changing the target model of reform from "planned economy as the mainstay, market regulation as the supplement" to "planned commodity economy." However, there were divergent opinions within the drafting group on this issue.
In July and August 1984, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China held a meeting in Beidaihe. Under the leadership of Hu Yaobang, the drafting group discussed the outline twice. Hu Yaobang was not satisfied with the outline. He emphasized repeatedly that this was a historic document and must be well-written. He also stated that the opinions of Zhao Ziyang on economic issues had to be considered, and proposed including the development of multiple economic elements. Hu Yaobang strengthened the drafting group by adding Lin Jianqing, Lin Zili, Gong Yuzhi, Zheng Bijian, and others. Lin Jianqing took over as the leader from Yuan Mu.
After returning from Beidaihe to Yubei Mountain in Beijing, both Hu Yaobang and Zhao Ziyang separately presided over discussions. When discussing the relationship between planning and the market, Zhao Ziyang said, "I am inclined to write about a planned commodity economy." During this period, many people made suggestions to Zhao Ziyang. For example, in August, more than ten economists such as Dong Fuchu, Tong Dalin, and Yu Guangyuan held a conference at Beijing Baiwanzhuang, strongly advocating for the inclusion of the term "planned commodity economy." They wrote a conference brief to Zhao Ziyang, stating their reasons. It can be seen that Zhao Ziyang's preliminary establishment of the term "planned commodity economy" took into account opinions from various sources.
Zhao Ziyang also convened the drafting group for two discussions in Zhongnanhai. During the last discussion, in addition to the members of the drafting group, Deng Liqun was also invited. Zhao Ziyang asked everyone, "Are there any theoretical problems?" Yang Qixian replied, "Theoretically, it holds up." Zhao Ziyang asked again, "Is there any contradiction with the constitution?" Zheng Bijian replied, "There is no contradiction." "There is no mention in the constitution of 'planned economy as the mainstay, with market regulation as auxiliary'." Zhao Ziyang announced the adjournment of the meeting, and people stood up to prepare to leave. Zhao Ziyang asked Deng Liqun, "Old Deng, what do you think?" Deng Liqun replied, "I proposed this back in 1979." Sometimes the details of history are thought-provoking.
On September 9th, Zhao Ziyang wrote letters to Hu Yaobang, Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian, and Chen Yun, suggesting that China's economic system be summarized as follows:
(1) China implements a planned economy, not a market economy.
(2) Spontaneous and blind production and exchange regulated by the market are limited to small commodities, three types of agricultural and sideline products, and service and repair industries, which play a complementary role in the overall national economy.
(3) Planned economy does not mean that command planning is dominant. Both command planning and guiding planning are specific forms of planned economy... In the current and future a considerable period of time, our policy should be to gradually reduce command planning and expand guiding planning.
(4) Guiding planning mainly uses economic means for regulation, and command planning must also consider the role of economic laws, especially the law of value. The socialist economy is a planned commodity economy based on public ownership. Planning must be realized through the law of value and rely on the law of value to serve planning. The expression "planning first, law of value second" is not accurate and should not be continued in the future...
Zhao Ziyang's letter quickly received the approval of the four members of the Politburo Standing Committee. On September 11th, about 1500 people were convened by the central government to discuss the draft for soliciting opinions. The attendees included central committee members, alternate committee members, central advisory committee members, central disciplinary commission members, main responsible comrades from various central departments, responsible comrades from provinces, municipalities, autonomous regions, and major military regions, as well as leaders from 26 major enterprises. Through discussions, the participants strengthened their understanding of the necessity and urgency of economic system reform, especially urban system reform. They agreed to include "planned commodity economy" in the "Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Economic System Reform" (referred to as the "Decision") at the Third Plenum of the Twelfth Central Committee. At the same time, the title of Part IV of the original draft, "Reform Planning System, Conscious Application of the Law of Value," was changed to "Conscious Application of the Law of Value in the Planning System, Developing a Socialist Commodity Economy."
"But including it in the decision does not mean that everyone's thinking has been clarified." Yang Qixian said that due to ongoing controversies, the day before the formal writing of the "Decision," a sentence was added: "However, under socialist conditions, labor, banks, land, and mines are not commodities." This actually means that the commodity economy is limited to the production of products and does not include production factors. It is not a complete commodity economic system.
The "Decision" passed at the Third Plenum of the Twelfth Central Committee on economic system reform clarifies the necessity and urgency of accelerating the reform of the entire economic system with a focus on cities. It sets the direction, nature, tasks, and basic principles and policies for the reform.
The most significant contribution of this "Decision" is breaking through the traditional notion of opposing planned economy with commodity economy and confirming that our country's socialist economy is a "planned commodity economy based on public ownership." The reform in our country is the self-improvement and development of the socialist system. The basic task of the reform is to further implement the policy of revitalizing the economy internally and opening up externally, gradually establish a socialist economic system with Chinese characteristics, full of vitality and vigor, and promote the development of social productive forces.
The "Decision" clearly states the main issues that need to be addressed in relation to the basic tasks of reform, namely establishing a dynamic socialist economic system; enhancing enterprise vitality as the central focus of economic system reform; establishing a planned system that conscientiously applies the law of value and developing a socialist commodity economy; establishing a rational price system and giving full attention to the role of economic leverage; implementing the separation of government and enterprise responsibilities and correctly playing the role of government institutions in managing the economy; establishing various forms of economic responsibility systems and earnestly implementing the principle of distribution according to work; actively developing various forms of the economy and further expanding economic and technological exchanges with foreign and domestic sources; employing a new generation, cultivating a large contingent of socialist economic management cadres; and strengthening party leadership to ensure the smooth progress of reform.
This "Decision" makes the direction, tasks, and requirements of China's reform more clear and is a programmatic document guiding the comprehensive implementation of economic system reform in our country. Although it does not explicitly propose the establishment of a socialist market economic system as the reform goal, the proposal of a planned commodity economy target based on public ownership already implies a clear market orientation, which is a significant breakthrough in socialist economic theory. Deng Xiaoping highly praised this, believing that it was "the combination of basic principles of Marxism and socialist economic practice in China."
Practice has proven that the release and implementation of the "Decision on Economic System Reform" at the Third Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee was another liberation of the thinking of the cadres and the masses. After this plenary session, economic system reforms focusing on cities began to gradually unfold in areas such as expanding enterprise autonomy, conducting pilot projects for a shareholding system, reforming ownership structures, changing employment systems, and implementing factory director responsibility systems.
III. Clarify the themes of the times and the development of foreign relations
After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, when the party and the state shifted their focus to socialist modernization centered on economic construction, foreign affairs, like other work, served the central task of economic construction and the key point of socialist modernization. In order to adapt to this need, the party and the state made adjustments to their foreign relations strategies.
1. Adjustment of international strategy and foreign policy
With economic construction as the center, there is a need for a favorable external environment, namely a peaceful international environment. How to create a peaceful international environment is subject to various factors. How to correctly analyze and assess the international situation and adopt the correct foreign relations strategies and policies is an extremely important aspect.
(1) Preliminary adjustments by Chinese leaders to their understanding of war and peace. When New China was just established, in order to resist and break the United States' hostility, isolation, and blockade, the Chinese government pursued a "leaning to one side" foreign policy and formed an alliance with the Soviet Union. This was necessary given the international environment at the time. In the late 1950s, the Soviet Union pursued great-power chauvinism and forced China to accept demands that compromised Chinese sovereignty, exerting political, economic, and military pressures that rapidly deteriorated Sino-Soviet relations. By the 1970s, the United States, one of the two superpowers, was strategically retreating due to its weakening in the Vietnam War, while the Soviet Union, at a stage of increasing military strength, took advantage of the situation to expand its influence on a global scale, posing a serious threat to global peace and China's security. In response to this international situation, the Chinese government adjusted its foreign policy and adopted a "one line" diplomatic strategy of simultaneously allying with the United States and resisting the Soviet Union. This strategy not only effectively safeguarded China's own security but also greatly curbed the momentum of global expansion by the Soviet Union.
After the end of the Cultural Revolution, how to analyze and judge the international situation and formulate foreign strategies and policies based on these became a major issue in China's foreign relations. In December 1977, the Central Military Commission held a meeting, and Chairman Hua Guofeng of the Communist Party of China made a speech regarding the international situation, especially the issue of war and peace. He believed that because imperialist and social-imperialist systems inherently breed war, the struggle between the Soviet Union and the United States, sooner or later, will erupt into a world war. Therefore, a world war is unavoidable, sooner or later it will break out, and we must seize the opportunity and be well prepared for war. But compared to the global war caused by the competition between the United States and the Soviet Union, the greatest threat to Chinese security is still the Soviet Union's invasion of China. Because the heart of the Soviet Union's desire to destroy us is not dead, it is our main and most dangerous enemy. In this regard, we must be sufficiently aware and cautious, focus on its aggression towards us, be prepared for an early and large-scale fight, conduct surprise attacks, be prepared to face the most serious situation, and never harbor any lucky mentality. The older comrades present here must be prepared to fight another major war in their lifetime. This understanding, to a certain extent, represents the views of Chinese leaders at that time. This understanding indicates that at that time, there was still a strong sense of crisis regarding the inevitability and imminent nature of war, especially the Soviet Union's invasion of China war.
Although it was believed that a global war and the Soviet Union's invasion of China were inevitable and imminent, Chinese leaders still sought to postpone the war, buy time, and focus on construction and strengthening national defense capabilities. Moreover, there were certain favorable conditions for delaying the outbreak of war: Mao Zedong's theory and revolutionary diplomatic strategy of dividing the world into three parts could help establish an international united front against hegemony. In addition, the Soviet Union's global strategy was not fully prepared, and after the United States' failure in Southeast Asia, their global strategy was defensive, and they were not fully prepared for a world war. Therefore, it was possible to gain some time and delay the outbreak of war. However, due to the grave estimation of the danger of war, it was still difficult to determine how much time could be gained to delay the outbreak of war. It was highly possible to gain five years or a little more time without engaging in war, but it might also be only two, three, or four years. In any case, it was necessary to prepare well in advance for all aspects of military preparedness. Before the outbreak of war, it was crucial to utilize the possible peace time to rapidly establish our country's strong economic and defense capabilities. Low speed was not acceptable, medium speed was not acceptable, it had to be high speed.
By early 1980, the basic estimation of the international situation mentioned above remained unchanged. China still believed that various contradictions in the world would continue to develop, the international situation would become more turbulent, and war factors would continually increase. However, considering the international political reality that war had not yet broken out and the domestic political reality that China was not fully prepared for war, Chinese leaders still hoped to postpone the arrival of war as much as possible. Deng Xiaoping proposed, "It is possible for us to gain some more time without engaging in war," and "we can delay the outbreak of war." "It is advantageous for us to gain a relatively long period of time for the modernization of our army, the improvement of our military combat capabilities, and our war preparedness work." At this time, while insisting that a large-scale global war was inevitable, there seemed to be a gradual easing of the highly urgent sense of an impending world war.
However, afterwards, the Chinese leaders' views on war and peace gradually began to adjust in response to the development and changes in the international situation. On January 16, 1980, Deng Xiaoping stated at the Central Committee Cadre Meeting of the Communist Party of China: 
"We have confidence that if the struggle against hegemony is done well, it is possible to delay the outbreak of war and strive for a longer period of peace." He also proposed the view that through the struggle against hegemony, the strategic deployment of the United States and the Soviet Union could be disrupted to delay the outbreak of war. Deng Xiaoping further eased his sense of crisis about the imminent war and strengthened his confidence in striving for a longer period of peace. Due to a more moderated judgment of the danger of war, Deng Xiaoping extended the previously proposed time for delaying war and seeking peace from five years or less to ten years or even twenty years. In April 1980, during his meeting with the President of the World Bank, Robert McNamara, Deng Xiaoping said: It seems that there will be some storms in the international arena, but taking a longer-term perspective and adopting effective measures, the dangers of the 1980s can be overcome, and it is possible to strive for a peaceful environment for twenty years. We need a relatively long-term peaceful environment for development. Although the international situation was unstable at that time, especially after the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan at the end of 1979, the international situation became even more turbulent. However, Deng Xiaoping continuously extended the obtainable peace time, which shows a significant and fundamental change in his views on the world situation as well as war and peace. He shifted his focus from emphasizing the danger of war to stressing the importance of obtaining more extended periods of peace, and he emphasized the need to seize this peaceful time to develop the economy instead of preparing for war.
(2) A new summary of the world era theme. As China's relations with several major powers underwent significant changes, the Chinese side quickly noticed the positive role of these changes.
At the end of the 1970s, the international situation was still volatile, and the Soviet Union invaded Afghanistan at the end of 1979. In response to this international situation, the focal point of China's foreign relations was to "strive for more time without war," to "delay the outbreak of war," and to "seize time for development."
After establishing diplomatic relations with the United States, China initially strengthened the "One Line" strategy of cooperating with the United States against the Soviet Union. This was done both out of considerations for national security and the need to accelerate foreign opening-up. However, the normal development of China-US relations always encountered obstacles, with the Taiwan issue being the most significant. Shortly after establishing diplomatic relations with the United States, the US Congress passed the "Taiwan Relations Act," causing damage to China-US relations. On August 17, 1982, the governments of China and the United States issued a joint communiqué, stipulating step-by-step resolutions to the problem of US arms sales to Taiwan, which led to a basic stabilization of China-US relations. However, the US government did not fulfill its promises. In this situation, China began to widen the distance between itself and the United States.
In 1982, based on the need to strive for peace, delay war, and establish more balanced external relations, the Chinese government began to promote opposing hegemonism, safeguarding world peace, and strengthening solidarity and cooperation with the Third World as the basic principles of its new diplomatic policy. Regarding the implementation of this policy, Deng Xiaoping emphasized, "When we propose to safeguard world peace, it's not just empty talk. It is based on our own needs and also meets the needs of the world's people, especially the people of the Third World. Therefore, opposing hegemonism and safeguarding world peace are our genuine policies and the guidelines for our foreign policy." In September of the same year, Hu Yaobang stated in his report at the 12th National Congress, "China adheres to an independent foreign policy and develops relations with other countries based on the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence."
In the mid-1980s, the international situation clearly began to ease. Not only did US-Soviet relations improve, but Sino-Soviet relations also became more relaxed. In light of these new changes in the international situation, in May 1984, Deng Xiaoping explicitly stated that the "peace issue" and the "North-South issue" had become two prominent issues in the world. On March 4, 1985, during a meeting with Japanese guests, he further concluded that "peace and development are the two major issues facing the contemporary world." He said, "The truly significant global strategic issues in the world today are peace and economic development or development issues. The peace problem is an East-West issue, and the development problem is a North-South issue. To sum it up, it's about the four directions: East, West, North, and South." The proposal of the theme of peace and development has laid an important foundation for the transformation of China's diplomatic strategy in the new era.
(3) Reestablishing an independent foreign policy. On September 1, 1982, Deng Xiaoping solemnly announced in the opening speech of the 12th National Congress: Independence, self-reliance, whether in the past, present, or future, are our footholds. The Chinese people cherish their friendship and cooperation with other countries and peoples, and cherish the right to independence and self-determination that they have gained through long-term struggles. No foreign country should expect China to be its vassal, nor should it expect China to suffer from actions that harm our interests.
It is obvious that Deng Xiaoping's remarks are aimed at the changes in Sino-US relations in the previous period, indicating the Chinese government's firm position and announcing the transformation of China's diplomatic strategy.
Deng Xiaoping also pointed out in his speech: Accelerating socialist modernization, striving to achieve reunification of the motherland, including Taiwan, opposing hegemonism, and maintaining world peace are the three major tasks for the Chinese people in the 1980s. Among these three major tasks, the core is economic construction, which is the foundation for solving international and domestic problems.
Deng Xiaoping's speech clearly indicated that the goal of China's diplomatic strategy is to create a favorable international environment for China's domestic socialist modernization, reflecting the guiding principle of diplomatic work serving the center of economic construction.
Hu Yaobang, General Secretary of the Communist Party of China, comprehensively expounded the issue of China's adherence to independent foreign policy in the political report of the 12th National Congress. He declared: "China will never attach itself to any big country or bloc of countries, nor will it yield to the pressure of any big country." "The Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence are applicable to our relations with all countries, including socialist countries."
Independence and peaceful coexistence have been the diplomatic policies pursued by the People's Republic of China since its establishment. However, from the 1950s to the late 1970s, due to the limitations of the international environment and historical conditions at that time, there were tendencies to "align with the United States" and "align with the Soviet Union" in the strategy of "leaning to one side" and "drawing a line", which to some extent affected the implementation of independent foreign policy and peaceful coexistence in diplomatic work, and also affected China's relations with some countries friendly to the United States or the Soviet Union.
After entering the 1980s, based on China's long-standing diplomatic practice and the new changes in the international situation, Deng Xiaoping added new connotations to the diplomatic policy of independence and peaceful coexistence. The new connotation of independence and self-reliance is "non-alignment", not attaching itself to any big country or bloc of countries; the new connotation of the principle of peaceful coexistence is that the relations between countries should not be judged based on differences or similarities in social systems and ideologies; regardless of differences in social systems and ideologies, they should be established on the basis of the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence. Deng Xiaoping believed that dividing lines and determining closeness or distance based on social systems or ideologies are unreliable. Only by going beyond the differences in social systems and ideologies and universally implementing the five principles of peaceful coexistence can normal state-to-state relations be developed, international cooperation be enhanced, and world peace be maintained. China's adherence to an independent foreign policy of non-alignment and the universal implementation of the principle of peaceful coexistence have received widespread praise and support internationally.
China regards the maintenance of world peace and the promotion of human progress and development as the fundamental goals of its diplomatic work, and to achieve world peace, it is first necessary to stop the arms race and implement genuine disarmament. To this end, the Chinese government has changed some of its views and practices on disarmament in the past, actively participated in various international disarmament activities, and put forward many new proposals and propositions on this issue. For example, it proposed that the goal of disarmament should be the comprehensive prohibition and thorough destruction of nuclear weapons; the United States and the Soviet Union, which possess the largest nuclear arsenals in the world, should take the lead in stopping the testing, production, and deployment of all types of nuclear weapons and substantially reduce their various types of nuclear weapons in their domestic and foreign territories.
In order to prevent the outbreak of a nuclear war, the Chinese government has also proposed that all nuclear states should undertake the obligation not to be the first to use nuclear weapons under any circumstances, especially not to use or threaten to use nuclear weapons against non-nuclear countries and non-nuclear regions. On this basis, an international convention should be concluded with the participation of all nuclear states to ensure the prohibition of the use of nuclear weapons. Concurrently with nuclear disarmament, significant reductions in conventional arms should also be carried out. No country should develop, test, or deploy weapons in outer space in any way. An international convention banning and completely destroying chemical weapons should be concluded at an early date. To ensure the implementation of disarmament, disarmament agreements must include necessary and effective verification measures.
Considering that disarmament issues are related to the security interests of all countries in the world, the Chinese government has also proposed that disarmament issues should not be monopolized and dominated by a few major countries, and their disarmament agreements should not harm the interests of other countries. Regardless of the size or military strength of a country, all countries should have the equal right to participate in the discussion and resolution of disarmament issues, and achieve effective disarmament based on the principles of fairness, reasonableness, comprehensiveness, and balance.
In addition to proposing the above fair and reasonable suggestions, the Chinese government has also taken a series of practical actions on disarmament issues. For example, in 1985, the Chinese government reduced military personnel by 1 million and converted military production to civilian production, and converted a large number of military facilities for civilian or dual-use purposes. At the same time, defense spending was significantly reduced, and by the early 1990s, China's military expenditure as a proportion of GDP was the lowest among all countries. China's reasonable propositions and practical actions to reduce military armaments have gained universal welcome and praise from the international community.
Deng Xiaoping's international strategic thinking and diplomatic theories proposed in the new era, as well as the adjustments made by the Chinese government to its diplomatic principles and policies, have made China's independent and peaceful diplomacy more perfect, created a new situation in China's diplomatic work, and thereby played an important role in China's socialist modernization construction, safeguarding world peace, developing friendly cooperation with other countries, and promoting common prosperity, making great contributions.
2. Development of peaceful and friendly relations with major countries
As the leaders of China are undergoing changes regarding war and peace issues, China's relations with several major countries are also changing.
(1) The good development of Sino-Japanese relations. After the conclusion of the Treaty of Peace and Friendship between China and Japan in October 1978, the relations between the two countries began to develop well in politics, economy, science and technology, culture, and other fields. In December 1979, Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira of Japan officially visited China. During this visit, both sides believed that, although China and Japan have different systems, it is necessary to further strengthen intergovernmental dialogue and promote exchanges at various levels between the two countries in order to deepen mutual understanding and trust. During this visit, the leaders of both countries focused on discussing China-Japan economic cooperation issues. The leaders of the two countries unanimously agreed that further cooperation between China and Japan in the fields of resources and energy is desirable, and agreements were reached on cooperation in exploring and developing oil in Bohai Sea, as well as cooperating in the development of coal resources, etc. The Japanese side also stated that from 1979 to 1983, Japan would provide 330 billion yen (about 1.5 billion US dollars) in economic cooperation funds loans to China for priority construction projects, including two ports (Qinhuangdao Port and Shijiusuo Port) and two railways (Jingqin Railway and Yanshi Railway), and from April 1980, preferential tariff treatment would be provided to Chinese products. During Prime Minister Ohira's visit, the two sides also signed a cultural exchange agreement. Through Prime Minister Ohira's visit, economic cooperation between China and Japan was significantly advanced.
1982 marked the 10th anniversary of the normalization of diplomatic relations between China and Japan. Chinese Premier Zhao Ziyang and Japanese Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki conducted reciprocal visits. At the end of May and the beginning of June 1982, during Zhao Ziyang's visit to Japan, he proposed three principles for the development of Sino-Japanese relations: based on the "Sino-Japanese Joint Statement" and the "Sino-Japanese Treaty of Peace and Friendship", actively develop the economic relationship between the two countries on the basis of the existing peaceful and friendly relationship; Sino-Japanese economic relations should follow the principles of equality, mutual benefit, complementarity, and continuously develop towards new breadth and depth based on their respective needs and capacities; the development of this economic relationship is in line with the fundamental interests of the Chinese and Japanese peoples and their desire for everlasting friendship, and should be long-term, stable, and not affected by international vicissitudes. The three principles for Sino-Japanese relations proposed by China received positive responses from Prime Minister Suzuki and the Japanese government. In September of the same year, Prime Minister Suzuki returned to China. Deng Xiaoping told Prime Minister Suzuki that in summary, Sino-Japanese relations means that the peoples of the two countries will be friends for generations, which is our national policy.
In November 1983, General Secretary Hu Yaobang visited Japan. Prime Minister Nakasone proposed to change the three principles of Sino-Japanese relations to four principles, adding "mutual trust" in addition to the existing three principles of "peace, friendship, equality, mutual benefit, long-term stability". Hu Yaobang agreed. In accordance with the agreed upon during this visit, the "China-Japan Friendship Committee for the 21st Century" was established in 1984 with representatives from various sectors of China and Japan, and 3,000 Japanese young people visited China in the same year. The following year, 500 Chinese young people visited Japan.
In March 1984, Prime Minister Nakasone visited China. In April 1985, Chairman Peng Zhen visited Japan. The above visits by leaders of the two countries made positive contributions to the establishment of the four principles of Sino-Japanese relations and the promotion of long-term and stable friendly cooperation between China and Japan. During this period, exchanges and cooperation between China and Japan in the fields of economy, culture, science and technology were more active. By 1989, the total trade volume between China and Japan reached 18.9 billion US dollars, 2.7 times the total trade volume of 1979; Japan became China's second largest trading partner, ahead of the United States. Progress was made in financial cooperation and technology transfer between the two countries. In December 1979, when Japanese Prime Minister Zenko Suzuki visited China, the Japanese government officially announced its financial cooperation for the six large-scale projects proposed by China, deciding to provide the first batch of 50 billion yuan in government loans to China in 1979, with an annual interest rate of 3%, a repayment period of 30 years, and a 10-year grace period. This was referred to as government development aid, abbreviated as ODA. In 1984, the second batch of low-interest loans amounted to 470 billion yen (about 2.1 billion US dollars). In December 1984, the Japanese side agreed to provide the second batch of energy development loans to the Chinese side for about 2.4 billion US dollars. In 1988, the Japanese side proposed the third batch of low-interest loans amounting to 810 billion yen, mainly for the construction of 42 key projects during the "Eighth Five-Year Plan" period. New progress was also made in Sino-Japanese cooperation in the development of offshore oil fields, with five contracts signed and a total investment of 800 million US dollars from the Japanese side. In order to promote and guarantee the smooth development of economic cooperation between the two countries, the two governments signed the Sino-Japanese Avoidance of Double Taxation Agreement in 1983. The increasingly close economic cooperation between China and Japan has effectively promoted the development of their respective economies and brought great benefits to both parties.
Of course, while China and Japan have achieved good development in their bilateral relations, some problems have also occurred. For example, in 1979 and 1980, the Japanese side infringed on China's sovereignty in the Diaoyu Islands issue; in the spring of 1982, the "textbook incident" occurred. At that time, the Japanese Ministry of Education tampered with the history of Japan's militarist aggression against China when approving history textbooks for primary and secondary schools, changing "invasion" to "entry", changing "comprehensive invasion" by Japan into "comprehensive attack", and even stating that the cause of the "Nanjing Massacre" was "due to the fierce resistance of the Chinese army, the enraged Japanese army killed many Chinese soldiers and civilians," etc., absolving Japan of any guilt. In 1985, the Prime Minister of Japan and other government members formally paid homage to the Yasukuni Shrine, which enshrines war criminals, and so on. Although these events have to some extent affected the smooth development of Sino-Japanese relations, overall, the development of relations between the two countries during this period was relatively good.
(2) Sino-US relations continue to progress in promoting understanding. China and the United States officially established diplomatic relations in 1979. In order to further strengthen mutual understanding between China and the US and promote the development of Sino-US relations, Deng Xiaoping accepted President Carter's invitation to make an official friendly visit to the United States in early 1979. This was the first visit by a Chinese leader to the US after the establishment of the People's Republic of China and received a warm welcome from the US government and people. During the visit, Deng Xiaoping exchanged views with President Carter on the international situation, especially the issue of Vietnam invading Cambodia with the support of the Soviet Union. The two sides also discussed Taiwan-related issues and Sino-US relations. During the visit, China and the US signed agreements on scientific and technological cooperation, cultural cooperation, cooperation in education, business, and space, as well as agreements to establish consular relations, mutually set up consulates general, and decided to hold negotiations on trade, aviation, and maritime agreements. During the visit, Deng Xiaoping had extensive contacts with people from all walks of life in the United States.
The establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the US and Deng Xiaoping's visit to the US promoted the development of Sino-US relations in various fields. In August 1980, China and the US signed agreements on civil aviation, maritime, and textile, which significantly increased bilateral trade and facilitated rapid cultural exchanges. However, some misguided actions by the United States on the Taiwan issue continue to be a major obstacle to the smooth development of Sino-US relations.
After the formal establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the US, President Carter proposed a "legislative adjustment" bill to Congress regarding US-Taiwan relations on January 26, 1979, stating that in the future, commercial, cultural, and other relations with Taiwan will be maintained on an unofficial basis and an "American Institute in Taiwan" will be established to handle relevant affairs. When discussing this bill, both Houses of the US Congress proposed a series of amendments that severely violated the principles of the Joint Communiqué on the Establishment of Diplomatic Relations between China and the US and blatantly interfered in China's internal affairs. This strongly provoked opposition from the Chinese side.
At the end of March 1979, the US Congress passed the "Taiwan Relations Act," which violated the fundamental principles of the Joint Communiqué on the Establishment of Diplomatic Relations between China and the US and recognized international law in terms of its basic spirit and many specific provisions. This was particularly evident in the so-called "guaranteeing Taiwan's security" issue and the nature of US-Taiwan relations. The "Taiwan Relations Act" declared, "The President shall inform the Congress promptly of any threat to the security or social and economic system of the people on Taiwan and any danger to the interests of the United States arising therefrom and determine the appropriate action to be taken in accordance with the constitutional processes by the United States and the Congress." These provisions actually reinstated the US-Taiwan "Mutual Defense Treaty," which was announced to be terminated in the Joint Communiqué on the Establishment of Diplomatic Relations between China and the US, and blatantly interfered in China's internal affairs.
The "Taiwan Relations Act" also legally stipulated that the US would continue providing so-called "defense articles" and "defense services" to Taiwan. The law stated that the recognition of the People's Republic of China should not in any way affect the various tangible or intangible properties that the Taiwan authorities possessed in the United States before the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the US. According to international law, after the US recognized the government of the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate government of China, the US had an obligation to promptly hand over the official properties of China that were previously occupied by the Taiwan authorities to the People's Republic of China. Many provisions in the "Taiwan Relations Act" actually treated Taiwan as an independent political entity and attempted to give the US-Taiwan relationship an official nature.
On April 10, Carter signed the "Taiwan Relations Act," with reservations only on specific issues, indicating that he would exercise the "consideration power" granted by the law in a manner consistent with the agreement on the establishment of diplomatic relations between China and the US. China is furious about the emergence of the "Taiwan Relations Act". On April 19th, Deng Xiaoping, when meeting with the US Senate Foreign Relations Committee delegation visiting China, pointed out that the political foundation of Sino-US normalization is the recognition of one China. Now this foundation has been disrupted; China is dissatisfied with the "Taiwan Relations Act" passed by the US Congress. The fundamental problem of this bill is that it does not actually recognize the existence of one China. On April 28th, the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs notified the US Embassy in China, pointing out that the "Taiwan Relations Act" essentially intentionally continues to treat Taiwan as a "country" and the Taiwan authorities as a "government", and many of its clauses violate the principles of the China-US Joint Communique on the Establishment of Diplomatic Relations. The US Embassy in China responded on July 6th, saying, "The United States will abide by the understandings reached with the People's Republic of China regarding the establishment of diplomatic relations", and "the final version of the Taiwan Relations Act passed by Congress does not fully reflect the government's intentions in every detail, but it provides the President with sufficient discretionary power to allow the President to carry out this law in a manner consistent with normalization." However, the US Congress eventually passed this bill.
Following the "Taiwan Relations Act" incident, the United States increased arms sales to Taiwan. After long-term negotiations between China and the United States, the "817" Communiqué was reached in 1982, which further clarified the principles and directions for resolving the issue of arms sales to Taiwan. This took an important step in removing obstacles in China-US relations.
To enhance mutual understanding between China and the United States, stabilize bilateral relations, promote China-US friendship, and maintain world peace, in January 1984, Premier Zhao Ziyang of the State Council visited the United States at the invitation of President Reagan and exchanged views with President Reagan and other leaders of the US government on international situations and major international issues of mutual interest. In April of the same year, President Reagan paid a return visit to Chinese leaders. In July 1985, Chairman Li Xiannian visited the United States, followed by Vice President Bush's visit to China in October of the same year. The visits of leaders of the two countries continued to exchange views on bilateral relations and major international issues, with the Taiwan issue being one of the core issues. Obviously, only by removing the obstacle of the Taiwan issue can a truly reliable foundation be established for the stable and lasting development of China-US relations.
Although there have always been obstacles between China and the United States on the Taiwan issue, the overall trend of development in economic, trade, scientific, technological exchanges, and cooperation between the two countries is positive. Economic and technological cooperation between China and the United States has gradually developed. By the end of 1986, the total amount of direct investment contracts by the United States in China exceeded 2.627 billion US dollars. Among them, joint ventures invested 400 million US dollars, and investment in offshore oil development was nearly 600 million US dollars. There were a total of 62 approved Sino-US joint ventures, accounting for 6% of the total number of Chinese foreign-funded joint ventures, second only to the Hong Kong region, ranking first among all countries. From 1979 to 1986, the Chinese and US governments signed 27 official agreements on scientific and technological cooperation, with more than 500 cooperative projects and over 5,000 personnel exchanges.
Bilateral trade between the two countries, which was almost zero in 1972, reached 3.53 billion US dollars by 1985, making the United States China's third-largest trading partner. From 1981 to 1986, the cumulative bilateral trade volume exceeded 35.3 billion US dollars. Among them, 5.9 billion dollars in 1981; 5.28 billion dollars in 1982; it dropped to 4 billion dollars in 1983, but rebounded to 6.1 billion dollars in 1984; reached 7.4 billion dollars in 1985; and 7.3 billion dollars in 1986.
During the visit to China by US Secretary of Commerce Baldrige in May 1983, he announced to the Chinese government the Reagan administration's new regulations to relax technology exports to China, changing China from a "P" group country subject to US export controls to a "V" group country, placing China in the same category as friendly non-aligned countries. This regulation was officially announced by the United States on June 21st of the same year. In October 1985, the United States opened up the export of 27 different categories of equipment to China. US technology exports to China have loosened to some extent.
However, there are also many problems in economic trade and technological cooperation between China and the United States. The trade protectionism within the United States has posed a threat to the development of Sino-US economic and trade relations. For example, the United States has repeatedly restricted the import of Chinese textiles. From 1972 to 1986, China's trade deficit with the United States amounted to a cumulative $18.4 billion. The Sino-US investment protection agreement has also failed to reach a result after several years of negotiations due to the United States' insistence on more stringent conditions compared to other developed countries. In terms of technology transfer, the United States still imposes many restrictions on the export of advanced technology to China, which requires approval from the United States' national security review and the "Paris Coordinating Committee".
(3) The Sino-Soviet relationship developed during the process of "thawing". Starting from the 1960s, Soviet leaders seriously violated the spirit of the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Alliance, and Mutual Assistance, leading to a serious deterioration of relations between the two countries. In the late 1970s, the Soviet Union continued to maintain and strengthen its military pressure on China's northern border, posing a serious threat to China's security. This made the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Alliance, and Mutual Assistance in name only. In view of this, in accordance with the relevant provisions of the Sino-Soviet Treaty of Friendship, Alliance, and Mutual Assistance, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress made a decision on April 3, 1979, not to extend the treaty after its expiration. On the same day, Chinese Foreign Minister Huang Hua met with Soviet Ambassador to China Xie Erbakov and handed him a Note from the Chinese government to the Soviet government, informing the Soviet side of the above decision of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress.
In 1982, progress was made in the talks between China and the United States on the issue of selling weapons to Taiwan, which led to a new improvement in Sino-US relations and had a positive impact on Sino-Soviet relations. On March 24, Soviet leader Brezhnev delivered a speech in Tashkent expressing a willingness to improve relations with China. Deng Xiaoping took note of the information conveyed by the Soviet side and immediately instructed the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to respond to it. On March 26, the Ministry of Foreign Affairs held a press conference and issued a brief statement on Sino-Soviet relations. The next day, the People's Daily published this statement prominently on its front page, causing widespread international repercussions. In the summer, Deng Xiaoping invited several leaders from the Central Committee and the Ministry of Foreign Affairs to a meeting and proposed to take a major action to send a message to the Soviet Union and strive for a major improvement in Sino-Soviet relations. But this had principles and conditions, and the condition was that the Soviet Union had to do something, so it was proposed that the Soviet Union take the initiative to resolve the "three major obstacles". Subsequently, senior officials from the foreign ministries of both China and the Soviet Union visited the other country as embassy guests to conduct work visits. On August 10, the head of the Soviet European Department of the Chinese Ministry of Foreign Affairs visited Moscow in the name of inspecting embassy work and proposed to hold political consultations at the level of deputy foreign ministers. On the 20th, the Soviet side presented a memorandum as a formal reply, agreeing to discuss bilateral relationship issues with the Chinese side at any time, any place, and any level, in order to "eliminate obstacles to the normalization of relations". In view of the positive response from the Soviet side, Deng Xiaoping decided to reopen the Sino-Soviet negotiations after listening to the report from the Ministry of Foreign Affairs. Thereafter, the two sides agreed to establish an official dialogue channel and hold political consultations at the level of deputy foreign ministers in Beijing and Moscow alternately, to discuss how to achieve the normalization of relations between the two countries. In September, Hu Yaobang mentioned in his report at the 12th National Party Congress that as long as the Soviet Union took practical steps to remove the security threat to China, Sino-Soviet relations could move towards normalization. Regardless of the state of Sino-Soviet relations, China will uphold and develop the friendship between the two peoples. This expressed a positive response to speeches by Soviet leaders regarding policies towards China. In October, the two countries resumed political dialogue and held the first round of deputy foreign minister-level consultations. China proposed the elimination of three major obstacles, namely withdrawing troops from Mongolia and the Sino-Soviet border, withdrawing troops from Afghanistan, and urging Vietnam to cease aggression against Cambodia and withdraw its troops from Cambodia. This is the key to achieving the normalization of Sino-Soviet relations. Unfortunately, the Soviet Union used the excuse of not harming the "interests of third countries" to adopt an attitude of non-recognition and refusal to discuss the "three major obstacles." 
Subsequently, when several Soviet leaders passed away, China sent delegations to the Soviet Union to attend funerals, led by members of the Central Political Bureau, the Foreign Minister, and the Secretary of the Central Secretariat and Vice Premier respectively. Through high-level contacts, they affirmed the socialist construction of the Soviet Union, expressed a desire to improve Sino-Soviet relations, and urged the Soviet side to take practical actions to normalize Sino-Soviet relations. In December 1984, Deputy Prime Minister Aksyuchits visited China. Bilateral contacts were raised from vice-ministerial to vice-premier level, and the Economic, Trade, and Technological Committee was established. An economic and technical cooperation agreement was signed for industrial projects in China and their reconstruction, as well as a barter and payment agreement from 1986 to 1990. Bilateral trade increased, border trade resumed, and cooperation expanded, significantly improving bilateral relations.
In March 1985, Gorbachev assumed the position of General Secretary of the Soviet Communist Party. In October 1985, Deng Xiaoping asked the leader of Romania, who was visiting China, to deliver a message to Gorbachev: if the Soviet Union could persuade Vietnam to withdraw its troops from Cambodia, he would be willing to meet with Gorbachev. In November, the Soviet side proposed that the time was ripe for the highest-level meeting between the Soviet Union and China and the restoration of relations between the two parties and countries, suggesting that the meeting be held in the Soviet Far East or within Chinese territory to discuss the normalization of Sino-Soviet relations. In July 1986, Gorbachev made a speech in Vladivostok, stating that the Soviet Union would withdraw six divisions from Afghanistan by the end of 1986, discussing the withdrawal of a "considerable number of Soviet troops" from Mongolia, and expressing willingness to demarcate the border on the main channel of the Sino-Soviet boundary river. He also said, "The Soviet Union is willing to seriously discuss supplementary measures to establish a good-neighborly situation with China at any time and at any level." China cautiously welcomed this and made a positive gesture, agreeing to resume border negotiations. In September, Deng Xiaoping pointed out that if the Soviet Union took solid steps to eliminate the three major obstacles in Sino-Soviet relations, especially in urging Vietnam to stop aggression in Cambodia and withdraw its troops, he would be willing to meet with Gorbachev anywhere in the Soviet Union.
Due to the improvement in bilateral relations, Sino-Soviet border negotiations officially resumed in February 1987. After two rounds of negotiations, progress was finally made after years of stalemate. From August 27th to September 1st, 1988, Vice Foreign Minister Tian Zengpei and Soviet Deputy Foreign Minister Rogachev held working discussions in Beijing specifically on the issue of Cambodia. The two sides reached a certain level of internal understanding. On September 16th, Gorbachev made a speech in the Siberian city of Krasnoyarsk, proposing that the Soviet Union was ready to start preparations for the highest-level meeting between the Soviet Union and China. Based on the working discussions between the vice foreign ministers of China and the Soviet Union and Gorbachev's speech on September 16th, a meeting was held on September 28th in New York between Qian Qichen, the Chinese Foreign Minister attending the 43rd United Nations General Assembly, and Shevardnadze, the Soviet Foreign Minister. Both sides believed that the discussion of the Cambodian issue should continue. From December 1st to 3rd, Chinese Foreign Minister Qian Qichen made an official visit to the Soviet Union at the invitation. This was the first official visit by a Chinese Foreign Minister to the Soviet Union since 1957, with the main task of preparing for a Sino-Soviet summit. From February 1st to 4th, 1989, Soviet Foreign Minister Shevardnadze made a return visit to China, also in preparation for the Sino-Soviet summit. On February 6th, both sides issued statements regarding the Cambodian issue and Gorbachev's visit to China. The statements indicated that "both sides advocate for an early and fair political solution to the Cambodian issue and express their willingness to make efforts to promote the realization of this goal"; "both sides believe that Vietnam's withdrawal from Cambodia is an important part of the political solution to the Cambodian issue." Both parties note Vietnam's decision to withdraw all troops from Cambodia by the end of September 1989 at the latest, and hope that the implementation of this decision will promote progress in other aspects of resolving the Cambodian issue. Both parties also agree to continue discussions on resolving the Cambodian issue. As a result, one of the most important obstacles, namely the Cambodian issue, has essentially been resolved.
Of the "three major obstacles," the other two obstacles were relatively easily resolved. Regarding the issue of reducing Soviet troops stationed along the Sino-Soviet and Sino-Mongolian borders, the Soviet Union announced in January 1987 that it would withdraw a motorized infantry division and other parts of its troops from Mongolia in the next 4 to 6 months. In December 1988, Gorbachev announced in his speech at the United Nations General Assembly that the Soviet Union would withdraw 75% of its troops from Mongolia within two years. On May 15, 1989, this withdrawal process began. Regarding the issue of withdrawing troops from Afghanistan, in July 1986, Gorbachev announced in a speech in Vladivostok that the Soviet Union, after withdrawing troops from Afghanistan, would hold negotiations with Pakistan, the Kabul government of Afghanistan, and the United States under the auspices of the United Nations. On April 14, 1988, the four parties signed an agreement in Geneva on the political resolution of the Afghan issue, which stipulated that the Soviet Union would begin withdrawing troops from Afghanistan on May 15, 1988, and complete the withdrawal within 9 months. Finally, the Soviet Army completely withdrew from Afghanistan by February 15, 1989. With this, the "three major obstacles" that impacted the relations between the two countries were essentially resolved, and the path to the Sino-Soviet summit was finally cleared.
From May 15 to 18, 1989, at the invitation of Chairman Yang Shangkun, Mikhail Gorbachev, the Chairman of the Presidium of the Supreme Soviet of the Soviet Union and General Secretary of the CPSU Central Committee, made an official visit to China. During this visit, Gorbachev held meetings separately with Chairman Yang Shangkun, General Secretary of the CPC Central Committee Zhao Ziyang, and Premier of the State Council Li Peng, among other Chinese leaders. However, the most crucial meeting was the high-level meeting with Deng Xiaoping on the morning of May 16.
Prior to the meeting, Deng Xiaoping first clarified that the theme of the meeting was "ending the past and opening up the future," while emphasizing that "the normalization of Sino-Soviet relations is based on the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence." Based on this, Deng Xiaoping set the policy for the meeting: not to evade differences, not to dwell on old accounts, to seek common ground, focus on the future, and explore the establishment of a new type of friendly neighborly relationship on the basis of the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence. Through this high-level meeting, the two neighboring countries, China and the Soviet Union, finally ended decades of abnormal state and reestablished normal state-to-state relations. On the evening of the 16th, General Secretary of the CPC Central Committee Zhao Ziyang met with Gorbachev, signifying the normalization of relations between the two parties.
On May 18, the joint communique between China and the Soviet Union was issued in Beijing, summarizing the consensus reached during the high-level meeting between China and the Soviet Union. The communique officially confirmed the guidelines for bilateral relations agreed upon by the top leaders of the two countries. It is different from the alliance relationship of the 1950s and the confrontational state of the 1960s and 1970s. It is a normal state-to-state relationship of non-alignment, non-confrontation, non-targeting of third countries, and friendly neighborliness.
3. Development and expansion of neighborhood diplomacy and multilateral diplomacy
After entering the 1980s, with the adjustment of China's diplomatic strategy, in addition to focusing on advancing major country diplomacy, China also vigorously developed neighborhood and multilateral diplomacy, achieving positive results. From 1983 to 1987, China established diplomatic relations with 10 more countries, bringing the total number of diplomatic relations to 135. The Chinese government and the country's top leaders made friendly visits to 46 countries, and vice-premiers, government envoys, and foreign ministers visited 77 countries. China hosted visits from heads of state, heads of government, vice presidents, vice premiers, and foreign ministers from more than 90 countries. Chinese and foreign senior parliamentary leaders visited each other 113 times. China has participated in 64 international conventions, signed 12 bilateral consular treaties, and many other operational agreements, laying a foundation for friendly cooperation between China and countries around the world.
Of particular note is the significant improvement in China's relations with neighboring countries. From 1984 to 1987, China's leaders visited Pakistan, Bangladesh, Sri Lanka, Thailand, Myanmar, and Nepal. Trade and friendly exchanges between China and Mongolia increased, and the two countries signed a new consular treaty. China negotiated the normalization of relations with Laos and the two countries resumed the exchange of ambassadors. China's relations with Indonesia improved through multiple contacts, and both sides resumed direct trade.
Overall, China's foreign relations have developed well with clear results:
First, in terms of relations with neighboring countries. China attaches importance to properly handling historical issues with neighboring countries and has made certain adjustments to its policies towards Southeast Asian countries, distinguishing strictly between party-to-party relations and state relations, which greatly improved bilateral relations between China and Southeast Asian countries. At the same time, China proposed the Five Principles for resolving the China-India border issue, leading to the resumption of high-level visits and border negotiations between the two countries.
Second, in terms of relations with developing countries. China emphasizes practical cooperation and has put forward the four principles of "equality, mutual benefit, practical results, and diversified forms" for economic cooperation, which has deepened China's economic foundation with developing countries.
Third, in terms of relations with Western European countries. By the late 1970s, China had established diplomatic relations with all Western European countries except Andorra, Liechtenstein, Monaco, and the Vatican. China also proposed specific ways to accelerate economic cooperation with Western European countries, such as joint ventures, cooperative development, compensatory trade, processing of supplied materials, and processing of samples, particularly through the joint development of oil, coal, and non-ferrous metal resources. In the 1970s and early 1980s, China signed cooperation agreements with many Western European countries in the fields of economy, trade, science and technology, culture, civil aviation, and maritime transportation. In 1978 and 1979, China also signed trade and textile agreements with the European Community. From 1980 onwards, China received most favored nation treatment from the European Community. During this period, there was a significant increase in China's trade with Western Europe, as well as a promising start in other forms of economic cooperation. China imported some advanced technologies from Western European countries and began to attract funds needed for modernization from them. The common desire for "development in peace" laid a solid foundation and opened up broad prospects for China's relations with Western European countries.
After 1983, China's trade with Western European countries continued to grow. The trade volume reached 9.575 billion US dollars in 1985, an increase of 40.7% compared to 1984. In 1986, the trade volume reached 11.339 billion US dollars, an increase of 39.3% compared to 1985. However, China's trade deficit was relatively large.
Fourth, in international organizations, China actively participates in multilateral diplomatic activities centered around the United Nations, utilizing its international position as one of the five permanent members of the Security Council. China has joined 64 international conventions and played an important role in promoting world peace and development. In terms of development promotion, China emphasizes that it is a member of developing countries and strives to strengthen its relations with them. China actively contributes to promoting North-South dialogue, South-South cooperation, and international economic and technological cooperation. In the government work report at the Fourth Session of the Sixth National People's Congress in March 1986, Zhao Ziyang clearly stated that multilateral diplomacy is an important part of China's independent and peaceful foreign policy:
"China adheres to the purposes and principles of the United Nations Charter, supports the work carried out by the United Nations and its specialized agencies in accordance with the spirit of the Charter, and actively participates in activities favorable to world peace and development conducted by the United Nations and its specialized agencies. China actively participates in various international organizations and engages in active multilateral diplomatic activities, striving to enhance cooperation among countries in various fields. By the end of 1986, China had entered almost all important areas of intergovernmental multilateral diplomacy, participating in nearly 400 international organizations and approving accession to 13 international conventions. China has established 11 permanent multilateral diplomatic institutions in various countries, as well as 10 representative offices of the United Nations and its specialized agencies in China. In 1984, Chinese renowned jurist Ni Zhenghuan was elected as a judge of the International Court of Justice at the 39th session of the United Nations General Assembly, bringing an end to the historical absence of Chinese nationals serving in this important institution. In November 1986, Chinese jurists were again elected as members of the International Law Commission.
In the aspect of multilateral economic and technical assistance, China actively participates and strives to promote cooperation in all aspects. By the end of 1986, China had signed and implemented loan agreements with the World Bank totaling 4.15 billion US dollars, of which 1.6 billion US dollars were concessional loans, accounting for 39%. There were 41 loan projects mainly used for education, health, agriculture, transportation, hydroelectric power, energy, etc. China borrowed the first tranche of credit loans from the International Monetary Fund twice in 1981 and 1986, totaling 1.048 billion special drawing rights. In seven years, institutions such as the United Nations Development Programme, the United Nations Population Fund, and the United Nations Children's Fund promised more than 800 million US dollars in free technical assistance to China and arranged approximately 600 projects. At the same time, China also made contributions to United Nations economic institutions, donating a total of 25.48 million yuan and 25.51 million US dollars in convertible currencies by the end of 1986. These contributions have played a positive role in promoting China's economic construction and strengthening international economic and technological cooperation.
In the past decade since the reform and opening-up, through a new round of adjustments to its foreign policy, China's diplomacy has begun to develop comprehensively. An international environment and surrounding environment favorable to our country's modernization construction and reform and opening-up has initially formed.
IV. Proposing the "One Country, Two Systems" concept and initiating the peaceful reunification process
After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the collective leadership of the Party Central Committee with Deng Xiaoping at the core, based on the significant changes in domestic and international situations and from the perspective of the fundamental interests of the country and the nation, creatively put forward the scientific concept of "peaceful reunification, one country, two systems," ultimately making it a basic national policy of our country.
1. The genesis of the scientific concept of "one country, two systems" for peaceful reunification of the motherland
The policy of "one country, two systems" for the peaceful reunification of the motherland is the inheritance and development of the Chinese Communist Party's policy towards Taiwan since the founding of the People's Republic of China. In 1949, the Chinese People's Liberation Army's advance was unstoppable, and the goal of "overthrowing Chiang Kai-shek and liberating the whole of China" quickly became a reality. Chiang Kai-shek fled to Taiwan in despair. Since then, the unfortunate separation of the two sides of the Taiwan Strait occurred. Mao Zedong and others, faced with the situation of the mainland and Taiwan being separated, have been tirelessly exploring and seeking ways and means to achieve the reunification of the motherland, proposing a series of policies towards Taiwan.
From 1949 to 1955, the Chinese Communist Party's policy towards Taiwan can be summarized as solving the problem through "relying solely on armed force." On December 31, 1949, the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party issued a "Letter to the Frontline Soldiers and Compatriots Nationwide," indicating that the reactionary rule of imperialism and the Kuomintang had been permanently overthrown, and the task in 1950 was to liberate Hainan Island, Taiwan, and Tibet, completely destroying the remnants of the Chiang Kai-shek group. By May 1950, except for Tibet, the mainland of China had been completely liberated, and the Chinese People's Liberation Army, with high morale, actively prepared for a cross-sea war to liberate Taiwan. However, not long after, the Korean War broke out, and the US Seventh Fleet invaded the Taiwan Strait, using force to prevent our country from liberating Taiwan. Subsequently, China sent volunteers to fight in Korea, temporarily suspending the action to liberate Taiwan. After the end of the Korean War, the Chinese government reiterated its policy of using force to solve the Taiwan issue on multiple occasions.
In 1955, our army conducted amphibious operations and liberated the islands of Yijiangshan and Dachen. In May 1955, the Communist Party of China had a new change in its policy towards Taiwan. On May 13th, Zhou Enlai first proposed two possible ways to liberate Taiwan during the 15th meeting of the National People's Congress Standing Committee: through war or through peaceful means. The Chinese people are willing to strive for the peaceful liberation of Taiwan under possible conditions. This is not a joke, but a solemn promise approved by Mao Zedong. In April 1956, Mao Zedong put forward the policies of "peace is precious," "loving the country is a priority," and "loving the country regardless of order". On June 28th of the same year, Zhou Enlai conveyed a new message to the world during the third meeting of the first session of the National People's Congress: "Our government has repeatedly pointed out that there are two possible ways for the Chinese people to liberate Taiwan, through war or through peaceful means; the Chinese people are willing to strive for the peaceful liberation of Taiwan under possible conditions. There is no doubt that if Taiwan can achieve peace, it will be most beneficial for our country, our Chinese people, and the peace of Asia and the world... Now, on behalf of the government, I officially state that we are willing to negotiate with the authorities in Taiwan on the specific steps and conditions for the peaceful liberation of Taiwan, and we hope that the authorities in Taiwan will send representatives to Beijing or other appropriate locations to start such negotiations when they deem it appropriate."
At the same time, the CPC Central Committee also sent a message through Zhang Shizhao in Hong Kong to Chiang Kai-shek, stating "the tomb cottage in Fenghua is still standing, and the flowers and grass in Xikou are unharmed". It aimed to move Chiang Kai-shek with a sense of hometown sentiment. On July 16th, 1956, Zhou Enlai met Hong Kong journalist Cao Juren in Beijing. He was a mysterious figure with a special relationship with the leaders of both the Kuomintang and the Communist Party. During the meeting, Zhou Enlai said, "The Kuomintang and the Communist Party have cooperated twice. The first cooperation resulted in the success of the Northern Expedition of the National Revolution, and the second cooperation resulted in the victory of the War of Resistance Against Japan. These are all facts. Why can't there be a third cooperation? We are not surrendering to Taiwan, but we want to talk to each other. As long as the political power is unified, everything else can be discussed and arranged." 
Mao Zedong later personally met with Cao Juren, which shows the importance Mao Zedong attached to this matter. During the meeting, Mao Zedong said, "If Taiwan is unified with the mainland and lives according to their own way of life, even the fish in the water have regional specificity. Mao's fish won't survive in other places." Mao Zedong also stated that if Chiang Kai-shek is connected with the mainland and dissolves the alliance with the United States, the root will still be his own, so he can continue to survive and carry out his own system. His army can be preserved, I will not oppress him to reduce troops, I don't need him to simplify his government, and let him carry out the Three Principles of the People. Zhou Enlai summed up these ideas as "one principle, four goals," which means that Taiwan must be unified with the mainland (one principle); after Taiwan and the mainland are unified, except for diplomacy, all military and political powers and personnel arrangements will be decided by Chiang Kai-shek; the funding shortage for all military, political, and construction expenses will be allocated by the central government; social reforms in Taiwan can proceed gradually through negotiations; both sides should agree not to send people to disrupt each other's unity (four goals). In fact, it also includes the basic idea of "one country, two systems."
However, the Kuomintang did not respond positively to the Communist Party of China's peace initiative. On the contrary, it continued to increase troops in Kinmen and Matsu, while the United States intensified its activities behind the scenes, attempting to make the Kuomintang accept its scheme of "controlling the straits". In this situation, on the one hand, to strike against the reactionary atmosphere of the United States and Chiang Kai-shek, and on the other hand, to maintain the "connection" between the mainland, Taiwan, Penghu, Jinmen, and Matsu in the form of armed conflict, the Chinese People's Liberation Army's frontline forces in Fujian were ordered to launch a fierce attack on the islands of Jinmen and Da Dan, Er Dan in August 1958, with "a simultaneous barrage of ten thousand cannons". However, despite this, the government of our country still adhered to its policy of primarily liberating by force and seeking peace as a supplement. During the period of the "Cultural Revolution," influenced by "leftist" ideology, our government adopted a tougher stance in its policy towards Taiwan, which was a phase of "continuing to maintain the military confrontation and engaging in diplomatic struggles."
2. Preliminary Ideas on the Policy of Peaceful Reunification of the Motherland in the New Era
In the late 1970s, due to the relatively relaxed international situation, China's diplomacy entered a new phase. China successively restored and established normal relations with the United States and Japan. The United States and Japan both recognized the People's Republic of China as the only legitimate government of China and that Taiwan is part of China's territory. By 1978, the number of countries that had established diplomatic relations with the People's Republic of China had increased to 116, while only 23 countries and regions maintained diplomatic relations with Taiwan.
On New Year's Day of 1979, the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress issued the "Message to Compatriots in Taiwan," which marked the comprehensive determination of the Chinese government's policy of peaceful reunification. The Communist Party of China stated in the "Message to Compatriots in Taiwan": "Today, the realization of China's reunification is the common aspiration of the people and the overall trend. It is universally recognized that there is only one China and that the government of the People's Republic of China is the sole legitimate government of China. The recent signing of the Sino-Japanese Peace and Friendship Treaty and the normalization of relations between China and the United States are further evidence that nothing can stop the trend. At present, the motherland is stable and united, and the situation is better than ever before. The people of all ethnic groups on the mainland are working together to achieve the great goals of the four modernizations. We earnestly hope that Taiwan will return to the motherland as soon as possible and jointly develop the cause of building the country. Our national leaders have expressed their determination to consider the actual situation and accomplish the great cause of reunifying the motherland, respecting the status quo of Taiwan and the opinions of people from all walks of life in Taiwan, and adopting reasonable policies and measures so as not to cause any harm to the Taiwanese people."
"The Chinese government has ordered the People's Liberation Army to stop shelling islands such as Kinmen starting today. There is still military confrontation between both sides in the Taiwan Strait, which can only create artificial tension. We believe that the military confrontation should be ended through negotiations between the government of the People's Republic of China and the authorities in Taiwan in order to create the necessary conditions and a safe environment for any form of exchange between the two sides."
