The "Message to Compatriots in Taiwan" not only marked the comprehensive determination of the Chinese government's policy of peaceful reunification but also contained the germination of the idea of "one country, two systems." Shortly after the publication of the "Message to Compatriots in Taiwan," during his visit to the United States, Deng Xiaoping explained China's policy toward Taiwan to relevant American figures, saying: "According to our wishes, we entirely hope to resolve this issue through peaceful means because it is more beneficial to the nation and the Chinese people. We no longer use the term 'liberate Taiwan' but as long as the reunification of the motherland is achieved, 'we will respect the reality and the existing system there.'" This was actually the first time that the idea of using the "one country, two systems" approach to resolve the Taiwan issue was publicly proposed.
On December 6 of the same year, during his meeting with visiting Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, Deng Xiaoping further specified the idea of "one country, two systems." He said: "The conditions we have for Taiwan are very simple. That is, the system in Taiwan remains unchanged, the way of life remains unchanged, and the people-to-people relations between Taiwan and foreign countries remain unchanged, including foreign investments and people-to-people exchanges in Taiwan. Taiwan, as a local government, can have its own self-defense and military capabilities. There is only one condition, which is that Taiwan must be an integral part of China. As a local government of China, it has ample autonomy."
On September 30, 1981, Chairman of the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, Ye Jianying, issued the Nine Guidelines for Peaceful Reunification of Taiwan, namely:
(1) In order to quickly end the unfortunate situation of national division for the Chinese nation, we suggest holding equal negotiations between the Communist Party of China and the Kuomintang, implementing a third cooperation, and jointly accomplishing the great cause of reunification. The two sides can first make contact and fully exchange opinions.
(2) The people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait urgently hope for information exchange, family reunification, trade development, and increased understanding. We suggest that both sides jointly provide convenience for postal, trade, visiting relatives, tourism, as well as academic, cultural, and sports exchanges, and reach relevant agreements.
(3) After national reunification, Taiwan can become a special administrative region with a high degree of autonomy and retain its military. The central government will not interfere in the affairs of Taiwan.
(4) The current social and economic systems of Taiwan will remain unchanged, as well as the way of life and economic and cultural relations with foreign countries. Private property, houses, land, business ownership, legal inheritance rights, and foreign investments shall not be infringed upon.
(5) The authorities and representatives from all sectors in Taiwan can assume leadership positions in national political institutions and participate in national governance.
(6) When Taiwan's local finances encounter difficulties, the central government can provide appropriate subsidies.
(7) The people from all ethnic groups and various sectors in Taiwan who are willing to settle in the mainland of the motherland shall be properly arranged, free from discrimination, and enjoy freedom of coming and going.
(8) Taiwanese business and industrial figures are welcome to invest in the mainland of the motherland and establish various economic ventures, guaranteeing their legal rights and profits.
(9) It is the responsibility of every individual to reunify the motherland. We wholeheartedly welcome the people from all ethnic groups, various sectors, and mass organizations in Taiwan to provide suggestions and discuss national issues through various channels and in various ways.
Up to this point, the Communist Party of China has outlined the basic content of "one country, two systems" in practice.
3. Formal Proposal of "One Country, Two Systems"
In January 1982, Deng Xiaoping formally proposed the concept of "one country, two systems" for the first time in a conversation, pointing out that the nine principles proposed by Ye Jianying were in fact "one country, two systems". Afterwards, the leaders of the Party and the country made statements on "one country, two systems" on different occasions. In September of the same year, Deng Xiaoping stated during his meeting with British Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher on the issue of recovering Hong Kong's sovereignty that the issue could be resolved with the "one country, two systems" approach. This indicates that the policy of using "one country, two systems" to solve the issue of national reunification has expanded from Taiwan to Hong Kong and Macau.
In December of the same year, in the amendment to the Constitution of the People's Republic of China passed at the fifth session of the Fifth National People's Congress, consideration was given to the special situations in the regions of Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macau. It legally confirmed the policy of establishing special administrative regions after the recovery of Hong Kong and Macau's sovereignty and after achieving unification with Taiwan, and maintaining the capitalist systems in these regions unchanged. Article 31 of the Constitution states: "The state may establish special administrative regions when necessary. The systems implemented in special administrative regions shall be prescribed by law by the National People's Congress in accordance with specific conditions." This affirms the idea that within a unified country, two different social systems can be implemented in the form of a fundamental law of the state.
On June 26, 1983, Deng Xiaoping received a group of visiting American guests, including the renowned professor Yang Liyu from Seton Hall University in New Jersey. During the meeting, based on the discussions of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China Central Committee, Deng Xiaoping elaborated on the essence and specific ideas of the policy of peaceful reunification. He said, "The core issue is the reunification of the motherland. Peaceful reunification has become the common language of both the Communist Party and the Kuomintang. But it is not a matter of one side swallowing the other, nor is it a matter of you swallowing me." Instead, it is the implementation of two systems within one country. We will steadfastly adhere to the policy of peaceful reunification. After the reunification of the motherland, the local government in Taiwan can implement its own policies, have its own independence in internal affairs; it does not need to go to Beijing for judicial power and final appellate power; the military will be independent; the mainland will not send military or political personnel to Taiwan; Taiwan's party, government, and military systems will be managed by Taiwan itself; and the central government must reserve a quota for Taiwan. Deng Xiaoping also said that the implementation of "one country, two systems" is to complete the great cause of reunification that previous leaders did not accomplish. If the Communist Party and the Kuomintang jointly accomplish this, the history of the Chiang family will be written in a better light.
At the time, the domestic news media did not pay special attention to this meeting and Deng Xiaoping's speech. A month later, Yang Liyu published an article in the Hong Kong magazine "Wide Angle Mirror," introducing the circumstances of the meeting and the main content of Deng Xiaoping's conversation. Deng Xiaoping's speech immediately received strong reactions from Hong Kong, Macau, Taiwan, and both domestic and overseas Chinese, and it was widely praised as the "Six Points of Deng." The publication of the "Six Points of Deng" marked the complete formation of the concept of "one country, two systems." In May 1984, this scientific concept was officially incorporated into the Government Work Report passed at the Second Session of the Sixth National People's Congress, becoming a fundamental national policy with legal guarantees.
Deng Xiaoping answered the question of what "one country, two systems" actually meant on multiple occasions and to different audiences. In June 22 and 23, 1984, when he respectively met with a visiting delegation of Hong Kong businessmen and prominent figures including Zhong Shi Yuan, he provided the most concise, specific, easy-to-understand, and memorable explanation. He said, "Our policy is to implement 'one country, two systems.' Specifically, it means that within the People's Republic of China, with its billion population, we implement a socialist system on the mainland, and capitalist systems are implemented in Hong Kong and Taiwan."
"One country, two systems" is a complete scientific concept. Here, the premise is one China, without which there can be no talk of reunification. One China refers to the People's Republic of China, and it is not permissible to have any form or disguised form of "two Chinas," "one country, two governments," "one China, one Taiwan," "two equivalent political entities," "the Republic of China in Taiwan," or "Taiwan as a sovereign independent country."
Under the premise of "One China", the main body of the country is socialist. Deng Xiaoping pointed out that the main body of China must be socialist. In mainland China, we must resolutely adhere to the socialist system. After the founding of the People's Republic of China in 1949, through the joint efforts of the people, socialism has taken root firmly in the mainland. Practice has proved and will continue to prove that only socialism can save China, and only socialism can develop China. Therefore, in the mainland, we must uphold socialism. Under the premise of adhering to "One China", socialism is practiced in mainland China while capitalism is practiced in Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macau. In these regions, the current social and economic systems remain unchanged, lifestyles remain unchanged, and existing laws remain basically unchanged. Taiwan is also allowed to retain its military. This system will remain unchanged for a considerable period of time.
The policy of "One Country, Two Systems" has aroused strong reactions at home and abroad. On August 27, 1984, the Hong Kong Ming Pao published an editorial stating that "One Country, Two Systems" is the "fundamental principle of Marxism today." In 1984, the America Chinese Daily published an editorial titled "A Major Event in the History of International Relations", believing that the implementation of "One Country, Two Systems" in Hong Kong and mainland China will have far-reaching impacts on China's reunification and world affairs. The Taiwanese authorities have stubbornly refused to negotiate with the Chinese Communist Party and have made many self-serving remarks about the Hong Kong issue, only to further alienate Taiwan from people both domestically and internationally. I hope the Taiwanese authorities change their course, follow the tide of history, or it will be too late to regret.
4. Launch negotiations for the return of Hong Kong and Macau in accordance with the policy of "One Country, Two Systems".
Although the concept of "One Country, Two Systems" was originally proposed to resolve the Taiwan issue, it was first successfully applied to resolve the Hong Kong and Macau issues.
The Hong Kong issue is a historical legacy of British colonial aggression against China. The Hong Kong region includes Hong Kong Island, Kowloon, and the New Territories, which have always been Chinese territories. After the Opium War in 1840, the British forced the Qing government to sign the unequal treaties of the Treaty of Nanjing, Treaty of Beijing, and the Convention for the Extension of Hong Kong Territory, forcibly occupying the Hong Kong, Kowloon, and New Territories regions and subjecting Hong Kong to British colonial rule. The successive Chinese governments since the 1911 Revolution have not recognized the aforementioned unequal treaties, and have conducted multiple negotiations with the British to recover Hong Kong. In the eve of the establishment of the People's Republic of China, due to the special domestic and international circumstances, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and Mao Zedong decided to "temporarily leave Hong Kong alone". After the founding of the People's Republic of China in 1949, the Chinese government adopted a policy of "long-term planning, full utilization" for Hong Kong, not recognizing the three unequal treaties imposed by imperialism on China. However, considering historical reasons, the status quo was temporarily maintained and resolved peacefully through negotiation at the appropriate time.
According to the provisions of the aforementioned unequal treaties, the "New Territories", which accounts for 92% of the entire Hong Kong area and concentrates the major energy and industrial sectors, will expire on June 30, 1997. As the expiration of the lease on the "New Territories" approaches, the question of whether the land lease can be extended beyond "97" becomes more urgent, causing hesitation among investors. In order to extend the period of governance over Hong Kong, in March 1979, the British sent Governor MacLehose to visit Beijing, attempting to understand the Chinese government's attitude towards the Hong Kong question. Deng Xiaoping pointed out during the meeting that it has always been our belief that the sovereignty of Hong Kong belongs to the People's Republic of China, but Hong Kong also has its special status. The position of the Chinese government does not affect the investment interests of investors. This is why Hong Kong can have its capitalism during a long period of time in the 20th and early 21st centuries, while we practice our socialism.
In early 1981, Deng Xiaoping proposed that the Hong Kong issue has been put on the agenda and we must have a clear policy and attitude. Subsequently, he instructed the establishment of a specialized group to discuss countermeasures for the Hong Kong issue. In December of that year, the Central Secretariat Meeting made the decision to reclaim Hong Kong sovereignty on July 1, 1997. In April 1982, when Deng Xiaoping met with former British Prime Minister Heath, he explained the Chinese government's basic stance on resolving the Hong Kong issue, clearly stating that now is the time to consider dealing with the Hong Kong issue.
In June 1982, when Deng Xiaoping met with prominent figures from Hong Kong, he officially announced the Chinese government's basic position and principles for dealing with the Hong Kong issue: first, Hong Kong must be reclaimed by 1997, to restore sovereignty, no later than that; second, on the premise of restoring sovereignty, to maintain Hong Kong's prosperity and stability. At the same time, the research group approved by the central government went to Hong Kong to conduct investigations and studies, and formulated the Twelve Policies for resolving the Hong Kong issue, with "one country, two systems" as the core. The main essence of these policies is to restore sovereignty, maintain unchanged systems, let Hong Kong people govern Hong Kong, and ensure a high degree of autonomy. These policies further specified the guidelines for resolving the Hong Kong issue according to the principle of "one country, two systems," thus laying a foundation for the Sino-British negotiations to resolve the Hong Kong issue.
On September 24, 1982, when Deng Xiaoping met with British Prime Minister Thatcher, he explicitly expounded the Chinese government's basic position on the Hong Kong issue: first, the question of sovereignty is not open for discussion. China has no room to maneuver on this issue. China and the UK negotiate and discuss ways and means to resolve the Hong Kong issue on this premise. Second, after China reclaims Hong Kong in 1997, policies suitable for Hong Kong will be implemented. Hong Kong will continue to practice capitalism. Third, the Chinese and British governments need to properly negotiate how to avoid major fluctuations in Hong Kong during the fifteen years from now until 1997.
Based on the principles put forward by Deng Xiaoping, formal negotiations between China and the UK on the Hong Kong issue officially began. The entire negotiation lasted for two years and can be broadly divided into two stages: the first stage from September 1982 to June 1983, during which the two sides held preliminary discussions on some fundamental and procedural issues, and the Chinese side finalized its Hong Kong policies; the second stage from July 1983 to September 1984, during which substantive negotiations were conducted, leading to the formation of the Sino-British agreement text on the Hong Kong issue based on the Chinese policy.
In September 1984, China and the UK reached an agreement. On December 19 of the same year, the heads of state of China and Britain officially signed the Sino-British Joint Declaration on the Hong Kong issue in Beijing, announcing that the government of the People's Republic of China would restore sovereignty over Hong Kong on July 1, 1997, and the British government would hand over Hong Kong to China on that day. During the transitional period from the date of effectiveness of the Joint Declaration to June 30, 1997, the British government would be responsible for the administrative management of Hong Kong, with cooperation from the Chinese government. The two-year Sino-British negotiation came to a successful conclusion. On May 27, 1985, the two governments exchanged the instruments of ratification for the Sino-British Joint Declaration and its three annexes in Beijing, and the Joint Declaration came into effect. Hong Kong entered the transitional period before the restoration of Chinese sovereignty.
After Hong Kong entered the transition period, the Chinese government began to formulate the Basic Law of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region. On April 10, 1985, during the third session of the Sixth National People's Congress, the Hong Kong Basic Law Drafting Committee was established to be responsible for drafting the Basic Law. On July 1, the Hong Kong Basic Law Drafting Committee was officially established and began its work. In February 1990, after extensive solicitation of opinions and repeated revisions, the ninth plenary session of the Hong Kong Basic Law Drafting Committee deliberated on the draft Basic Law and submitted it for review and approval by the National People's Congress. On April 4, during the third session of the Seventh National People's Congress, the "Basic Law of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region of the People's Republic of China" and its three annexes: "Method for the Selection of the Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region", "Method for the Formation of the Legislative Council of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region and Its Voting Procedures", and "National Laws Applied in the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region", as well as the flag and emblem of the Hong Kong Special Administrative Region, were reviewed and passed. The cooperation between China and the UK in resolving the Hong Kong issue basically went smoothly in the 1980s.
With the launch of the Hong Kong's return process, the issue of Macau's return also came on the agenda. As early as 1974, the Portuguese government announced the abandonment of all overseas colonies and recognized Macau as Chinese territory rather than a colony. In February 1979, China and Portugal established diplomatic relations and reached an understanding on the issue of Macau. The Portuguese government recognized Macau as Chinese territory, and both sides agreed to settle the issue through negotiations between the two governments at an appropriate time.
In the autumn of 1984, the Chinese and British governments reached an agreement on the Hong Kong issue, and the conditions for resolving the Macau issue through negotiations between China and Portugal became mature. On October 6 of the same year, when Deng Xiaoping met with prominent figures from Macau, he further elaborated on the principles of resolving the Macau issue: the resolution of the Macau issue would also be conducted in accordance with the principles used to resolve the Hong Kong issue, namely "one country, two systems", "Macau people ruling Macau", and unchanged for 50 years. In June 1986, the Chinese and Portuguese governments began negotiations on the Macau issue. On April 13, 1987, the prime ministers of China and Portugal officially signed the "Joint Declaration of the Government of the People's Republic of China and the Government of the Portuguese Republic on the Question of Macau" in Beijing. The declaration announced that Macau is Chinese territory, and the People's Republic of China government would resume the exercise of sovereignty over Macau on December 20, 1999. On January 15, 1988, representatives of the two governments exchanged instruments of ratification of the Joint Declaration in Beijing, officially entering the transitional period of Macau's return.
Chapter 5: The Theory of the Primary Stage of Socialism and the "Three-Step" Development Strategy
I. The Proposal of the Theory of the Primary Stage of Socialism and the Establishment of the Party's Basic Line
During the period from the 12th National Congress to the 13th National Congress of the Party, under the guidance of the spirit of the 12th National Congress, the entire party and the people of the whole country made efforts to create a new situation in the socialist modernization construction, and achieved certain progress through exploration and efforts. On this basis, the 13th National Congress of the Party was held in victory in 1987, marking the formal establishment of the Party's basic line in the primary stage.
1. Preparation and holding of the 13th National Congress of the Party
On October 25, 1987, the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of China was grandly opened at the Great Hall of the People. The convening of the 13th National Congress was decided in September 1986 at the Sixth Plenary Session of the 12th Central Committee of the Party. Subsequently, the Party Central Committee began preparations for the 13th National Congress. The preparations for the 13th National Congress mainly consisted of two aspects:
The first aspect was the election of delegates to attend the congress. According to the resolutions of the Sixth Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee, the number of representatives for the Thirteenth National Congress of the Party is 1950. The central committee requires that the composition of representatives should be broad. There should be an appropriate proportion of minority party members and women party members. Special attention should be paid to the election of a certain number of young and middle-aged party members who have made outstanding achievements in socialist modernization construction and various reforms.
Through democratic elections, 1936 representatives with broad representation were selected. Among them, cadres at all levels accounted for 75.7%, personnel from various fields such as economy, science and technology, culture, education, sports and health accounted for 18.9%, famous model workers and heroic fighters accounted for 5.4%. Women accounted for 14.9%. Minorities accounted for 10.8%. Those with a college education or higher accounted for 59.5%. Among the representatives, there are a certain proportion of old party members who joined the party from the early days of the party to the period of the liberation war, and the majority are party members of the new China. There are veterans of the proletarian revolution and energetic young and outstanding party members, with those under 55 accounting for 58.8%.
The second point is the preparation of the conference documents. The Party Central Committee established a drafting group for the political report. The entire drafting work was carried out under the care and guidance of Deng Xiaoping.
On March 21, 1987, Zhao Ziyang, the head of the drafting group at the time, made a written report and request to Deng Xiaoping regarding the outline of the draft report for the Thirteenth National Congress. Seven parts were proposed for the report: (1) Talk about the historical changes that have occurred in China since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, including since the Twelfth National Congress. (2) Talk about the line since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, which is a Marxist line based on China's national conditions. Emphasize that China is still in the primary stage of socialism, which is the fundamental basis for adopting the current policy instead of other policies. (3) The economic development strategy derived from this. (4) The task of developing a socialist commodity economy and the direction of China's economic system reform derived from this. (5) The task of building a socialist democratic politics and the principles of China's political system reform derived from this. (6) The task of strengthening and improving the Party's leadership, including the leadership system of the ruling party, inner-party democracy, supervision of party leaders, party cadres, and party conduct. (7) The necessity of avoiding "left" and right" tendencies in theoretical and ideological guidance, emphasizing the two basic points of the line since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, which are sticking to the Four Cardinal Principles and adhering to reform and opening up to invigorate. It points out that in new practices, there must be creative theoretical exploration.
The request also proposed that the Thirteenth National Congress's political report should be based on the theory of the primary stage of socialism. Why should the theory of the primary stage of socialism be used as the basis for argumentation? The request said: to confirm that China is in the primary stage of socialism, first, it is to clearly state that we are socialist and cannot go back to capitalism; full-scale westernization is harmful to the country and the people. Second, it is to clearly state that we are in the primary stage of socialism, and we can only progress gradually, we cannot rush or seek perfection prematurely. It seems that by discussing the primary stage of socialism, it is possible to clarify the need to avoid both "left" and right" tendencies, as well as the nature and basis of our reform. If this can be achieved, it would be beneficial for achieving a unified understanding within the party and for ensuring long-term stability in foreign understanding of our policies. Please indicate if you agree. If so, the drafting of the report will proceed in this direction, and a rough draft can be expected by early May, with revisions until July and then submitted for central review at Beidaihe. If not, please give instructions!
Four days later, Deng Xiaoping gave instructions: "This design is good."
On November 16, 1987, Deng Xiaoping said during a meeting with Tatsuko Doi, Chairman of the Japan Socialist Party: "The report of our Party's Thirteenth National Congress was collectively written, reflecting the wisdom of several thousand people. Many of its contents were not proposed by me. Of course, there were also my views and opinions, but the majority were collective opinions."
After the initial draft of the political report of the Thirteenth National Congress was released, the CPC Central Committee invited leaders of various democratic parties, relevant organizations, and some non-party patriotic intellectuals, as well as representatives from ethnic and religious communities, to hold a week-long symposium to solicit their opinions on the draft. At the symposium, participants freely expressed their opinions and put forward valuable suggestions for modification.
On October 20, 1987, the Seventh Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee of the CPC discussed and approved the report of the Central Committee to the Thirteenth National Congress, as well as the partial amendments to the Party Constitution. There was unanimous agreement to submit these two documents for deliberation at the Thirteenth National Congress.
With this, the preparations for the Thirteenth National Congress of the CPC were fully completed.
On the morning of October 25, the Thirteenth National Congress of the CPC opened at the Great Hall of the People.
The delegates, carrying the heavy responsibility of 46 million party members, wearing the red attendance badges, happily arrived at the Great Hall of the People to attend the opening ceremony. Among them were veteran proletarian revolutionaries and outstanding middle-aged and young people who had made contributions to reform and opening up. Vice Chairman of the National People's Congress Standing Committee, non-party Vice Chairman of the National Committee of the Chinese People's Political Consultative Conference, leaders of various democratic parties, and the All-China Federation of Industry and Commerce, as well as non-party patriotic intellectuals, representatives from ethnic and religious communities, were invited as guests and seated at the presidium. Some members of the Twelfth Central Committee who were not delegates to the Thirteenth National Congress, members of the Central Advisory Commission, members of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, and some old comrades within the Party and other relevant personnel attended the meeting.
Deng Xiaoping presided over the congress and announced its opening. Zhao Ziyang delivered the political report on behalf of the Twelfth Central Committee.
The political report was divided into seven parts: (1) Historic achievements and the tasks of this congress; (2) The primary stage of socialism and the Party's basic line; (3) Economic development strategy; (4) Economic system reform; (5) Political system reform; (6) Strengthening Party building in the course of reform and opening up; (7) Striving for new victories for Marxism in China.
The report clearly put forward and expounded on the theory of the socialist stage, namely: First, our country is already a socialist society. We must adhere to and not deviate from socialism. Second, our socialist society is still in its primary stage. We must start from this reality and not surpass this stage. The primary stage of socialism in our country is not a generic reference to the initial stage that any country entering socialism will go through, but specifically refers to the specific stage that our country must go through in constructing socialism under the conditions of backward productive forces and underdeveloped commodity economy. This stage will take at least hundreds of years. 
Based on the theory of the primary stage of socialism, the report formulates the Party's basic line during the primary stage of socialism, which is: to lead and unite the people of all ethnic groups in the country, with economic construction as the central task, uphold the four basic principles, adhere to reform and opening up, self-reliance, hard work, and strive to build our country into a prosperous, democratic, and civilized socialist modernized country.
The report summarizes the 12 basic points of building socialism with Chinese characteristics, namely: emancipating the mind, seeking truth from facts, taking practice as the sole criterion for testing truth; building socialism must be based on our own national conditions and follow our own path; in the conditions of backward economy and culture, building socialism must go through a long primary stage; the fundamental task of socialist society is to develop productive forces and concentrate efforts on modernization; socialist economy is a planned commodity economy; reform is an important driving force for the development of socialist society, opening up is a necessary condition for realizing socialist modernization; socialist democratic politics and socialist spiritual civilization are important features of socialism; upholding the four basic principles and adhering to the overall policy of reform and opening up are two basic points that must be combined and cannot be separated; "one country, two systems" is used to achieve national unity; the style of the ruling party is related to the life and death of the party; the principles of independence, equality, mutual respect, and non-interference in internal affairs are used to develop relations with foreign communist parties and other political parties; peace and development are the themes of the contemporary world.
The report formally formulates the "Three-Step Development Strategy" for economic development. The first step is to double the gross national product compared to 1980 and solve the problem of people's basic needs. The second step is to double the gross national product again by the end of the twentieth century and achieve a moderate level of living for the people. The third step is to reach the level of moderately developed countries in terms of per capita gross national product by the middle of the twenty-first century, with the people's living conditions being relatively affluent and realizing basic modernization.
The report also formulates an action plan to accelerate economic and political system reform and officially puts political system reform on the agenda of the Party. Regarding economic system reform, focusing on transforming the enterprise management mechanism as the central link, phased reforms are carried out in areas such as planning, investment, pricing, finance, and foreign trade to establish the basic framework of a new planned commodity economy system. Political system reform aims to eliminate disadvantages and build a socialist democratic political system with Chinese characteristics. The long-term goal of reform is to establish a highly democratic, fully legal, efficient, and dynamic socialist political system. The short-term goal of political system reform is to establish leadership system that is conducive to improving efficiency, enhancing vitality, and stimulating various initiatives.
In addition, the report explicitly puts forward the criterion of productivity, that is, whether it is conducive to the liberation and development of social productive forces as the standard to evaluate reform measures and other party policies.
After eight days of intense and orderly work, the 13th National Congress of the Party successfully completed all tasks, and the Congress elected the 13th Central Committee, the 2nd Central Advisory Committee, and the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection. The Congress closed on November 1st in a democratic and united atmosphere.
The Congress calls on all Party comrades to, under the banner of building socialism with Chinese characteristics, under the leadership of the 13th Central Committee, adhere to the Party's basic line, firmly grasp the "one central task, two basic points" as stipulated by this basic line, strengthen Party unity, strengthen close ties with the people of the whole country, work together with one heart and one mind, inspire spirits, work hard, forge ahead, and strive to achieve the grand goal of socialist modernization.
The conference emphasized that the entire party must resolutely implement the party's basic line for the primary stage of socialism as formulated in the conference, conscientiously implement the resolutions passed by the conference, strive to complete the tasks proposed by the conference, and lead the people of all ethnic groups to continue moving forward along the path of socialism with Chinese characteristics. During the conference, many political parties and organizations from other countries called to congratulate the conference. Representatives of democratic parties, non-party patriotic democrats in China also expressed their congratulations to the conference, and the presidium of the conference expressed gratitude to them. 
On November 2, the first plenary session of the 13th Central Committee was held, and the meeting elected members of the Politburo of the Central Committee, including Wan Li, Tian Jiyun, Qiao Shi, Jiang Zemin, Li Peng, Li Tieying, Li Ruihuan, Li Ximing, Yang Rudai, Yang Shangkun, Wu Xueqian, Song Ping, Zhao Ziyang, Hu Qili, Hu Yaobang, Yao Yilin, Qin Jiwei, and alternate members of the Politburo Ding Guangen; members of the Standing Committee of the Politburo Qiao Shi, Zhao Ziyang, Li Peng, Hu Qili, Yao Yilin; General Secretary of the Central Committee Zhao Ziyang; Secretaries of the Central Secretariat Hu Qili, Qiao Shi, Rui Xingwen, Yan Mingfu, and alternate Secretary Wen Jiabao; and the decision to appoint Deng Xiaoping as Chairman of the Central Military Commission, Zhao Ziyang as First Vice Chairman, and Yang Shangkun as Executive Vice Chairman. The plenary session approved Chen Yun as Director of the Central Advisory Committee and Qiao Shi as Secretary of the Central Discipline Inspection Commission. 
It is worth noting that in the new Central Committee, a large number of relatively young comrades were selected, while a group of outstanding and respected old proletarian revolutionaries retired. This vividly demonstrates the vigorous development of our party's cause, and is a reliable guarantee for the continued and stable implementation of our party's correct line. 
Compared with the previous central leadership structure, the average age of the Politburo, the Standing Committee of the Politburo, and the Central Secretariat has significantly decreased. The average age of the members and alternate members of the 12th Central Committee when they were elected was 59.1 years old, while that of the 13th Central Committee is 55.2 years old, fully showing that our party's cause is flourishing, vibrant, and has successors. At this conference, Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun, and other old proletarian revolutionaries withdrew from the Central Committee and the Politburo of the Party, which played a very important role in further rejuvenating the central leadership body and the new and old alternation of the leadership structure. 
This conference is a democratic, united, open, comprehensive conference to promote reform and construction, and also a conference that makes our party more vibrant and vigorous.
2. The Deepening of Understanding of the "Primary Stage of Socialism" and Its Historical Significance 
It is the primary issue to correctly understand the historical stage in which our society is currently located, and it is the fundamental basis for us to formulate and implement correct lines and policies in building socialism with Chinese characteristics. 
In building socialism with Chinese characteristics, the primary issue is, of course, to understand the national conditions of China. On this issue, both the Soviet Union and China have profound lessons. 
The Soviet Union was the world's first socialist country. Its greatest achievement is to turn socialism from theory into reality. But in a country like the Soviet Union, there was no ready-made successful experience for us on how to build socialism. At the time, the situation in the Soviet Union was very difficult. The domestic hostile forces wanted to overthrow the Soviet power, and the international enemies wanted to strangle the socialist system that had not yet stood firm. Faced with internal and external pressures, the Soviet people, under the leadership of the Soviet Communist Party, finally overcame various difficulties. Socialism not only stood firm but also presented a thriving scene. Based on practice, Lenin proposed: From the standpoint of communism, to deny political parties means to leap from the eve of capitalism's collapse (in Germany) to its highest stage, communism, rather than to its lower and middle stages. We were still in the initial stage of transition from capitalism to socialism and to communism in Russia (the third year after the overthrow of the bourgeoisie). After Lenin's death, just over 12 years later, Stalin declared in 1936: "Our Soviet society has basically achieved socialism, established the socialist system, and realized the system known to Marxists as the first stage or lower stage of communism." Three years later, Stalin declared again: "We are moving towards communism." This practice was obviously rash. After Stalin's death, Khrushchev pushed the idea of rushing towards communism to the extreme. Following the 21st Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, which proposed comprehensive communist construction, Khrushchev proposed at the 22nd Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union in 1961 that the Soviet Union would take 20 years to basically build a communist society. The new program adopted by the 22nd Congress of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union was: "Our generation will live under the communist system." When boasting about the significance of this program, Khrushchev said, "The three programs of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union are like a three-stage rocket. The first stage enables us to break away from the capitalist world, the second stage elevates us to socialism, and the task of the third stage is to introduce communism." 
Twenty years passed and the plan completely failed, becoming a mirage, which showed that the Soviet Union's estimation of the stages of social development did not match reality. It was not until the 1980s that the Soviet Union and some countries in Eastern Europe began to reevaluate the stage of their own social development. 
The Communist Party of China also took a detour in understanding the historical stage in which China was situated. 
After 28 years of effort, the Communist Party of China achieved great victory in the new democratic revolution, and in a relatively short period of time, it restored the national economy and carried out socialist transformation, establishing a socialist system in China. Regarding the national conditions of China, Mao Zedong analyzed it as follows at the Second Plenary Session of the Seventh Central Committee: In terms of the proportion of industry and agriculture in the national economy, before the War of Resistance Against Japan, modern industry accounted for about 10% and agriculture and handicraft industry accounted for about 90% in the country as a whole. This was the manifestation of the oppression of imperialist and feudal systems on China. This was the manifestation of the semi-colonial and semi-feudal nature of old China in the economic sphere. This was also the fundamental starting point for all periods during the Chinese revolution and for a considerable period after the revolutionary victory. Based on this point, a series of strategic, tactical, and policy issues emerged within our party. 
Based on this analysis, Mao Zedong proposed the major economic policies that our party should implement after the Second Plenary Session of the Seventh Central Committee. After the establishment of New China, in the process of socialist transformation, our party made adjustments to some of the policies put forward by the Second Plenary Session of the Seventh Central Committee based on the new situation, and the basic spirit was implemented. However, after the basic completion of socialist transformation, we relaxed our investigation and analysis of the new national conditions. We should have drawn the necessary conclusions based on the 10% modern industry and 90% agriculture and handicraft industry. Unfortunately, at that time, we were too excited about the victory of socialist transformation and distanced ourselves from reality, taking a circuitous route. 
The Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Communist Party of China marked a major turning point in China's history. With the launch of rectification, when the Party analyzed the tortuous path and causes of development mistakes that China has gone through since the establishment of New China, it began to involve the issue of the stage of social development in China. In 1979, in his speech at the thirtieth anniversary of the National Day, Ye Jianying pointed out: "Compared with the capitalist system, which has already had a history of three to four hundred years, socialism is still in its infancy. "Our country is still a developing socialist country." This already includes the idea of the primary stage.
In 1981, the Sixth Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) passed the "Resolution on Certain Historical Issues of the Communist Party of China since the Founding of the People's Republic of China," which clearly stated for the first time that our socialist system is still in the primary stage. However, there is no doubt that China has established a socialist system and entered a socialist society. Any viewpoint that denies this basic fact is incorrect.
The political report of the Twelfth CPC National Congress in 1982 stated that our socialist society is still in the early stage of development and that material civilization is not yet highly developed.
The "Resolution on the Guiding Principles of Socialist Spiritual Civilization Construction by the CPC Central Committee" passed at the Sixth Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee of the CPC in 1986 stated: "Our country is still in the primary stage of socialism. We must not only implement the principle of distribution according to work and develop a socialist commodity economy and competition, but also, for a considerable period of time, develop various economic components under the condition of public ownership as the mainstay and encourage the well-off of a certain part of the population under the goal of common prosperity." 
These three important documents all put forward the major theoretical proposition of "the primary stage of socialism" in China and made clear and scientific explanations of it, but they did not play a role.
The political report of the Thirteenth CPC National Congress systematically expounded on this issue of significant theoretical and practical significance for the first time and used it as the basis for the entire report, clearly affirming that China is currently in the primary stage of socialism, and clarifying the two levels of meaning of the primary stage of socialism: first, our society is already a socialist society. We must adhere to socialism and cannot deviate from it. Second, the socialist society in China is still in the early stage.
The content of the primary stage of socialism in our country not only refers to the first stage or the earliest stage in the development sequence, but mainly refers to a special stage of development for a country with underdeveloped economy and culture like China. Its meaning has two levels: first, in terms of the nature of society, China has already reached socialism and is not in a transitional period. Therefore, we must adhere to the socialist direction and road and cannot go back to capitalism or engage in "full Westernization" or "capitalist lessons." Any tendency to go backwards and deviate from the socialist track is incompatible with the socialist nature. Second, in terms of the level of development, the maturity level of China's socialist society is still very low, only at the primary stage, not at a higher stage. Therefore, we must start from this most basic and important national condition and objective reality, engage in construction and reform, and cannot demand excessively high achievements. The proposition of the primary stage of socialism, by clearly distinguishing it from the transitional period and the higher stage of socialism, provides a scientific foundation for our party's line, principles, and policies, thereby avoiding the left-wing mistakes of surpassing the stage in the past.
China is in the primary stage of socialism due to the level of its productive forces. The political report of the Thirteenth CPC National Congress analyzed it as follows: on the one hand, the socialist economic system based on public ownership of the means of production, the socialist political system of people's democratic dictatorship, and the guiding position of Marxism in the ideological field have already been established; the system of exploitation and the exploiting classes have been eliminated; the national economic strength has experienced significant growth, and education, science, and cultural undertakings have developed considerably. On the other hand, China has a large population, a weak foundation, and its per capita GDP still ranks low in the world. The prominent features are as follows: with a population of over one billion, eight hundred million live in rural areas and still rely mostly on manual tools for their livelihood; there is a certain amount of modern industries coexisting with a large number of industries that are several decades or even hundreds of years behind the modern level; economically developed areas coexist with underdeveloped and impoverished areas; although there are a few areas with world-advanced scientific and technological levels, the overall level of science and technology is not high, and illiteracy and semi-literacy still account for nearly one-fourth of the population. The backwardness of productivity determines that the degree of production socialization necessary for the development of socialist public ownership is still low. The commodity economy and domestic market are not well developed, and natural economy and semi-natural economy account for a considerable proportion. The socialist economic system is still immature. In terms of the superstructure, a series of economic and cultural conditions necessary for the construction of highly socialist democratic politics are insufficient. Feudalism, decaying capitalist ideology, and the habits of small-scale production have a widespread influence in society and often infiltrate the ranks of the party cadres and government officials. This situation indicates that we are far from surpassing the primary stage of socialism today.
The primary stage of socialism in our country is a relatively long historical stage. As pointed out in the political report of the 13th National Congress: From the basic completion of the socialist transformation of private ownership of the means of production in the 1950s to the basic realization of socialist modernization, it will take at least hundreds of years, all of which belong to the primary stage of socialism.
In this stage, the main contradiction we face is the contradiction between the growing material and cultural needs of the people and the backwardness of social production. Therefore, in order to solve the main contradiction, we must give top priority to liberating and developing the productive forces and always take economic construction as the central task.
China is in the primary stage of socialism, not in a general sense, but in a specific sense. The so-called not in a general sense means that it is not the initial stage that any country enters into after entering socialist society. Developed capitalist countries and countries with medium development levels do not need to go through such a "primary stage" after entering socialist society. The so-called specific sense means that countries like us, which were originally economically and culturally backward, must go through a specific historical stage after entering socialist society, which is the "primary stage". So, what kind of historical stage is the primary stage of socialism in our country? The political report of the 13th National Congress answered this question:
In summary, the primary stage of socialism in our country is a stage of gradually getting rid of poverty and backwardness; it is a stage where the agrarian country based on manual labor of the majority of the agricultural population gradually transforms into a modern industrial country with a majority of non-agricultural population; it is a stage where the natural economy and semi-natural economy, which account for a significant proportion, transform into a highly developed commodity economy; it is a stage where a vibrant socialist economic, political, and cultural system is established and developed through reform and exploration; it is a stage where the whole nation rises up, works hard, and realizes the great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation.
Based on the reality of the primary stage of socialism, we must concentrate our efforts on modernization construction, uphold comprehensive reform, adhere to opening up, give priority to the public sector while vigorously developing the commodity economy, take stability and unity as a premise, and strive to build a democratic political system. We must also take Marxist ideology as guidance and strive to build spiritual civilization.
The Chinese Communist Party's recognition of the primary stage of socialism in our country has significant theoretical and practical significance. Theoretically, it enriches and develops the theory of Marxist socialism development stages, providing a scientific basis for our party to formulate correct lines and policies. In practice, it guides our country's reform, opening up, and construction along the path of scientific socialism, helping us to guard against both "left" and right deviations. If we cannot see that our country has already achieved socialism, there is a possibility of making right-wing errors. If we do not recognize that our country is in the primary stage of socialism, there is a possibility of making "left" errors. The recognition roots of both "left" and right deviations stem from being divorced from reality, from the national conditions, and from not realizing that our country is in the primary stage of socialism.
3. Deep analysis of the "one central task and two basic points"
Based on the judgment that China is in the primary stage of socialism, the political report of the 13th National Congress put forward the Party's basic line for the primary stage of socialism, which is to "lead and unite the people of all ethnic groups, take economic construction as the center, adhere to the four cardinal principles, adhere to reform and opening up, rely on our own efforts, work hard, and strive to build our country into a prosperous, democratic, and civilized socialist modern country."
This basic line of thinking is not easy to obtain.
The basic line or general line refers to the party's fundamental guiding principles in a large historical stage. All other policies and measures must be subordinate to and serve the basic line or general line. Because of the significant importance of the basic line, the party's top leaders attach great importance to its formulation.
During the period of democratic revolution, the first generation leadership collective of the CPC with Mao Zedong as its core formulated the correct general line, which is: "a proletarian-led, people's, anti-imperialist, anti-feudal, and anti-bureaucratic capitalist revolution."
Under the guidance of this general line, the Communist Party of China led the people to drive away the Japanese aggressors, defeated Chiang Kai-shek and established the new China.
The founding of the People's Republic of China marked the basic completion of the new democratic revolution and the beginning of the socialist revolution. During this period, our country was in the transition from new democracy to socialism. The party's general line during the transition period was: "from the founding of the People's Republic of China to the basic completion of socialist transformation, this is a transitional period. The general line and overall task of the party during this transitional period is to gradually realize the socialist industrialization of the country and gradually carry out socialist transformation of agriculture, handicraft industry, and capitalist industry and commerce." Practice has proved that this general line is correct. By implementing this general line, the socialist system in our country has been established, and our country's socialist industrialization has taken a gratifying step.
After our country entered the socialist society, our party put forward the general line of "gaining momentum and striving for the best, and promoting socialist construction in an all-round way with greater, faster, better and more economical results." As for this general line, the Resolution on Several Historical Issues passed in 1981 made the following evaluation: "In 1958, the correct aspect of the general line for socialist construction and its basic point approved at the Second Plenary Session of the Eighth Party Congress reflects the widespread desire of the people for urgently changing the backward economic and cultural conditions in our country, but the drawback is that it neglects the objective economic laws." This evaluation is objective. By implementing this general line, our country experienced the "Great Leap Forward" in the eagerness to develop productive forces and the eagerness to change production relations and transition to "people's communes". As a result, the desire for quick success ultimately led to failure. Violating economic laws, we suffered the consequences of these laws. After this, we achieved certain achievements on one hand, but on the other hand, we made mistakes, suffered setbacks, widened the gap between us and developed countries, and affected the demonstration of the superiority of socialism.
During the "Cultural Revolution", the 9th Party Congress proposed a basic line for the whole socialist historical stage, which was a "left" erroneous line with "class struggle as the key". It was not a "lifeline", but a "death line" that led the country towards collapse and chaos.
History is the mirror by which one can know the rise and fall of a nation. The Party has several basic lines or general lines in its history, some of which have been successful while others have taught valuable lessons through failure. Faced with history, the Party reflects, and so do its leaders. Why does one line lead to victory while another leads to failure, and what are the reasons behind this? The result of this reflection undoubtedly holds significant importance in shaping the Party's basic line during the primary stage of socialism. Its direct consequence is that the Party gradually formed its basic line during the primary stage of socialism by summarizing its historical experiences.
As early as 18 years before the concept of the "primary stage of socialism" was proposed, Zhou Enlai laid the initial foundation for the formation of this basic line in the Government Work Report during the first session of the Third National People's Congress held in December 1964. In the report, Zhou Enlai pointed out that the main task of future economic development is to transform our country into a socialist power with modern agriculture, industry, national defense, and science and technology at a relatively short historical period, catching up with and surpassing the advanced level of the world. In order to achieve this great historical task, starting from the third Five-Year Plan, the development of our national economy can be divided into two stages: the first stage is to establish an independent and relatively complete industrial system and national economic system, and the second stage is to comprehensively modernize agriculture, industry, national defense, and science and technology, leading our country's economy to the forefront of the world.
This vision, hindered by erroneous interference from the "left," failed to become a reality, but its historical significance cannot be underestimated. The Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, held at the end of 1978, reaffirmed the correct ideological line, rejected the previous "left" line that prioritized class struggle, shifted the focus of work to economic construction, and formulated the basic principles of reform and opening up. This laid a solid foundation for the formulation of the Party's basic line during the primary stage of socialism.
After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, the Party repeatedly emphasized the importance of focusing on economic construction, adhering to the four fundamental principles, and carrying out reform and opening up. After successfully rectifying the chaos, the Party's 12th National Congress put forward the overall task for the Party in the new era, which is to unite all the people of our country, rely on our own efforts, work hard, gradually achieve modernization in industry, agriculture, national defense, and science and technology, and build our country into a highly civilized and democratic socialist state.
In September 1986, the 6th Plenary Session of the 12th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China proposed the overall layout of socialist modernization: focusing on economic construction, resolutely carrying out economic system reforms, resolutely carrying out political system reforms, resolutely strengthening the construction of spiritual civilization, and coordinating and promoting these aspects together. This "overall layout" already encompassed the main contents of the basic line summarized by the 13th National Congress, but it was still incomplete.
On January 28, 1987, the Communist Party of China Central Committee stated in its notice "Regarding Several Issues on Opposing Bourgeois Liberalization" that the line since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee is based on China's actual conditions to build socialism with Chinese characteristics. The basic points of this line are twofold: adhering to the four fundamental principles and adhering to the policy of reform, opening up, and invigorating. The introduction of these "two basic points" directly prepared for the final formation of the basic line.
Under these circumstances and based on the theory of the primary stage of socialism, the 13th National Congress of the Party explicitly proposed and summarized the Party's basic line during the primary stage of socialism.
The key points of the Party's basic line during the primary stage of socialism are "placing economic construction at the center, adhering to the four fundamental principles, and persevering with reform and opening up," also known as the "one central task, two basic points."
The "one central task, two basic points" embodies Deng Xiaoping's painstaking efforts and condensed his strategy for national rejuvenation. The Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, led by Deng Xiaoping, implemented a strategic shift and decided on the basic national policy of reform and opening up. From then on, it led China's giant ship into a new era and new fields. However, Deng Xiaoping felt that something was missing. So, at the theoretical work conference in early 1979, Deng Xiaoping timely proposed to adhere to the four basic principles. After that, Deng Xiaoping always held onto the central link of economic construction and grasped the two basic points to promote the sustained and healthy development of Chinese society. When someone summarized the party's basic line in the primary stage of socialism as "one central task, two basic points," Deng Xiaoping expressed appreciation and believed it was well summarized.
"One central task, two basic points" are interrelated, interdependent, and indispensable.
"To take economic construction as the center" runs through the whole process of completing the fundamental task of socialism and is the red line for developing social productive forces. It not only reveals and defines the central position of economic construction in the work of the Party and the country, but also requires other tasks to be subordinate to and serve the center of economic construction, in order to ensure the development of social productive forces. Why should we adhere to economic construction as the center? This is because the fundamental task of socialism is to develop productive forces. Specifically, because our socialist system did not originate from a developed capitalist society like Russia, but rather from a semi-colonial and semi-feudal society with a weak foundation and poor conditions. Although great achievements have been made in developing productive forces since the founding of the People's Republic of China, we are still far behind developed countries. Therefore, it is necessary to adhere to economic construction as the center, carry out socialist modernization, and concentrate our efforts on developing productive forces. "Adhering to reform and opening up" and "adhering to the four basic principles" are the two basic points, which revolve closely around the center of economic construction and the central task of developing productive forces. The basic characteristics of the primary stage of socialism are: underdeveloped productivity, immature production relations, and imperfect superstructure. Therefore, it is necessary to adhere to reform. Reform and opening up are the only way for our country to develop social productive forces and achieve socialist modernization. The four basic principles are the fundamental guarantee for developing social productive forces and socialist modernization. The "two basic points" are the unity of adhering to the socialist direction and the self-improvement and development of the socialist system.
"One central task, two basic points" also constrain and promote each other. With the objective requirement of developing productivity as the benchmark, the center is to develop productive forces, while the "two basic points" are like the two wings of an aircraft, providing balance to the main body in the center position. The two basic points are constrained by the "one central task" while also mutually constraining each other.
The party's basic line in the primary stage of socialism not only defines "one central task, two basic points," but also defines our goal of struggle. This is to "strive to build our country into a prosperous, democratic, and culturally advanced socialist modern country." Prosperity, democracy, and cultural advancement actually include requirements in the economic, political, and ideological and cultural aspects. This is not only a trinity modernization goal, but also three important aspects of socialism with Chinese characteristics.
"Prosperity" is the goal and requirement in the socio-economic field. A socialist society must be prosperous rather than poor. The 13th National Congress was the first to include "prosperity" as a goal of the party's struggle.
"Democracy" is the goal and requirement in political construction. Socialist democracy is substantially higher than capitalist democracy. Socialist democracy requires the broad masses of the people to participate in the management of the country and society, truly achieving "people as masters of their own affairs".
"Civilization" refers to spiritual civilization, which is the goal and requirement in the ideological and cultural field. Socialist spiritual civilization is an important characteristic of socialism. To construct socialism with Chinese characteristics, it is necessary to eliminate various forms of ignorance and backwardness left over from the old society. For a long period in the past, our understanding of socialism was not completely clear, and we did not formulate a scientific goal that suits our national conditions. This lack of clarity was an important manifestation of this.
The goal of striving for prosperity, democracy, and civilization is a three-dimensional reflection of our new understanding of socialism. This is a major achievement in understanding our national conditions and socialism since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee.
The basic line of the Party in the primary stage of socialism stipulates the reliance on strength to achieve the goals of struggle. This is "leadership and unity of people of all ethnic groups". After the basic completion of the socialist transformation of the ownership system, the exploiting class as a class has been eliminated. Apart from a few hostile elements, the people of all ethnic groups in the country under the leadership of the Communist Party are the reliance in accomplishing the various tasks of the primary stage of socialism.
The basic line of the Party in the primary stage of socialism poses requirements for the spiritual state in accomplishing various tasks, namely, "self-reliance and hard work". What does China rely on for development? What does China rely on to achieve the goals of prosperity, democracy, and civilization? Foreign aid is undoubtedly important, but it is not our base point. Our base point is to rely on self-reliance. In other words, primarily relying on the strength of the people themselves, relying on the enthusiasm and creativity of the people.
The Chinese people have a glorious tradition. They are indomitable in the face of difficulties. It is precisely relying on this spirit of hard struggle that they have overcome difficulties and won one victory after another. This spirit was a winning weapon in the era of revolutionary warfare, and it is also necessary to achieve the goal of a three-dimensional combination of prosperity, democracy, and civilization. To fulfill the historical mission of achieving the great rejuvenation of the Chinese nation in the primary stage of socialism, people of all ethnic groups in China must actively engage in the tide of reform and construction with the attitude of masters. Only in this way can we become part of the world's civilized nations.
II. The introduction of the "Three-step Development" strategy
Starting from 1979, Deng Xiaoping began to design the specific blueprint for China's modernization and gradually formed the strategy of "two steps" to achieve a "two-fold increase" and reach the goal of a "moderately prosperous level" by the end of the 20th century.
The 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) shouldered the historical task of shifting the focus of the Party's work and the attention of the people to socialist modernization construction. It reaffirmed the goal of achieving the four modernizations within the 20th century and put forward the need to "correctly resolve the specific paths, principles, methods, and measures to achieve the four modernizations". It should be said that the 3rd Plenary Session established the overall goal of the economic development strategy of "achieving the four modernizations" and put forward the basic principles to achieve this goal. However, what does the blueprint for the "four modernizations" look like? How can it be achieved through what means and steps? At that time, the understanding was still relatively abstract and vague.
1. New thinking on China's modernization development strategy
After the 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, the second generation of the central leadership group with Deng Xiaoping at the core began to seriously contemplate and explore how to achieve China's modernization. In March 1979, Deng Xiaoping proposed in his speech "Adhere to the Four Fundamental Principles": "In the past, we carried out the democratic revolution, which had to be adapted to China's conditions and followed the path of surrounding the cities from the countryside opened up by Comrade Mao Zedong. Now, in doing construction, we must also adapt to China's conditions and follow a Chinese-style path of modernization." He also proposed, "Chinese-style modernization must start from China's characteristics". Deng Xiaoping summarized at least two important characteristics that must be seen in order for China to achieve modernization: one is a weak foundation and the other is a large population with limited arable land. These two characteristics determined that China's starting point for modernization was very low, so the time it would take to achieve modernization would be relatively long. China could only gradually achieve modernization step by step based on this low starting point. Afterward, the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee and the State Council discussed and studied how China could achieve socialist modernization. They believed that "in carrying out modernization, we must start from China's national conditions". The Central Work Meeting held in April 1979 analyzed China's national conditions and pointed out: "We are a populous country with more than 900 million people, of whom over 80% are farmers. Although we have achieved victory in the revolution for 30 years, our economy is still very backward and the living standards of our people are still very low. Our country is poor, and modernization requires a large amount of capital, while the people want to improve their lives. This is a contradiction; in carrying out modernization, we need fewer people, but we have a large amount of labor force that needs employment, which is also a contradiction. In such contradictions, we can only carry out the 'Four Modernizations'; this is the reality and the basic starting point that we must consider when planning and building the blueprint."
It was precisely based on the basic starting point of China's national conditions that Deng Xiaoping began to conceive the specific blueprint for China's modernization. This is both a requirement for the construction of modernization and an inevitable result of the logical development of Deng Xiaoping's thinking. On December 6, 1979, during a meeting with Japanese Prime Minister Masayoshi Ohira, Deng Xiaoping answered the question of how the blueprint for China's modernization was conceived, saying: "The four modernizations we want to achieve are Chinese-style four modernizations. Even if by the end of this century, our four modernizations have achieved certain goals, the average income of our nation will still be very low. In order to reach the level of a relatively well-off third world country, such as an average income of 1,000 US dollars, we still need to make great efforts."
Even if it reaches that level, compared to the West, China is still lagging behind. I can only say that China is still in a moderately prosperous state." Here, Deng Xiaoping first defined the four modernizations as reaching a level of "one thousand dollars" and entering a "moderately prosperous" state. The concepts of "one thousand dollars" and "moderately prosperous" were also formed during this conversation. Over a month later, when discussing his response to Prime Minister Takeo Miki's question, Deng Xiaoping said, "Of course, this answer is not accurate, but it is not said randomly either." Deng Xiaoping analyzed that currently, we only have a few hundred US dollars, if we were to reach 1000 dollars, it would need to triple. Singapore and Hong Kong have over 3000 dollars. It is not easy for us to reach that level because we have a vast territory and a large population, with conditions that are very different. But it should be said that if our GDP really reaches an average of 1000 dollars per person, then our lives will be much better than theirs, even better than their 2000 dollars. If the conversation between Deng Xiaoping and Prime Minister Miki was the first time that he discussed his vision for the next 20 years with a foreign guest, then in January 1980, in his speech titled "The Current Situation and Tasks," although he was just recounting his conversation with Prime Minister Miki, he presented his vision to the entire party for the first time. He pointed out: To realize the Chinese-style four modernizations, it will be accomplished in two decades, with each ten-year period consisting of important and determining stages. Therefore, the 1980s are very important and decisive. This decade lays a solid foundation while the following decade, within the next 20 years, will truly achieve the Chinese-style four modernizations and have real hope.
According to Deng Xiaoping's conception, in June 1981, the 6th Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee put forward the goal of "achieving modernization in a step-by-step and phased manner." In November 1981, at the Fourth Session of the 5th National People's Congress, the "moderately prosperous level" was defined as the prospect of China's economic development. The congress believed that the development speed during the sixth five-year plan cannot be fast, but there is hope for higher development speed during the seventh five-year plan, and even higher in the following decade. The congress proposed to strive to double the total output value of industry and agriculture within 20 years, achieving a moderately prosperous level of living for the people. By September 1982, at the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, Deng Xiaoping's proposed "moderately prosperous" level was officially put forward and established as the strategic goal for the entire party and the entire Chinese nation towards the end of the 20th century. The report of the 12th Congress pointed out that from 1981 to the end of the 20th century, the overall main objective of China's economic construction is to continuously improve economic efficiency, strive to double the annual total output value of industry and agriculture nationwide, increase it from the 710 billion yuan in 1980 to around 2.8 trillion yuan in the year 2000, and have the people's material and cultural lives reach a moderately prosperous level. In order to achieve the goal of the 20-year struggle, it needs to be divided into two steps strategically. The first ten years mainly lay a solid foundation, accumulate strength, create conditions, and the following ten years will enter a new period of economic rejuvenation.
After proposing the "two-step approach" to achieve the goal of "moderate prosperity" by the end of the 20th century, Deng Xiaoping began to further conceive the economic development goals of China in the mid-21st century starting in 1984, gradually forming the complete "three-step approach" of economic development strategy.
2. The Brewing and Elaboration of the "Three-Step Approach" Development Strategy
The development strategy of the "three-step approach" began to be brewed before 1984. The original wording was to achieve the Four Modernizations by the end of the 20th century. Later, the Party gradually realized that this task could not be quickly completed by the end of the 20th century, so the term "reaching a moderately prosperous level" was used instead. Although the term "achieving the Four Modernizations by the end of this century" is still sometimes used, its meaning has gradually changed, and it is no longer used in terms of completion but in terms of stages. In this case, in September 1982, the 12th National Congress of the Party proposed the goal of achieving double the economic output. Since only a moderately prosperous level could be achieved by the end of the 20th century, it would take some time to reach the level of modernization. In December 1980, Deng Xiaoping said in his speech on "Implementing Adjustments and Ensuring Stability and Unity" that after reaching a moderately prosperous level, "we should continue to advance and gradually achieve a higher level of modernization." In November 1981, the government work report of the Fourth Session of the Fifth National People's Congress pointed out that when people's living standards reach a moderately prosperous level by the end of the 20th century, our country's economy can start from a new starting point and quickly reach the level of economically developed countries.
