It can be seen that at this time, the goal of reaching the level of economically developed countries in stages had begun to take shape. However, by 1984, the conditions for clearly proposing the "Three-step Development Plan" goals were not yet met because the achievement of the "moderately prosperous" goal still needed to be tested. Shortly after the 12th National Congress of the Party, on October 14, 1982, Deng Xiaoping had a conversation with the responsible comrades of the National Development and Reform Commission, saying, "Can we achieve double the economic output by the end of the 20th century? The 12th National Congress of the Party said we can, and I also believe we can, but whether we can achieve it remains to be seen in our future work." "We need to focus on long-term planning now, and the key to long-term planning is to prepare for the next decade." "Preparation is a matter of racing against time and cannot be taken lightly." Deng Xiaoping’s remarks mean that there is a risk of failing to achieve double the economic output if time is not seized and taken seriously. 
After the 12th National Congress of the Party proposed the goal of doubling the economic output, Deng Xiaoping's lingering question was whether the goal could be achieved or if it would fall through. From 1982 to 1984, China's economic development was very fast, greatly exceeding the economic growth rate stipulated in the Sixth Five-Year Plan. Significant breakthroughs were achieved in rural reform, and in 1984, China's grain production reached a record high. Urban reform also began to take off, and the situation nationwide was encouraging. In early 1983, Deng Xiaoping inspected Jiangnan. He traveled through Jiangsu, Zhejiang, and Shanghai and saw that the situation was very good. People were happy, many new houses were being built, the market was well stocked, and the cadres were confident. Seeing these vivid scenes, Deng Xiaoping believed that "it seems that the prospects for the Four Modernizations are very good." After returning to Beijing, when Deng Xiaoping talked to several responsible comrades of the Central Committee, he pointed out that in order to achieve double the economic output by the end of the 20th century, there needs to be a comprehensive and more specific plan, and each province, autonomous region, and municipality directly under the central government also needs to have its own specific plan and be well-informed. In March 1984, when he talked with Japanese Prime Minister Yasuhiro Nakasone, Deng Xiaoping clearly stated, "The goal of doubling the economic output will not fall through." In June, when Deng Xiaoping met with the representative delegation of the Japanese side for the second meeting of the China-Japan Committee of Non-Governmental Personnel, he confidently stated that if China's economy continues to develop in the same way in the coming years, "the goal of doubling the economic output by the end of this century will surely be achieved." On October 1, at the celebration of the 35th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China, Deng Xiaoping solemnly declared that the recent situation indicates that the grand goal of doubling the economic output proposed by the 12th National Congress is achievable. 
Considering that achieving "moderate prosperity" by the end of the 20th century had already become a realistic goal, Deng Xiaoping, thinking about the future and long-term interests of the Chinese nation, began to contemplate the economic development strategy of China in the 21st century and design a grand blueprint. 
On April 18, 1984, Deng Xiaoping met with British Foreign Secretary Geoffrey Howe. Before and after this, Deng Xiaoping had already made it clear that achieving a moderately prosperous society by the end of the 20th century was only the "minimum goal" of the Four Modernizations. So, how long will it take to achieve the "four modernizations" and the basic realization of modernization? He first proposed the idea of this question during a conversation with Jeffrey Howe. He said that compared to our grand goals, the development in the past few years is just the beginning. After reaching a moderately prosperous level, we still need to approach the level of developed countries within 30 to 50 years in the 21st century. Deng Xiaoping mentioned this idea repeatedly. On May 29th, when Deng Xiaoping met with Brazilian President Figredo, he said: China is still poor now, with a per capita GDP of only 300 US dollars. But we have ambitious goals, to reach 800 US dollars per capita by the end of the 20th century. 800 US dollars is not much for economically developed countries, but it is a true ambition for China. What's more important is that with this foundation, we can approach the level of developed countries in another 30 to 50 years of development. Subsequently, in three conversations on June 30th, October 6th, and October 22nd of the same year, Deng Xiaoping expressed his ideas in roughly the same language, that is, the per capita GDP would reach 800 US dollars by the end of the 20th century, not 1000 US dollars. This is because he considered that by the end of the 20th century, China's population would exceed one billion and needs to be controlled to around 1.2 billion. If the total GDP doubles and the population grows to 1.2 billion, then the per capita GDP would be a little over 800 US dollars. Later, Deng Xiaoping also used the flexible term "800 to 1000 US dollars", but sometimes still said "800 US dollars" or "1000 US dollars". In addition, the goal Deng Xiaoping mentioned at that time was to "approach the level of developed countries", and the required time was "30 to 50 years", which is not exactly the same as his later statements.
As time entered 1985, Deng Xiaoping's "Three-Step Development Strategy" moved forward. In his speech at the National Conference on Science and Technology on March 7th, 1985, he pointed out that we have been striving for decades to eradicate poverty. The first step is to reach a moderately prosperous level by the end of the 20th century, which means not being poor or rich, but having a relatively good life. The second step is to approach the level of developed countries economically within another 30 to 50 years, making the people relatively affluent. This is the overall situation. Deng Xiaoping's words in this passage have several new elements compared to his speech in 1984: firstly, he used the terms "first step" and "second step", which prepared for the later summary of the "Three-Step Development Strategy"; secondly, he explained the "moderately prosperous level" as not being poor or rich but having a relatively good life; thirdly, he equated "making the people relatively affluent" with approaching the level of developed countries as a goal to strive for; fourthly, he pointed out that this is the "overall situation" for the entire party and the country. On March 25th, 1985, in his conversation with American journalists and his conversation with Tanzanian Vice President Mwinyi on April 15th of the same year, Deng Xiaoping said that the first step is to reach a moderately prosperous level by the end of the 20th century. From the time this goal was proposed at the end of 1979 until the end of the 20th century, there are 20 years. Based on a GDP of one trillion US dollars, it will take another 30 to 50 years, or more precisely, 50 years, to come close to the level of developed countries and achieve our second-step goal. It will take 70 years to accomplish this. In these two conversations, Deng Xiaoping clearly extended the time span of China's economic development strategy from 20 years to 70 years and divided the development goals into two steps, making the strategic goals and deployments increasingly clear. In September 1985, the Communist Party of China held the National Congress. Deng Xiaoping pointed out at the meeting: People now say that China has undergone significant changes. I have mentioned to some foreign visitors that this is just a minor change. Doubling the income and achieving a moderate level of prosperity can be considered a medium change. It is only when we can approach the level of developed countries by the middle of the 21st century that we can say it is a major change. Deng Xiaoping used the terms "minor change," "medium change," and "major change" to clearly represent the three stages of economic development. This "three changes" clearly demonstrate the three stages of economic development, which are very similar to the later concept of the "three-step approach" that he summarized.
By 1987, Deng Xiaoping's strategic plan for the "three-step approach" was complete. The positive economic development trends in 1985 and 1986 indicated that most of the main indicators of China's Seventh Five-Year Plan could be achieved ahead of schedule, which meant that the strategic goal of doubling the income by 1990 could be achieved earlier than expected. This made Deng Xiaoping more confident and his vision for future economic development became clearer. On March 8, 1987, Deng Xiaoping told visiting Tanzanian President Mwinyi that in the past eight years, we have gained experience and achieved satisfying results in construction. "In the first decade, from 1981 to 1990, doubling the GDP is estimated to be easily achieved and can be completed ahead of schedule. In the second decade, from 1991 to the end of this century, doubling it again is also reliable based on the development trend. People's living standards have improved significantly in the past eight years since the Third Plenum of the 11th Central Committee. By the end of this century, although our per capita GDP of 800 to 1,000 US dollars is not much, the annual GDP will exceed one trillion US dollars. With this foundation, it is hopeful to strive for the level of a moderately developed country." Deng Xiaoping has actually proposed the strategic plan of the "three-step approach" here, but just did not explicitly use the terms "first step," "second step," and "third step." Additionally, Deng Xiaoping changed the development strategic goal of our country from "approaching the level of developed countries" to "reaching the level of a moderately developed country" by the middle of the 21st century. On April 16 of the same year, when meeting with members of the Hong Kong Basic Law Drafting Committee, Deng Xiaoping again used the standard of a "moderately developed country" and quantified this goal as "per capita income of 4,000 US dollars" and "GDP of 60 trillion yuan," making the strategic goal of our country by the middle of the 21st century clear. On April 30 of the same year, when meeting with Spanish Deputy Prime Minister Lara, Deng Xiaoping explicitly and comprehensively described the economic development goals of the "three-step approach" for the first time. Deng Xiaoping pointed out: "Our original target was to double the income in the 1980s. Based on the 1980 GDP per capita of only 250 US dollars, doubling it would reach 500 US dollars. The second step is to double it again by the end of the 20th century, reaching 1,000 US dollars per capita. Achieving this target means that we will enter a moderately prosperous society, transforming impoverished China into a moderately prosperous China. By then, the GDP will exceed one trillion US dollars, although the per capita figure will still be relatively low, but the strength of the country will greatly increase. The most important goal we have set is the third step, doubling the income again by two to three times in 30 to 50 years in the 21st century, to reach a per capita income of around 4,000 US dollars. By achieving this, China will reach the level of a moderately developed country. This is our ambitious goal."
At this point, Deng Xiaoping's vision for the "Three-Step Development Strategy" for China's modernization construction is complete.
3. Establishment of the "Three-Step Development Strategy"
Based on Deng Xiaoping's vision and the basic national conditions of China's primary stage of socialism, the Socialist Modernization Construction "Three-Step Development Strategy" was formally established at the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of China in October 1987. The report of the 13th National Congress stated, "After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the strategic arrangement for China's economic construction is roughly divided into three steps. The first step is to double the gross national production value compared to 1980 and solve the people's basic material needs. This task has been basically achieved. The second step is to double the gross national production value by the end of the 20th century and achieve a moderately prosperous standard of living for the people. The third step is to reach the per capita gross national production value of a moderately developed country by the middle of the 21st century, achieve a relatively affluent life for the people, and basically achieve modernization. Then, we will continue to advance on this basis." The formulation of the "Three-Step Development Strategy" for economic development resolves the significant issues regarding the goals and steps of China's modernization construction, and will have a profound and lasting impact on China's development in the coming decades.
Compared with China's previous development strategies, the characteristics of the Socialist Modernization Construction "Three-Step Development Strategy" are as follows: First, it is realistic. Compared with the goals of "surpassing Britain and the US in 15 years" and "achieving four modernizations by the end of this century," it is a lower goal, but it is indeed a realistic goal. The early achievement of the first step of the "Three-Step Development Strategy" is powerful evidence. Second, it starts and ends with the improvement of the people's material and cultural living standards. Using "basic needs," "moderately prosperous," and "affluent" as the goals of modernization allows the people to vividly and intuitively understand and experience the process of achieving these goals, mobilizes their enthusiasm, and strengthens their confidence, which is in line with the fundamental purpose of socialism. Third, it is explicit, specific, and quantifiable. Quantifying the goals as "1000 US dollars" and "4000 US dollars" makes the goals very clear, specific, and easy to operate and measure. Fourth, it is connected to the world economy. This goal uses the "US dollar" as the unit of measurement, considering and comparing China's economy within the broader scope of the world, making the gap between China and developed countries clear and placing China's economy in the development of the world economy. Fifth, it is not only an economic goal but also a political goal. The fundamental task of socialism is to develop productive forces, and modernization construction is China's greatest political task. Whether the strategic goals of the "Three-Step Development Strategy" can be achieved is related to the future and destiny of socialism. Therefore, it is not just an economic development goal but also a political goal.
The significance of achieving the strategic goals of the "Three-Step Development Strategy" is immense. It is a strategic goal that enables China to gradually move away from poverty and towards prosperity. To achieve this strategic goal, not only can it greatly enhance China's comprehensive national strength, significantly improve people's lives, greatly enhance China's international influence, and contribute greatly to humanity, but it can also better reflect the superiority of the socialist system. Deng Xiaoping pointed out, "To prove that socialism is truly superior to capitalism, we need to wait for the third step, it is still premature to boast about it." With China's large population, if by the middle of the 21st century, the population reaches 1.5 billion and the per capita income reaches $4,000, the annual GDP will reach $6 trillion, greatly surpassing the United States' $4.97 trillion GDP in 1987. "This not only provides a way out for the three-quarters of the world's population in the Third World but, more importantly, it demonstrates to humanity that socialism is the only way and socialism is superior to capitalism."
The "three-step" economic development strategy goals constitute an important part of the construction of the theory of building socialism with Chinese characteristics. It is a specific implementation plan and fundamental embodiment of the central task of socialist modernization construction. Some major principles and policy guidelines for the construction of socialism with Chinese characteristics revolve around and serve this development strategy. This development strategy points the direction for the construction of socialism with Chinese characteristics in the primary stage of socialism. It can be foreseen that as long as we continue to follow the road of socialism with Chinese characteristics, the development strategy goals of Deng Xiaoping's designed "three-step" modernization construction will definitely be achieved.
III. Further clarification of the goals of political system reform
With the deepening development of economic system reform, the task of political system reform has become more urgent on the party's agenda. The task of political system reform has attracted attention as early as around the 11th Plenary Session. In 1980, in his speech on "Reform of the Party and State Leadership System" at the expanded meeting of the Central Political Bureau, Deng Xiaoping solemnly put forward the major task of political system reform. The central government was ready to gradually implement political system reform from then on, but due to various reasons, political system reform was not fully implemented until 1986.
1. Deep understanding of the importance and urgency of promoting political system reform
With the development of the situation, political system reform has inevitably come back on the agenda. On June 10, 1986, when Deng Xiaoping listened to the report on the current economic situation by responsible comrades at the central level, he explicitly pointed out: It seems now that without political system reform, we cannot adapt to the situation. Reform should include the reform of the political system, and it should be considered as a sign of progress in the reform. Deng Xiaoping also emphasized that all comrades, especially the members of the Central Secretariat, should consider the issue of political system reform and find someone to figure it out and get things in order. He requested that before the 13th National Congress, the party-government relationship should be straightened out, the content of political system reform should be clarified, and a blueprint for political system reform should be formulated.
Deng Xiaoping's series of ideas laid the foundation for the discussion and design of the framework for political system reform. The Central Committee of the Communist Party of China decided in 1986 to establish the Central Political System Research Group. The group consisted of five people, including members of the Central Secretariat, the Central Advisory Committee, the State Council, and the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress, and conducted research under the direct leadership of the Political Bureau Standing Committee.
The Central Political System Reform Discussion Group organized practical workers from relevant departments and theoretical workers from various fields, and established seven thematic groups to conduct specialized discussions and demonstrations on topics such as the separation of party and government, intra-party democracy, institutional reform, personnel system reform, socialist democracy, socialist legal system construction, and the basic principles of reform. At the same time, the Central Political System Reform Discussion Group requested that the Central Party School also establish a discussion group to conduct in-depth investigations and research parallel to the above-mentioned thematic groups, extensively solicit opinions from the CPPCC, mass organizations, and other parties, carefully study the historical experience of the political system since the establishment of the new China, especially the practical experience of reform since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, and combine with the actual situation of our country to study and draw on the experience of foreign political system structures and operations, and to submit research reports on each topic.
Based on the research reports on the topics proposed by the thematic groups and the absorption of research achievements from the theoretical community, the Central Political System Reform Discussion Group gradually developed a general plan for political system reform. This plan, with the consent of the Central Political Bureau, was submitted to the Seventh Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee in October 1987. After full discussion, the plenary session agreed in principle to the "General Plan for Political System Reform" and decided to include the basic content of the plan in the report of the Central Committee to the Thirteenth National Congress and submit it for discussion at the congress.
The report of the Thirteenth National Congress of the Party, based on the actual conditions of the primary stage of socialism and the needs of socialist modernization construction in our country, on the basis of a profound analysis of the necessity and urgency of political system reform, expounds the goals, tasks, and principles to be grasped in the reform, and puts forward a blueprint for political system reform in our country.
2. Planning the Goals of Political System Reform
The Thirteenth National Congress divides the goals of political system reform into long-term goals and short-term goals. The long-term goal of political system reform stipulated by the Thirteenth National Congress is to establish a highly democratic, comprehensive legal, efficient, and vibrant socialist political system. The short-term goal is to establish a leadership system that is conducive to improving efficiency, enhancing vitality, and mobilizing initiatives from all sides. Regarding the main content of the reform, the Thirteenth National Congress proposed reforms in seven areas in the short term:
First, to achieve the separation of party and government and strengthen the institutional building of the party. The key to political system reform is the separation of party and government. The leadership of the party is political leadership, which means leading and recommending important cadres to the state power organs in terms of political principles, political orientation, and major decisions. The main way for the party to exercise political leadership in state affairs is to turn the party's propositions into national will through legal procedures, and to promote the party's line, principles, and policies through the activities of party organizations and the exemplary role of party members, thus achieving the expected goals. In order to achieve the separation of party and government, the party's organizational form and working institutions must be adjusted, the institutional building of the party must be strengthened, and the party's understanding of achieving the separation of party and government must be improved. Only in this way can the expected goals be achieved.
Second, further decentralize power. The phenomenon of excessive concentration of power is not only manifested in the excessive concentration of power in the administrative, economic, cultural organizations, and mass organizations in the party's leading organs, but also in the excessive concentration of power at the grassroots level in the higher-level leading organs. This not only traps the leading organs in dilemmas of formalism and unable to extricate themselves, but also deprives the grassroots of autonomy, making it difficult to fully mobilize the enthusiasm of the people. The Thirteenth National Congress established the overall principle of decentralizing power, which is that anything suitable for lower-level handling should be decided and executed by the lower-level authorities.
Third, reform government institutions. The government's bloated and oversized institutions, excessive layers, unclear responsibilities, and mutual buck-passing are important reasons for the formation of bureaucracy. Reform of government institutions must be implemented from top to bottom. The principles of reform are streamlining, unification, and efficiency. The Thirteenth Congress proposes that the State Council should immediately begin to formulate a plan to reform the central government institutions, and after approval by the Seventh National People's Congress, it should be implemented.
Fourth, reform the cadre personnel system. The focus of the reform is to establish a national civil servant system, that is, to formulate laws and regulations to scientifically manage personnel in the government who exercise national administrative power and perform national duties in accordance with the law. At the same time, according to the principle of separating the Party and the government, separating the government from enterprises, and closely integrating the management of people and affairs, personnel of all kinds should be classified and managed. The main categories are: leaders and staff of Party organizations and government agencies, managed by Party committees at all levels; leaders and staff of state power institutions, judicial institutions, and procuratorial institutions, managed by a system similar to national civil servants; leaders and staff of mass organizations and managers of enterprises and institutions, generally managed by their respective organizations or units according to their own constitutions or regulations.
Fifth, establish a system of consultation and dialogue. The system of consultation and dialogue is not only conducive to the correct handling and coordination of various social interests and contradictions, but also conducive to ensuring that the work of various levels of leadership is based on listening to public opinions, accepting supervision, and avoiding mistakes. The basic principles of establishing a system of consultation and dialogue are: carry forward the fine tradition of "coming from the masses and returning to the masses", improve the openness of activities of leadership organs, let the people know about major situations, and discuss major issues with the people.
Sixth, improve several systems of socialist democratic politics. These systems include: strengthening the system of people's congresses; improving the system of multi-party cooperation and political consultation under the leadership of the Communist Party; strengthening the construction of mass organizations; improving the electoral system; strengthening the institutionalized construction of grassroots democratic life; further improving the system of regional national autonomy.
Seventh, strengthen the construction of socialist legal system. Every aspect of the country's political life, economic life, and social life, as well as every link of democracy and dictatorship, should have laws to rely on, laws must be followed, law enforcement must be strict, and violations of the law must be prosecuted.
Starting from the blueprint of political system reform proposed by the Thirteenth Congress of the Communist Party of China, the reform of the political system in our country has gradually entered a stage of goal-oriented and step-by-step supporting reforms after being implemented in a local scope.
On November 14, 1987, the new Central Political Bureau held its first plenary meeting, discussing and passing the "Working Rules of the Thirteenth Central Political Bureau (Trial)", "Working Rules of the Thirteenth Central Political Bureau Standing Committee (Trial)", and "Working Rules of the Thirteenth Central Secretariat (Trial)". These three rules, along with the subsequent working rules of the State Council, further clarified the relationship between the Central Political Bureau, its Standing Committee, the Central Secretariat, and the Central Plenum, with the Central Secretariat serving as an executive agency rather than having decision-making powers. The Central Political Bureau Standing Committee regularly reports its work to the Central Political Bureau, and the Central Political Bureau regularly reports its work to the Central Plenum. The frequency of the Central Plenum has also increased from once a year to twice a year. At the same time, it also clarified the functions, scope of work, and working methods of the Party Central Committee and the central People's Government, forming a reasonable framework in accordance with the requirements of separating Party and government functions, providing initial regulations. This is an important step in the construction of intra-Party and national democracy.
At the same time, the party began to implement the system of differential elections. According to the method of differential elections stipulated by the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party, 20% of the delegates to the 13th Party Congress, 5% of the Central Committee members, and 12% of the alternate Central Committee members were elected differentially. The results of the election at the 13th Party Congress were that 10 candidates for Central Committee member were not elected, there were 16 alternate Central Committee members, and 4 members of the Disciplinary Commission were not pre-selected. At the provincial level, the differential election has been implemented in the selection of provincial party committee standing committee members, chairpersons and vice chairpersons of provincial, autonomous region, and directly administered municipal standing committees, governors and vice governors. In the provincial-level elections after the 13th Party Congress, the chairpersons of the standing committees of the people's congresses of 11 provinces, autonomous regions, and directly administered municipalities, and the governors and chairpersons of 8 provinces and autonomous regions were elected through differential elections. A total of 99 candidates recommended by the people's congresses of 28 provinces, autonomous regions, and directly administered municipalities were listed as official candidates, and 12 were elected, including 4 chairpersons of the standing committees, 2 vice chairpersons, 5 vice governors, and 1 chief judge of a high-level court. This is unprecedented in the history of the people's power elections since the founding of New China, and it has caused a strong reaction in China's political life.
In accordance with the requirements of separating the functions of the Party and the government and improving the principle of Party leadership, the central organs directly under the Party underwent reforms in 1988. There were originally 26 working institutions and institutions directly under the Party Central Committee, and in the reform, 8 were abolished, 3 were restructured, and 15 were retained, with 5 new ones established. After the adjustment, there were a total of 23 working institutions and institutions directly under the Party Central Committee. During the reform, attention was paid to distinguishing the responsibilities of the Party's work departments and the administrative departments, straightening out the relationship between the Party's work institutions and government institutions, transferring work that should be undertaken by government departments to relevant government departments, and no longer setting up leadership groups and offices that overlap with Party Central Committee and State Council departments. Each province, autonomous region, and directly administered municipality has formulated some rules accordingly, and has carried out reforms in terms of specific organizational forms and methods of work. Party committees generally do not have full-time secretaries in charge of government work, abolished the departments responsible for counterpart work in the Party committee offices, streamlined Party committee institutions, and reduced full-time cadres.
In enterprises, according to the "Draft Law of the People's Republic of China on Industrial Enterprises with the Entire People's Ownership System" adopted at the first session of the Seventh National People's Congress, enterprises implement the system of responsibility by the factory director (manager), with the factory director serving as the legal representative of the enterprise, occupying a central position in the enterprise, and leading the production, operation, and management of the enterprise, with overall responsibility for the material and spiritual civilization construction of the enterprise. The grassroots organizations of the Communist Party of China in enterprises ensure supervision of the implementation of the Party's and the state's policies and guidelines in the enterprise. These provide a legal basis for separating the functions of the Party and the government in enterprises. After the implementation of the Enterprise Law, the system of responsibility by the factory director (manager) and the separation of Party and government functions have been widely implemented in enterprises, forming the basic pattern.
3. Initiation of government institutional reform and personnel system reform
According to the political system reform blueprint designed at the 13th Party Congress, government institutional reform and personnel system reform were put on the agenda. The first session of the Seventh National People's Congress held from March 25 to April 14, 1988, approved the "State Council Institutional Reform Plan." In his report on government work, Li Peng expounded the goals, principles, and priorities of government institutional reform. He stated: The long-term goal of government institutional reform is to gradually establish an administrative management system with complete functions, reasonable structure, coordinated operation, and flexible and efficient efficiency based on the principles of separating the Party and the government, separating politics and enterprises, and streamlining, unifying, and enhancing efficiency with Chinese characteristics. Achieving this goal requires long-term efforts. In the next five years, efforts should be made to create conditions to gradually straighten out the relationship between the government and enterprises, people's organizations, the relationship between government departments, and the relationship between the central government and local governments.
The "State Council Institutional Reform Plan" determines that 12 ministries and commissions will be abolished at the ministerial level, 9 new ministries and commissions will be established, and 32 will be retained, reducing the total number from the original 45 to 41. Xinhua News Agency will be transformed into a public institution. In addition, the number of central government institutions will be reduced from 22 to 19, the number of administrative agencies will be increased from 4 to 7, the number of national bureaus managed by various ministries and commissions will be increased from 14 to 15, and the number of non-specialized institutions will be reduced from 77 to 44. The reduction in personnel will be about 20%.
The biggest difference between the State Council's institutional reform this time and the reform in 1982 is that it is based on the requirements of political and economic system reforms, with the transformation of functions as the key, and it is coordinated with the internal institutional construction of the government and preparatory work for the implementation of the national civil service system. In terms of approach, the key is to focus on the transformation of functions, decompose functions according to the principle of separating government and enterprises, transfer functions of directly managing enterprises, delegate functions of directly managing money and goods, and strengthen the functions of decision-making, consultation, regulation, supervision, and information management that belong to the central government. At the same time, it also strengthens the social management functions that were originally undertaken by party departments but should be undertaken by government departments. Based on this, institutions are set up and personnel establishment is determined according to the new functions. Based on the functions, departments that undertake the same or similar businesses are abolished and the business is assumed by one department; general economic departments generally do not have specialized institutions in charge, and industry management work is undertaken by competent departments; only two levels of divisions and offices are set up within ministries and commissions to reduce the management levels within departments. This institutional reform of the State Council has promoted the transformation of the government's management of enterprises from direct management to indirect management, and it has made significant progress in reducing the cross-functionality and overlap of work and enhancing the vitality and efficiency of institutions, laying a good foundation for further reforms and local institutional reforms.
The reform of central government institutions also requires corresponding links to local reforms. Therefore, the State Council Institutional Reform Office began preparations in August 1988. Prior to this, the pilot work of local institutional reform had been conducted in 16 medium-sized cities in May 1986. In 1989, with the approval of the State Council, Harbin, Qingdao, Wuhan, Shenzhen, and other four planned sub-provincial cities, Jicheng, Shanxi Yuangping, Zhuozi Mountain, Shangyu in Zhejiang, Huaxian in Henan, Huarong in Hunan, Bao'an in Guangdong, Qionglai in Sichuan, Dingxi in Gansu, and other 9 counties conducted institutional reform pilots. After gaining experience through pilot projects at different levels and types, the pilot was expanded in 1991. After the pilot projects, the pilot units not only achieved certain results in institutional reform, but also further clarified the ideas for local institutional reform. Based on the pilot experience, the State Council plans to gradually promote local institutional reform, with the basic idea of starting from straightening out relationships and transforming functions, including straightening out the relationship between the central and local governments, and the relationships between local governments at all levels; rationalize the division of powers, and transform the functions of local governments at all levels in accordance with the requirements of separating government and enterprises; and then strive to achieve the scientificization of the administrative decision-making system, improve the administrative execution system, and rationalize the administrative supervision system, and improve the operational mechanism of administrative management.
Establishing the national civil service system is the focus of personnel and personnel system reforms determined at the Thirteenth National Congress. According to the Thirteenth National Congress's deployment, the state established the Ministry of Personnel as the management institution for national civil servants. After the establishment of the Ministry of Personnel, on the one hand, it began to formulate regulations on the management of national civil servants, and at the same time, it conducted pilot projects in six departments, including the Auditor General's Office, the General Administration of Customs, the National Bureau of Statistics, the State Taxation Administration, the State Building Materials Bureau, and the State Environmental Protection Bureau. In 1991, Harbin and Shenzhen were selected for the pilot projects of the local civil service system. The pilot projects in the six departments of the State Council initially started with the classification of positions. The determination of government functions is the basis for setting up institutions and the prerequisite for establishing a civil service system. In the past, unclear functions resulted in improper allocation of positions to individuals, but now that the functions are clear, positions can be allocated based on qualifications, which is undoubtedly a significant advancement. These six departments began the pilot position classification in April 1989, based on the "Three Fixes" plan, and by the end of June 1990, they completed the investigation, analysis, evaluation, and formulation of position classification standards, position levels, and other work for a total of 2618 positions.
Another important aspect of the civil service system is the examination, recruitment, and training system for civil servants. From 1987 to 1988, a method of provincial examination and recruitment was adopted for the recruitment of civil servants in 13 departments such as politics, law, industry and commerce, and taxation. Over 1 million people nationwide applied to take the exam, and over 80,000 were recruited. In January 1989, the Central Organization Department and the National Ministry of Human Resources issued a notice on the examination and assessment methods for the recruitment of staff in national administrative agencies. It required that the examination and assessment methods be implemented for the recruitment of staff in administrative agencies at the county level and above. The procedures include: announcement, qualification review, written test, interview, medical examination, assessment, and recruitment. The examination system has a history in China. The imperial examination system that was formed over thousands of years is the main way to select officials in China. The examination and recruitment system for civil servants is definitely not a revival of the traditional imperial examination system, but a necessary reform of the previous cadre selection system to meet the needs of modern social life. This method, which is oriented towards society, open for examination, and recruits based on merit, has had a positive impact on implementing the principle of competition, strengthening democratic supervision, preventing corruption in personnel matters, and ensuring the quality of recruited personnel.
Reform of personnel systems in enterprises and institutions has also made significant progress. In May 1988, the Central Organization Department and the Ministry of Human Resources formulated the "Several Opinions on the Reform of the Personnel System in State-owned Enterprises to Introduce Competitive Mechanisms and Management of Cadres" and required the introduction of competitive mechanisms into personnel management in state-owned enterprises and the selection of enterprise managers through open bidding. Various forms of appointment system, hierarchical appointment, and selection based on merit should also be implemented for the appointment of internal managerial staff at all levels of enterprises. Enterprises have the right to appoint and dismiss, and individuals have the right to be appointed and resign. In 1991, the Central Organization Department and the Ministry of Human Resources issued the "Interim Regulations on the Appointment Management of Cadres under State-owned Enterprises", which unified the regulations on appointment, transfer, retirement, and benefits, further improving the cadre appointment system within enterprises.
By the end of 1990, there were already 1.7 million appointed cadres in state-owned enterprises, with over 90% of them being recruited from workers. Practice has proven that the implementation of the appointment system for cadre in enterprises has been relatively successful. Therefore, many institutions have also adopted similar methods of bidding and appointing cadre leaders within their own organizations. The professional and technical appointment system is widely implemented among scientific and technological cadres.
IV. Taking the path of strengthening the Party's construction through institutional development
Whether China's reform and modernization can achieve the expected goals depends on various factors, but one of the most important factors is the condition of the Communist Party of China as the governing party. Since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, while leading the reform and economic development, the Communist Party of China has firmly grasped the key link of strengthening its own construction and gradually embarked on a new path of strengthening the Party through institutional development, while strengthening ideological and political construction. 
1. Completion of a new round of Party consolidation work
Already at the time of the Twelfth National Congress, the Party Central Committee decided to conduct a comprehensive rectification of the Party's style and organization in stages and batches over a period of three years starting in the second half of 1983.
The 2nd Plenary Session of the 12th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) was held in Beijing from October 11th to 12th, 1983. Based on the decision of the 12th National Congress of the CPC, the plenary session made arrangements for the comprehensive Party rectification work. The session adopted the "Decision of the CPC Central Committee on Party Rectification" (referred to as the "Decision"). The "Decision" analyzed the necessity and urgency of the Party rectification, proposed the overall objectives and requirements of the rectification, which is to, under the guidance of Marxism-Leninism and Mao Zedong Thought, rely on the revolutionary consciousness of all Party comrades, correctly use the sharp weapon of criticism and self-criticism, enforce Party discipline, expose and resolve serious ideological, work style, and organizational impurities within the Party, achieve fundamental improvement in Party conduct, raise the ideological and work levels of the entire Party, strengthen the connection between the Party and the people, and strive to build the Party into a strong core leading the socialist modernization cause.
The "Decision" clearly stipulates that the task of this Party rectification is to unify thinking, rectify work style, strengthen discipline, and purify the organization, and provides specific explanations for these:
Unifying thinking means further achieving a high degree of ideological and political unity within the Party, correcting all "left" and "right" incorrect tendencies that violate the four cardinal principles and the Party's line since the 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee.
Rectifying work style means promoting the revolutionary spirit of wholeheartedly serving the people, correcting all acts of seeking personal gain through abuse of power, and opposing irresponsible bureaucratism towards the Party and the people.
Strengthening discipline means adhering to the organizational principles of democratic centralism, opposing disorganized and undisciplined paternalism, factionalism, anarchism, and liberalism, and changing the Party's weak and lax organizational conditions.
Purifying the organization means, in accordance with the Party's Constitution, cleaning out those elements that persistently oppose the Party and harm the Party.
The "Decision" stipulates that the steps of the Party rectification are to be carried out from the central to grassroots Party organizations, from top to bottom and in stages. The rectification of each Party organization should also be carried out from top to bottom, first rectifying the leadership team and leading cadres, and then rectifying the Party members and masses. The basic method of Party rectification is: on the basis of earnestly studying documents and improving ideological understanding, carry out criticism and self-criticism, distinguish right from wrong, correct mistakes, and purify the organization. Throughout the Party rectification process, it is necessary to strengthen ideological education from start to finish, with a focus on raising the ideological awareness of the majority of Party members. The "Decision" announced the establishment of the Central Committee Work Guidance Commission for Party Rectification.
According to the Party rectification decision and the deployment of the CPC Central Committee's Work Guidance Commission for Party Rectification, the comprehensive Party rectification is actually carried out in three stages.
The first stage is carried out in central and state organs, ministries and commissions, and at the provincial, autonomous regional, and directly-administered municipal level, as well as in major units of the People's Liberation Army. In order to strengthen the leadership of the first stage of the Party rectification, the Central Committee's Work Guidance Commission and the Central Military Commission dispatched 90 Party rectification liaison groups consisting of 850 personnel, and established ten Party rectification work guidance groups for central and state organs. During this period, the Central Committee's Work Guidance Commission issued 11 notifications and other documents. These documents provided specific instructions on the study of Party rectification-related documents, fully listening to the opinions of non-Party friends and the masses, forming two sets of work teams for Party rectification and routine work, conducting comparative checks, carrying out simultaneous rectification and improvement, organizing disciplinary actions and Party member registration, conducting inspections, summarizing and consolidating the Party rectification, and so on. They not only timely guided the work of various stages of the first stage of the Party rectification but also played an important role in all stages of the Party rectification work.
The second phase of the party consolidation work was carried out in the party organizations at the local, county, and corresponding levels of enterprises, institutions, colleges, and research institutes. From February 28 to March 6, 1985, the Central Party Consolidation Guidance Committee held the second phase of the party consolidation work meeting and deployed the second phase of the consolidation. In response to the various disruptive forces affecting construction and reform within the party and society at that time, the Central Party Consolidation Guidance Committee emphasized in its notification the need to enhance party members' party spirit, rectify the new improper practices, ensure the smooth progress of reform, and promote the continued healthy development of the political and economic situation. This was highlighted as the key focus of the consolidation work at the local and county levels. In order to grasp the basic situation of the second phase of the consolidation work in various regions, the Central Party Consolidation Guidance Committee sent out seven inspection teams to investigate, identify problems, summarize experiences, and make recommendations.
The third phase was carried out in grassroots party organizations in rural areas. On November 24, 1985, the Central Party Consolidation Guidance Committee issued a notification on the deployment of the consolidation work in rural areas, providing comprehensive arrangements for the specific requirements, methods, and steps of the work. Each province, autonomous region, and municipality directly under the central government sent out 630,000 speakers and liaison officers to help with the consolidation work in rural areas. From May to June 1986, the Central Party Consolidation Guidance Committee held symposiums on the consolidation work with the provincial party committee secretaries, clarifying the fundamental guiding ideology for the consolidation work in rural areas and emphasizing the need to seriously address and effectively strengthen the construction of leadership teams in rural areas, while focusing on tackling the serious issues of abuse of power for personal gain and serious violations of laws and discipline among party members and cadres at the district, township, and village levels.
The nationwide consolidation work, which lasted for three and a half years, was basically completed in the spring of 1987. On May 26, Bo Yibo, the Executive Deputy Director of the Central Party Consolidation Guidance Committee, delivered a report entitled "Basic Summary of the Consolidation Work and Further Strengthening Party Building," providing an overall assessment of the consolidation work. In summarizing the achievements in various aspects of the consolidation work, Bo Yibo specifically pointed out the following:
The main achievements in unifying thinking are as follows: (1) From senior cadres to the broader party members, through careful and relatively systematic study of the consolidation documents, many vague understandings have been clarified, and a deeper understanding of the socialist path with Chinese characteristics since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Party has been achieved. It has been made clear that adhering to reform, opening up, revitalizing the economy, and vigorously developing a planned socialist market economy is the only way to build a strong, democratic, and civilized socialist country. Furthermore, it has further increased the awareness of party members in implementing and carrying out these Marxist policies. (2) By carrying out thorough education to completely negate the "Cultural Revolution," the majority of party members have clearly recognized that both factions during the "Cultural Revolution" were operating under the misguided theoretical guidance of "class struggle as the key link" and "continuing the revolution under the dictatorship of the proletariat," and overall, they were mistaken. This has promoted the further elimination of factionalism and the negative influence of the "left," laying a more solid ideological and political foundation for enhancing party unity and inspiring party members' innovation and reform spirits. (3) Through widespread education on party spirit, ideals, and purposes, the situation of some party members having a weak understanding of communist ideals and the concept of serving the people has been changed. This has resulted in an increase in ideological consciousness among the majority of party members and enhanced their ability to resist the erosion of capitalist and feudal thoughts.
The progress made in rectifying work style is mainly as follows: (1) Efforts have been made in various regions to investigate and handle cases of party members seriously violating laws and discipline, abusing power for personal gain, and being irresponsible. This has basically curbed the new improper practices of party and government cadres managing enterprises, and there has been varying degrees of improvement in party conduct. (2) The transformation of the work style of leadership organs at all levels has been promoted, leading to a reduction in bureaucratic tendencies and the strengthening of the idea of serving grassroots levels. In many regions and departments, party members in leadership positions have taken the lead in going to grassroots levels, conducting investigations and research, solving practical problems in construction, reform, and people's livelihood, and strengthening the relationship between the party and the people. (3) In the process of rectifying the Party in rural areas, efforts were made to clean up the financial work. Party members and cadres took the lead in returning long-overdue public funds and property, and took the lead in serving the people, which was welcomed by the rural masses.
The main achievements in strengthening discipline and purifying the organization are as follows: (1) Efforts were made to clean up the "Three Types of People" and those who committed serious mistakes during the Cultural Revolution. Party organizations at all levels invested a lot of energy in participating in special Party rectification checks. Comrades who participated in these checks overcame various difficulties and resistance, and conducted many arduous investigation and evidence gathering tasks. On the basis of the previous cleaning and handling of 400,000 people, a total of 5,449 "Three Types of People" and 43,074 people who committed serious mistakes were identified nationwide (excluding the Guangxi Zhuang Autonomous Region). (2) Criticism and self-criticism and the strict organization life in the Party have been restored and carried forward. Party members' awareness of organizational discipline has been strengthened compared to before. Some Party organizations that were previously paralyzed or partially paralyzed have shown significant improvement after rectification. (3) A group of party members with serious problems and unqualified status were dealt with through party member registration and organizational handling. A total of 33,896 people were expelled from the Party, 90,069 people were not registered, and 145,456 people were temporarily registered. In addition, 184,071 people received disciplinary actions such as being put under Party probation, revocation of Party positions, recommendation for revocation of positions outside the Party, serious warnings, and warnings. (4) Adjustments were made to a group of leadership teams with problems and weaknesses. About half of the leadership teams at the county level and above were supplemented to varying degrees. Through adjustments and supplementation, the construction of leadership teams was promoted. A group of outstanding young and middle-aged party members with strong party spirit, upright conduct, and the ability to lead the masses in resolutely implementing the Party's current policies have taken up leadership positions at all levels.
The most important significance of this Party rectification work in the history of Party building is to clean up the "Three Types of People" (referring to those who rose to power by following the counter-revolutionary Lin Biao and Jiang Qing factions during the Cultural Revolution, those with serious gangster tendencies, and those who engaged in looting, smashing, and robbery) hidden within Party organizations at all levels. This has eliminated hidden dangers that affect Party unity and interfere with Party construction, and purified the Party's organization.
Of course, while achieving results, there are also some shortcomings in this Party rectification work. The development of the work is unbalanced, and some units, including some higher and intermediate Party and government leadership organs, have not fully completed the four basic tasks of Party rectification, and some have even gone through the motions, which has affected and damaged the reputation of Party rectification among the masses. Units that have handled the Party rectification relatively well still have some problems in terms of Party conduct and other aspects, which need to be addressed in the future regular Party building.
2. The advent of a new stage in the construction of the Party's cadre team
Comrade Mao Zedong once said, "Once the political line is determined, the cadre is the determining factor." Mao Zedong attached the greatest importance to the cultivation of the Party's cadre team. Chen Yun once said that from the Zunyi Conference to the victory of the War of Resistance Against Japan, Mao Zedong's incomparable achievement was the cultivation of a generation of people, including us and a group of cadres known as the "March 8th Style".
After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, the second generation of central leadership collective with Deng Xiaoping as the core gradually found the path of building socialism with Chinese characteristics, formed a set of correct principles, policies, and opened up a new situation in socialist modernization construction. Deng Xiaoping did not indulge in this, but extended the scope of thinking deeper and further, that is, how to ensure the succession of the cause created by the older generation of revolutionaries.
As early as August 18, 1980, when Deng Xiaoping spoke at an expanded meeting of the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee, he first proposed the "Four Mordernizations" for cadres. On December 25 of the same year, Deng Xiaoping clearly stated the "Four Modernizations" criteria for cadres under the theme of "Implementing the Adjustment Policy and Ensuring Stability and Unity" at the central working conference. He said: In order to make our cadre team younger, more knowledgeable, and more professional under the premise of adhering to the socialist path, we must gradually establish and improve the cadre system to ensure this. The three conditions of youthfulness, knowledgeability, and specialization are proposed, and of course, the first requirement is to be revolutionary, so it is necessary to adhere to the socialist path.
On July 2, 1981, Deng Xiaoping delivered a speech at the symposium of provincial, autonomous region, and directly governed municipality party secretaries, entitled "The primary task of the elderly cadres is to select young and middle-aged cadres." After analyzing the importance of promoting young and middle-aged cadres, he proposed to establish goals and plans for training and selecting these cadres. He said: I suggest, comrades, let's discuss it, shall we propose a five-year plan? It'd be best to make it four years, lasting until 1985. Regarding cadre issues, I suggest making two plans: a five-year plan and a ten-year plan. In the first five years, let's select, for example, 50,000 people and place them in suitable positions for training. During these five years, we should gradually have a certain proportion of our leadership members, members at the division level, members at the provincial, autonomous region, and directly governed municipality level who are around 50 years old or 40 years old. In the second five years, what level of leadership members (such as the provincial, municipal, and autonomous region level or ministerial level) do we want to attain, except for special circumstances, and what is the age limit?
At the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC), Deng Xiaoping delivered the opening speech. He placed the "four modernizations" of the cadre team as the top priority of the current work. At this representative conference, the goals of "revolutionization, youthfulness, knowledgeability, and specialization" were written into the newly passed Party Constitution.
The construction of the "four modernizations" of the cadre team is the concrete application of the principle of being both morally and intellectually qualified, and being both red and specialized, in the construction of the cadre team, reflecting the objective requirements of China's socialist modernization construction. Revolutionization means that cadres must adhere to the political and ideological lines since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, practice Party spirit, not factionalism, adhere to the socialist path, and have a strong sense of mission and responsibility. Youthfulness, under the precondition of revolutionization, is to select a large number of outstanding young and middle-aged cadres for various levels of leadership positions, so that the cadre structure of the Party and the state at all levels is energetic and maintains strong vitality. Knowledgeability and specialization require leaders to have a certain level of cultural education and knowledge, and be able to grasp and apply modern natural science, social science, and management science knowledge, in order to scientifically lead and manage socialist modernization construction. This fundamentally changes the trend of emphasizing family background, length of party membership, and seniority in the selection criteria for leadership cadres in the past.
To achieve the "four modernizations" of the cadre team, it is necessary to abolish the lifetime tenure system for leadership cadres. This is a key issue and also a difficult point. In this regard, the Party and the state have adopted the following four measures to abolish the lifetime tenure system for cadres:
First, establish a term-based system for cadre positions. The Constitution of the People's Republic of China, passed at the Fifth Session of the Fifth National People's Congress, abolished the lifetime tenure system for cadre positions as the fundamental law of the country. The Constitution stipulates that the term of office for various highest state leadership positions is five years, and consecutive re-elections shall not exceed two terms.
Second, establishing a retirement system for cadres. In 1982, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued a decision on establishing a retirement system for cadres, which stipulated that main leading comrades holding ministerial-level positions in central and state organs and at the provincial level should retire at the age of 65 for principals and 60 for deputy principals, and cadres at the departmental level generally should not exceed the age of 60. If some individuals have health problems before reaching retirement age, they can retire early. After retirement, the political treatment of the cadres remains unchanged. According to the spirit of this document, by the end of 1982, more than 7,260 senior cadres from the directly affiliated institutions of the Central Committee and the central state organs had completed the retirement procedures. In August 1982, at the Seventh Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, Liu Bocheng and Cai Chang stepped down from leadership positions. In September 1985, at the Fourth Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee, 64 senior comrades, including Ye Jianying, Deng Yingchao, Xu Xiangqian, and Nie Rongzhen, requested to no longer hold positions as members and alternate members of the Central Committee; 37 senior comrades, including Li Jingquan, Xiao Jingguang, and He Changgong, requested to no longer serve as members of the Central Advisory Commission; and 30 senior comrades, including Huang Kecheng and Wang Congwu, requested to no longer serve as members of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection.
Deng Xiaoping, who advocates abolishing the lifetime leadership system, has long wanted to gradually disappear from the political stage. He realizes that having too much prestige is a burden for himself and having too much personal weight is also a burden for the party and the country. It is abnormal and dangerous for a country's fate to rely on the reputation of one or two individuals, as many countries place their policy towards China on whether he is sick or dead. If any changes occur to that person, instability will arise. If nothing happens, it's fine, but once an incident occurs, it will be uncontrollable. Deng Xiaoping does not want such a situation to appear behind him. Therefore, as early as November 2, 1979, he said at a senior cadres meeting, "I have this idea myself. If the party allows me to retire today, I'll retire immediately." This is not a false statement, it is true.
On September 2, 1986, when meeting with American journalist Mike Wallace, Deng Xiaoping said: "I advocate abolishing the lifetime system and also advocate establishing a retirement system. You also know that when I talked to Italian journalist Oriana Fallaci, I said I would be fine if I worked until 1985, but it's been over a year now. I am considering when to retire. Personally, I hope to retire early."
In 1987, before the convening of the 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, Deng Xiaoping officially expressed his desire to retire in order to actively abolish the lifetime leadership system for cadres. At this time, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China repeatedly considered Deng Xiaoping's personal wishes and the opinions within and outside the party, and decided to allow him to retain the position of Chairman of the Central Military Commission while agreeing to resign from other positions. Thereafter, he no longer participated in the daily work of the central government, achieving a semi-retirement status.
The third measure is to reduce the number of deputy positions and part-time positions. In August 1980, Hua Guofeng no longer served as the Premier of the State Council, and Deng Xiaoping, Li Xiannian, Chen Yun, Wang Zhen, and Wang Renzhong no longer served as vice premier. In 1982, during the central and State Council institutional reform, the number of deputy positions was reduced. The number of vice premiers of the State Council was reduced from 13 to 2. According to statistics from 38 ministries and commissions, excluding ministers and directors who hold part-time positions, there are a total of 167 deputy ministers and deputy directors, which is a decrease of 338 people, or 67%, compared to the original 505 people; their average age is 58 years old, a decrease of 6 years; the proportion of cadres with a university education has increased from 37% to 52%. According to statistics from 28 ministries and commissions, the original 720 agencies and bureaus were reduced to 488, a decrease of 32%; the number of directors and deputy directors was reduced from 2450 to 1398, a decrease of 43%; their average age was reduced from 59 to 54 years old; the proportion of cadres with a university education has increased from 36% to 49%.
The fourth measure is to establish the advisory system. Deng Xiaoping proposed the idea of establishing an advisory committee in 1981: in addition to the Central Committee, an advisory committee should be established to "accommodate some old comrades." Advisors do not hold current positions, so that positions can be given to young people. Being an advisor is also a kind of position, and its level is not lower than that of members of the same level party committee. This allows old comrades to move to this position and have a comparatively easier job. Of course, being an advisor is not just for consolation, but also serves the purpose of "passing on knowledge and experience." Deng Xiaoping's intention behind this is profound because China's leadership not only faces the problem of aging but also the issue of succession. Establishing the advisory system is a good way to address these two issues. The Central Advisory Committee was formally established in September 1982, and Deng Xiaoping was elected as the Chairman of the Advisory Committee.
The establishment of the Central Advisory Committee has made a historic contribution to ensuring the long-term stability of the Party and the country during this historical turning point. After its establishment, the Central Advisory Committee has provided effective assistance to the Party Central Committee in maintaining unity and social stability, promoting reform, opening up, and modernization.
Deng Xiaoping predicted that after another ten years, or at most fifteen years, the advisory committee should be abolished. The Central Advisory Committee lasted from 1982 to 1992, exactly ten years. In these ten years, there has been smooth cooperation and alternation between the new and old cadres of the Party. At the same time, as the members of the Advisory Committee have aged over the course of two terms, and as a transitional measure, their mission has been accomplished. In view of this, the Central Advisory Committee proposed to the 14th Party Congress that there should no longer be a Central Advisory Committee after the 14th Party Congress. After serious and full discussion, the CPC Central Committee decided not to establish a Central Advisory Committee and provincial, municipal, and autonomous region advisory committees.
The above measures have created favorable conditions for the selection of young cadres and the realization of the Party's "four modernizations" goals for the cadre team. Seizing this opportunity, the CPC Central Committee has accelerated the "four modernizations" construction of the cadre team.
From 1984 to 1985, there was a relatively centralized adjustment of leadership teams at all levels. During this year-long period, the central government and the State Council appointed a total of 47 new ministers, directors, and directors of directly affiliated bureaus. There were also 80 new deputy ministers, deputy directors, and deputy bureau chiefs, with nearly 100 young and middle-aged cadres being selected. Before the adjustment, the average age of the main leaders of the 81 departments under the State Council was 56.6 years old. After the adjustment, the average age decreased by 5 years, the proportion of those under 55 years old increased from 10% to 30%, and the proportion of those with a college education increased by 27.5% to reach 71%. During the same period, the average age of the members of the standing committee of the Party committees, the governors, presidents, and mayors of 29 provinces, autonomous regions, and municipalities directly under the central government decreased from 57 years old to 53 years old. The proportion of those under 55 years old reached 90% and the proportion with a college education increased to 80%. During the same period, the leadership teams of more than 3,000 large and medium-sized key enterprises in the country were adjusted, forming a stepped structure, with cadres in their forties becoming the main body. According to statistics from 2,900 of these enterprises, among the 18,000 leading cadres, 20% were under 40 years old, 63% were between 41 and 50 years old, and the average age was 45 years old. Those with a college education or above accounted for 74%, among which 89% of the factory directors had a college education or above, an increase of 40% compared to before the adjustment. Among the party secretaries, 81% had a college education or above, an increase of 70% compared to before the adjustment. In order to accelerate the rejuvenation of the cadres, the Party's National Congress was held in 1985. This was a conference that focused on solving the problem of rejuvenating the cadres. At this conference, 131 senior leaders with long experience withdrew from the main leadership positions of the Party, and 179 new leaders were elected. The newly elected central committee members, new ministers, and provincial party secretaries were generally in their fifties, and some were in their early forties. This was an unprecedented power metabolism in the history of the Communist Party of China. Deng Xiaoping said that this event is worth recording in the history of the Party.
In view of the fact that a considerable number of old cadres at all levels will gradually resign from their current positions for a period of time, if there is no necessary number of new people as reserves, there will be a disconnect. Therefore, the central government decided to establish a reserve cadres system, establish a reserve cadre team consisting mainly of outstanding young and middle-aged cadres under the age of 50, especially around the age of 40, and put them into practice for training. By achieving practical achievements, they will undergo further inspection by the organization and the masses, and those who achieve excellent political performance will be promptly promoted and used.
Through strengthening the "four modernizations" of the cadre team, our cadre team has begun to show a new face. Under the premise of revolutionization, a large number of young and middle-aged cadres have taken leadership positions, forming a team with a combination of youth, middle-aged, and older cadres. This cadre team is both experienced and vibrant, and its combat effectiveness and cohesion have been strengthened. Of course, the "four modernizations" construction of the cadre team is still a long and arduous task, and there is still much work to be done and many contradictions to overcome.
3. Correcting various unhealthy tendencies within the Party
Party conduct reflects the Party's spiritual demeanor, directly relates to the Party's image among the people, and affects the level of the Party's prestige among the people. Therefore, the Party Central Committee attached great importance to and has been making efforts to earnestly address various unhealthy tendencies that emerged during the process of reform and opening up.
First, party and government officials, as well as their children and spouses, are prohibited from engaging in business activities and participating in corrupt practices. After the Third Plenary Session of the 12th Central Committee, China shifted its focus from rural to urban areas and entered a phase of comprehensive reform. The country entered a new phase of economic growth, and commercial activities became prevalent nationwide. Some party and government organs, as well as officials, consciously or unconsciously became involved in these activities, becoming a peculiar phenomenon in economic life. Before the comprehensive rectification of companies in 1988, there were over 470,000 registered companies in China. Among these companies, there were centrally-controlled companies established by various party, government, and military departments, national-level mass organizations, "subsidiary companies" established by various regions, and "excess heat companies" established by retired cadres. A significant portion of these companies blurred the line between the government and businesses, engaged in profiteering through resale, and some officials abused their powers for corruption, embezzlement, speculation, bribery, and other illegal activities. This seriously disrupted clean governance and the establishment of a sound socialist economic order, exacerbated social inequalities, and affected social stability.
The CCP Central Committee has maintained a clear understanding of the situation regarding party and government officials engaging in business activities and the serious harms it brings. On December 3, 1984, the CCP Central Committee and the State Council issued the "Decision on Strictly Prohibiting Party and Government Organs and Party Members from Engaging in Business and Establishing Enterprises," which clearly stated that party and government leadership at all levels, especially in economic departments, must correctly fulfill their duties in leading and organizing economic construction. They must adhere to the principle of separating responsibilities and separating the government from businesses, promote integrity, fairness, and uprightness, and strictly prohibit the use of power to engage in commercial activities, establish enterprises, seek personal gains, and compete with the people for profits. The central government required party and government leadership at all levels and officials to maintain a clear mind, take a firm stance, and resolutely eliminate corrupt practices.
However, after the prohibition of party and government organs and serving officials from engaging in business activities, new situations emerged. The participation of the children and spouses of some leading officials in business activities was unexpectedly fierce. After discovering this problem, on May 23, 1985, the CCP Central Committee and the State Council issued the "Decision on Prohibiting the Children and Spouses of Leading Cadres from Engaging in Business," which stipulated that the children and spouses of cadres at or above county and division levels are strictly prohibited from engaging in business, except in state-owned, collective, and Sino-foreign joint ventures.
