On July 9 of the same year, the General Office of the CCP Central Committee and the General Office of the State Council issued the "Supplementary Notice on Party and Government Officials Not Concurrently Holding Positions in Economic Entities," which made relevant provisions.
For a period of time, most of the enterprises operated by party and government organs were shut down or dissociated from the party and government organs. Most party and government officials engaged in business activities returned to their positions or resigned from their leadership positions. However, the harmful practices persisted. Some party and government organs and officials employed various means to continue engaging in business activities, some officials continued to hold concurrent positions in enterprises, and family members took advantage of their relationships with leading officials to engage in business activities. Some serious illegal activities in business operations, particularly those involving certain leading officials, were not properly resolved.
In order to firmly put an end to the phenomenon of party and government organs and officials engaging in business activities, on February 4, 1986, the CCP Central Committee and the State Council issued the "Regulations on Further Prohibiting Party and Government Organs and Officials from Engaging in Business and Establishing Enterprises," requiring all levels of party committees and governments to resolutely implement the central regulations and strictly enforce them. Those who refuse to comply should be sternly dealt with and held accountable for leadership responsibilities. The discipline inspection commissions at all levels and the administrative organs for industry and commerce should closely cooperate with the departments of organization, personnel, auditing, banks, judiciary, and others to supervise implementation.
By implementing the spirit of this document, the problem of party and government organs and officials engaging in business activities has been initially resolved.
Second, the investigation and prosecution of party and government officials involved in bribery and extortion.
In the process of prohibiting party and government officials from engaging in business activities and engaging in improper conduct, investigations were also conducted on the issue of bribery and corruption by party and government officials. When the commodity economy began to become active and administrative behavior, market behavior, and enterprise behavior had not yet been strictly regulated by legal forms, corrupt activities such as the exchange of power and money were most likely to breed and spread. In response to the new characteristics of party discipline and clean government construction in the new situation, on June 30, 1987, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection issued the "Decision on Resolutely Investigating the Issue of Bribery by Communist Party Members", pointing out that in recent years, in our foreign economic activities, feudal society and capitalist society have been commonplace. The ugly behavior of bribery and corruption has spread in some places and departments. This situation has aroused strong dissatisfaction from within and outside the party, both domestically and internationally. This must be given high attention by the whole party, and resolute measures must be taken to severely investigate and deal with acts of bribery and corruption. To this end, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection has made three decisions: (1) Communist Party members, especially leading cadres, regardless of who they are, if they violate criminal laws due to bribery and corruption, they will be expelled from the party. Party members who take bribes must actively confess the problem by whatever means, otherwise, once discovered, regardless of the severity of the circumstances, they will be expelled from the party. (2) In the normal "kickbacks" in economic activities, no one is allowed to take them for themselves for any reason or excuse. They must all be turned over to the state or the collectives. Violators will be seriously dealt with according to party discipline and laws. (3) Party organizations at all levels, including disciplinary inspection agencies, must effectively strengthen the education, management, and supervision of party members, and never allow the party's principles to be traded. Party members with issues of bribery and corruption must be resolutely investigated. If they are tolerated and not dealt with, the leadership responsibilities of their party organizations should be pursued.
After a period of efforts, due to the strong measures, the improper conduct of bribery and corruption has basically been curbed, but it has not been completely eradicated, so the central authorities require the whole party to persistently fight against this corruption phenomenon.
Third, firmly curb the improper conduct of selecting and appointing cadres and cadres in overseas issues. After the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, great achievements were made in selecting and appointing cadres. However, there are also some problems, highlighted as follows: Some leading cadres do not abide by the party's principles, violate organizational and personnel disciplines, and some of them select and appoint people based on personal likes, dislikes, and personal gains, or select people based on feudal clan and sectarian views; Some people use various means to "backdoor" the promotion and appointment of children, relatives, and friends; some people use positions to give favors and engage in transactions; some people do not follow policy regulations, argue for the rank and treatment of cadres in their own systems or units, and upgrade their subordinate units; Some comrades who are responsible for organizational and personnel work abandon their duties, ignore principles, and even use their power for personal gain; and so on.
In order to curb the improper conduct of selecting and appointing cadres, on January 6, 1986, the CPC Central Committee put forward eight regulations for selecting and appointing cadres: (1) Leading cadres must modelly abide by the party's principles and maintain the discipline of organizational and personnel work. (2) The selection and appointment of cadres must strictly follow democratic recommendations, widely listen to opinions, propose selection targets; the organization and personnel departments conduct inspections, and after collective discussions by the Party Committee, they are reported according to the cadre management authority; further inspections are conducted by higher-level organizational departments, and then submitted to the Party Committee for discussion and approval. (3) The selection and appointment of leading cadres must fully take the mass line. (4) Before deciding on the promotion of cadres, strict inspections must be conducted according to the moral and intellectual conditions required by the proposed position. (5) The selection and appointment of cadres must be decided through collective discussions of the Party Committee, and individuals are not allowed to make final decisions. (6) The promotion of cadres should be based on comrades who have been tested and tempered in practice. (7) It is strictly prohibited to set up institutions, raise the level of institutions, and increase the number of leading cadres without authorization. (8) Organizational and personnel departments at all levels must earnestly fulfill their duties and serve as consultants and assistants to the Party Committee.
From early 1986, the Central Organization Department conducted extensive research and proposed some ideas and principles on the establishment of a system for party and government officials to abstain: first, abstention from taking office. Spouses, children, and relatives of cadres who hold leadership positions in the Party Committee, government, discipline inspection commission, public security, court, and procuratorate should not have direct hierarchical relationships with the leading cadres, and they should not hold leadership positions in the general office, organization, personnel, supervision department, and peer disciplinary inspection institutions of the leading cadres' organization. Second, abstention from official duties. Party and government leaders should not participate in various business activities related to their own appointment, file management, and transfer, nor should they instruct or indirectly influence others or intervene. In cases involving the appointment and adjustment of cadres, salary adjustments, party membership, assessment and appointment of professional and technical positions, handling of illegal and disciplinary cases, sending personnel abroad, recruitment, allocation of college and technical school graduates, and placement of military personnel, if it involves the relatives of leading cadres, the leading cadres themselves should actively explain to the organization and abstain from participating in inspections, investigations, discussions, and approvals, and should not instruct or indirectly influence others to intervene. The spouse, children, relatives, and staff members of the leading cadres should not participate in the official duties that should be abstained from in the name of the leading cadres or by taking advantage of work convenience. Third, abstention from regional issues. County (city) party secretaries, county (city) mayors, county (city) discipline inspection commission secretaries, organization department directors, personnel bureau directors, public security bureau directors, court presidents, and procurator generals should not be appointed by local cadres. If local cadres hold these positions, those who have served a full term cannot continue to be reappointed in the original region.
The unhealthy practices of cadres going abroad is a special form of corruption that emerged during China's reform and opening up process. Since the reform and opening up, the number of people going abroad for official and private purposes in China has increased significantly. However, there have also been unhealthy practices in terms of going abroad, mainly manifested in the excessive formation of groups of party and government officials going abroad, frequent repetitive inspections, rotation of overseas travel, and party and government officials replacing professional personnel for overseas travel, etc. Additionally, some party and government officials, under the pretext of inspections, engage in sightseeing and tourism abroad, which has led to increased foreign exchange expenditure and serious waste, causing adverse effects both domestically and internationally.
In order to curb this unhealthy trend, on July 4, 1987, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council issued the "Several Provisions on Strictly Controlling the Issue of Party and Government Officials Going Abroad," stating that party and government officials who have no direct relationship with foreign missions and do not hold relevant business responsibilities shall not be allowed to go abroad under any pretext. Party and government officials should not participate in overseas missions that can be completed by professionals. Party and government organs and other officials in charge of business should not use hierarchical or work relationships as a reason to openly or implicitly demand participation in the overseas delegations of enterprises and institutions. Enterprises and institutions should also not invite party and government organs and other officials in charge of business departments without direct relevance to the overseas missions for the purpose of "consideration" or achieving certain goals. The regulations require local people's governments and central and state government departments with the power to approve foreign travel matters to conduct strict and serious examinations of overseas delegations based on relevant regulations of the Central Committee and the State Council. Those who do not meet the requirements should adhere to principles and not be approved. For those who have already been approved for going abroad, if problems that do not comply with the regulations are discovered before departure, the higher-level approving authority should promptly instruct the original approving authority to correct it, and if necessary, the case can be reviewed and approved again. After the issuance of this document, the unhealthy practices of cadres going abroad were initially curbed.
When the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China is promoting the construction of party conduct and clean governance, it focuses on major cases to facilitate the improvement of party conduct.
In July 13, 1985, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection issued an open letter to the Jinjiang City Committee and Administrative Office Party Group regarding the large-scale production of counterfeit drugs by some enterprises in the Jinjiang area and their sale through various bribery methods. The letter demanded that they handle this case according to party discipline and laws and report to the central authorities. On July 27, after listening to the report from the Communist Party of China (CPC) Fujian Provincial Committee and the Provincial Discipline Inspection Commission, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection (CCDI) dealt with the individuals involved according to the law and decided to dismiss the Deputy Secretary of the Jinping County Committee and the Secretary of the County Discipline Inspection Commission who were involved in the production and sale of counterfeit drugs for personal gain.
From early 1986 to April 1989, a few leading cadres of the Ministry of Railways and the Zhengzhou Railway Bureau took advantage of their positions to embezzle and accept bribes by using various methods to seek personal gain through the allocation of railway carriages due to the inability of the railway transport capacity to meet the demand. After investigation, it was found that a total of 48 cadres above the rank of division Chief from the Zhengzhou Railway Bureau of the Ministry of Railways were involved in this case, along with one Deputy Minister of Railways, 15 bureau-level cadres, and 19 department-level cadres. The amount of criminal funds was over 960,000 yuan. The Ministry of Railways Transportation Bureau illegally demanded and accepted various sums totaling over 760,000 yuan from shippers or lower-level units under various pretexts in violation of regulations. The CCDI dealt with this case seriously. The State Council removed Luo Yunguang, the Deputy Minister of Railways, from office for bribery and for being responsible for the bribery and corruption of his subordinates, and the procuratorial organs initiated an investigation against Luo Yunguang for bribery. The CCDI also decided to expel Xu Jun, the former director of the Ministry of Railways Transportation Bureau, Jia Shuang and Hu Jun, deputy directors of the bureau, Wei Guofan, executive assistant director of the bureau (department-level status), Ma Mingshan, dispatcher of the bureau (department-level status), He Zhigui, former director of the Zhengzhou Railway Bureau, Liu Demin, Party Secretary of the bureau, and Pan Keming, deputy director of the bureau, revoking their party membership due to their violations of criminal laws. Their cases were to be examined by the judicial organs.
From May 6 to June 2, 1987, a major forest fire broke out in Daxing'anling, resulting in significant losses to national property and human lives, some of which could not be quantified in monetary terms. Yang Zhong, the Minister of Forestry, seriously lacked the party spirit and political responsibility that party members and leading cadres should possess and committed serious bureaucratic and dereliction of duty errors in his actions towards the party and the people. Dong Zhiyong, the Deputy Minister in charge of forest fire prevention, also lacked a sense of responsibility in his work and committed serious bureaucratic and dereliction of duty behaviors. He also had important responsibilities for the Daxing'anling forest fire accident. With the approval of the CPC Central Committee, the CCDI made the decision to dismiss Yang Zhong from his position as Party Secretary of the Ministry of Forestry. The State Council submitted a proposal to the Standing Committee of the National People's Congress to dismiss Yang Zhong from his position as Minister of Forestry, as well as dismissing Dong Zhiyong from his position as Deputy Minister of Forestry, and assigned the Heilongjiang Provincial Government to conduct a thorough investigation.
The CPC Central Committee educates the entire party through handling major and significant cases, promoting a profound education on party conduct, and encouraging the entire party to jointly address issues related to party conduct. However, the struggle against corruption, advocating integrity, and correcting improper behaviors is a long-term process that runs through the entire process of reform, opening up, and modernization construction, so there is still a long way to go in this work.
Chapter 6: The Formation of the Third Generation of Central Leadership Collective and the Preliminary Establishment of Deng Xiaoping's Guiding Position
I. The Comprehensive Launch of Governance and Rectification, and the Proposal of a Series of "Dual Emphasis" Policies
After the 13th National Congress of the CPC, the Party continued to lead the people of the whole country in advancing along the path of socialism with Chinese characteristics. Since the start of reform and opening up, significant achievements have been made in economic development, which mainly include: sustained and stable economic growth, during the ten-year period, the gross domestic product (GDP), national fiscal revenue, and average income of urban and rural residents have all roughly doubled; some of the severe economic and social problems that have long plagued China have begun to be solved or have found solutions; the majority of the 1 billion population have achieved a decent standard of living, and some regions have started to move towards a well-off life. For the areas that have not yet completely achieved a decent standard of living, there have also been improvements in people's lives: market supply has greatly improved, fundamentally reversing the long-lasting scarcity of consumer goods in the past. From 1984 to 1988, it was a period of rapid development, with the GDP increasing from 717.1 billion yuan to 1.49 trillion yuan, demonstrating the dynamic situation of agriculture and industry, rural and urban areas, reform and development mutually promoting each other, and the comprehensive national strength reaching a new level.
1. The Comprehensive Launch of Governance and Rectification
With the deepening of reforms and rapid economic development, some deep-seated contradictions in the economic system have gradually emerged. At the same time, there has been a tendency to pursue speed and ignore objective constraints in the reform and construction process. In August 1988, in a situation where the macroeconomic environment was not relaxed, a decision was made to push for price reform, triggering a mass buying frenzy and causing social upheaval. A series of unstable and uncoordinated contradictions appeared in the economic operation, manifested as "four excesses and one disorder", namely excessive social demand, too fast industrial development speed, excessive credit and monetary injection, high inflation, and disorderly economic order. In response to these issues, the Party Central Committee timely made decisions to govern and reform: curb economic overheating, contain inflation, earnestly adjust economic structure to increase the production of major agricultural products such as grain, cotton, and oil, establish and improve necessary economic regulations, as well as macro-control system and supervision system, and actively promote the construction of a new socialist market economic order. After about a year of governance and rectification, the trend of excessive economic development and the chaos in the economic field were reversed. 
With the deepening of reform and opening up, while the deep-seated contradictions in the economic system are highlighted, there have also been many new situations and problems in social trends. In this situation, the Party Central Committee has put forward the guideline of "both hands" to address these issues.
2. The era requires the guideline of "both hands".
Why should we adhere to the guideline of "both hands" in the process of socialist modernization construction? This is not the subjective imagination of a certain individual, but the embodiment of the objective laws of socialist modernization construction in China.
The 13th National Congress of the Communist Party of China explicitly put forward that the guideline of "both hands" is the strategic guideline for building socialism with Chinese characteristics. The so-called strategic guideline has two aspects of meaning: first, in terms of importance, it means that both aspects of civilizational development should be pursued together, which is related to the fundamental direction and fundamental path of building socialism with Chinese characteristics. Because only by "both hands" can material civilization and spiritual civilization develop comprehensively, so as to improve China's overall national strength. Second, in terms of long-term perspective, it means that we must adhere to the pursuit of both aspects of civilization throughout the entire primary stage of socialism, rather than just for a while or in a specific period. If the Party's basic line in the primary stage of socialism remains unchanged for a hundred years, then the guideline of "both hands" must also remain unchanged for a long term. Adhering to the guideline of "both hands" is a profound summary of the lessons from the experience of reform and opening up. In order to promote the development of productive forces, we must accelerate the pace of reform. This revolution will unfold in a wide range of fields and to a considerable depth. It is related to the future of socialism and the interests of hundreds of millions of people. It is an extremely complex and mass exploration and innovation endeavor, which will not only bring about major changes in people's economic and political lives but also cause significant changes in their ways of life, thinking, and spiritual state. Therefore, it is inevitable to encounter some problems and negative phenomena.
From the practice of reform and opening up, we face three types of problems: the first is the inevitable emergence of new contradictions and problems in the process of transforming the old and new systems; the second is due to the reformers' inaccurate and incomplete understanding of the central policies, or due to lack of experience and inadequate consideration, certain deviations and mistakes occur in bold explorations; the third is some people taking advantage of the banner of reform to make illicit gains, engaging in corruption and illegal activities, undermining economic order and committing other crimes. We must handle the first two situations with caution, improve the understanding of the people, especially party members and cadres through education, and ensure the healthy progress of reform and opening up. For the third case, we will handle it strictly in accordance with party discipline, administrative discipline, and legal discipline, especially for serious economic crimes and other criminal activities. We will punish them severely according to the law, resolutely crack down on them, and never be lenient. Practice has proven that the deeper the reform, the more we must adhere to the "two-handed approach." Otherwise, the reform cannot proceed.
In the process of opening up to the outside world, on the one hand, we have introduced advanced technology, advanced equipment, and some management experiences and methods that are in line with large-scale socialized production. On the other hand, it is also difficult to avoid the mixed influences of the decayed elements of foreign capitalist capitalism, their way of life, certain reactionary political views, and sociological theories of the bourgeoisie. They may penetrate and even flow into our social life and people's spiritual world, causing serious harm. For example, in politics, the Western bourgeoisie's political views of "liberalism," "democratization," and "multi-party system" may infiltrate and give rise to bourgeois liberal trends. In terms of the economy, the Western bourgeoisie's values of pursuing only profit, harming others for one's own gain, materialism, as well as the behaviors of deception, fraud, smuggling, bribery, corruption, speculation, and profiteering may flow in, leading to economic crimes and other criminal activities. In terms of ideology and culture, some obscene videos, photos, movies, and yellow literature, books, music, and toxic sociological theories from overseas may be transmitted, polluting people's spiritual world and corroding their souls. Deng Xiaoping had foreseen this situation early on. He said that opening up to the outside world has opened windows for fresh air, but it has also let in mosquitoes and flies. Faced with this, what should we do? Closing the door is clearly not an option. The only choice is to both adhere to reform and opening up and oppose bourgeois liberalization and combat all kinds of criminal activities.
Therefore, in the historical process of deepening reform and opening up, adhering to the "two-handed approach" is an important condition to ensure the continuous vitality of the cause of reform and opening up, and it is also an objective requirement to maintain the correct path of reform.
3. The proposal and elaboration of a series of "two-handed approach" guidelines
The "two-handed approach" is an important governance experience summarized by the Communist Party of China during the process of reform and opening up in the new era. The so-called "two-handed approach" guideline has the following different levels of connotations: Firstly, one hand promotes the construction of material civilization, and the other hand promotes the construction of spiritual civilization; secondly, one hand promotes reform and opening up, and the other hand upholds the four fundamental principles; thirdly, one hand promotes reform and opening up, and the other hand combats economic crimes and other criminal activities; fourthly, one hand promotes the construction of two civilizations, and the other hand promotes the construction of democracy and the rule of law.
The "two-handed approach" guideline has evolved and enriched during the practice of reform and opening up in China. Deng Xiaoping, the architect of reform and opening up, was the first leader in the party to propose and emphasize the "two-handed approach" guideline.
After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, while formulating the strategic guidelines for reform, opening up, and modernization construction, Deng Xiaoping began to pay attention to the issue of the "two-handed approach." On October 30, 1979, in his speech representing the Central Committee to the Fourth National Congress of Chinese Literature and Art Workers, he first proposed the idea of simultaneously promoting the two civilizations. He said, "Our country has entered a new era of socialist modernization construction. We need to significantly improve social productivity while reforming and perfecting the socialist economic system and political system, promoting advanced socialist democracy and the comprehensive socialist legal system. In addition to building a highly developed material civilization, we must improve the scientific and cultural level of the entire nation, develop a noble and rich diverse cultural life, and construct a highly developed socialist spiritual civilization."
On December 25, 1980, the Central Working Conference was held in Beijing. Deng Xiaoping gave an important speech at this meeting, elaborating on the relationship between material civilization construction and spiritual civilization construction, and further put forward the idea of "grasping both hands". He said, "The socialist country we want to build should not only have a high degree of material civilization, but also a high degree of spiritual civilization... The more the Party and the government implement various economic reforms and the policy of opening up to the outside world, the more party members, especially senior party cadres, should attach great importance to and practice communist ideology and communist morality."
On March 27, 1981, the person in charge of the General Political Department of the Chinese People's Liberation Army reported to Deng Xiaoping on the army's practice of "grasping both hands", which made Deng Xiaoping very happy. He said, "One thing that has been done well recently is emphasizing spiritual civilization. There have been achievements in this regard, and we must continue to do well."
With the development and deepening of reform and opening up, criminal activities in the economic field have shown a trend of growth and spread. The Communist Party of China Central Committee and the State Council, in response to this situation, conducted investigations and research and made the "Decision on Crackdown on Serious Criminal Activities in the Economic Field" (referred to as the "Decision"), and began to investigate and punish economic crimes.
On April 10, 1982, the Central Political Bureau held a meeting specifically to discuss this "Decision". Deng Xiaoping made an important speech at the meeting, clearly stating the issue of adhering to the "grasping both hands" principle in the reform and opening up. He said, "We must have both hands, one hand is to insist on the policy of opening up to the outside world and activating the domestic economy, and the other hand is to resolutely crack down on economic crimes. Without cracking down on economic crimes, the policy of opening up to the outside world will definitely fail, and the policy of activating the domestic economy will also fail. With the crackdown on economic crimes, opening up to the outside world and activating the economy can move in the right direction."
From this, it can be seen that Deng Xiaoping's meaning of "grasping both hands" has developed further, not only referring to grasping both types of civilization together, but also includes the reform and opening up as well as cracking down on economic crimes. Because this is related to the success or failure of the reform and opening up policy.
In order to make the whole Party deeply understand the importance, necessity, and urgency of "grasping both hands", Deng Xiaoping repeatedly emphasized this guideline.
On July 4, 1982, the Central Military Commission held a symposium, and Deng Xiaoping proposed four guarantees for adherence to the socialist system and good modernization construction in his speech: the first is institutional reform; the second is to promote socialist spiritual civilization; the third is to resolutely crack down on criminal activities in the economic field; and the fourth is to improve the Party's construction, rectify the Party's organization and style. He emphasized, "We must adhere to the 'grasping both hands' approach of opening up to the outside world and activating the domestic economy. However, in order to ensure that this policy can truly benefit the Four Modernizations construction and not deviate from the socialist direction, we must also have another hand, which is cracking down on economic crimes. Without this hand, there will be no constraints." "The four guarantees cannot be achieved all at once, they must be pursued in the long term. Although we do not advocate for movements, with the progress of the four modernizations, we must adhere to the four guarantees and never deviate from them, turning them into ongoing work and struggle."
In October 1982, at the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC), under the guidance of Deng Xiaoping's "grasping with both hands" ideology, the principle of simultaneously developing both material and spiritual civilization was established as a strategic guideline for socialist modernization, guiding the work of the entire Party. According to the principle of "grasping with both hands," the Party not only focused on the development of material civilization but also strengthened the construction of spiritual civilization, achieving certain results.
However, due to various subjective and objective reasons, the construction of spiritual civilization in our country did not achieve the expected results and even exhibited a trend of deterioration, with both hard and soft approaches being adopted. Specifically, the manifestations are as follows:
(1) The rampant breeding of corruption, and the continuation of negative practices within the Party. The central government has taken measures to investigate and handle major cases, achieving some results. However, these results were not consolidated, and coupled with the lack of corresponding reforms, the weakening of ideological and political work has led to a significant increase in illegal practices by some party and government officials, such as using their positions for personal gain, bribery, indulging in extravagant lifestyles, and corruption. Privileges, connections, and nepotism have become prevalent, and the Party's original purpose of wholeheartedly serving the people has been forgotten, causing extreme dissatisfaction among the masses.
(2) The decline in social morals, with many members of society losing their sense of direction. The failure to effectively curb negative practices and corruption within the Party has severely affected the credibility and cohesion of the Party and the government among the masses. Superstitions and feudal activities in certain areas have not been effectively suppressed, and issues such as gambling, prostitution, and pornography continue to exist. Particularly, the proliferation of explicit videos and publications have seriously harmed the thoughts and souls of young people.
(3) The worrying situation in education and scientific and technological development. Due to difficulties and problems encountered in the reform of the education and scientific and technological systems, as well as insufficient financial support from the government, the income of a large number of education and scientific workers has remained low for a long time. The phenomenon of intellectuals prioritizing physical labor over mental labor persists and even expands. The conditions for education and scientific research have not seen the necessary improvements, severely impacting the enthusiasm of intellectuals. As a result, brain drain and job-hopping among intellectuals in some regions are on the rise. Under such circumstances, the motivation for students to study has decreased, and the slogan "60 points is enough" has become a common phrase among some students, with dropout rates increasing in rural areas. China's education and scientific and technological development are once again facing formidable challenges.
The central leadership soon became aware of this situation of adopting both hard and soft approaches. On September 23, 1985, Deng Xiaoping sharply criticized this mistake during the CPC's national congress. He said, "The construction of socialist spiritual civilization was proposed a long time ago. The central government, local governments, and the military have all done a lot of work, especially with the emergence of a large number of advanced individuals who have had a positive influence. However, looking at the whole country, the results are still not ideal. The main problem is that the entire Party has not taken it seriously... Production has improved in recent years, but the influence of capitalism and feudalism has not been reduced to the minimum, and even some bad things that had long disappeared after liberation are making a comeback." If we do not make a major determination to change this situation quickly, how can we fully realize the superiority of socialism? How can we effectively educate our people and future generations? Without strengthening the construction of spiritual civilization, the construction of material civilization will also be destroyed and go astray. Relying solely on material conditions, our revolution and construction cannot be victorious."
In order to attract the attention of the whole party, especially the central leadership comrades, Deng Xiaoping once again discussed the issue of "grasping both hands" on January 17, 1986, at the meeting of the Standing Committee of the Central Political Bureau. He pointed out: To achieve the four modernizations, we must have both hands, one hand is not enough. The so-called "both hands" refers to one hand for construction and one hand for the legal system... We have achieved significant success in economic construction and the situation is favorable, which is the success of our country. But if the moral atmosphere continues to deteriorate, what is the meaning of economic success? It will degenerate in another aspect and develop into a world of rampant corruption, theft, and bribery. Therefore, we must adhere to the four persistences and adhere to the dictatorship, which can ensure the smooth progress of our socialist modernization construction and effectively deal with those who undermine construction. He emphasized that we must focus on the construction of spiritual civilization and improve the party's style and social atmosphere starting from specific events. He also emphasized that the higher the cadres' children, the higher the cadres, and the more famous they are, the more their illegal activities must be closely investigated and typical cases should be grasped. Because these people commit crimes and cause great harm, catching and dealing with them will have a great effect, demonstrating our determination to overcome all obstacles in building spiritual civilization. He believed that if this matter is done well, it can truly promote reform and construction. With such determination, it will take at least ten years of struggle to restore the party's style and social atmosphere to the best period of the 1950s.
From the above situations, Deng Xiaoping made great contributions in the process of formulating the party's strategic policy of "grasping both hands". In order to firmly adhere to the policy of "grasping both hands", he has long struggled against various erroneous thoughts. He never compromises or gives in on this important principle issue. In the process of fighting against erroneous thoughts, Deng Xiaoping also enriched and developed the strategic thinking of "grasping both hands".
4. Gradual advancement of the policy of "grasping both hands" in practice
With the deepening of the reform and opening up, the party's thinking on "grasping both hands" has also been gradually implemented in practice. While concentrating on promoting economic construction, the whole country has also begun to vigorously strengthen the "other hand" in terms of ideology, culture, and other fields.
(1) Gradual development of socialist spiritual civilization construction. After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, with the start of reform and opening up and the comprehensive development of socialist modernization construction, the Party Central Committee gradually put the task of socialist spiritual civilization construction on the agenda.
① The proposal of the ideological construction of spiritual civilization. In March 1979, Deng Xiaoping proposed in his speech on "Adhering to the Four Fundamental Principles" at the Party's theoreticians' conference to maintain lofty revolutionary ideals, improve the moral level of the whole people, transform social atmosphere, and rectify the party's style, etc. This actually proposes some fundamental requirements for the construction of socialist spiritual civilization. In September of the same year, Ye Jianying first proposed the concept of socialist spiritual civilization in his speech at the celebration of the 30th anniversary of the founding of the People's Republic of China. He said, "While building a highly material civilization, we must improve the education, science, and cultural level of the whole nation, establish lofty revolutionary ideals and revolutionary moral standards, develop noble and colorful cultural life, and build a highly socialist spiritual civilization. These are important goals of our socialist modernization and necessary conditions for achieving the Four Modernizations." This statement not only clearly puts forward the concept of spiritual civilization, but also outlines the content of socialist spiritual civilization, including education, science, health, revolutionary ideals, revolutionary moral standards, and cultural life, thus clearly stating the construction of socialist spiritual civilization as an important goal and necessary condition for China's modernization.
On December 20, 1980, at the Central Work Conference, Li Chang, one of the leaders of the Chinese Academy of Social Sciences at the time, wrote a letter to Deng Xiaoping calling for the strengthening of the construction of socialist spiritual civilization. Deng Xiaoping wrote in his reply, "The questions raised in Comrade Li Chang's letter are worth considering. It is proposed to issue this letter for the comrades who attended the Central Work Conference to read." On December 25, in his speech at this conference, Deng Xiaoping accepted Li Chang's suggestion and discussed the construction of socialist spiritual civilization as an important topic, once again emphasizing its importance. He said, "The so-called spiritual civilization not only refers to education, science, and culture (which is completely necessary), but also refers to the ideology, ideals, beliefs, morals, discipline of communism, revolutionary positions and principles, comradeship between people, and so on." Here, the construction of socialist spiritual civilization is summarized into two basic aspects, namely scientific and cultural construction, and ideological and moral construction, making the connotation of spiritual civilization construction more clear.
In June 1981, the Resolution on Certain Questions in the History of the Party since the Founding of the People's Republic of China, passed at the 6th Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, included spiritual civilization as one of the ten basic points of China's socialist modernization construction. Moreover, for the first time in the form of a resolution of a plenary session of the Party's Central Committee, it determined the construction of a "modern, highly democratic, and highly civilized socialist power" as the guiding program for the Party in the new historical period.
② The gradual development of the construction of socialist spiritual civilization. In February 1981, nine units including the All-China Federation of Trade Unions, the Central Committee of the Communist Youth League, and the All-China Women's Federation jointly issued a proposal in response to the central government's call to strengthen the construction of spiritual civilization, advocating the promotion of the "Five Emphases and Four Beauties" activities, including advocating civilization, politeness, hygiene, orderliness, morality, aesthetic beauty, language beauty, behavioral beauty, and environmental beauty among the people, especially the youth. On February 28, the Ministry of Propaganda, the Ministry of Education, the Ministry of Culture, the Ministry of Health, and the Ministry of Public Security jointly issued a notice on the promotion of civilized and polite activities. In accordance with the requirements of the notice, the publicity and education activities focusing on the "Five Emphases and Four Beauties" as the main content were widely carried out throughout the country.
At the beginning of 1982, the General Office of the Communist Party of China Central Committee forwarded a report from the Ministry of Propaganda on the in-depth promotion of the "Five Emphases" and "Four Beauties" activities. That spring, according to the deployment of the Secretariat of the Central Committee, the "National Civilization and Politeness Month" activity was carried out nationwide, focusing on improving environmental hygiene and addressing the problems of "dirtiness," "disorder," and "poor quality." In January 1983, more than 20 departments including the Ministry of Propaganda proposed to carry out educational activities promoting "love for the motherland, love for socialism, and love for the people" in the "Five Emphases and Four Beauties" activities, further enriching the content of the spiritual civilization construction activities.
In September 1982, the 12th National Congress of the Communist Party of China summarized the achievements of the Party's understanding of the construction of socialist spiritual civilization since the 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, emphasizing the theoretical exposition of the construction of a highly socialist spiritual civilization. The Twelfth National Congress proposed that "socialist spiritual civilization is an important characteristic of socialism and an important manifestation of the superiority of the socialist system", and determined the construction of a high level of socialist material civilization while striving to build a high level of socialist spiritual civilization as a strategic policy for China's socialist modernization construction.
In accordance with the requirements put forward by the Twelfth National Congress to strive for the construction of socialist spiritual civilization, in March 1983, the CPC Central Committee and the State Council decided to establish the "Five Emphasizes, Four Beautifies, Three Loves" activity committees at the central and provincial, autonomous region, and directly administered municipality levels, and established corresponding offices. In that year, the "Creating a Civilization City" activity began to rise in Sanming, Fujian. There were also military-civilian joint construction of civilized villages and towns and civilized street activities in Baoding, Hebei, and other places. The following year, relevant departments of the central government held the National Conference on "Five Emphasizes, Four Beautifies, Three Loves" activities in Sanming, Fujian, summarizing the experience of carrying out the activities in large and medium-sized cities nationwide, especially the experience of Sanming. It required the whole country to learn from Sanming to promote the construction of spiritual civilization in cities. Since then, the "Five Emphasizes, Four Beautifies, Three Loves" activities have been widely carried out in urban and rural areas of our country in an organized and leadership-driven manner, focusing on creating a beautiful environment, establishing good order, providing quality services, and constructing civilized units, among other things.
③ The formulation of the first guiding principle for the construction of spiritual civilization. After 1984, with the comprehensive opening up and reform in our country, a large number of new contradictions and problems emerged in the social field, making the task of constructing spiritual civilization more prominent than before. In October 1984, the Third Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee of the CPC passed the "Decision on Economic System Reform by the Central Committee of the CPC", which also put forward corresponding requirements for the construction of spiritual civilization. The National Congress of the Party, held in September 1985, also regarded "adhering to the simultaneous advancement of material civilization construction and vigorously strengthening socialist spiritual civilization construction" as one of the basic guiding principles that must be followed in the national economic and social development during the Seventh Five-Year Plan period. This was the first time that the problem of spiritual civilization construction had been included in the planning for national economic and social development, indicating that the Party had started to consider the issue of spiritual civilization construction from the perspective of development strategies and guiding ideology. Based on this, the Sixth Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee of the Party, held in September 1986, deliberated and passed the "Resolution of the Central Committee of the CPC on the Guiding Principles for Socialist Spiritual Civilization Construction" (referred to as the "Resolution"). This was the first programmatic document issued by our Party on the construction of socialist spiritual civilization. The "Resolution", starting from the strategic height of building socialism comprehensively and the overall layout of our country's modernization construction, made clear provisions on the guiding principles and fundamental tasks for the construction of spiritual civilization.
First, it clarifies the position and role of the construction of spiritual civilization in the overall layout of China's socialist modernization construction. The "Resolution" points out that the overall layout of China's socialist modernization construction is: taking economic construction as the center, adhering to economic system reform, adhering to political system reform, and strengthening the construction of spiritual civilization, and ensuring coordination and mutual promotion among these aspects.
Second, it puts forward the guiding principles and fundamental tasks for the construction of spiritual civilization. The guiding principle is that the construction of spiritual civilization must promote socialist modernization; it must promote comprehensive reform and opening up; it must adhere to the four cardinal principles. The fundamental task is to meet the needs of socialist modernization construction, cultivate socialist citizens with ideals, ethics, culture, and discipline, and improve the ideological, moral, scientific, and cultural qualities of the entire Chinese nation.
Third, it provides a more practical exposition of the specific content of the construction of spiritual civilization. The resolution proposes to mobilize and unite the people of all ethnic groups in China with the common ideal of building socialism with Chinese characteristics, and clarifies the relationship between the highest ideals of our party and the common ideals of the people of all ethnic groups in China. It dialectically combines the requirements of advancement with the requirements of broadness. It puts forward the basic requirements for the construction of socialist ethics, emphasizes the education of socialist democracy, the rule of law, and discipline among all the people, vividly reflecting that the socialist spiritual civilization we want to build is the unity of revolutionary spirit, democratic spirit, and scientific spirit. It emphasizes the solid promotion of education, science, and culture throughout the nation.
The resolution also clarifies the guiding role of Marxism in the construction of spiritual civilization and the responsibilities of party organizations and party members in the construction of spiritual civilization. The resolution adheres to the basic viewpoints on the construction of socialist spiritual civilization put forward by our party since the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, and at the same time, it has made new developments in many aspects, marking the preliminary formation of the theoretical framework for the construction of socialist spiritual civilization with Chinese characteristics. This resolution has important guiding significance for guiding and promoting the construction of socialist spiritual civilization and ensuring the smooth development of socialist modernization.
(2) Eliminating the spiritual pollution in the ideological field and opposing bourgeois liberalization. In the early 1980s, in the field of theory, some people created confusion in the issues of humanism and alienation, attributing all the problems existing in society to the socialist system and the leadership of the Communist Party; in the field of news, some people set up an opposition between party nature and public nature; in the field of literature and art, some people denied Mao Zedong's literary and artistic thoughts, showing indifference towards the slogan proposed by the CPC Central Committee that literature and art should serve the people and socialism, leading to the appearance of works with serious erroneous tendencies, even low-level vulgar and pornographic books and magazines on screen, stage and in the book market.
In response to this situation, at the Second Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee held in October 1983, Deng Xiaoping delivered a speech proposing "we cannot allow spiritual pollution on the ideological front", "the essence of spiritual pollution is the dissemination of various decadent and corrupt ideas of the bourgeoisie and other exploiting classes, the dissemination of distrust towards the cause of socialism, communism and the leadership of the Communist Party". "In the long run, this issue is related to what kind of generation will take over our cause, and it is related to the fate and future of the Party and the country." Criticism and correction must be carried out in response to this.
Based on the spirit of this conference, struggles against spiritual pollution and bourgeois liberalization were launched throughout the country. After a series of efforts, the spread of bourgeois liberalization trend was basically curbed, and the leadership of the Communist Party of China on the ideological front was strengthened. However, the elimination of interference does not mean that there will be no more interference from bourgeois liberalization.
In 1986, Fang Lizhi, Liu Binyan, Wang Ruowang, and others, taking advantage of the opportunity to study political system reform, brazenly attacked the leadership of the Communist Party of China and the socialist system, attracting the attention of some senior leaders of the Communist Party of China, especially Deng Xiaoping. In September 1986, at the Sixth Plenary Session of the Twelfth Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, in response to some opinions that were not in favor of opposing bourgeois liberalization, Deng Xiaoping explicitly stated: "I have talked the most and I am the most persistent in opposing bourgeois liberalization." "What is liberalization? In actuality, it means pushing our current policies towards the road of capitalism." "Liberalization itself belongs to the bourgeoisie, there is no proletarian or socialist liberalization. Liberalization itself is in opposition to our current policies and systems, it is either against, or modifying." "It seems that opposing liberalization needs to be discussed not only this time, but also in the next ten or twenty years."
However, Deng Xiaoping's warning did not receive enough attention, especially from the leaders who were in charge of the central work at that time. In the second half of 1986, the trend of liberalization once again spread. Fang Lizhi, Wang Ruowang, Liu Binyan, and others became even more active. They pointed their fingers at our country's political system, claiming that the socialist cause since the founding of the new China has failed, and the communist movement over the past thirty years has been a failure; they completely reject the leadership of the Communist Party of China, advocate for the implementation of a multi-party system, and attack the leadership of the Communist Party of China as a continuation of feudal rule and a one-party dictatorship; they glorify bourgeois democracy and advocate abandoning people's democratic dictatorship; they belittle the guiding role of Marxism in China's revolution and construction.
In this situation, the propaganda of party newspapers and magazines did not take strong measures to resist, resulting in mistakes in guiding public opinion, allowing bourgeois liberalization to spread at one point. In the second half of 1986, various liberal ideas flowed into the lecterns of universities. According to incomplete statistics, from October to late December 1986, Beijing University, Tsinghua University, and Beijing Normal University jointly held more than twenty speeches, symposiums, and other events attended by these people. These reports had a great impact on the thinking of some students.
In January 1987, several young ideological and political workers conducted investigations on the ideological status of university students in several key universities in Beijing and found that students were engaging to varying degrees in discussions on political system reform and cultural reflection. According to the survey, students had four dissatisfactions: First, they were dissatisfied with the pace of reform, believing that the progress was too slow and faced significant resistance with minimal effects; second, they were dissatisfied with democratic rights, believing that the democratic rights of workers, peasants, and intellectuals were practically insignificant; third, they were dissatisfied with the state of party discipline, believing that although major corruption cases had been cracked down upon, people were still resentful of the phenomenon of officials using their power for personal gain; fourth, they were dissatisfied with the implementation of policies concerning intellectuals, believing that there was much fanfare but little actual impact. These four dissatisfactions led to four reflections among university students: first, reflection on the fundamental lessons of the Chinese revolution; second, reflection on the comparison of two social systems; third, reflection on traditional Chinese culture; fourth, reflection on Marxism.
"Reflection" gave rise to many negative things, and combined with the rapidly changing international political scene in 1986, such as the escape of former Philippine President Marcos and the disintegration of dictatorial rule in Haiti, all of these continuously impacted students' values. They were no longer satisfied with mere changes in ideas and empty rhetoric. The emotions of most students shifted from uneasiness to dissatisfaction, with a latent sense of impulse and a strong sense of participation. In the second half of 1986, various cities saw demonstrations and other activities of varying scales.
In response to the above phenomena, on December 30, 1986, Deng Xiaoping met with Hu Yaobang and other top leaders of the central government and clearly stated the need to adhere to the four cardinal principles, oppose bourgeois liberalization, and emphasized the extreme importance of maintaining and developing the good situation of stability and unity, advancing reform and opening up, and promoting socialist modernization. The correct handling of the problem of student unrest at the current time was also elucidated. The core was that "the four cardinal principles must be upheld," "without the dictatorship of the people, it won't work," "China has no future without the leadership of the Communist Party," and "democracy can only be gradually opened up and we cannot adopt the Western model." Resolutely "oppose bourgeois liberalization" for "China to have hope." Deng Xiaoping's speech further strengthened the determination of the Communist Party of China to oppose bourgeois liberalization. On January 6, 1987, Beijing's universities disseminated Deng Xiaoping's aforementioned speech to all students and promptly resolved the issues of student unrest in a few universities.
On January 12, the CPC Central Committee and the State Council decided to restructure the leadership team of the University of Science and Technology of China. On January 13, 17, and 23, respectively, the Shanghai Municipal Commission for Discipline Inspection, the Anhui Provincial Commission for Discipline Inspection, and the Discipline Inspection Commission of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China made the decision to expel Wang Ruowang, Fang Lizhi, and Liu Binyan from the Party.
After a series of work, the Party and the government quelled the student movements that occurred at the end of 1986, adhered to the Party's correct leadership in reform, opening up, and socialist modernization, and ensured the healthy development of China's socialist cause.
(3) Severe crackdown on economic crimes. After the 3rd Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the Party and the state formulated and implemented policies centered on economic development, opening up to the outside world, and revitalizing the economy, which led to rapid development of our country's economy. However, during the process of reform and opening up, some unhealthy factors inevitably emerged. Due to the failure to timely keep up with necessary management measures, insufficient attention to and inadequate prevention and crackdown on economic crimes, and various other factors, economic criminal activities increased. Some staff members of state organs were corrupted in their thinking, taking advantage of their powers or loopholes in economic management, willfully embezzling, stealing, and defrauding national assets, forming a wave of economic crime. Along with the serious development of other criminal activities, economic crimes such as smuggling, speculation, embezzlement, theft, and market disruptions also escalated and proliferated.
The aforementioned economic crimes have attracted the attention of the central government. In January 1982, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China issued an urgent notice on cracking down on serious economic crimes, pointing out that this is a major issue related to the construction of the Four Modernizations in our country and the survival or demise of the nation. On March 8th, the 22nd meeting of the Standing Committee of the 5th National People's Congress passed the "Decision on Severe Punishment of Criminals Who Seriously Undermine the Economy", which increased the penalties for serious economic crimes, including the death penalty for economic criminals with particularly serious circumstances and extremely heinous nature. On April 10th, Deng Xiaoping pointed out at a meeting of the Political Bureau of the Communist Party of China's Central Committee discussing "the crackdown on serious criminal activities in the economic field": cracking down on economic crimes is a long-term and constant struggle accompanying the construction of the Four Modernizations. "We must have two hands, one is to adhere to the policy of opening up to the outside world and revitalizing the economy internally, and the other is to resolutely crack down on economic criminal activities. Without the hand of cracking down on economic criminal activities, the policy of opening up to the outside world is bound to fail, and the policy of revitalizing the economy internally will also fail. With the hand of cracking down on economic criminal activities, the policies of opening up to the outside world and revitalizing the economy can go in the right direction." "This wave has come ferociously. If our party does not pay serious attention to it and does not firmly stop it, then our party and country will indeed face the problem of whether or not to 'change their appearance.'"
On April 13, 1982, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council issued the "Decision on Cracking Down on Serious Criminal Activities in the Economic Field", sharply pointing out that cracking down on serious criminal activities in the economic field, conducting the struggle against corruption and degeneration, is related to the success or failure of our country's socialist modernization construction, and is related to the rise and fall of our party and nation. This struggle will inevitably be long-term and protracted. In accordance with the requirements of the central government, a massive campaign to crack down on economic crimes was carried out nationwide. According to the report submitted by the Discipline Inspection Commission of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China to the Standing Committee of the 6th National People's Congress in July 1983, a total of more than 190,000 economic crime cases of various types that were exposed and investigated in accordance with Party discipline and state laws from January 1982 to the end of April 1983, involving more than 71,000 party members. More than 131,000 cases have been closed, nearly 30,000 people have been sentenced according to law, and more than 8,500 people among the party members involved in the cases have been expelled from the party. A total of 24,400 people have voluntarily surrendered and confessed various economic crimes. More than 410 million yuan of illicit money and property have been recovered. On May 31st, at a party and government cadre conference held by the Discipline Inspection Commission, Wan Li delivered a speech demanding that all units carry out the crackdown on serious criminal activities in the economic field seriously. The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection has dispatched 151 officials at or above the bureau level to various locations to strengthen the investigative strength in combating economic crimes, directly participating in the investigation and handling of major cases.
According to the central deployment, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection has resolutely dealt with some major cases that violated party discipline and had a severe impact. At that time, the major cases that had a significant impact mainly included the "Jinjiang Fake Medicine" case in Fujian and the "Hainan Island Sale of Imported Cars" incident.
In order to open up the sales of white fungus drinks, some people in Chenkang Town, Jinjiang County, Fujian (now Quanzhou City) falsely claimed it to be cold medicine, printed the words "nourishes Yin and moistens the lungs, treats asthenia cough" on it, and imitated the pharmaceutical department's approval number to promote it within and outside the province. From September 1982 to April 1985, lawbreakers from 59 township enterprises successively forged more than 170 approval numbers from the health administrative department, among which 62 were widely used, producing more than 100 varieties of counterfeit drugs with a total output of more than 100,000 boxes and a total value of about RMB 40 million. These counterfeit drugs were sold to 28 provinces (regions) nationwide, causing a great sensation and attracting the attention of senior leaders in the central government. On July 13, 1985, the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection issued an open letter to the Jinjiang Prefectural Party Committee and the Prefectural Government, demanding that the case of some enterprises in Jinjiang manufacturing a large quantity of counterfeit drugs and selling them through various forms of bribery be investigated in accordance with the law and reported to the central government. On July 27, after listening to reports from the Fujian Provincial Party Committee and the Provincial Commission for Discipline Inspection, the Standing Committee of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection took legal measures against those involved and decided to dismiss and investigate the Jinjiang County Standing Committee Member and Secretary of the Commission for Discipline Inspection who participated in manufacturing and selling counterfeit drugs for profiting. In September 1986, the Higher People's Court of Fujian Province and the Intermediate People's Court of Quanzhou City sentenced the criminals involved in the "Jinjiang Fake Medicine Case" who manufactured and sold counterfeit drugs. Among them, 3 were sentenced to imprisonment for more than 10 years, 7 were sentenced to imprisonment ranging from 1 year and 6 months to 8 years, 4 were sentenced to probation, and 3 were exempted from criminal punishment. The handling of the "Jinjiang Fake Medicine Case" severely cracked down on the illegal activities of economic criminals.
From January 1, 1984, to March 5, 1985, the leading comrades of the Hainan District Party Committee and the District Government violated party discipline and relevant national regulations, and used the autonomy granted by the central government to import a large number of goods that were controlled by the state from abroad and sold them for profit. More than 10,000 imported cars have been sold off the island. Most of the other imported goods were also sold off the island. In order to import cars and other goods, the relevant cadres in Hainan Island violated the national foreign exchange management regulations and illegally acquired US $570 million in foreign exchange from outside the island at a high price, which was ten times the amount of foreign exchange allowed for Hainan to retain. At the same time, loans for importing cars and other goods amounted to a cumulative total of RMB 4.21 billion, which was 1 billion yuan more than Hainan's total industrial and agricultural output value in 1984. Many of the loans were actually unable to be repaid, with 2.01 billion yuan still outstanding at the time of the case. These actions not only violated relevant national regulations, but also undermined national plans, markets, and credit policies, and also hindered the development of Hainan's emerging large-scale development and construction. After the "Car Incident" occurred, a joint investigation group composed of the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection, the National Audit Office, the National Economic Commission, the Ministry of Economic Affairs, the State Council Special Economic Zone Office, the State Supplies Bureau, the Guangdong Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China, and the Guangdong Provincial People's Government conducted an investigation for more than two months and wrote the "Investigation Report on the Issue of Importing and Selling Cars and Other Goods in Hainan". On July 31, the report was forwarded by the central government and the State Council. The Central Commission for Discipline Inspection agreed with the Guangdong Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China and the Provincial Government's disciplinary actions against the parties involved in this disciplinary violation case. The Guangdong Provincial Committee of the Communist Party of China and the Provincial Government also conducted inspections as a result.
The investigation and handling of the above-mentioned economic criminal cases effectively safeguarded the seriousness of party discipline and national laws, and to a certain extent ensured the healthy development of the reform, opening up, and modernization construction endeavors.
II. The "Tiananmen Square Incident" and the Formation of the Third Generation Central Leadership Collective
Just as the work of governing the economic environment and rectifying the economic order needed to be deepened, a political turmoil took place in Beijing and other areas in the spring and summer of 1989. The Party Central Committee took resolute measures and effectively quelled the turbulence. For a long time, certain political forces from Western countries had been using various channels to infiltrate socialist countries ideologically and politically, supporting various anti-communist and anti-socialist activities. After the occurrence of turmoil in some socialist countries in Eastern Europe, some Western countries further intensified their efforts to promote peaceful evolution in China through various channels. In addition, during a period of time, a minority of leading comrades within the Party lacked consistency in adhering to the four cardinal principles and the ideological and political work weakened, while the serious phenomenon of corruption among some officials seriously damaged the Party's image among the people. In the spring and summer of 1989, a small number of people took advantage of existing problems within the Party's work and the public's dissatisfaction with rising prices, especially the corruption of some officials, to incite activities against the leadership of the Communist Party and the socialist system. They spread rumors on a large scale under the pretext of the masses mourning for Hu Yaobang, and organized a planned and organized anti-Party and anti-socialist turmoil. In the Beijing area, they incited some uninformed people to occupy Tiananmen Square and attack key departments of the Party and government. With the strong support of the older generation of revolutionaries such as Deng Xiaoping, the Political Bureau of the Central Committee, relying on the people, resolutely opposed the turmoil, quelled the political turbulence, defended the socialist state power, and safeguarded the fundamental interests of the people.
This political turmoil deeply educated the Party and the people. On June 9, 1989, Deng Xiaoping pointed out in a speech: the nature of this incident is the opposition between bourgeois liberalization and adherence to the four cardinal principles. This turmoil was bound to happen sooner or later, determined by the international climate and China's own small climate, and could not be changed by people's will. This incident, which erupted, is worth pondering and prompts us to calmly reflect on the past and consider the future. He raised two questions that need serious consideration. First, is the route, principles, and policies established by the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, including the development strategy of the "three-step" plan, correct or not? Does the correctness of the route, principles, and policies we formulated have problems because of this turmoil? Should we continue to use it as the goal of our future struggle? Second, does the summary of the "one central task, two basic points" at the 13th Party Congress hold true? Were the four cardinal principles and the policy of reform and opening up wrong? To these two questions, he firmly answered that the route, principles, and policies established by the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee of the Party, including our development strategy of the "three-step" plan, are not wrong, and the correctness of our strategic goals should not be questioned because of this incident. The route of the "one central task, two basic points" is not wrong. The four cardinal principles themselves are not wrong, and the policy of reform and opening up is also not wrong. The basic route, principles, and policies we have formulated should be steadfastly implemented. "If there are any mistakes, it is that we have not consistently adhered to the four cardinal principles"; "If anything is lacking, it is that the reform and opening up has not gone far enough."
This turbulence seriously disrupted the progress of reform and opening up and modernization construction, while also exposing problems within the central leadership of the Party, necessitating a reshuffle. Even before the turbulence had been completely extinguished, Deng Xiaoping proposed the change of the central leadership, stating that the new central leadership should present a new appearance to the people and be a promising leading core that implements reforms. People who are recognized by the people as upholding the route of reform and opening up and having achievements should be selected to form a promising leadership collective that implements reforms. Trust must be gained from the people, and the Party must be trustworthy, as well as trusted by the people. According to Deng Xiaoping's suggestions and after sufficient deliberation, Jiang Zemin, a member of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee and the Communist Party Secretary of Shanghai, became the candidate to lead the new generation of central leadership. In late June 1989, the Fourth Plenary Session of the 13th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China (CPC) analyzed the nature and causes of the recent political turbulence in the country, and preliminarily summed up the experiences and lessons learned. The plenary session made the decision to remove Zhao Ziyang from all his leadership positions within the party due to serious mistakes he made during the crucial moment of suppressing the turmoil, and made adjustments to some members of the central leadership. The plenary session elected Jiang Zemin as the General Secretary of the Central Committee and formed a new Standing Committee of the Political Bureau of the Central Committee. The plenary session emphasized the need to resolutely implement the party's policies, principles, and guidelines since the Third Plenary Session of the 11th Central Committee, as well as the fundamental guideline of "one central task and two basic points" determined at the 13th National Congress of the CPC.
Suppressing domestic political turbulence was originally China's internal affair. However, some Western countries took advantage of this opportunity to impose sanctions on China, attempting to force a change in the direction of socialist development. Facing tremendous pressure domestically and internationally, the central leadership collective with Jiang Zemin as the core took up the important responsibility of leading the party and the country, leading the whole party and the people of all ethnic groups in withstanding the pressure and firmly adhering to the basic line of socialism in the primary stage. The CPC Central Committee took a series of major measures to quickly restore normal production and social order in Beijing and other places, and maintained the political stability of the whole country. They investigated and dealt with major cases and intensified the fight against corruption. In order to overcome the phenomenon of being "hard in one hand and soft in the other," all levels of party organizations were required to focus on party building and strengthen their leadership in propaganda and ideological work. The policies of governance and rectification were continued, and the reform and opening up as well as economic development progressed, gradually improving the national economic situation.
Since the new central leadership collective has effectively carried out their work, Deng Xiaoping requested to resign from the position of Chairman of the Central Military Commission of the CPC to the Political Bureau of the Central Committee. In November 1989, the Fifth Plenary Session of the 13th Central Committee of the CPC approved Deng Xiaoping's request. The plenary session expressed high respect for Deng Xiaoping's act of personally setting an example by resigning from his current position in accordance with the fundamental interests of the party and the country, thus abolishing the lifelong tenure system for leading cadres. It also emphasized that "Comrade Deng Xiaoping's series of viewpoints and theories based on integrating Marxism-Leninism with China's practice, especially the basic theory of building socialism with Chinese characteristics, are an important part of Mao Zedong Thought, a continuation and development of Mao Zedong Thought under new historical conditions, and a valuable spiritual wealth of the Communist Party of China and the Chinese people."
