In summary, the construction of advanced socialist culture with Chinese characteristics is to vigorously develop advanced culture, support healthy and beneficial culture, strive to transform backward culture, resolutely resist decadent culture, constantly enrich people's spiritual world, constantly strengthen people's spiritual power, and strive to form theoretical guidance, public opinion force, spiritual pillar, and cultural conditions that reflect the requirements of China's advanced productive forces, reflect the direction of China's advanced culture, and reflect the fundamental interests of the broadest people of China.
While the theoretical understanding of socialist culture with Chinese characteristics continues to become more enriched and improved, the Party Central Committee also emphasizes several important aspects of the specific implementation of developing advanced socialist culture with Chinese characteristics, and increases the efforts to improve and reform."
Firstly, promoting ideological and moral construction promotes the healthy development of social and cultural undertakings and the socialist market economy. Ideological and political work is an important political advantage of the Communist Party of China. Jiang Zemin pointed out that the more we develop the economy and the more we reform and open up, the more we need to attach importance to ideological and political work. "Strengthening socialist ideological and moral construction is an important content and central link in the development of advanced culture." In September 2001, based on summarizing years of practical experience, the Party Central Committee issued the "Outline for the Implementation of Citizen Moral Construction." The "Outline for the Implementation of Citizen Moral Construction" proposes that it is necessary to firmly establish the common ideal of building socialism with Chinese characteristics, the correct world view, life view, and values ​​of the whole nation; vigorously promote the basic moral norms of "loving the country and abiding by the law, polite and honest, unity and friendship, diligence and self-improvement, professionalism and dedication" in the whole society; establish a socialist ideological and moral system that is compatible with the socialist market economy, coordinated with socialist legal norms, and inherited from the traditional virtues of the Chinese nation.
Secondly, promoting and cultivating the great national spirit. National spirit is the spiritual support for the survival and development of a nation. A nation cannot stand among the nations of the world without an inspiring spirit and noble character. Jiang Zemin pointed out that in the more than 5,000 years of development, the Chinese nation has formed a great national spirit with patriotism as the core, unity and unity, love for peace, diligence and bravery, and the spirit of self-improvement. This national spirit is broad and profound, long-lasting, and an indispensable component of the Chinese nation's life organism. This national spirit, combined with the fine traditions and spirit of the times formed by our party in the long-term revolution, construction, and reform, is a powerful spiritual driving force for the continuous development and growth of the Chinese nation.
Thirdly, promoting the development of cultural undertakings fundamentally through education and science. Education is the foundation for the development of science and technology and the cultivation of talents. It plays a leading and overall role in modernization construction and must be given strategic priority in development. Deng Xiaoping pointed out: "We must do everything possible to solve the education problem, even sacrificing some speed and tolerating in other areas." Jiang Zemin once emphasized that in the entire process of socialist modernization construction, the strategic position of prioritizing the development of education must be adhered to and cannot be shaken. If we do not recognize the education problem in this way now, we will miss the opportunity and delay important matters, and we will make historical mistakes. In view of the fact that philosophy and social sciences have not received the attention they deserve in society, Jiang Zemin pointed out that philosophy and social sciences are important tools for people to understand and transform the world and important forces to promote historical development and social progress. "In the process of understanding and transforming the world, philosophy and social sciences are equally important as natural sciences; it is equally important to cultivate high-level philosophers and social science researchers as it is to cultivate high-level natural scientists; it is equally important to improve the philosophical and social science literacy of the entire nation as it is to improve the natural science literacy of the entire nation; it is equally important to appoint and make good use of philosophers and social science talents as it is to appoint and make good use of natural science talents." It is necessary to correct the bias of some regions and departments that do not value philosophy and social sciences.
Fourthly, vigorously promote cultural system reform. Since the Fourth Plenary Session of the 13th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, the Party Central Committee has vigorously promoted the reform of the cultural management system in accordance with the characteristics and laws of socialist spiritual civilization construction, and to adapt to the requirements of the development of socialist market economy. The National Conference on Propaganda and Ideological Work held in January 1994 further clarified the guidelines of promoting the main theme and advocating diversified cultural construction. Localities and departments adhere to the guidance, overall planning, structural adjustment, and efficiency improvement in cultural construction, actively cultivate the socialist cultural market and promote its healthy development. Based on this, the Sixth Plenary Session of the 14th CPC Central Committee held in 1996 made detailed plans for the development of socialist cultural undertakings in the new century. The meeting pointed out that the primary task of prospering literature and art is to produce excellent works with ideological and artistic unity, strong attractiveness, and infectiousness under the correct guidance; news and propaganda must adhere to the Party's principles, seek truth from facts, focus on promoting solidarity and stability, carry out positive propaganda, and firmly grasp the correct direction of public opinion; philosophy and social sciences must adhere to the guidance of Marxism-Leninism, Mao Zedong Thought, Deng Xiaoping Theory of Socialism with Chinese Characteristics, and adhere to the integration of theory with practice, provide services for the Party and government decision-making, and serve the construction of the two civilizations; the cultural market should both prosper and be regulated, vigorously support healthy cultural products, advocate beneficial cultural and entertainment activities suitable for the consumption level of the masses, and promote the healthy development of the cultural market. In order to achieve the above objectives, it is necessary to continue to deepen the reform of the cultural management system, and quickly form a development pattern in which the state guarantees the development of key cultural undertakings and encourages social organizations to establish cultural undertakings.
Under the above ideological guidance, the reform of the cultural management system and operational mechanism has gradually deepened. In terms of ownership, the practice of the state monopolizing cultural undertakings for a long time has been changed, allowing the development of various forms of cultural industries. In terms of administrative management, a cultural management system with classification guidance and hierarchical management has been established, and the personnel system and distribution system within cultural institutions have been reformed. This change has turned attention from supporting individuals to supporting the development of cultural undertakings, fully stimulating the vitality of cultural institutions.
Since the Sixth Plenary Session of the 14th CPC Central Committee and the 15th National Congress of the Party, the construction of cultural undertakings has taken "quality strategy" as its core. Under the promotion of strengthened management and deepened reforms, a new situation of prosperity and development has emerged. In addition to continuing to organize and implement the "Five Projects" of spiritual civilization construction, various departments and regions have also strengthened the management of spiritual products production and cultural markets. The state has successively formulated and improved relevant policies and regulations such as the "Regulations on Publishing Management," "Regulations on Printing Industry Management," "Regulations on Audio and Video Product Management," "Regulations on Commercial Performances Management," and "Regulations on Radio and Television Management," providing necessary legal and policy support for the entry of cultural quality products into the market, ensuring that healthy cultural products firmly occupy the dominant position in the cultural market. By the end of 2000, the national radio coverage rate and television coverage rate reached 92.1% and 93.4% respectively, increasing by 13.4% and 8.9% compared with 1995. Excellent works reflecting the spirit of the times and close to people's lives have emerged continuously. Through the exhibitions, screenings, broadcasts, and displays of award-winning works of the "Five Projects," the exemplary role of excellent works has been fully played. The socialist cultural position has been consolidated, and a healthy and positive public opinion environment, a civilized and harmonious social atmosphere, and rich and diverse cultural life have been formed.
After the Fourth Plenary Session of the 13th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China, a relatively complete and systematic theory of building an advanced socialist culture with Chinese characteristics was established. It is a new development of the Party's ideology in cultural construction under new historical conditions and a new achievement in exploring the path of Marxist Chinese-style development.
Chapter 9: Strategy for the Development of Reform and Opening-Up in the New Century and the Development of the Cause of Socialism with Chinese Characteristics
Since the 1990s, when the Party Central Committee with Jiang Zemin as the core was promoting the cause of socialism with Chinese characteristics, it comprehensively arranged and deployed how China could cross the century in terms of development strategy, diplomacy, national defense, and the reunification of the motherland. These issues fully reflect the theoretical development and practical innovation of Marxism in China, combining the international and national situations faced by the third generation of central leadership collective.
I. Formulation of the development strategy for reform, opening-up, and modernization
After the early realization of the "first step" and "second step" strategic goals of social development in China in the 1990s, the third generation of the Party's central leadership collective, with Jiang Zemin as the core, formulated a new plan for the realization of the "third step" strategic goals and successively put forward a series of strategic deployments such as "rejuvenating the country through science and education," "sustainable development," and "combining introduction and going out," further enriching and developing the strategic development of China's modernization with Chinese characteristics.
1. Rejuvenating the country through science and education and sustainable development strategies
The strategy of rejuvenating the country through science and education and sustainable development is a major strategic decision made by the central leadership based on Deng Xiaoping's theory and the Party's basic line, starting from the national conditions of China, and scientifically analyzing the trends of world economic and social development in order to achieve the grand goal of the "three steps."
From the late 1970s to the early 1990s, Deng Xiaoping stressed on multiple occasions the importance of "achieving the Four Modernizations, with science and technology as the key and education as the foundation" and "paying attention to education and science and technology in the long run" and stated that "science and technology are the primary productive forces."
In the 1990s, based on the inheritance of Deng Xiaoping's theory, the central leadership collective with Jiang Zemin as the core further clarified the strategic thinking of rejuvenating the country through science and education and included it as a basic national policy. At the 14th National Congress of the Party in 1992, Jiang Zemin pointed out, "We must shift economic development to rely on scientific and technological progress and improve the quality of the workforce." The Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council on Accelerating Scientific and Technological Progress, promulgated on May 6, 1995, first proposed the strategy of rejuvenating the country through science and education nationwide. Jiang Zemin stated, "Rejuvenating the country through science and education means fully implementing the idea that science and technology are the primary productive forces, adhering to education as the foundation, giving science and technology an important position in economic and social development, enhancing the country's scientific and technological strength and its ability to transform productivity, and improving the scientific and cultural quality of the entire nation." In the same year, the Fifth Plenary Session of the 14th Central Committee made implementing the strategy of rejuvenating the country through science and education one of the important guidelines for accelerating socialist modernization in China in the next 15 years and until the 21st century, in its recommendations on the "Ninth Five-Year Plan" for national economic and social development and the 2010 long-term goals. In 1996, the Fourth Session of the Eighth National People's Congress formally approved the "Ninth Five-Year Plan" for national economic and social development and the 2010 long-term goals, making "rejuvenating the country through science and education" a basic national policy.
Rejuvenating the country through science and education is not only aimed at promoting rapid economic development but also at promoting the coordinated development of the economy and society. Achieving rapid development and coordination requires considering the sustainability of development, adapting the scale and speed of development to the basic national conditions and conforming to the objective laws of economic and social development. Therefore, after the rapid development of China's economy in the 1980s, the Party Central Committee began to pay more attention to the issue of sustainable development in China, drawing lessons from the development of industrialized countries in the world while summarizing China's historical experience and continuously understanding the laws of economic development, and proposed the strategy of sustainable development.
In October 1993, based on Deng Xiaoping's ideas on coordinating population, environment, and resource development and China's actual situation, the Party Central Committee and the State Council proposed the concept of implementing the strategy of sustainable development in China. In 1994, the Chinese government formulated and approved the "China Agenda 21 - China's 21st Century White Paper on Population, Environment, and Development," establishing the overall strategic framework and main goals for China's sustainable development in the 21st century. In March 1996, the "Ninth Five-Year Plan" for national economic and social development and the 2010 long-term goals, approved by the Fourth Session of the Eighth National People's Congress, made sustainable development an important guiding principle and strategic goal, and clearly made a major decision for China to implement the strategy of sustainable development in its future economic and social development. The 15th National Congress of the Party reiterated this strategic decision and emphasized that China, as a country with a large population but relatively insufficient resources, must implement a sustainable development strategy in its modernization process.
The sustainable development strategy represents a significant breakthrough from traditional development perspectives. It provides a new angle and fully elucidates the major issues concerning China's future development, including how to build socialism in a country with a backward economic and cultural foundation and extremely imbalanced levels of productive forces, as well as how to promote economic growth and comprehensive social development. It sets the correct direction for the construction of socialism with Chinese characteristics.
2. The Western Development Strategy
The implementation of the Western Development Strategy and the acceleration of development in the central and western regions were significant decisions made by the Party Central Committee, with Jiang Zemin as the core, in line with Deng Xiaoping's strategic thinking on China's modernization process in the late 1990s. It was a visionary and comprehensive decision for the future, looking ahead to the 21st century.
In 1988, after the comprehensive launch of reform and modernization, Deng Xiaoping proposed the strategy of "two major undertakings" in China's modernization process. He said, "We need to accelerate the opening-up of the coastal regions, so that this vast region, with a population of 200 million, can rapidly develop and drive the development of the inland areas. This is a matter concerning the overall situation. The inland regions must consider the overall situation as well. Conversely, when development reaches a certain stage, it will require the coastal regions to provide more support for the development of the inland areas. This is also a major issue. At that time, the coastal regions must also abide by this overall situation." He also envisioned that when the entire nation reaches a moderately prosperous level by the end of the 20th century, more efforts should be made to help accelerate development in the central and western regions. After 1995, as China's second-step development goals for modernization were achieved ahead of schedule, the Party Central Committee began to consider Deng Xiaoping's second major undertakings more prominently. When formulating the "9th Five-Year Plan" and the 2010 Perspective Target Outline, narrowing the regional development gap and promoting coordinated regional economic development were regarded as important guidelines. The 15th National Congress of the Party in 1997 also explicitly stated the need to promote a rational regional economic layout and coordinated development, gradually narrowing economic development gaps between regions. Based on the general principles of "overall planning, adapting to local conditions, leveraging strengths, division of labor and cooperation, and coordinated development," the Party Central Committee made comprehensive arrangements for the healthy development of China's regional economy. On June 17, 1999, Jiang Zemin presided over a symposium on reform and development in the five northwestern provinces in Xi'an, where he proposed the timely implementation of the Western Development Strategy to accelerate development in the central and western regions. He pointed out that accelerating the development of the western regions is a strategic decision that has significant economic, political, and social implications. The conditions for accelerating the development of the central and western regions are basically in place, and the timing is ripe. From now on, this should be regarded as a major strategic task for the Party and the country, given greater prominence.
After a series of preparations, in October 2000, the 5th Plenary Session of the 15th Party Congress passed the "Suggestions of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Formulating the 10th Five-Year Plan for National Economic and Social Development," formally proposing the Western Development Strategy. It stated that the implementation of the Western Development Strategy and the acceleration of development in the central and western regions are crucial measures for economic development, ethnic unity, social stability, regional coordination, and ultimately achieving common prosperity, which are essential steps towards accomplishing the strategic goals of the third stage of development. Subsequently, the Western Development Strategy was swiftly implemented, and remarkable achievements were made.
3. The combination strategy of "bringing in" and "going out"
Based on the new trend of global economic globalization and the development process of China's reform and opening up, the Party Central Committee timely proposed and implemented the strategy of combining "bringing in" and "going out" in the new era, promoting the formation of a new pattern of comprehensive, multi-level and broad-based development of opening up.
In February 1998, Jiang Zemin proposed at the Second Plenary Session of the 15th Central Committee the guidelines for responding to the Asian financial crisis: while actively expanding exports, we should systematically organize and support a group of state-owned enterprises with strength and advantages to invest and establish factories overseas, both "bringing in" and "going out". The two aspects of opening up are interrelated and interdependent. In October 2000, the Fifth Plenary Session of the 15th Central Committee officially proposed: with a more proactive attitude, seize opportunities, meet challenges, seek benefits and avoid harm, promote comprehensive, multi-level and broad-based opening up, develop an open economy, implement the "going out" strategy, and strive for new breakthroughs in utilizing domestic and foreign resources and markets.
In March 2001, the Fourth Session of the 9th National People's Congress passed the Outline of the Tenth Five-Year Plan for National Economic and Social Development of the People’s Republic of China, which further deployed the implementation of the "going out" strategy of opening up. According to this deployment, China's opening up has shifted from focusing on "bringing in" in the past to a combination of "bringing in" and "going out", actively participating in international cooperation, expanding the scope of opening up, adopting a more proactive approach, and achieving significant results in a short period of time. By the end of 2001, China had participated in 195 overseas resource cooperation projects, with a total investment of 4.6 billion US dollars; established 6,610 overseas enterprises with a total agreed investment of 12.3 billion US dollars, of which Chinese investment amounted to 8.4 billion US dollars; signed total contracts for foreign contracted projects amounted to 99.7 billion US dollars, with a turnover of 71.5 billion US dollars, driving exports of nearly 6 billion US dollars; signed foreign labor service contracts amounted to 26.8 billion US dollars, with a turnover of 20.7 billion US dollars, and dispatched 2.52 million person-times of labor services. Various forms of foreign economic cooperation have continued to grow steadily. In 2001, 15 large-scale engineering projects involving electricity, transportation, construction, petrochemicals and other industries were newly signed, with an average foreign investment of 2.52 million US dollars, an increase of nearly 30% over the previous year. Large backbone enterprises such as China National Petroleum Corporation, China Petrochemical Corporation, Haier Group, etc., have played a leading role in implementing overseas investment strategies and have begun to take shape as multinational corporations.
The combination strategy of "bringing in" and "going out" has effectively promoted the development of an open economy and made the comprehensive, multi-level and broad-based pattern of opening up clearer. The Chinese economy has further integrated into the process of economic globalization and has gained a broader development space. This is another far-sighted decision made by the Party Central Committee on the development path across the century.
The introduction and implementation of the above development strategies reflect the objective process and laws of China's modernization construction, which not only have Chinese characteristics but also embody the glorious tradition of communists in China's combining Marxist basic principles with China's actual conditions.
II. Deepening the reform of state-owned enterprises
State-owned enterprises are the backbone of China's national economy and have made tremendous contributions to the country's construction and development. However, due to the long-term operation under the planned economic system, there have been significant shortcomings such as excessive control by the state, rigid operating mechanisms, and neglect of the role of the market. Therefore, the task of reform is also the most arduous.
1. Achieve the three-year goal of getting out of the crisis and establishing a modern enterprise system.
After the establishment of the goal of reforming the socialist market economy system, starting from 1994, the reform of state-owned enterprises entered the stage of transforming operating mechanisms and establishing modern corporate systems. With the transformation of the system and the dramatic changes in the market environment, many contradictions and problems accumulated by state-owned enterprises under the planned system were exposed, mainly manifested as inactive mechanisms, and a considerable number of enterprises did not adapt to the requirements of the market economy. Therefore, they fell into unprecedented difficulties in fierce market competition. In the first quarter of 1996, after the profits and losses of 68,800 independently accounted state-owned industrial enterprises were offset, the first net loss since the founding of New China occurred.
In response to this situation, the central government believed that the only way for state-owned enterprises to overcome difficulties was to adapt to the needs of developing the socialist market economy, continue to accelerate and deepen reforms, and establish modern corporate systems. In order to achieve this, the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China further clarified the direction of state-owned enterprise reform and proposed the goal of striving to initially establish modern corporate systems in the majority of large and medium-sized state-owned backbone enterprises by the end of the 20th century, with significant improvements in operational conditions, and to open up a new situation in the reform and development of state-owned enterprises, thus pushing forward the state-owned enterprise reform to a crucial stage.
The difficulties in the operation of state-owned enterprises are not only due to inactive mechanisms but also due to the unreasonable layout and structure of the state-owned economy. The frontline is too long and too dispersed, and the scale of enterprises is small with low quality. This is an important reason for high input and low output, high consumption, and low efficiency. If this layout and structure are not changed, it is difficult to promote the reform of individual enterprises. Therefore, the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China also proposed that, strategically adjusting the layout of the state-owned economy, the state-owned economy must dominate in important industries and key areas that are related to the lifeline of the national economy. In other areas, the overall quality of state-owned assets can be improved through asset reorganization and structural adjustment. The reform of state-owned enterprises should be combined with reorganization, transformation, and strengthening of management, focusing on the overall state-owned economy, strengthening large enterprises, activating small ones, and implementing strategic reorganization of state-owned enterprises.
The First Plenary Session of the 15th Central Committee made it clear that within about three years, through reform, reorganization, transformation, and strengthening of management, most large and medium-sized state-owned loss-making enterprises should be freed from difficulties, and by the end of the 20th century, efforts should be made to initially establish modern corporate systems in the majority of large and medium-sized state-owned backbone enterprises.
After the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, a comprehensive reform focusing on establishing modern corporate systems was launched. The pilot program for establishing a modern corporate system, which started in 1994, expanded significantly in 1997. The number of pilot cities for "optimizing the capital structure" increased from 18 to 111, and the number of pilot enterprise groups increased from 56 to 120. Through these pilot programs, in accordance with the requirements of developing a socialist market economy, a strategic reorganization of the entire state-owned enterprise was implemented and a new management system was established.
A number of large enterprise groups were successively formed, including China National Petroleum Corporation, Sinopec Group, Shanghai Baosteel Group Corporation, 10 defense industry groups, 3 non-ferrous metal groups, 4 information industry groups, and so on. These large enterprise groups operate according to market requirements, no longer assuming administrative functions, and are authorized by the government to operate state-owned assets, thereby enhancing their ability to develop independently and participate in international competition.
The cities involved in the pilot program for "optimizing the capital structure" have begun to form a competition mechanism of survival of the fittest through encouraging mergers, regulating bankruptcy, downsizing and transferring employees, and reducing personnel to improve efficiency. For state-owned small enterprises, various forms such as reorganization, collaboration, merger, leasing, contracting, cooperative stock, and sale are adopted to loosen and revitalize, and some key aspects of the sale of small enterprises are regulated. 
The basic characteristic of the modern enterprise system is the corporate system, and the typical forms of the corporate system are joint-stock limited companies and limited liability companies. The prominent feature is that small amount of capital combines in a shareholding manner to form a corporate capital, in order to adapt to the needs of socialized large-scale production and pursue greater capital appreciation. This is a typical form of enterprise organization in modern economic society. The reform of the shareholding system in China gradually began in the mid and late 1980s, and a large number of shareholding pilot enterprises have appeared in various parts of the country in the early 1990s.
On December 19, 1990, and July 3, 1991, with the approval of the State Council, the Shanghai Stock Exchange and the Shenzhen Stock Exchange were successively established. After 1992, inspired by Deng Xiaoping's speech in the south, the shareholding system reform entered a new stage of development. In March of the same year, relevant departments of the State Council jointly formulated 11 regulations including the "Pilot Measures for Shareholding Enterprises", further standardizing and promoting the shareholding system reform.
After 1998, in accordance with the requirements of establishing a modern enterprise system, a large number of state-owned enterprises carried out corporate and shareholding reforms. Many large-scale enterprises and enterprise groups, after asset restructuring according to international practice, have successfully listed on domestic or overseas capital markets. This not only raised a large amount of social capital and improved asset structure and operational conditions but also played an important role in establishing a modern enterprise system, promoting the formation of a diversified investment and financing system, expanding the channels for national fiscal revenue, and improving the efficiency of economic operation.
By the end of 2000, there were 1,088 listed companies in the Shanghai and Shenzhen stock markets, with 1,257 listed securities. The number of investors in the stock market reached 58.01 million, and the total market value of stocks reached 4.8091 trillion yuan, accounting for more than 50% of the GDP. In just a decade, China's shareholding economy has gone through a path that took Western developed countries more than 100 years to complete, and it has occupied a significant position in the national economic life, with an increasingly prominent role in promoting economic development and reform.
To reverse the loss situation of state-owned enterprises, the textile industry, which suffers from the most severe losses, was chosen as a breakthrough. Starting with "reducing the number of spindles, reducing staff, and improving efficiency," the textile industry underwent asset restructuring, adjusted production structure, and transformed management mechanisms in accordance with market requirements. In 1998, a total of 5.12 million backward cotton spindles were eliminated, 660,000 laid-off workers were resettled, and losses were reduced by 2.6 billion yuan, taking an important step towards achieving the goal of turning the entire industry from loss to profit within three years. The coal industry also reversed the loss situation by measures such as "decentralization, closing mines, and reducing production capacity," reducing excess production capacity and eliminating backward enterprises.
To ensure that state-owned enterprises achieve the overall goal of reform and revitalization within three years, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the State Council also decided to establish a system of special inspectors dispatched by the State Council. Special inspectors of state-owned enterprises are held by vice-ministerial-level or higher cadres. The state plans to gradually dispatch inspectors to 1,000 large-scale enterprises and enterprise groups, and in 1998, inspectors were first sent to 500 enterprises. Their main task is to conduct financial audits, examine the profit and loss and asset-liability situations of enterprises, and evaluate the financial conditions and work performance of the main leaders of the enterprises, and then make reports to the State Council after being reviewed by relevant departments. Local governments dispatch members of the supervisory board to state-owned enterprises or wholly state-owned companies and state-owned holding companies under their jurisdiction for oversight.
On April 28, 1998, the first batch of 21 inspection envoys and over 80 inspection envoy assistants began their training. In order to ensure that the envoys fulfill their responsibilities effectively, the State Council formulated and promulgated the "Regulations on Inspection Envoys". Inspection envoys represent the state in exercising supervisory powers, strengthening the government's supervision over enterprises while implementing the separation of administration and enterprise, and allowing state-owned enterprises to operate independently. Through financial supervision and examination of operational results, they evaluate the implementation of the Party's policies, state laws and regulations, as well as the performance of the main leaders of the enterprise. Based on inspection conclusions, the State Council makes rewards, punishments, and appointments of the main leaders of the enterprise through the personnel department. The implementation of this system has played a significant role in the construction of leadership teams in state-owned enterprises and the implementation of various reform measures.
2. Implementation of the reemployment project for laid-off workers in state-owned enterprises
Ensuring the basic livelihood and reemployment of laid-off workers in state-owned enterprises is an important aspect of the success of the reform of state-owned enterprises. "The way to govern lies in reassuring the people, and reassuring the people lies in understanding their suffering." The Party Central Committee has paid high attention to the temporary difficulties encountered by some laid-off workers. Jiang Zemin emphasized on multiple occasions that the vast number of employees in state-owned enterprises have made significant contributions to the country's economic construction, reform and opening up, and the development and growth of state-owned enterprises over the past decades. Party committees and governments at all levels must always care for them and effectively safeguard their interests.
From May 14th to 17th, 1998, the Party Central Committee and the State Council held a conference on the livelihood guarantee and reemployment of laid-off workers in Beijing, and formulated measures for the transfer of surplus personnel and the implementation of the reemployment project. Jiang Zemin pointed out at the conference: This work is not only a major economic issue but also a major political issue; it is not only an urgent practical issue but also a long-term strategic issue. Party committees and governments at all levels must prioritize and handle it well as a top priority. The conference proposed that the basic living expenses of laid-off workers must be guaranteed. The funds should be jointly provided by the government, enterprises, and society, and the basic living expenses should be timely and accurately distributed to each laid-off worker, without delay, misappropriation, or deduction. Otherwise, responsibilities should be pursued. The most important thing is to help laid-off workers find reemployment. This work is related to the success or failure of SOE reform, the interests of workers, and is an indispensable stage in the reform process, it is a major issue and an important task for the overall situation.
In June, the CPC Central Committee and the State Council issued a notice on doing a good job in the basic livelihood and reemployment of laid-off workers in state-owned enterprises, stating that in the future, to ensure the realization of the goals of state-owned enterprise reform proposed at the 15th Party Congress, to complete the strategic adjustment of state-owned economy, it is necessary to make solving the basic livelihood and reemployment issues of laid-off workers in state-owned enterprises a top priority, and strive to achieve the number of people reemployed each year to be greater than the number of newly laid-off workers in that year, with more than 50% of the already laid-off and newly laid-off workers in 1998 getting reemployed. Efforts should be made to establish, in about five years, a social security system and employment mechanism that adapt to the requirements of a socialist market economy.
Central leaders have frequently visited grassroots communities to conduct investigations and research on the employment and livelihood issues of laid-off workers, and to extend condolences to those facing difficulties. In accordance with the central government's arrangements, local governments have successively established "three guarantees" for laid-off workers: first, a basic living allowance for laid-off workers; second, those who remain unemployed after three years can transition to receiving unemployment insurance benefits; third, those who remain unemployed after two years of receiving unemployment insurance can be eligible for the minimum living guarantee for urban residents as stipulated by regulations. At the same time, governments at all levels have strengthened vocational training in various forms, expanded employment channels, established re-employment service centers, guided workers in changing their job-seeking mindset, and vigorously promoted the re-employment of laid-off workers. From 1998 to 2000, a total of 21 million laid-off workers from state-owned enterprises nationwide entered re-employment service centers, of which 13 million successfully re-employed, providing strong support for the smooth progress of state-owned enterprise reforms.
3. Strengthening party leadership over large state-owned enterprises
To strengthen leadership over large and medium-sized state-owned enterprises, the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China approved the establishment of the Central Committee for Work in Large Enterprises on July 9, 1998. Wu Bangguo, member of the Political Bureau of the CPC Central Committee and Vice Premier of the State Council, served as the secretary. Its responsibilities are as follows: responsible for managing the party leadership positions within large state-owned enterprises supervised by the State Council and state-owned enterprises under state control, in order to promote the implementation of the Party's line, principles and policies, as well as relevant spirits of the Party Central Committee and the State Council, in large state-owned enterprises; based on the requirements of the socialist market economic system and the establishment of a modern enterprise system, research and explore reforms and strengthen the construction of leadership teams in large state-owned enterprises; complete other work assigned by the Central Committee. The State Council also stipulated that government agencies are strictly prohibited from providing guarantee for enterprise economic activities. The implementation of these supporting measures has accelerated the pace of state-owned enterprise reforms.
During this period, the Party Central Committee strengthened its research work on state-owned enterprises, and central leaders went to the frontlines multiple times to provide specific guidance on reforms. From April to August 1999, Jiang Zemin visited Chengdu, Wuhan, Xi'an, Qingdao, Dalian, and other places for inspections, and presided over a series of symposiums to express important opinions on the reform and development of state-owned enterprises. He pointed out that the comprehensive promotion of the reform and development of state-owned enterprises is an inevitable and crucial task. To win this tough battle not only determines the success of state-owned enterprise reforms but also relates to the overall success of the economic system reform. We must seize opportunities, make resolute decisions, exert great efforts, effectively solve the deep-rooted contradictions and problems faced by state-owned enterprises, and further enhance their vitality. The state should concentrate its efforts on developing a group of large enterprises and enterprise groups in key industries and areas that are vital to the national economy, making them the main force of the national economy. Various forms should be adopted for small and medium-sized state-owned enterprises, allowing them to operate more flexibly and encouraging their accelerated development. The establishment of a modern enterprise system is the fundamental system for the development of enterprises under the conditions of a socialist market economy. Without the establishment of effective mechanisms for management and market operations in enterprises, the socialist market economic system cannot ultimately be established, and the combination of public ownership and a market economy cannot be realized. In the reform of state-owned enterprises, it is necessary to pay attention to strengthening party leadership. These important speeches have further provided guidance for the breakthroughs in state-owned enterprise reforms.
In September 1999, the Fourth Plenary Session of the 15th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China further discussed issues related to the reform and development of state-owned enterprises and passed the "Decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on Several Major Issues Concerning the Reform and Development of State-Owned Enterprises" (referred to as the "Decision"), which set goals for the reform and development of state-owned enterprises until 2010. "The Decision" points out that the reform of state-owned enterprises is a broad and profound transformation. To enhance the country's economic strength, national defense capabilities, and national cohesion, it is necessary to continuously promote the development and growth of state-owned economy, and overall enhance the vitality of state-owned enterprises and the controlling power of state-owned economy. This is of great significance for establishing a socialist market economy system, promoting sustained, rapid and healthy economic development, improving people's living standards, maintaining a stable and united political situation, and consolidating the socialist system. To advance the reform and development of state-owned enterprises, the first priority is to make every effort to achieve the goals set forth in the 15th Party Congress and the 1st Plenary Session of the 15th Central Committee. By 2010, in order to adapt to the fundamental changes in the economic system and the economic growth model and meet the requirements of expanding opening up, it is necessary to basically complete the strategic adjustment and restructuring of state-owned enterprises, form a relatively rational layout and structure of state-owned economy, establish a relatively sound modern enterprise system, significantly improve economic efficiency, and significantly enhance the ability of technological development, market competition, and risk resistance. This will enable state-owned economy to better play a leading role in the national economy. "The Decision" also puts forward a series of major policy measures, mainly including: strategically adjusting the layout of state-owned economy, combining it with the optimization and upgrading of industrial structure and ownership adjustment, adhering to both advancement and retreat, and doing what should be done and avoiding what should not be done based on different circumstances; continuing to carry out strategic restructuring of state-owned enterprises; giving priority to the separation of government and enterprises, exploring effective forms of state-owned assets management, carrying out standardized corporate system reform, and transforming the operating mechanism, and establishing and improving the modern enterprise system; gradually solving issues such as high debt ratio, insufficient capital, and heavy social burdens of state-owned enterprises; effectively reducing number of employees, increasing efficiency, promoting reemployment, and social security work; accelerating technological progress and industrial upgrading; strengthening the Party's leadership over the reform and development of state-owned enterprises, and so on. 
The above goals and policy measures make the overall thinking of the reform of state-owned enterprises clearer and the guidelines more explicit. They are not only guiding significance for achieving the three-year goals of reform and revitalization, but also for the development of state-owned enterprises in the new century.
Under the guidance of the spirit of the Fourth Plenary Session of the 15th Central Committee, state-owned enterprises continue to make great strides in deepening reforms from multiple perspectives. From 1998 to 2000, more than 2,700 pilot enterprises were established to implement modern enterprise system, as determined by the central government and selected by local governments. Most of them have carried out corporate or shareholding system reforms. Among the 520 state-owned and state-controlled enterprises listed as national key enterprises, 430 have undergone corporate system reform, accounting for 83.7%. Profits in state-owned and state-controlled industries have increased substantially. By the end of 2000, the number of large and medium-sized state-owned and state-controlled enterprises that suffered losses in 1997 had been reduced by more than 70%; profits of state-owned and state-controlled industrial enterprises reached 239.2 billion yuan, a 1.97-fold increase over 1997’s 80.6 billion yuan; state-owned small enterprises also achieved profits of 4.81 billion yuan, ending six consecutive years of net losses. Many state-owned enterprises that have long been in difficulties have begun to emerge from the bottom, with significantly improved operating conditions, creating a new situation for the reform and development of state-owned enterprises, and basically achieving the three-year goals of reform and revitalization proposed at the 15th Party Congress. This is the result of the Party Central Committee's timely grasp of the opportunity and correct decision-making at the critical stage of reform and development, as well as the significant contributions made by the Chinese working class and the Party to the country's economic construction and reform cause.
III. Adhering to the principle of "One Country, Two Systems" and advancing the great cause of national reunification
Adhering to the principle of "One Country, Two Systems" and advancing the reunification of the motherland, this great cause has already been initiated in the 1980s and has achieved good results. In the 1990s, this cause continued to make significant progress.
1. The proposal of the eight-point statement on the development of cross-strait relations
After the proposal of the "One Country, Two Systems" policy by the Communist Party of China and the historical changes that have taken place in the mainland of the motherland, the Kuomintang authorities in Taiwan were forced to adjust their policies towards the mainland. In 1987, Chiang Ching-kuo announced the lifting of martial law in Taiwan from July 15th and subsequently opened up for compatriots from Taiwan to visit the mainland. Since then, the long-standing separation between compatriots on both sides of the strait has finally been broken. A large number of Taiwanese compatriots have come to the mainland to visit relatives, travel, and do business, and the economic and trade relations across the Taiwan Straits have rapidly expanded. 
The Communist Party of China (CPC) attaches great importance to the new changes in the cross-strait relations and actively promotes further development of the cross-strait relations. In December 1990, the CPC held a national conference on Taiwan affairs, proposing that the top priority of Taiwan work is to strengthen cross-strait contacts, further expand personnel and various exchanges, especially strengthen economic and trade exchanges, and achieve two-way and direct "Three Links". On March 5, 1994, the 6th session of the Standing Committee of the 8th National People's Congress passed the "Law on the Protection of Investments by Taiwan Compatriots in the People's Republic of China", which put the protection of Taiwanese investment on the track of legal institutionalization and further promoted the development of cross-strait economic relations. In April 1994, the CPC Central Committee and the State Council held a special conference on Taiwan's economic work, which comprehensively summarized the successful experience in the development of economic relations across the Taiwan Straits and proposed the principle of "equal priority, appropriate relaxation" in the areas and projects of Taiwan's investment. It required all regions and departments to attach great importance to Taiwan's economic work, take practical measures to protect the legitimate rights and interests of Taiwanese businessmen in the mainland, and improve the investment environment for Taiwanese businessmen in the mainland.
In order to promote substantive progress in cross-strait relations and establish channels of communication between the two sides of the strait, on December 16, 1991, the mainland side set up the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits. This is a non-governmental organization whose purpose is to promote cross-strait exchanges, develop cross-strait relations, and achieve peaceful reunification of the motherland. In March 1992, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits initiated substantive negotiations with the Taiwan Strait Exchange Foundation. In order to clarify the adherence to the principle of one China, after the first round of working negotiations in March 1992, Tang Shubei, the executive deputy director of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, further expounded the attitude of adhering to the principle of one China in the working negotiations on cross-strait affairs. In response, the Taiwan side had to express its adherence to the principle of one China and recognize the fact that Taiwan is part of Chinese territory. After multiple consultations, the two sides reached the "1992 Consensus", each expressing in oral form the adherence to the principle of one China.
On August 4, 1992, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, wrote to Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation, expressing his hope to hold talks on issues such as the economic development of the two sides of the strait and the affairs of the two organizations. On the 22nd, the Strait Exchange Foundation replied accepting the invitation. After several preparatory consultations, from April 27 to 28, 1993, Wang Daohan, chairman of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, and Koo Chen-fu, chairman of the Strait Exchange Foundation, held the first talks in Singapore. Although this meeting was only of a civil, economic, functional, and transactional nature, its content was extensive and its significance was significant, attracting attention at home and abroad. The two sides reached agreements such as the "Wang-Koo Talks Joint Agreement" and the "Agreement on Contact and Talks between the Two Organizations". Subsequently, in order to implement the various agreements reached in the "Wang-Koo Talks", from August 1993 to January 1995, the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits and the Strait Exchange Foundation held six working negotiations at the level of deputy secretary-general in Beijing, Taipei, and Nanjing. Tang Shubei, the executive deputy director of the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits, also went to Taiwan to hold talks with Jiao Renhe, deputy director and secretary-general of the Strait Exchange Foundation, and reached specific consensus on three topics: resolving disputes over fishing in the sea between the two sides, negotiating the repatriation of hijackers and the repatriation of personnel who violate relevant regulations to the other side's territory. Both sides believed that strengthening multi-level communication between the two organizations will help further enhance understanding, eliminate misunderstandings, narrow differences, and foster mutual trust.
To provide a clearer explanation of the Chinese government's policy on the Taiwan issue to both domestic and international audiences, on January 30, 1995, Jiang Zemin, on behalf of the Communist Party of China and the Chinese government, delivered an important speech entitled "Continuing to Struggle for the Completion of the Great Cause of National Reunification" in which he put forward eight propositions for the current development of cross-strait relations and the promotion of peaceful reunification of the motherland: (1) Adhere to the one-China principle, which is the basis and prerequisite for achieving peaceful reunification; (2) Cross-strait peaceful reunification negotiations can be conducted step by step; (3) Efforts should be made to achieve peaceful reunification, but the use of force is not ruled out; (4) Strongly develop economic exchanges and cooperation between the two sides of the strait in the face of the 21st century; (5) Both sides of the strait should jointly inherit and carry forward the fine traditions of Chinese culture; (6) Further place hope in the compatriots in Taiwan; (7) Welcome parties and individuals from Taiwan to exchange opinions with us on cross-strait relations and peaceful reunification; (8) The leaders of both sides visit each other in appropriate capacities.
These eight propositions put forward by Jiang Zemin further advanced the nine guidelines proposed by Ye Jianying in 1981, making Deng Xiaoping's thoughts on "peaceful reunification, one country, two systems" more specific in terms of prerequisites, principles, methods, and steps. These eight propositions not only embody the consistency and continuity of the Communist Party of China and the Chinese government's policy towards Taiwan, but also demonstrate their firm determination and sincere intention to develop cross-strait relations and achieve peaceful reunification of the motherland. They are a landmark document for resolving the Taiwan issue in the new era, with strong practical and profound historical significance. 
2. Successfully resolving the return of Hong Kong and Macao to the motherland
Just as cross-strait relations were developing smoothly, the return of Hong Kong and Macao entered the "countdown" phase. The continuous development of relations between Taiwan, Hong Kong, Macao, and the mainland can be attributed, to a large extent, to the policy of "one country, two systems". While the concept of "one country, two systems" was initially proposed to resolve the Taiwan issue, it was first successfully applied to the resolution of the Hong Kong and Macao issues.
The issue of Hong Kong is a historical legacy of British colonial aggression against China. The Hong Kong region consists of Hong Kong Island, Kowloon, and the New Territories, which have been Chinese territory since ancient times. After the Opium War in 1840, the British forced the Qing government to sign three unequal treaties: the Treaty of Nanjing, the Treaty of Beijing, and the Convention for the Extension of Hong Kong Territory, which resulted in the occupation of Hong Kong, Kowloon, and the New Territories, and subjected Hong Kong to British colonial rule. The successive governments of China before the 1911 Revolution did not recognize the aforementioned unequal treaties and conducted multiple negotiations with Britain to recover Hong Kong. In the eve of the founding of the People's Republic of China, due to special internal and external circumstances, the CPC Central Committee and Mao Zedong decided to "temporarily leave Hong Kong alone". After the establishment of the People's Republic of China in 1949, the Chinese government adopted a policy of "long-term planning and making full use of" regarding Hong Kong. It did not recognize the three unequal treaties imposed on China by imperialism but, considering historical factors, temporarily maintained the status quo and sought to peacefully resolve the issue through negotiations at an appropriate time.
In the new era of reform and opening up, as the deadline for the "lease" of Hong Kong approached, the Communist Party of China began to consider the policy of "one country, two systems" to reclaim sovereignty over Hong Kong. Starting from October 1982, after three stages and 22 rounds of arduous negotiations, the leaders of China and the United Kingdom finally signed the Sino-British Joint Declaration on the Question of Hong Kong on December 19, 1984. The declaration announced that the Chinese government had decided to resume the exercise of sovereignty over Hong Kong on July 1, 1997, and the British government would hand over Hong Kong to China on the same day. In accordance with the relevant provisions of the Joint Declaration, the handover ceremony of the Hong Kong political regime between China and the UK took place in Hong Kong from midnight on June 30 to the early hours of July 1, 1997. The smooth return of Hong Kong is the result of the successful implementation of the "one country, two systems" concept. It symbolizes the rectification of the century-long national humiliation suffered by the Chinese people in Hong Kong and marks the entry of Hong Kong's development into a new era.
When the process of Hong Kong's return started, the issue of Macau's return was also put on the agenda.
In 1974, the Portuguese government announced the abandonment of all overseas colonies and recognized Macau as Chinese territory, not a colony. In February 1979, China and Portugal established diplomatic relations and reached an understanding on the issue of Macau. The Portuguese government recognized that Macau is Chinese territory, and both sides agreed to resolve this issue through negotiations between the two governments at an appropriate time. In June 1986, the Chinese and Portuguese governments began negotiations on the issue of Macau. On April 13, 1987, the Prime Ministers of the two countries officially signed the Joint Declaration between the Government of the People's Republic of China and the Government of the Portuguese Republic on the Question of Macau in Beijing. It declared that the Macau Special Administrative Region is Chinese territory, and the Government of the People's Republic of China would resume the exercise of sovereignty over Macau on December 20, 1999. In the early hours of December 20, 1999, under the attendance of the highest leaders of the country, government representatives from China and Portugal held a grand ceremony for the transfer of sovereignty in Macau. President Jiang Zemin solemnly announced that the Chinese government would resume the exercise of sovereignty over Macau. 
The smooth return of Hong Kong and Macau opened a new era of common development between the two regions and the mainland. By resolving the issues of Hong Kong and Macau through diplomatic negotiations and the principle of "one country, two systems," the Communist Party of China made a significant contribution to the world's peaceful development and progress. The successful practice of "one country, two systems" after the return of Hong Kong and Macau has proven that it is not only the most realistic approach to achieve national reunification but also the most important institutional guarantee for the stability, prosperity, and development of the returned regions.
3. Promote the early resolution of the Taiwan issue in accordance with the principle of "one country, two systems"
In the late 1980s, there were major changes in the political situation in Taiwan. With the lifting of martial law and the localization of political power, the "Taiwan independence" forces became increasingly active. From early 1988 to 2000, Lee Teng-hui used power tactics to consolidate his position and gradually abandoned the principle of "one China," promoting the policy of creating "two Chinas." Since 1993, the Taiwan authorities have intensified their efforts to seek "participation in the United Nations" and engage in so-called "holiday diplomacy" and "dollar diplomacy," intentionally creating the concept of "two Chinas" or "one China, one Taiwan" in the international community. Especially in June 1995, with the permission of the United States, Lee Teng-hui visited the United States and delivered a political speech at Cornell University, repeatedly emphasizing the "Republic of China in Taiwan" and intensifying activities to create "two Chinas" internationally. At the same time, Taiwan has conducted consecutive "military exercises" targeting the mainland, creating a tense atmosphere between the two sides.
The Chinese government and the Chinese people have always maintained a high degree of vigilance against the escalating separatist activities of the Taiwan authorities and have firmly fought against separatism and "Taiwan independence" in politics, military, diplomacy, and public opinion. The Chinese people's struggle against separatism and "Taiwan independence" has effectively countered the separatist forces advocating "Taiwan independence" on the island and made the international community further recognize the harm of "Taiwan independence," and the majority of Taiwanese people have come to understand that "Taiwan independence" is a dead-end path. The US government has also made a commitment to continue to adhere to the "one China" policy and stated that it does not support Taiwan independence. Under various pressures, the leader of Taiwan had to express that it is currently unnecessary and not necessary to immediately declare "Taiwan independence".
Due to Li Denghui's visit to the United States, the second "Wang-Koo meeting" could not proceed as planned, and negotiations at all levels were forced to be completely suspended. In order to ease and improve cross-strait relations, the Taiwan Affairs Office of the Communist Party of China, the Taiwan Affairs Office of the State Council, and the Association for Relations Across the Taiwan Straits have respectively expressed their willingness to resume negotiations on the basis of the One China principle. In September 1997, Jiang Zemin once again solemnly called on the Taiwan authorities to engage in political negotiations with us as soon as possible in his report to the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China. After numerous consultations, from October 14 to 19, 1998, Koo Chen-fu led a delegation from the Taiwan Strait Exchange Foundation to visit the mainland. Jiang Zemin met with Koo Chen-fu and his wife, and Wang Daohan had two meetings with Koo Chen-fu, reaching a four-point consensus, thereby ushering in the beginning of political dialogue between the two sides and improving the atmosphere of cross-strait relations.
However, just when knowledgeable people in the mainland and Taiwan were actively promoting the development of cross-strait relations, the Taiwan authorities chose to continue on the path of destruction and confrontation. On July 9, 1999, Li Denghui openly proposed the "two-state theory" and claimed that the cross-strait relations were "the relations between countries, at least the relations between special countries". In March 2000, in the elections held in Taiwan, the Kuomintang was defeated and Democratic Progressive Party leader Chen Shui-bian was elected as the new leader of Taiwan. Although at the beginning of his term, he repeatedly advocated "sincerity" and "goodwill" in reopening dialogue and improving cross-strait relations, he adopted an evasive, vague, and refusal attitude towards the key issue of accepting the One China principle. Subsequently, he not only denied the existence of the "1992 Consensus", deliberately obstructed the resumption of cross-strait negotiations, but also used various means to gradually implement the "Taiwan independence" agenda. On August 3, 2002, Chen Shui-bian gave a televised speech to the 29th World Conference of Taiwanese Compatriots held in Tokyo, Japan, openly declaring "Taiwan and mainland China as two separate countries" and advocating the use of a "referendum" to decide "Taiwan's future, destiny, and present situation", revealing the nature of his obstinate adherence to the "Taiwan independence" stance.
Whether it is the "two-state theory" or the "two separate countries theory", these remarks disregard the well-being of the people of Taiwan and lead Taiwan towards disaster. As soon as these remarks were made, they were immediately met with strong opposition from all Chinese people, including Taiwanese compatriots. People from all walks of life in various regions of the country as well as overseas Chinese strongly condemned the words and actions of the Taiwan authorities in dividing the motherland.
Although the Taiwan authorities are engaged in "Taiwan independence" activities, which restrict and hinder further development of cross-strait relations, various exchanges and cooperation between the two sides are unstoppable. With the increasing interactions between people from both sides, Taiwanese compatriots have gained a better understanding of the situation in mainland China, and more and more people realize that the development and future of Taiwan are inseparable from the mainland. Economic and trade exchanges are the most active and dynamic factors in cross-strait relations. As of October 2002, Taiwanese investors have made more than 55,000 investments in the mainland, with contracted Taiwanese capital exceeding $60 billion. The total trade volume between the two sides has reached over $260 billion. In this case, Taiwanese people urgently demand the realization of direct "Three Links". With the mainland of our country and Taiwan joining the World Trade Organization, closer economic relations have been established between the mainland of our country and Taiwan, Hong Kong, and Macau. Undoubtedly, this trend will further increase the common interests of the people on both sides of the Taiwan Strait in the economy, promote the common development and prosperity of the economies of the two sides, and become an important force for maintaining and promoting cross-strait relations and achieving national reunification.
The process of promoting the great cause of national reunification by the Communist Party of China clearly shows that "peaceful reunification, one country, two systems" is the basic policy for national reunification. It is the creative development of Marxist strategic thinking by the Communist Party of China on how to achieve national reunification. The efforts of the Communist Party of China to promote peaceful reunification of the motherland represents the common interests and wishes of all Chinese people and compatriots at home and abroad. Adhering to this basic policy and realizing the complete reunification of the motherland at an early date is an unshakable belief of all Chinese sons and daughters and an irresistible trend of historical development.
IV. Establishing a comprehensive foreign relations framework for the new century
Adhering to and developing the independent and peaceful diplomatic thinking is the new contribution of the Communist Party of China in the 20th century Marxist diplomatic thinking. This thinking further enhances the ability of the Communist Party of China to deal with international affairs in its external interactions. The construction of a comprehensive and multilevel diplomatic relations framework, the rapid development of various partnership relationships, and frequent summit diplomacy are all manifestations of the enhanced ability of the Communist Party of China to respond to international affairs. These all reflect the promotion and development of Marxist diplomatic thinking by Chinese communists in a "new" sense.
From a practical perspective, since the mid-1990s, China's diplomatic work has mainly faced three tasks: firstly, it needs to respond to various changes in international relations brought about by the trend of multipolarity and establish a comprehensive and multilevel framework for foreign relations in the 21st century; secondly, it needs to oppose various hegemonism and power politics, maintain world peace, and promote the establishment of a more just and reasonable international political and economic new order to safeguard the rights and interests of all countries in the world, especially the majority of developing countries; and thirdly, it needs to respond to the impact of the trend of economic globalization and rapid development of high technology on our country.
Under the leadership of the Party Central Committee with Comrade Jiang Zemin as the core, China has fully implemented its established basic diplomatic policies and enriched and developed its ideological connotations according to changes in the international situation and new practices. The independent and autonomous nature of China's diplomacy has become more distinct. Its prominent manifestations are as follows: First, starting from national interests and always placing the sovereignty and security of the country in the first place, and never allowing any country to interfere in China's internal affairs. Second, insisting on determining the areas and pace of opening up independently based on national conditions. It is not only insisting on expanding opening up and fully utilizing various favorable conditions and opportunities brought about by economic globalization, but also maintaining a clear understanding of possible risks, strengthening prevention, and effectively safeguarding national economic security. Third, adhering to true non-alignment. China not only does not form alliances with any country, but also does not take the lead in the world socialist movement or developing countries. Fourth, respecting world diversity, handling international affairs in a spirit of mutual respect and seeking common ground while reserving differences, and promoting the democratization of international relations.
China's diplomacy also exhibits some new characteristics in terms of form: First, summit diplomacy has played an unprecedented and irreplaceable role. Chinese leaders frequently appear at important international occasions, expanding China's international influence and demonstrating the increased international status of China. The second is that China has established regular meetings, consultations, and dialogue mechanisms of different levels in its partnerships and cooperation with other countries and regional organizations. This new mechanized mode of operation not only enhances the effectiveness of bilateral and multilateral cooperation but also contributes to the stability and further development of relations among all parties. The third is that the Communist Party of China focuses on practical results and extensively exchanges and cooperates with ruling parties and legitimate opposition parties in countries around the world, ensuring that the relationship between parties serves the country's development strategy and overall diplomacy, and providing an important guarantee for the long-term stability and healthy development of bilateral relations.
At the turn of the century, China basically established a comprehensive and multi-layered diplomatic relationship pattern. Since the reform and opening-up, China's diplomacy has been developing in this direction. In the second half of the 1990s, this work made significant progress. When building a new foreign relationship pattern for the 21st century, China takes into account its relations with major powers and developed countries, as well as its relations with neighboring countries and developing countries. It attaches importance to the development of bilateral relations with various countries, actively engages in multilateral diplomacy, attaches importance to relations with governments of various countries, pays attention to the development of the Communist Party of China's relations with political parties around the world, and also emphasizes the conduct of various forms of people-to-people diplomacy.
Stabilizing and developing relations with major powers and developed countries is of great significance to China's socialist modernization construction and to maintaining world peace and development. In the mid-1990s, Chinese leaders proposed to actively develop a new type of major power relationship characterized by non-alignment, non-confrontation, and not targeting third parties. Based on this principle, China has established and developed the basic framework of bilateral relations with Russia, the United States, France, the United Kingdom, Japan, Canada, and the European Union facing the 21st century.
China and the United States, one being the largest developing country and the other being the largest developed country in the world, have always had some contradictions and differences, some of which have been difficult to eliminate for quite some time. However, they also have common interests in major issues concerning world peace and development. It is precisely because of this that although the China-US relationship has experienced ups and downs, the overall trend is to continue moving forward. Chinese leaders have always viewed China-US relations from a strategic perspective and a long-term perspective, insisting on taking the three joint communiqués between China and the United States as the foundation for developing bilateral relations. They advocate dealing with the differences between the two countries in the spirit of mutual respect, equality, consultation, and seeking common ground while reserving differences, actively seeking convergence of common interests. In October 1997, President Jiang Zemin paid a state visit to the United States and the two sides announced that they would jointly work towards establishing a constructive strategic partnership for the 21st century. Maintaining and developing a healthy and stable China-US relationship not only serves the fundamental interests of the two peoples but also benefits the peace, stability, and development of the Asia-Pacific region and the entire world.
China and Russia are each other's largest neighbors. With the disintegration of the Soviet Union in 1991, China and Russia established diplomatic relations and smoothly transitioned from Sino-Soviet relations to Sino-Russian relations. Since then, the relationship between the two countries has entered a new stage of mutual respect and friendly neighboring. In the second half of the 1990s, China-Russia relations made more explicit progress. In April 1996, President Yeltsin visited China on a state visit. China and Russia signed a Joint Declaration, announcing the determination to develop a strategic partnership based on equality and trust for the 21st century. In April 1997, Chairman Jiang Zemin visited Russia on a state visit, and the two countries signed a Joint Declaration on world multipolarity and the establishment of a new international order, expressing their willingness to work together to establish a new international political and economic order that is peaceful, stable, just and equitable. In July 2001, Chairman Jiang Zemin visited Russia on a state visit again, and the heads of state of both countries officially signed the Treaty of Good-Neighborliness and Friendly Cooperation between China and Russia, which marked an important milestone in the bilateral relationship. China and Russia have become good neighbors who get along with each other friendly, and there are vast prospects for exchange and cooperation in various fields between the two sides.
Since the basic resumption of normal relations with Western Europe in 1991, China's relations with Western Europe have entered a stage of steady development. Frequent visits between Chinese and European leaders have effectively promoted the development of bilateral relations. During his visit to France in September 1994, Chairman Jiang Zemin put forward four principles for China's relations with Western Europe, expressing the willingness to develop a long-term and stable friendly cooperation relationship towards the 21st century. In 1997 and 1998, China established comprehensive partnership with France and the United Kingdom respectively. As an important regional organization, the European Union has taken a series of measures conducive to the development of China-EU relations.
