In 1998, the first meeting between Chinese and EU leaders was held in London, and the two sides issued a joint statement, emphasizing the willingness of China and the EU to establish a long-term, stable and constructive partnership for the 21st century. Subsequently, the EU decided to elevate its relations with China to a level as important as those with the United States, Japan, and Russia. Through joint efforts, China and European countries have shown good prospects for cooperation in various fields.
China and Japan are neighboring countries separated only by a strip of water. Since the establishment of diplomatic relations in 1972 and the signing of the peace and friendship treaty in 1978, Sino-Japanese relations have entered a period of comprehensive development, and progress has been made in various fields of bilateral relations. In 1998, Chairman Jiang Zemin visited Japan on a state visit, and the two sides issued the "China-Japan Joint Declaration," announcing that China and Japan would establish a "friendly cooperative relationship oriented towards peace and development." At the same time, the Japanese side for the first time acknowledged its aggression against China, expressed deep reflection and apology, and jointly confirmed with the Chinese side that a correct understanding and handling of history is an important foundation for the development of Sino-Japanese relations. Overall, the development of China-Japan relations has been smooth, and friendly exchanges and mutually beneficial cooperation in various fields have made continuous progress, bringing significant benefits to both countries and making positive contributions to peace, stability, and development in the local region and the world.
Actively developing friendly relations with neighboring countries, maintaining peace and stability, and promoting common development, are important goals of China's diplomacy. In the early 1990s, China normalized relations with all neighboring countries. Since then, China's relations with neighboring countries have continued to develop. China established diplomatic relations and established the "Shanghai Five" mechanism with Central Asian countries, as well as the "Shanghai Cooperation Organization" consisting of China, Russia, Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Tajikistan, and Uzbekistan; participated in the Six-Party Talks involving China, North Korea, South Korea, the United States, Japan, and Russia, aimed at establishing a peace mechanism on the Korean Peninsula, and made positive contributions to maintaining peace and stability in the Korean Peninsula and Northeast Asia.
China's relationship with ASEAN has attracted attention. In 1996, China became a comprehensive dialogue partner of ASEAN. At the end of 1997, the two sides issued the "Joint Statement of the China-ASEAN Summit", which established the goal of building a neighborly partnership of mutual trust for the 21st century and provided guiding principles for bilateral relations. On issues with disputes such as the South China Sea, China clearly stated that it is willing to properly resolve relevant disputes through peaceful negotiations with the countries concerned based on universally recognized international law and other principles and legal systems. After the Asian financial crisis, China provided assistance to the relevant countries through bilateral and multilateral channels and fulfilled its commitment to keep the RMB stable, receiving widespread acclaim internationally. In the 21st century, China and ASEAN countries have continuously expanded mutually beneficial cooperation in various fields, playing an important role in promoting regional peace and stability.
Consolidating and developing friendly cooperation relations with countries in South Asia is an important part of China's stable periphery. In November 1996, Chairman Jiang Zemin made a state visit to India. During the visit, Chairman Jiang Zemin put forward five proposals for China and South Asian countries to jointly build a long-term and stable neighborly relationship for the future. The two countries decided to establish a constructive partnership for future cooperation based on the principles of peaceful coexistence. Subsequently, China and Pakistan also announced the establishment of a comprehensive partnership for the 21st century. In early 2002, the new government of Afghanistan was established, and the Chinese government immediately recognized and supported it. The improvement and development of China's relations with South Asian countries plays a significant role in maintaining peace and stability in the region.
Actively engaging in multilateral diplomacy is a prominent feature of China's diplomacy at the turn of the century. After China resumed its legitimate seat at the United Nations in 1971, it began to gradually participate in activities in various fields of multilateral diplomacy centered around the United Nations. In the mid-1980s, China clearly identified multilateral diplomacy as a major content of its independent, peaceful foreign policy. In the 1990s, China became increasingly active in the field of multilateral diplomacy and achieved remarkable results.
Opposing hegemonism and power politics and safeguarding the rights and interests of developing countries are important principles that China follows in its multilateral diplomatic activities. After the end of the Cold War, faced with the practices of Western countries interfering in the internal affairs of developing countries under various pretexts in the field of multilateral diplomacy, China has always adhered to principles such as respecting national sovereignty and independence, non-interference in internal affairs, and equality and mutual benefit. China has closely cooperated and supported developing countries, effectively resisting and fighting against various hegemonic acts in international relations. Since 1990, with the support of third world countries, China has successfully defeated proposals against China made by Western countries in the United Nations Human Rights Council for ten consecutive times. China has shown its support and active participation in various organizations, such as the United Nations, aimed at promoting North-South dialogue and strengthening South-South cooperation. China has established effective cooperative relationships with the Group of 77 countries and has participated as an observer in the Non-Aligned Movement.
The establishment of a new international political and economic order is a major issue in contemporary international relations. As early as the late 1980s, Deng Xiaoping proposed the establishment of a new international political and economic order based on the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence. This issue became even more prominent after the end of the Cold War. The Chinese government believes that the new international political and economic order should guarantee the rights of countries to sovereignty, equality, and non-interference in internal affairs. It should also ensure equal participation in international affairs and equal right to development, especially for developing countries. China advocates that the Five Principles of Peaceful Coexistence, the purposes and principles of the United Nations Charter, and other recognized international legal norms should be the political foundation of a new international order. In March 1999, President Jiang Zemin fully expounded China's basic propositions regarding the establishment of a new international political and economic order during his visit to Switzerland.
In the 1990s, an important aspect of China's multilateral diplomacy was the negotiation to join the World Trade Organization (WTO). Due to historical reasons, New China did not participate in the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) for a period of time after its establishment. After implementing the policy of reform and opening up, in July 1986, the Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party made a decision to apply for the resumption of China's status as a contracting party to GATT and immediately established a specialized organization to coordinate the external negotiation work. China's "resumption of GATT membership" and the negotiation to join the WTO have always been conducted under the leadership of the Party Central Committee. Throughout the 15-year negotiation process, China has consistently adhered to three principles: that the WTO, as an international organization, is incomplete without the participation of China, the largest developing country; that China can only participate as a developing country; and that China's accession to the WTO must be balanced in terms of rights and obligations. After continuous efforts and difficult negotiations, China ultimately reached an agreement with the relevant parties. On November 10, 2001, at the fourth ministerial conference of the WTO held in Doha, the capital of Qatar, the decision on China's accession to the WTO was deliberated and adopted unanimously through consultations. China's accession took a big step toward making the WTO a truly global trade organization and had a significant impact on China's economic system reform and economic development.
In the 1990s, China initiated and participated in a series of regional multilateral organizations with an open attitude. China explicitly expressed support for regional dialogue and cooperation based on equal participation, consensus through consultation, seeking common ground while reserving differences, and gradual progress. China actively promoted the establishment of multilateral confidence-building measures with neighboring countries, maintained regional security and stability, and promoted regional economic development. In October 2001, the ninth APEC Leaders' Informal Meeting was held in Shanghai. This was the highest-level and largest-scale international conference ever hosted by China. The successful holding of this conference has played a positive role in promoting economic recovery and development in the Asia-Pacific region.
At the beginning of the 21st century, although the international situation was volatile, the overall trend of development did not change. The 16th National Congress of the Communist Party of China in November 2002 pointed out that peace and development are still the themes of our times. Maintaining world peace and promoting common development are the common aspirations of people of all countries and an unstoppable historical trend. The development of multipolarization and economic globalization has brought opportunities and favorable conditions for world peace and development. A new world war is unlikely to break out in the foreseeable future, and it is possible to strive for a long period of peaceful international environment and a favorable surrounding environment. China will uphold the purpose of maintaining world peace and promoting common development, and consistently pursue an independent and peaceful diplomatic policy.
V. Actively promote China's military reform with Chinese characteristics
Placing the foundation of military struggle readiness on winning local wars under the conditions of high-tech and informationization, and strengthening the quality of the military, these are the new military strategic guidelines established by the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China based on changes in the world military development trend in the 1990s and the new century. This strategic guideline is a further development based on the foundation of the 1980s, and it is more in line with the technological background of the 1990s and the requirements of military strategic development.
1. Establishing China's military strategic guidelines under high-tech conditions
In the early 1990s, two significant changes occurred in the world military situation: the end of the Cold War and the disintegration of one of the two military alliances, the Warsaw Pact. The second change was the revolutionary development in the use of high-tech, represented by microelectronics and information science, in the military field. The first change made large-scale wars even more unlikely, and the probability of local wars increased. The second change led to an ongoing military revolution. The war model of the industrial age characterized by the pouring of steel and iron will become a thing of the past, and the competition between high-tech and informationization in armaments will continue to flourish. In this trend, countries around the world have accelerated military reforms, striving to establish a lean and efficient armed force that is of high quality and limited in quantity but adequate.
In view of the new situation, the new central military commission core led by Jiang Zemin promptly made another significant adjustment to China's national defense strategy. At the expanded meeting of the Central Military Commission held in early 1993, it was decided to place the strategic guideline of our military on winning local wars under modern technological, especially high-tech, conditions, accelerate the quality construction of the People's Liberation Army, and enhance emergency combat capabilities. In order to implement the new strategic guidelines, the Central Military Commission also put forward the "two fundamental transformations" with the "strengthening the military through science and technology" as the central idea, namely, the transformation from dealing with local wars under general conditions to winning local wars under modern technological, especially high-tech, conditions; in terms of military construction, the transition from a model based on quantity and scale to one based on quality and efficiency, and from a labor-intensive model to a technology-intensive model. This is the second adjustment of the national defense strategic guidelines conducted by our military since the 1990s.
High-tech requires high investment as a strong support, while national development requires the army to "endure" and "live through difficult times in the next few years." In response to this contradiction, China's defense research and equipment have taken a path of concentrating limited financial and material resources in the main direction for a considerable period of time, to ensure that in the event of any conflict, there is "the ability to fight back" against any strong enemy. However, the cost of doing so is that the overall level of military equipment has slowed down once again, and the gap between the equipment level of developed countries in the world has further widened.
After assuming the position of Chairman of the Military Commission, Jiang Zemin's immediate task was to determine how to build our own army according to higher standards, in order to accelerate the pace of military construction and adjust the military strategic direction in response to changes in the new situation and new tasks.
In December 1990, shortly after Jiang Zemin assumed the position of Chairman of the Central Military Commission, he put forward the general requirements for military construction under the new situation at an important military work conference held by the General Staff, namely: "politically qualified, militarily competent, strict discipline, effective support, and good work style." These five sentences constitute the fundamental direction of military construction in the new era, and also cover the basic content of military construction. This is an inheritance and development of the general guideline and overall task proposed by Deng Xiaoping in 1981 to "build a strong, modern, and regular revolutionary army."
After the formulation of the general requirements for military construction, the next major issue to be addressed is the proposal of the military strategic direction under the new situation. In this regard, shortly after Jiang Zemin assumed the position of Chairman of the Military Commission, he proposed that military strategy is ultimately the art of governing a country. A country and a nation cannot survive and develop, and cannot establish a firm foothold in fierce international competition without a correct military strategic direction.
So, in which direction should the new military strategic direction be adjusted? This is the immediate issue faced by the new Military Commission. In this regard, on November 9, 1992, Jiang Zemin explicitly stated at a military work conference that the international situation is developing rapidly now, and we must closely observe and grasp the development and changes in the situation in order to correctly decide our military strategic direction.
Based on Jiang Zemin's thoughts, the Military Commission convened a symposium on military strategic issues in December of that year. After sufficient brewing and discussion, Major General Zhang Zhen, Vice Chairman of the Military Commission, made a preliminary summary of the new military strategic direction in his concluding speech at the symposium: to be based on the ability to win a local war under high-tech conditions. After this symposium, the General Staff organized multiple research investigations according to the intention of the Military Commission, and the Standing Committee of the Military Commission also had multiple discussions, ultimately achieving a unified understanding.
In early 1993, an expanded meeting of the Central Military Commission was held, during which Jiang Zemin, on behalf of the Central Military Commission, formally proposed the military strategic direction of our military under the new situation, which is: "to make the foundation of military combat readiness focus on winning local wars under modern technology, especially high-tech conditions.
2. Promote military reform under the direction of "winning" and "no deterioration" in the face of a new situation. 
Guided by the overall requirements for military construction and the general principles of military strategy in the 1990s, the Central Military Commission led the whole army in carrying out continuous and in-depth reforms in various aspects of the military and national defense construction, with the direction of "winning" and "no deterioration" and the goal of building a quality army and strengthening the military with science and technology.
(1) Further strengthen the ideological and political construction of the military. The most important aspect of implementing the overall requirements for military construction in the new era is unwaveringly adhering to the Party's absolute leadership over the military and placing ideological and political work in the first place in all aspects of the army's work.
After the 14th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, the Central Military Commission made its first decision to reaffirm the tradition of carrying forward the spirit of the old Red Army and adhering to the principle of the Party commanding the gun. Wide-ranging and in-depth education on adhering to the Party's absolute leadership over the military was carried out throughout the army, which strengthened the obedience of Party leadership among the majority of officers and soldiers and their conscious adherence to the Party's basic line.
After the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, in accordance with the unified arrangements of the Party Central Committee, the entire army conducted learning and education activities with the main content of "learning, politics, and ethics" in a top-down manner and in stages, and conducted widespread education activities on the important thought of "Three Represents". The General Political Department and the General Staff Headquarters also formulated a series of resolutions and regulations, such as the "Opinions of the General Political Department on Strengthening the Education and Management of Middle and Senior Cadres in the Army," "Opinions on Implementing the CCP Central Committee's Decision on Strengthening and Improving Party Conduct and Party Building," and "Decisions on Several Issues Regarding Political and Ideological Construction of the Army under the Conditions of Reform, Opening Up and Developing the Socialist Market Economy," etc. The ideological and political work of the whole army was focused on ensuring that the Party truly grasps the army in terms of ideology and politics, continuously enhancing the consciousness and firmness of listening to the Party and following the Party. In-depth work was carried out in theoretical arming, patriotic dedication education, revolutionary outlook education, respect for cadres and love for soldiers, and hard work education. The comprehensive implementation of the "Outline for the Construction of Grassroots Units of the Army" was carried out, with efforts put into consolidating the foundation of unit construction and other aspects, and ensuring practical results.
From 1992 to 2001, the whole army held nearly ten thousand theoretical study classes, and 85% of battalion-level and above cadres received rotational training. The enthusiasm of grassroots officers and soldiers was greatly enhanced through activities of striving for excellence and creating superiority, and 60,000 advanced units and 3.6 million outstanding soldiers emerged from the activities of "striving to be an advanced company and striving to be an excellent soldier". Strong ideological and political work safeguarded the coordinated development and overall progress of military construction.
(2) Reform the command structure of the People's Liberation Army of China. The military reforms in the 1990s were comprehensive and included various aspects, with the establishment of the General Armament Department as a symbol, and various reforms were comprehensively promoted. These reforms included the reform of the command structure of our military, symbolized by the establishment of the General Armament Department; the reform of the education and training system with the purpose of "winning"; and the reform of the logistical support system of our military, symbolized by the joint logistics of the three services.
On April 5, 1998, the General Equipment Department of the People's Liberation Army of China was formally established. This marked a significant reform in the structure of our military's command organs. For a long time, our military's command organs consisted of three headquarters, but now it has been restructured to consist of four headquarters. The establishment of the General Equipment Department means that under the guidance of the new military strategic policy, the People's Liberation Army will pay more attention than ever before to the development and improvement of weaponry and equipment. Weapons and equipment are the material foundation for achieving victory, and the establishment of the General Equipment Department has great significance in strengthening the leadership, unified management, and overall planning of the scientific research, production, and development of weapons and equipment.
To address the contradiction between the practical needs of the military and the overall national economic development, Chairman Jiang Zemin of the Central Military Commission put forward a very insightful idea: to prioritize, to do some things and not do others, to catch up in certain areas and not in others, and to accelerate the development of "killer weapons" that would make the enemy afraid. Under this guiding principle, after ten years of efforts, our military has achieved modernization upgrades in major weapons such as main battle tanks, naval vessels, and combat aircraft; it has also developed its own distinctive features in certain missiles and counter-stealth technologies; and it has made remarkable achievements in the field of aerospace that have attracted worldwide attention.
(3) To improve the military's education and training system and further reduce troop numbers. The fundamental factor that determines the outcome of wars is personnel, and the quality of personnel is crucial to the outcome of modern warfare, especially in localized conflicts under high-tech conditions. Since the 1990s, the entire military has carried out a series of powerful reforms in the education and training system for military personnel.
In order to cultivate important military talents, the Central Military Commission has made major adjustments to the military's institutional system. In order to meet the needs of winning localized wars under high-tech conditions and develop talents for building a strong army through science and technology, five comprehensive universities have been newly established: National University of Defense Technology, Institute of Information Engineering, University of Science and Technology, Naval University of Engineering, and Air Force Engineering University. The training of military personnel has also moved away from the previous singular approach and gradually adopted a path of self-training and reliance on national education. More than 50 universities, including Peking University and Tsinghua University, have undertaken the task of training cadres for the military and provide a large number of outstanding talents to the military every year.
According to statistics from 2002, there were already more than 30,000 cadres in the military with doctoral or master's degrees. The proportions of personnel at the army, division, and regiment levels with at least a college education were 88%, 90%, and 75% respectively, and the proportion of officers with at least a college degree in the entire military was 71.8%.
Another important measure for building a quality army and a technologically strong military is the reduction of troop numbers and the pursuit of China's own distinct elite force. In September 1997, at the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, Jiang Zemin announced that, based on the previous reduction of 1 million troops in the 1980s, China would further reduce troop numbers by another 500,000 within three years. This major strategic decision was made in response to new changes in the international situation and the internal laws of military construction.
After the massive demobilization of more than one million troops since 1985, the total strength of the People's Liberation Army (including civilian personnel) is still slightly over three million. This number is obviously still relatively high, but large-scale demobilization is constrained by various factors both inside and outside the military. It is not possible to achieve it overnight, but rather to proceed with planned and step-by-step measures. The reduction of 500,000 troops is a specific arrangement to firmly and prudently decrease the quantity of the military and improve its quality. Its subsequent effects will not only be a simple reduction in numbers, but also, with the deepening of reform, the military's system and quality construction will reach a new level, and overall combat effectiveness will inevitably be enhanced. By 2002, the total number of personnel in the People's Liberation Army (including active and reserve forces) remained below 2.5 million.
(4) All commercial activities of the military and armed police forces shall be abolished. Since the reform and opening-up, the military has been subordinate to the overall situation of national economic construction and has been living a frugal life. In order to solve economic difficulties, the military and armed police forces have been engaged in productive and commercial activities for a period of time. The funds obtained were mostly used to improve the living and working conditions, as well as training conditions, of the troops. However, as time went on, some negative impacts gradually emerged, mainly including the dispersion of the attention of leaders at all levels on their work and the proliferation of corruption.
Shortly after Jiang Zemin assumed the position of Chairman of the Central Military Commission, he pointed out that the military should eat "state-provided food". To this end, the Central Military Commission took measures to gradually shrink and clean up the military's production and business activities, and finally, according to unified arrangements, in July 1998, all commercial activities were ceased. Within the specified time limit, the military and armed police forces transferred thousands of business enterprises and companies to localities or had them revoked. The troops fully implemented the orders of the Central Military Commission, demonstrating the consistent good style of the military's obedience to the overall situation and strict discipline.
After the military and armed police forces ceased all commercial activities, in order to guarantee the troops' livelihood, especially the livelihood of grassroots officers and soldiers, and create favorable conditions for them to serve and dedicate themselves to national defense, the state allocated a huge special fund for this purpose. The various headquarters of the People's Liberation Army follow the principle of directing funds towards combat forces, border defense forces, and grassroots units. Since the 1990s, more than 1.6 billion yuan have been invested successively to implement supporting governance projects for the living facilities of troops stationed in remote and harsh regions. Many border guard posts and highland and island units now have standardized barracks, fresh vegetables, hot showers, and access to television. Non-commercial agricultural and sideline productions of the troops have not been weakened, but have instead been strengthened. In the implementation of the "basket of vegetables" project, more than half of the units in the military have achieved a self-sufficiency rate of over 70% for essential food supplies, and a considerable number of units have basically achieved self-sufficiency in meat and vegetables. In order to improve the cultural life of grassroots officers and soldiers, the various headquarters have also earmarked funds to greatly improve grassroots cultural facilities and promote the development of grassroots cultural activities.
(5) Strengthen the rule of law in the military. In view of the new situations and problems brought to the construction of the military by the social environment of developing the socialist market economy, the Military Commission emphasized the importance of governing the military by law during the reform in the 1990s. In addition to revising the traditional three major regulations (namely, internal affairs regulations, discipline regulations, and combat regulations) according to the development of the situation, the National People's Congress, the State Council, and the Central Military Commission have also successively formulated and promulgated a series of laws, regulations, and rules. These include specialized laws related to the military and national defense construction, such as the National Defense Law, the Conscription Law, the Active Military Officer Law, and the Military Facilities Protection Law; and more than a thousand military regulations, including the Regulations on Enlistment, the Regulations on Defense Transportation, the Regulations on Headquarters, the Regulations on Political Work, the Regulations on Logistics, and the Regulations on Weapon and Equipment Management. In addition, the corresponding regulations and rules formulated by the General Staff Headquarters, various branches of the military, and major military regions amount to over two thousand.
After completing three consecutive five-year plans for popularizing legal knowledge, the entire army launched the fourth five-year plan for popularizing legal education in 2001. In the process of legal education, with military regulations as the focus, the entire army conducted extensive learning of legal knowledge. Many grassroots units in the military also carried out legal consultation activities during the popularization process, helping officers and soldiers solve legal issues encountered in their daily lives, and learning to use legal means to safeguard the lawful rights and interests of military personnel and their families, thus consciously enhancing their awareness of the rule of law. By the turn of the century, the military and national defense construction had basically achieved the availability of laws and regulations to follow. The military construction has been institutionalized, effectively guaranteeing and promoting the modernization and standardization of the military.
Apart from the aforementioned reforms, the People's Liberation Army has also carried out a series of reforms in the conscription system, the military officer service system, the military housing system, the military insurance system, and the operational command system. Through these reforms, the overall political and military quality of the armed forces has been significantly improved.
3. The Path of Elite Soldiers with Chinese Characteristics in the Informationized Era
Entering the 21st century, a series of new changes have occurred in the international and domestic environments. Informationization has occupied an increasingly prominent position in the field of high technology, which is the prominent feature of this change. In response to this change, the Central Military Commission timely adjusted the military strategic policy, transforming the objective of winning local wars under modern conditions, especially under high-tech conditions, to winning local wars under informationized conditions. At the same time, the "Three Provides and One Enhances" development goals for military construction were put forward. This further realized the advancement of the military strategic thinking of the Communist Party of China, forming the latest achievements of Marxist military thought and promoting this ideology to a new height in the new century and new stage.
Since the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe and the Soviet Union in the 1990s, the United States has been attempting to dominate the world alone in its foreign policy, which has sharp conflicts with the efforts of many countries, including China, advocating for a multipolar world. For a period of time, due to the lack of effective constraints on the United States in the world, it almost acted wantonly across the globe. According to statistical data, during this period, the United States intervened in the internal affairs of other countries using military force twice as much as during the Cold War. Its enhanced soft power also greatly exceeded the level during the US-Soviet rivalry.
In recent years, with rapid development in China, the United States' containment and suppression of China has become increasingly prominent in various aspects. There is contact, cooperation, struggle, and compromise between China and the United States. The competition between the two extends to politics, economy, military, diplomacy, and other areas.
Since the opening-up and reform, the high-speed development of the Chinese economy has not only brought great progress to China but also made significant contributions to the development of the world economy. This is the consensus of most countries today. However, not everyone is pleased with this. Some hostile forces always try their best to obstruct China's development and set up numerous hidden obstacles. At the same time, with the development of economic globalization, the integration of economies among countries is accelerating, and the interdependence of industries and businesses has become a global trend. In today's era of economic and technological advancement, the extension of national interests has also expanded. In the agricultural era, national interests were limited to the territory; in the industrial era, they expanded to the sea; after World War II, they spread to the sky; in the high-tech era, the collision of national interests extended to space, and in the present information age, it further penetrates into the electromagnetic field. The expansion of the borders of national interests requires the military's functions to also extend to provide a strong security guarantee and effective strategic support for maximizing national interests.
The development and changes in the international situation and military conditions quickly attracted high attention from our military. On January 1, 2002, the Liberation Army Daily mentioned in an article, "In the new year, we will continue to focus on the issue of joint operations in the information age, emphasizing the study of the basic theory of joint operations, especially the theory and practice of foreign joint operations, striving to reflect the general laws of joint operations, and proposing countermeasures in terms of cultivating joint operation talents and training joint operations. Improve the joint operational capabilities of our armed forces." Looking at the historical task of national reunification, the situation of national reunification in China after entering the new century is still not optimistic. The Taiwan independence forces are extremely rampant in activities on the island and continuously provoke the bottom line of peaceful reunification. While making every effort to strive for peaceful reunification of the motherland, we must be prepared for military struggle at any time.
These new characteristics of the era pose higher requirements on the functions of our military. On September 20, 2004, at the expanded meeting of the Central Military Commission, the just-retired Chairman of the Military Commission, Jiang Zemin, pointed out, "We must have a broad vision and a forward-looking perspective, adhere to innovation, innovation, and further innovation, actively respond to the severe challenges of the new global military revolution, promote China's military transformation with a sense of urgency, strive to accomplish the dual historical tasks of mechanization and informatization, and firmly achieve the strategic goal of building an informatized military and winning an informatized war."
Hu Jintao, who had just taken over as Chairman of the Military Commission, also demanded at the same meeting that the entire army "continuously improve the ability to strengthen the ideological and political construction of the troops and grasp the correct direction of troop construction, continuously improve the leadership of military preparedness and the ability to lead the troops in accomplishing operational tasks in an informationized environment, continuously improve the ability to promote China's military transformation and advance the mechanization and informatization construction of the troops, and continuously improve the ability to govern the troops strictly according to law and strengthen the regularized construction of the troops."
In 2004, China's Defense White Paper officially announced to the outside world: "The People's Liberation Army focuses on winning local wars under the conditions of informatization, emphasizing the enhancement of weapons and equipment, joint operational capability, and battlefield construction. It adheres to the people's war concept, and develops the strategy and tactics of the people's war. Establish a modern combat system that can fully exert the overall effectiveness of the armed forces and the national war potential in order to meet the requirements of integrated joint operations." At this point, our military has begun the transformation of the third military strategy in the new era, that is, from winning local wars under modern technology, especially high-tech conditions, to winning local wars under informationized conditions.
According to the requirements of this new military strategy, President Hu Jintao, on behalf of the Central Military Commission, made timely adjustments to the historical mission of our military. On March 13, 2005, President Hu Jintao made an important speech at the plenary meeting of the 10th National People's Congress of the People's Liberation Army delegation, demanding that the military "provide an important guarantee of power for the Party to consolidate its ruling status, provide strong security guarantees for maintaining the country's important strategic opportunities, provide powerful strategic support for safeguarding national interests, and play an important role in safeguarding world peace and promoting common development." These "three provisions and one role" embody the new requirements of the Party's historical tasks for our military, adapt to the new changes in our country's security situation, reflect the new needs of national development strategies, conform to the new trends in world military development, grasp the major issues that affect the overall and fundamental nature of military construction, further expand the functional tasks of our military, clarify the development goals of national defense and military construction, improve the standards of military preparedness, and enrich the guiding principles for the use of military forces. President Hu Jintao's important discourse, which is in line with the important thoughts of Mao Zedong, Deng Xiaoping, and Jiang Zemin regarding the historical mission of our military, is also keeping pace with the times. It is a significant innovation in the Party's military guidance theory, marking that our Party's understanding of the laws governing national defense and military construction in the new century and new stage has reached a new level.
The new mission entrusted to the People's Liberation Army by the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China and the Central Military Commission has epoch-making significance. In the past, the understanding of the historical mission of the Communist Party of China on the people's army was relatively vague. It was only generally believed that the military was the "strong pillar" of the people's democratic dictatorship and the "Great Wall of steel" defending the motherland. But the new historical mission is no longer just based on a political belief. It is based on the commanding height of the times and comprehensively examines the functions and roles of the current Chinese armed forces from a broader and deeper perspective.
Although the four aspects covered by the new historical mission are not completely new propositions, linking these four important propositions into a tight logical relationship is a first in history. The party commanding the gun is the basic principle of the establishment of the people's army; Marxist state theory believes that the military is the main component of the state. Based on these two basic principles, in a country under the people's democratic dictatorship, the armed forces must firmly be controlled by the ruling proletarian party and play an important role in its effective rule. The repeated experiences and lessons from both positive and negative aspects have proven that firmly grasping these two points will lead to the development of the socialist cause. Conversely, under the encirclement, attacks, and temptations of hostile forces both domestically and internationally, the party and the nation's cause are at the risk of being overthrown, and the interests of the people will suffer greatly. When we face a complex international environment and a period of multiple internal contradictions, the military's role in providing an important guarantee of power for the Party to consolidate its ruling status becomes especially important.
China's modernization cannot be achieved without a good international environment. Especially today, when the trend of global economic globalization is becoming stronger, defending world peace is also defending our own development. In the past, our comprehensive national strength was not strong enough, so we particularly emphasized seizing the opportunity for peace to develop ourselves. Now, we have a certain foundation, capability, and the necessity to create a peaceful and harmonious international environment by joining forces with all the forces that love and uphold peace in the world. The Central Military Commission has entrusted our military with the function of "playing an important role in safeguarding world peace and promoting common development," which can be said to be timely.
Chapter 10: Promote the new great project of party building and the formation of the important thought of the "Three Represents"
Under the leadership of the Party Central Committee with Jiang Zemin at the core, the party vigorously promoted the construction of socialist modernization and continuously pushed forward the new great project of party building. Through continuous summarization of the experience in socialist modernization and party building, the important thought of the "Three Represents" was gradually formed. The important thought of the "Three Represents" is the further enrichment and development of the theory of Marxist socialist construction and the party building doctrine in the new historical conditions. It is another important achievement in the process of Marxist sinicization of the Communist Party of China. This important thought fully reflects the new changes in historical development at home and abroad and the new requirements of the times, and it plays an extremely important guiding role in the development of various aspects of contemporary China. It is because of this that the 16th National Congress of the Communist Party of China officially established it as the guiding ideology of the party.
I. Further clarify the overall goal and overall tasks of party building and continue to promote the new great project
In the 1990s, the Communist Party of China encountered the new situation of socialist market economy in the process of reform and development. Under the conditions of socialist market economy, the construction of the party, how to build the party, and what goals to build the party according to have become new topics for the Communist Party of China. In response to this, the third-generation central leadership collective with Jiang Zemin at the core, based on the principles of Marxist party building and taking into account China's objective reality, creatively put forward the overall goal and overall tasks of party building under the conditions of socialist market.
1. New requirements posed by reform and development of market economy on party building
Combining the socialist system with the market economy is not only a great achievement but also a brand new topic and challenge. Strengthening the party building under the conditions of socialist market economy is not only an unprecedented cause for the Communist Party of China, but also a new challenge.
The development of the socialist market economy aims at the fundamental problem of how to transition from planned economy to market-oriented economy. This transition will inevitably bring profound changes to all sectors of society, including both positive influences and negative effects on party building.
The positive influences of the market economy on party building are mainly manifested in the following aspects: Firstly, the basic law followed by the market economy is the law of value. It emphasizes the principle of material interests and insists on putting efficiency at the center. Acting in accordance with this law is conducive to the party organizations and the majority of party members to further establish the concept of seeking truth from facts and working style, overcome the tendencies of formalism, deception, and detachment from reality. Secondly, the diversification of market entities, the diversification of transaction methods, and the value orientation of giving priority to efficiency and taking into account fairness are conducive to the party organizations and the majority of party members to maintain and carry forward a good mental state of striving upwards and fighting tenaciously, and overcome the ideological style of clinging to the old and being content with the status quo. Third, the openness and fairness of market competition are conducive to enhancing the democratic consciousness of party organizations and party members, overcoming the practice of "one-man rule" and subjective decision-making. Fourth, the unity and openness of the market system are conducive to party organizations and party members learning from and drawing on beneficial experiences from other regions and countries, overcoming closed and conservative thinking, and enhancing openness. Fifth, the market economy is a rule-of-law economy, and the relationships of responsibilities, rights, and obligations between various market behaviors and market entities need to be regulated by laws and regulations. This regulation is conducive to strengthening the ideological construction of party organizations and party members, overcoming the tendency to act without following rules and not abiding by party discipline. Sixth, the market economy mainly relies on indirect regulation through the market and does not emphasize direct administrative intervention. This is conducive to correctly handling the relationship between the party and the government and overcoming the practice of substituting the party for the government.
The negative effects of the socialist market economy on party building mainly manifest in the following aspects: First, the market economy emphasizes material interests. Under the drive of material interests, people's worldviews, outlooks on life, and values are prone to certain distortions, giving rise to materialism, hedonism, and individualism. Some individuals may even lose their party principles and engage in power and money transactions, thereby damaging the image of the party. This makes the task of educating the party's ideals, beliefs, worldviews, outlooks on life, and values more arduous under market economy conditions. Second, in terms of operational methods, the prominent characteristic of the market economy is the horizontal connection between market entities, and this connection has a strong spontaneity and dispersiveness. This easily downplays party members' overall and organizational awareness and breeds decentralism and anarchism, thereby increasing the difficulty of party members' organizational management work. Third, the market economy is an open economy, which not only manifests as internal openness but also requires external openness, connecting domestic and international markets, and participating in international division of labor and competition as much as possible in order to achieve more efficient allocation of domestic resources and utilization of international resources. On one hand, this openness promotes the accelerated flow of populations, and on the other hand, it is easy for foreign thoughts and cultures to spread and spread with the expansion of opening up. This results in instability within the party members' ranks and also poses difficulties for the work of unifying party members' thinking.
For party building, the socialist market economy is a double-edged sword, presenting both opportunities and challenges. Facing these opportunities and challenges, the Communist Party of China must adapt to the new requirements of changing circumstances, clearly propose the overall goals and tasks of party building that meet the requirements of the socialist market economy in practice, so as to continuously strengthen its own construction with the development of the times, thereby improving its ability to manage the market economy and consolidate its ruling position.
2. Further clarify the overall goals and tasks of party building
Clarifying the overall goals and tasks of party building is the primary issue in the construction of a ruling party. After the Communist Party of China came to power, it went through a long exploration to establish the correct goal of party building. After the Third Plenary Session of the Eleventh Central Committee, as the focus of the party's work shifted, it was proposed to build the party into a strong core leading the socialist modernization cause, thus clarifying the direction of party building throughout the entire socialist historical period. Following the Fourth Plenary Session of the Thirteenth Central Committee, the Party Central Committee with Jiang Zemin as the core, in accordance with Deng Xiaoping's political instructions to "focus on party building," earnestly summarized the experience and lessons of party building since the reform and opening up, actively explored new ways to strengthen party building under the conditions of developing the socialist market economy, and clearly proposed the overall goals and tasks of party building.
The overall goal and task of the party's construction are gradually formed by the central leadership collective with Jiang Zemin as the core through strengthening and improving the party's construction practice. In August 1989, the central government issued a notice on strengthening the party's construction, which required party committees at all levels to resolve urgent issues in the party's construction in accordance with the requirements of the party's basic line, so that the party could withstand the test of governance under new historical conditions, the test of reform, opening-up, and the development of a commodity economy, as well as the test of opposing peaceful evolution. In March 1990, the decision of the Central Committee of the Communist Party of China on strengthening the party's connection with the masses emphasized that our party and country are currently in a crucial period of historical development. In general, our party's relationship with the masses and the relationship between cadres and the masses are good. However, in recent years, serious corruption phenomena of party members and cadres being detached from the masses have also emerged. Therefore, all party members must remain highly vigilant and persistently struggle against these phenomena. In 1992, the 14th National Congress of the Communist Party of China, based on the need to develop a socialist market economy, highlighted the tasks of learning Deng Xiaoping's theory of socialism with Chinese characteristics, strengthening party construction, closely connecting with the masses, strengthening grassroots organization construction, and adhering to and improving the democratic centralism from the perspective of strengthening the party's construction.
To implement the various tasks of the party's construction proposed by the 14th National Congress, and to make the party's construction adapt to the reform of building a socialist market economic system, the 4th Plenary Session of the 14th Central Committee of the Communist Party of China in September 1994 made the "Decision on Strengthening Several Key Issues in Party Construction" (referred to as the "Decision"). The "Decision" clearly puts forward the overall goal and task of the new great project of party construction, that is, "building the party into a Marxist party armed with the theory of socialism with Chinese characteristics, wholeheartedly serving the people, being completely consolidated in terms of ideology, politics, and organization, being able to withstand various risks, and always leading in the forefront of the times". Based on this overall goal and task, the "Decision" requires that while continuing to implement the Central Committee's deployment on ideological and style construction, special attention should be paid to the central link of party organization construction, and particularly the three issues should be addressed: first, adhering to and improving the democratic centralism, with particular emphasis on institutional construction; second, strengthening and improving the construction of grassroots organizations of the party; third, cultivating and selecting leaders who possess both moral integrity and talent, especially young cadres. Emphasizing institutional construction is an important feature of the "Decision" adopted at this meeting.
In September 1997, the 15th National Congress of the Communist Party of China summarized the new experience of party construction and further summarized the overall goal and task of party construction proposed at the 4th Plenary Session of the 14th Central Committee as follows: "Build the party into a Marxist party armed with Deng Xiaoping Theory, wholeheartedly serving the people, being completely consolidated in terms of ideology, politics, and organization, being able to withstand various risks, always leading in the forefront of the times, and leading the people of the whole country to build socialism with Chinese characteristics." The conference called on the whole party to comprehensively strengthen the party's construction in terms of ideology, organization, and style in accordance with the overall goal of the new great project of party construction, continuously improve leadership capabilities, enhance the ability to resist corruption, prevent transformation, and resist risks, and lead the people to fulfill new historical tasks with a new appearance and greater combat effectiveness.
3. Initial Implementation of the Party's Overall Goal and Task
After the 4th Plenary Session of the 14th Central Committee, the party's construction gradually unfolded in various aspects such as ideology, politics, and organization in accordance with the requirements of the overall goal and task.
In terms of ideological construction, the 14th National Congress of the Communist Party of China established the guiding position of Deng Xiaoping Theory in building socialism with Chinese characteristics across the whole party, and put forward the strategic task of arming the whole party with this theory. After the publication of Volumes 1, 2, and 3 of "Selected Works of Deng Xiaoping" in 1993 and 1994, the Central Committee immediately issued a notice requiring the whole party to organize the study seriously. From the end of 1993 to May 1994, the central government organized 175 key leaders from the party, government, military, and experts and scholars from various departments in four batches to participate in the theoretical seminar for provincial and ministerial-level key leaders at the Central Party School, and they carefully studied "Selected Works of Deng Xiaoping". In order to further promote cadre training, in May 1996, the central government formulated the "1996-2000 National Cadre Education and Training Plan" and made comprehensive deployments to strengthen ideological and theoretical education for cadres.
In the process of carrying out theoretical studies throughout the party, a complete set of learning systems has gradually been established. For example, party committee members at and above the county level regularly participate in party school training, and there is a system for the central group of party committees to study. In addition, various levels of organizations have also adopted various forms such as organizing lecture teams for guidance and holding theoretical seminars to promote extensive learning. These measures have stimulated the enthusiasm of party members and cadres to study theory, and promoted the improvement of the ideological and theoretical level of the whole party.
In terms of improving the democratic centralism, after the 14th National Congress of the Communist Party of China (CPC), the CPC Central Committee gradually increased its efforts to build democratic centralism within the party in response to the problems of insufficient democracy and centralism. In guaranteeing the democratic rights of party members, the internal democratic channels of the party have been opened up and broadened, allowing party members to participate more in internal party affairs. By establishing effective mechanisms, grassroots party members are guaranteed the timely ability to reflect their opinions to higher-level party organizations. Based on fully listening to the opinions of party members and lower-level party organizations, valuable opinions are collected to continuously promote the scientific and democratic decision-making process. In terms of decision-making procedures, the principle of "collective leadership, democratic centralism, individual deliberation, and decision-making through meetings" is followed to further improve the internal deliberation and decision-making mechanisms of party committees. In terms of leadership and governance styles, it is emphasized to follow the principle of overall planning and coordination among all parties, further strengthen and improve the leadership system of the party, ensuring both the leading core role of party committees and fully leveraging the roles of the people's congresses, governments, political consultative conferences, people's organizations, and other aspects. The implementation of this series of measures has gradually institutionalized and standardized the construction of the CPC's democratic centralism.
In terms of the construction of grassroots party organizations in rural areas, in 1990, the Central Organization Department held a meeting in Laixi, Shandong, which determined the core leadership position of party branches in village-level organizations. In 1992, the Central Organization Department held a meeting in Zhangqiu, Shandong, focusing on summarizing and promoting the experience of "establishing a system in accordance with the law, governing villages with systems, and democratic management", and promoting the institutionalization and standardization of grassroots organizations in rural areas with the party branch as the core. In 1994, under the guidance of the spirit of the Fourth Plenary Session of the 14th CPC Central Committee on the construction of grassroots party organizations, the CPC Central Committee held the National Conference on the Construction of Grassroots Rural Organizations from October 26th to 29th in Beijing. On November 5th, the CPC Central Committee issued the "Notice on Strengthening the Construction of Grassroots Rural Organizations", clearly putting forward the requirements of the "five goods" for the construction of grassroots party organizations in rural areas, namely: building a good leadership team; cultivating and exercising a good team; choosing a good path for economic development; improving a good operational mechanism; and perfecting a good management system. Based on this, various regions have successively established and implemented the party building work responsibility system and the contact point system for leading cadres. Starting from 1994, the party's organizational departments have phased and batch rectification of 282,000 weak and disorganized party branches in rural areas and conducted phased training for rural party members and cadres, resulting in various degrees of improvement to about 80% of village-level party organizations.
In the construction of grassroots party organizations in state-owned enterprises, in December 1996, the CPC Central Organization Department, Central Policy Research Office, State Economic and Trade Commission, State Commission for Restructuring the Economic System, All-China Federation of Trade Unions, and other units jointly held the National Conference on the Construction of Party in State-owned Enterprises in Beijing. In January 1997, the Communist Party of China (CPC) issued the "Notice on Further Strengthening and Improving the Party Construction in State-owned Enterprises," which made clear provisions on the goals, principles, and policies of the party organization construction in state-owned enterprises. In accordance with the spirit of this document, party committees at all levels, in the process of establishing a modern enterprise system, adhere to the party's political leadership over enterprises, play the political core role of the party organization in enterprises, adhere to the guideline of wholeheartedly relying on the working class, explore new approaches and methods of party building in relation to enterprise reform and development, and have achieved remarkable results, accumulating new experiences.
In terms of party construction in urban streets, in June 1995, some cadres from 16 provinces and cities across the country discussed how to strengthen the party organization construction at the grassroots level in Tianjin and summarized and exchanged experiences. One year later, based on various situations, the Organization Department of the Central Committee issued the "Opinions on Strengthening the Party Construction Work in Streets" on September 3, 1996, which required street party construction work to take into account the characteristics and realities of urban work in the new situation, focus on improving urban management and social services, maintaining social stability and developing street economy, with a focus on enhancing the construction of leadership teams and improving the quality of cadres, strengthening the cohesion and combativeness of party organizations, fully exerting the vanguard and exemplary role of party members, and serving the healthy development of material and spiritual civilization in urban areas. In accordance with this spirit, urban areas across the country gradually established a working network of party organizations in street community, enabling street community party organizations to play an increasingly important role in strengthening spiritual civilization construction and ideological and political work among the masses, improving comprehensive social security and governance, maintaining close ties with the masses, and raising the quality and level of urban civilization.
In terms of party construction in non-public economic organizations, further strengthening has also been achieved during this period. In areas with relatively developed non-public economic sectors, party organizations have been established in some foreign-invested enterprises and private enterprises, and the cohesion of party organizations and the vanguard and exemplary role of communist party members have been well demonstrated in these enterprises. In September 2000, based on extensive investigations and research and the summary of local practical experiences, the Organization Department of the Central Committee issued the "Opinions on Strengthening Party Construction in Individual and Private Non-public Economic Organizations (Trial)," in accordance with which, by June 2001, party organizations established in non-public enterprises nationwide had reached 44,000.
At the same time, the CPC Central Committee also put forward a series of new ideas and requirements for party construction in government departments, schools, research institutes, and other sectors, which universally strengthened the construction of grassroots party organizations under the new historical conditions.
While strengthening the construction of grassroots party organizations, party organizations at all levels have also generally strengthened the construction of the party membership. Following the guideline of "adhering to standards, improving the structure, cautious development, and ensuring quality," exceptional individuals from various fronts continuously enrich the party membership, injecting fresh blood into the party organization. The cohesion and creativity of party organizations have been continuously strengthened.
4. Uphold and improve the system of democratic centralism and strengthen the construction of democratic systems within the Party
Democratic centralism is a system that combines democracy on the basis of concentration and the concentration of leadership under democracy. It is the application of Marxist epistemology and the mass line in the Party's life and organizational construction. The democracy in democratic centralism refers to the full expression of the will and views of party members and party organizations and the full play of their enthusiasm and creativity; the concentration in democratic centralism refers to the unity of the will and wisdom of the entire Party and consistent actions.
In accordance with the tasks and requirements put forward at the Fourth Plenary Session of the 14th CPC Central Committee, the Central Committee, in response to the insufficient democracy and concentration within the Party, has taken a series of measures to vigorously strengthen and improve the system of democratic centralism within the Party. On the one hand, it is insisted that the purpose of realizing the party's program is to guide, protect, and stimulate enthusiasm. It actively smooths and broadens the democratic channels within the party, so that party members can have a better understanding of and participation in internal party affairs. It is required that from the central committee to every branch, from decision-making in leadership organs to participating in policy discussions in party meetings and publications, from internal party elections to evaluating and supervising leading cadres, democracy must be fully promoted. In order to safeguard the democratic rights of party members, in December 1994, the Party Central Committee formulated and promulgated the "Regulations on the Protection of the Democratic Rights of Members of the Communist Party of China (Trial)", which clearly stipulated the principles for members to correctly exercise their rights and the measures to guarantee the exercise of their rights.
On the other hand, focusing on the overall work of the party, the party constitution is reiterated, emphasizing the "four obedience" and ensuring the smooth flow of orders from the central party, maintaining consistency with the central party on the fundamental principles, general policies, overall objectives, and major issues related to the overall situation. In order to strengthen and improve the leadership of the party, the central Party also proposed the principle of "collective leadership, democratic centralism, individual deliberation, and decision-making by meeting", further improving the internal decision-making mechanisms of party committees, establishing a sound decision-making mechanism combining leadership, experts, and the masses, gradually improving democratic and scientific decision-making systems. It insists on and improves the combination of collective leadership and individual division of labor and responsibility. It formulates regulations for the work of central and local party committees, further clarifying and standardizing the responsibilities, rules of procedure, and decision-making procedures of party committee meetings and standing committees. It improves the system of Party congresses, further playing the role of plenary meetings of central and local party committees. It improves the system of organizational life meetings and democratic life meetings of party members and leading cadres, and improves various guidelines for internal political life. It strengthens internal party supervision, strictly enforces party discipline, formulates internal party supervision regulations, improves the internal party supervision system, and combines internal party supervision with social supervision, public opinion supervision, and supervision from democratic parties and non-party individuals, gradually forming a strong supervision system. According to the principle of overall planning and coordination of all parties, it further strengthens and improves the party's leadership system, ensuring the core role of party committees while fully playing the role of the People's Congress, the government, the CPPCC, various mass organizations, and other aspects.
The implementation of these principles has gradually institutionalized and standardized the construction of the party's democratic centralism.
5. Carry out the "Three Stricts and Three Honests" education and explore new ways to strengthen party building
On the journey to the new century, facing the new situation and new tasks of deepening reform and opening up, the Party Central Committee with Jiang Zemin as the core, on the basis of a thorough summary of the party's historical experience, created a new form of party conduct and discipline education centered on the spirit of rectification and with the "Three Stricts and Three Honests" (being strict with oneself in morals and self-discipline, being strict with one's work, and being strict with money and material) as the main content, and achieved remarkable results.
In 1995, Jiang Zemin repeatedly mentioned the need to educate cadres on learning, politics, and integrity, in response to some cadres who neglected studying and self-improvement under the new situation of developing a market economy and lost their way in increasingly complex struggles, eventually becoming corrupt. This requirement immediately received high attention from party committees at all levels, and the "Three Stricts and Three Honests" gradually became an important content for educating party members and cadres. In 1998, the Central Organization Department, in conjunction with relevant departments, after repeated investigations and solicitations of opinions, formulated the implementation plan for the "Three Stricts and Three Honests" education.
On November 21 of the same year, the central government issued the "Opinions on Carrying Out Party Conduct and Discipline Education with 'Learning, Politics, and Integrity' as the Main Content among Party and Government Leading Groups and Leading Cadres at County Level and Above", comprehensively arranging the implementation of the "Three Stricts and Three Honests" education. Since then, the "Three Stricts and Three Honests" education has gradually been launched in stages and batches.
This "Three Stricts and Three Honests" education was carried out from top to bottom. The central government, central state organs, provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities directly under the central government, and directly affiliated organs were the first to carry out pilot programs, followed by implementation at the city and county levels. On December 5, 1998, the Central Committee convened a national teleconference and Hu Jintao delivered a speech on the mobilization of the "Three Talks" education. Starting from that month, the Central Committee conducted pilot programs in Shandong, Guangxi, Inner Mongolia, as well as the Ministry of Land and Resources, Ministry of Education, State Administration of Radio, Film, and Television, and the Communist Youth League Central Committee. From the beginning of the pilot programs, the "Three Talks" in various units were carried out in four steps: ideological mobilization and learning improvement, self-analysis and soliciting opinions, exchange of ideas and criticism and self-criticism, and serious rectification and consolidation of achievements.
On March 19, 1999, in order to summarize and exchange the situation and experience of the pilot programs for the "Three Talks" education, and to study and deploy the next steps of work, the Central Committee held the first national conference on the "Three Talks" education. The conference listened to the pilot units' experience presentations and made arrangements for the first phase of the "Three Talks" education work. It was decided that the "Three Talks" in various provincial and ministerial units would be carried out in two batches. The first batch included 16 provinces, regions, and cities such as Beijing and Hubei, as well as 70 central and national agencies such as the Supreme People's Procuratorate. The second batch included 12 provinces, cities, and regions such as Zhejiang and Ningxia, as well as six ministry-level departments such as the Ministry of Finance.
The members of the Central Political Bureau Standing Committee attached great importance to the "Three Talks" education. At the end of 1999, they also dedicated time to study the "Three Talks". They carefully reviewed and summarized the work and basic experience of the past ten years since the Fourth Plenary Session of the 13th Central Committee. They engaged in profound thought on major strategic issues in future reforms and development. Comrades of the Standing Committee, with a high sense of responsibility to the Party, to the country, and to the people, took the lead in identifying shortcomings in their work, conducting criticism and self-criticism, and proposing improvement measures. They effectively promoted the deepening of the "Three Talks" education.
After the first national conference on the "Three Talks" education, the Central Committee held the second and third national conferences on the "Three Talks" education in June 1999 and January 2000, respectively, to make arrangements for the "Three Talks" work in each phase. Based on these arrangements, the Central Committee dispatched several inspection teams and inspection groups to various provinces, autonomous regions, municipalities, and central government departments to understand the situation and strengthen guidance and inspection of the "Three Talks" education work. After the concentrated education on the "Three Talks" ended, localities and units organized and carried out "look-back" activities in accordance with the requirements of the Central Committee. These activities aimed to assess whether the consciousness of learning, politics, and integrity had truly improved, whether prominent problems reflected by the masses had been resolved, and whether there were significant improvements in the work of local regions and departments. This was done to consolidate and expand the achievements of the "Three Talks" education.
According to the deployment of the Central Committee, the "Three Talks" education at the county and city levels was also gradually implemented. In order to carry out this education well, members of the Central Political Bureau Standing Committee went to seven counties and cities for in-depth investigations and conducted specific guidance. On February 20, 2000, Jiang Zemin personally participated in the "Three Talks" education conference for the leadership cadres in Gaozhou City, Guangdong Province, and delivered a mobilization speech. These measures further demonstrated the high attention of the Party Central Committee to the "Three Talks" education and greatly promoted the "Three Talks" education at the county and city levels. By the end of September 2000, the "Three Talks" education for party and government leading teams at the county level and above throughout the country had basically come to an end and entered the stage of summarization and improvement, as well as in-depth rectification.
From 1998 to the end of 2000, a total of 700,000 party cadres participated in the "Three Talks" education. Cadres and the masses inside and outside the Party paid great attention to this educational activity and showed a high level of participation enthusiasm. There were more than 5 million people directly involved in listening to mobilization reports, participating in democratic evaluations, and assisting in rectification. Cadres have generally received profound Marxist education and undergone strict training in the inner-party democracy, which has significantly improved their adherence to the mass line and the democratic centralism of the party. Practice has shown that the "Three Teachings" education is a creative exploration and successful practice in strengthening the party building, especially the ideological and political construction of the leadership team and cadres. It enriches and promotes the spirit of rectification in Yan'an and the "Three Major Styles" of the party in the new historical period.
II. we need to cultivate and select leaders who possess both virtue and talent, and establish a high-quality cadre team. 
After the political line is determined, cadres become the determining factor.
